HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rain in Midwest Lowers Contract Prices for Grains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 11

 BODY:
Prices for grain and soybeans for delivery in July sank at the Chicago Board of Trade today following much-needed rainfall over the weekend in Kansas and forecasts of more rain on Thursday and Friday.
Wheat futures led the decline.
Wheat for delivery in May settled 3 1/2 cents lower at 3.77 1/2 a bushel; July wheat closed 4 cents lower at $3.65 3/4 a bushel. May corn settled 2 1/2 cents lower at $2.52 3/4 a bushel; July corn settled cents 3 1/4 lower at $2.58 a bushel. July soybeans closed a half-cent lower at $5.93 3/4 a bushel. 
 "The weather is still the most important factor," said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago.
Wheat led other grain and soybean prices lower this morning. Forecasts calling for more rain over the wheat belt this week and better chances for rain by the end of the week are likely to weigh on wheat prices, said Kyle Smith, an analyst with the Farmers Commodity Corporation in Kansas City.
 
U.S. Report on Leftover Stocks
 After the close, the Agriculture Department released its monthly report showing ending stocks, or what will be left over by the end of the year, for 1992-93. The department estimated ending stocks at 1.671 million bushels for corn, slightly above industry expectations; 1.618 million bushels for wheat, higher than expected, and 235 million for soybeans, lower than expected.
The report should send soybean prices higher and wheat lower on Tuesday, Mr. Lespinasse said. Corn could open steady to lower Tuesday, he said.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, energy futures prices settled higher, led by heating oil futures.
Still buoyed by tight supplies and unseasonably cool weather in the Unigted States and Europe, heating oil rose 0.65 cent to settle at 58.32 cents a gallon, the highest level since Nov. 11. Light sweet crude oil for delivery in June rose 14 cents to close at $21 a barrel, and June unleaded gasoline gained 0.46 cent to settle at 65.33 cents a gallon.
The price of coffee for delivery in July rose after traders "covered" short positions, or bets that the price of coffee would fall, by buying back outstanding contracts in case export quotas are established, analysts said.
July coffee settled 1.1 cent higher at 61.9 cents at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Representatives from the Colombian National Coffee Federation met with United States Agriculture and Commerce Department officials today to discuss support for new export quotas in an effort to shore up prices. And the Brazilian Coffee Council met today with the Brazilian economic secretary to discuss next month's International Coffee Organization talks.

HEADLINE: Despite New Data, Mysteries Of Creation Persist

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
THEORISTS digesting a NASA satellite's intriguing measurements of the faint ripples that emerged from the genesis of the universe say that far from resolving the major mysteries of creation, the discovery emphasizes a need for still deeper probing.
Indeed the measurements by the Cosmic Background Explorer satellite seem, if anything, to have heightened disagreements among some theorists as to how the universe acquired the structure it exhibits today. 
 The collection and analysis of the data, which scientists have called a landmark achievement, was reported at a meeting of physicists last month. Dr. George Smoot of the University of California at Berkeley, leader of the analysis team, announced that the COBE satellite's microwave telescope had found slight irregularities in the universal background of microwave radiation surviving from the earliest time to which astronomers can look back, a mere 300,000 years after the Big Bang creation event.
The discovery of minute ripples in the microwave background brought a collective sigh of relief from theorists.
Dr. Steven Weinberg of the University of Texas at Austin, winner of a Nobel Prize in Physics and a leading cosmological theorist, said in an interview that the satellite's detection of unevennesses in radiation dating from the infancy of the universe averted what might have been "a theoretical catastrophe." If the long-sought evidence of early structure in the universe had not been eventually discovered, he said, "there's no theory that would have survived."
One of the major mysteries that have long vexed astrophysicists has to do with the origin of structure in the universe. Just after the Big Bang event in which most scientists believe the universe sprang into existence, the initial fireball is generally thought to have been smooth and homogeneous, lacking any structure. By contrast, the present-day universe is lumpy and has lots of structure. Its visible matter is clumped into galaxies, clusters of galaxies, and clusters of clusters. This structure, indeed, was essential for the origin and evolution of life.
Once the free-wheeling atoms of matter in the early universe began to clump together, the formation of galaxies and clusters of galaxies could be readily explained in terms of the growing gravitational attraction of the snowballing clumps. But the central mystery remained: when and how did the very first clumping of matter, the genesis of universal structure, arise?
The COBE satellite's detection of very slight variations in the intensity and frequency of the left-over microwave radio waves that permeate the sky has apparently proved that the seeds of the universe's ultimate structure existed 300,000 years after the Big Bang.
Not even the most powerful telescope or radio antenna could detect radiation more ancient than that for the reason that during its first 300,000 years, the universe was opaque to all forms of radiation. Its temperature was so high that all the atoms in the early universe were shorn of their electrons, resulting in a "fog" in which matter and energy were unified. Photons, the particles that carry light, radio, gamma rays and all other forms of electromagnetic radiation were constantly produced during this epoch, but were instantly reabsorbed by the ultra-hot, electrically charged primordial soup that produced them. No photon could escape from the fireball era to travel down the ages to our own time. Hence, the photons of microwave radiation observed by the COBE satellite had to originate somewhat later, after the universe had cooled enough for matter and energy to assume separate identities. This transition to transparency is described by scientists as the "decoupling of matter and energy."
Another kind of signal from the Big Bang itself might one day be detected, however. Scientists believe that certain cosmic events, like the explosion of a supernova, produce gravity waves that ripple outward at the speed of light. Although no gravity wave has ever been detected, physicists hope that an apparatus may some day be developed that could detect and interpret such gravity waves. The National Science Foundation recently selected two sites at which it hopes to build Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatories that might be capable of detecting gravity waves.
 
The Discovery
Variations Hint At Early Structure
 The left-over microwave background radiation, which has an average temperature of 2.73 degrees, above absolute zero, or about 455 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, was detected in 1964 by an innovative radio telescope built by Dr. Arno Penzias and Dr. Robert Wilson of Bell Laboratories, an achievement for which they were awarded Nobel Prizes. After that, astrophysicists began an intense but vain search for the slight variations in the microwave radiation that could reflect the early clumping of matter that is required by theory to account for the evolution of today's universe. It was COBE's instruments that finally found the ripple in the microwave background.
But the discovery leaves unresolved the more fundamental question of how structure originated.
One of the most popular theories of recent years supposes that structure began in an "inflationary universe," a universe that at one point in its evolution almost instantaneously sprang from a size smaller than the elementary particles in atoms to something many orders of magnitude greater. This transition would have almost instantly transformed the universe from an ultrasmall realm ruled by the peculiar effects of quantum mechanics to the more familiar large-scale domain that obeys the laws of "classical" physics.
The principle author of the inflationary-universe theory, Dr. Alan H. Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, proposed such an "inflation" as a process that would have occurred during a tiny instant -- a period between 10-35 and 10-30 of a second -- after the Big Bang itself. Such an "inflation" would be a mechanism for translating the spontaneous fluctuations that constantly occur in ultrasmall "quantum" particles to large-scale objects, which do not undergo quantum fluctuations. The effects of quantum fluctuations imposed on a full-scale "inflated" universe could trigger the clumping of matter that led to a structured universe, Dr. Guth reasoned.
But what have COBE's measurements done for the inflationary theory?
"I think they have done a lot to help confirm the predictions of inflation, and I'm very, very happy about that," Dr. Guth said in an interview.
But Dr. Penzias reached a contrary conclusion. "I think COBE's measurements could well be a big setback for inflation," he said in an interview. "The data I've seen so far are consistent with a simple open Big Bang universe, one without enough matter to eventually stop its current expansion and contract again, and an open universe does not allow for the inflation idea."
Another leading astrophysical theorist, Dr. James E. Peebles of Princeton University, took the middle ground: "The inflationary theory is not contradicted by COBE's findings," he said, "but neither is it proved by them.
"The excitement and publicity occasioned by the COBE discovery is justified, because COBE has given us a hard number on which to rest some of our ideas," he said. "But it hasn't given us any final answers."
Dr. Peebles and other scientists said that "the single datum point" provided by COBE should prompt a major ground-based observational program to look for finer detail in the microwave unevennesses. The detail found by COBE takes the form of gigantic splotches strewn across the sky, splotches far too large to correspond to the clumping one would expect to see in nascent galaxies, galactic clusters or any of the other structural features astronomers have so far observed. Cosmologists would like to detect finer details in the microwave radiation, ones fine enough to correspond in size to observed structures like galaxies and galactic clusters.
 
The Debate
Data May Support An Older Theory
 Some scientists believe that even if COBE's data are consistent with the inflationary theory, they are equally consistent with an older theory proposed by Dr. Edward R. Harrison, now a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
In 1968, Dr. Harrison calculated that only a certain class of quantum fluctuations could survive from the early infancy of the universe to trigger the clumping of matter and the beginning of structure.
Dr. Guth describes such fluctuations as analogous to audible sounds, which consist of mixtures of frequencies, or tones, of varying intensities. A complex sound consists of all its frequencies at their respective intensities, and such a combination can be graphically plotted as a spectrum. The comparable spectrum of irregularities predicted by Dr. Harrison had a special shape called "scale invariant," in which wavelengths stretch as the universe expands.
"If the spectrum were different," Dr. Harrison said in an interview, "all the irregularities would grow too fast and become black holes. If the irregularities grew too slowly after the Big Bang, then by the time that matter and energy decoupled 300,000 years later, the irregularities would all have disappeared. Only the one spectrum would give a result consistent with the present-day universe."
The theoretical spectrum calculated by Dr. Harrison and, subsequently, by the Soviet physicist Dr. Yakov Borisovich Zeldovich, has a characteristic shape that very roughly approximates the spectrum of microwave radiation actually measured by the COBE satellite.
But neither Dr. Harrison nor Dr. Guth claims the match between the COBE measurements and either of their own theories is good enough to prove anything.
Said Dr. Harrison: "I enjoy ideas about cosmology, but I suspend all belief, because every 10 years the ideas change. It's ridiculous to say you believe in any of them, when things are always in such a state of flux with cosmology, and indeed, with science in general."
It may be, Dr. Harrison said, that the irregularities seen by COBE do not even date from so early an epoch as the "decoupling."
"After the decoupling," he said, "the universe continued to cool, and somehow or other, galaxies eventually began to form. But as they did so, gases were compressed by gravitational forces, heated up again, and hydrogen once again would have been stripped of electrons." This process in itself could have left its "imprint" of irregularities on the microwave background, so that the faint variations measured by COBE might not be primordial at all.
 
Other Theories
Some Seek Clues In 'Dark' Matter
 According to another theory, universal structure might have sprung from "cosmic strings" -- strings with no thickness but packing a mass of energy equivalent to some 20 quadrillion metric tons per inch -- which might have survived from the genesis explosion to this day because of their supposedly unique form. If they exist, they would be the skeletal remains of an ultradense state of matter spawned by the Big Bang.
Still other theories conjecture that the universe is full of exotic, undetected particles with such names as super-symmetric photinos, massive neutrinos, magnetic monopoles and "wimps." Such particles, many theorists believe, might make up most of the mass of today's universe. Although all these particles remain undetected, scientists hope eventually to find one or more of them.
Dr. Penzias, a physicist who now prefers to think of himself as an astronomer, does not believe in any of them. "The search for all this so-called missing mass is an act of desperation by physicists who are unwilling to accept the principle that in the universe, what you see is what you get," he said.
Some astrophysicists have calculated that only 10 percent of the mass of the universe has actually been observed or accounted for, but Dr. Penzias disagrees.
"You don't need hidden mass, because you don't need to close the universe," he said. "All the evidence suggests that the universe is open. Ultimately the universe and everything in it, created in a blinding flash, is doomed to disappear. There really is only one shot. The universe as we see it is a paradigm of our lives -- a very definite beginning with an indefinite but inevitable end."
Dr. Penzias, who recently underwent heart surgery, acknowledges that religious faith may color his thinking about cosmology, but he said: "If someone disproved the Big Bang theory I wouldn't start cheating or lying. My faith is not dependent on physics."
The evidence of astronomy seems to him consonant with general biblical precepts, but religious belief and science are not interdependent, he believes.
Dr. Guth, on the other hand, believes that the COBE results virtually prove the existence of large amounts of "dark" or unseen matter in the universe.
"For the very small amplitude of the density fluctuations that COBE has discovered," he said, "you need large amounts of dark matter to provide the gravitational influence needed to grow the large clumps we see in the universe today."
Whatever the theory, Dr. Weinberg said, "people shouldn't make dogmatic statements about it."
Has COBE settled any arguments?
Dr. Peebles commented: "It's worth emphasizing that one can invent many models for the early universe that equally well reproduce COBE's measurement. The point I want to stress is that this is an important step, but only a step."
At the very least, he added, COBE has won a new lease on life. "One very positive outcome of all this publicity is that NASA will now surely continue funding for COBE, and its measurements will improve," he said. "That in itself is good news."

Diagram: "Behind Earliest View Of Universe"
 What the Cosmic Background Explorer (COBE) has seen is radiation from the universe 300,000 year after the Big Bang. Before then, photons of light energy were reabsorbed by charged atoms as quickly as they were emitted. Only after the universe cooled so atoms could hold electrons did photons start escaping. In the earliest instants of an extremely dense, hot universe, matter and energy had extremely dense, hot universe, matter and energy had not yet assumed separate identities.
 The present-day universe of galaxies, galaxy clusters, stars, planets and electromagnetic radiation, including visible light.
 The COBE discovery of ripples in the background microwave radiation is a look backward to the universe as it was 300,000 years after the Big Bang. At this point photons decoupled from matter and the universe became "transparent."
 A transition to matter began to occur as temperatures cooled 10-12 seconds after Big Bang as quarks assembled into the sub-units of atoms. The particle accelerator at Fermi Lab has achieved the very high energies that resemble conditions at this time.
The early universe is known only by inference from experiments with particle accelerators.
 Rapid inflation is one theory to account for the expansion of the universe after the Big Bang. Someday, gravity wave detectors might be able to plumb phenomena from the Big Bang itself.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

A Lens for Conde Nast
After being wooed by Harper's Bazaar, the fashion photographer Steven Meisel has signed an exclusive magazine contract with Conde Nast, the publisher of Vogue and other magazines.
Mr. Meisel is also known for his advertising photographs, among them the current Barneys New York ads (including the Madison Avenue billboard of Linda Evangelista with a butterfly on her nose). He recently completed a book on Madonna that is to be published in September. 
 In the war for fashion talent, Vogue and Harper's Bazaar have been battling fiercely for the leading photographers, trying to sign the top guns to exclusive contracts and, in effect, banning photographers who shoot for the opposition.
Going the other way, Patrick Demarchelier, a regular Conde Nast contributor, recently signed an exclusive contract with Harper's Bazaar.
 
Tough Campaign in London
 The recession continues to wreak havoc on the London fashion-designer scene. Joe Casely-Hayford, a young designer who had dressed rock performers like U2, the Clash, Seal and Duran Duran, folded his nine-year-old designing business last week.
Mr. Casely-Hayford made his mark in the early 1980's by turning a cache of military surplus tents into safari clothes. His styles have been sold in Charivari stores in New York.
Last month, Val Piriou, another established British designer, closed her doors. John Galliano, an avant-garde London designer who had shown in Paris for two seasons, was unable to mount a collection last season after losing his financial backing. Norman Hartnell, an old-line British couture house that dresses the royal family, also has been seeking refinancing.
 
Accessorizing: The Delights
 This is accessories market week in New York, and buyers from around the country have been trooping through suites in the Plaza looking for the latest thrilling notions in belts, bags and baubles. (One learns from the promoters of the Accessorie Circuit, the trade show at the Plaza through today, that the "dandy" will be an important theme -- masculine vests, bow ties, ascots, cuff links and pocket watches -- along with "yin yang," or crossover styles like a camisole under a pin-striped vest.)
With perfect timing, Norma Kamali introduced her first collection of accessories yesterday. It includes belts, shoulder pads (she does a 40's look), bodysuits and collar-and-cuff sets. There are also sunglasses, made under a licensing agreement with Colors in Optics, and footwear (shoes, in fashionspeak) by Carrano.
A fashion accessory ball is to be held on Wednesday at the Marriott Marquis, where everyone can swish around in black tie and talk about accessories.
 
Jungle Clothes
 A who's who of international fashion, from Armani to Westwood, is contributing designs to the second Don't Bungle the Jungle party on May 18, which will raise money for preserving the world's rain forests.
All the fashions are jungle inspired and will be available for purchase during a silent auction throughout the evening at the Amazon Village Pier 25, on the Hudson River at North Moore Street. A fireworks show by Grucci and a performance by Queen Latifah are scheduled. Tickets: (212) 431-7845.
 
The Octogenerian Strut
 Irving Lazar, the powerful literary agent known as Swifty, has added fashion modeling to his accomplishments. Mr. Lazar, who is 85 years old, recently modeled in advertisements for Kenar sportswear with Linda Evangelista.
"Linda's so beautiful," Mr. Lazar said, "and unusually intelligent. She's got legs that never stop."
Ms. Evangelista could not be reached for comment on Mr. Lazar's legs. The ads are scheduled to begin appearing in September.

LENGTH: 547 words

HEADLINE: Don't Tie Foreign Students to Black Ph.D. Drop

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Drop in Black Ph.D.'s Brings Debate on Aid for Foreigners" (front page, April 21) compares two dissimilar issues in an inflammatory manner. To claim that the presence of foreigners is responsible, if only in part, for the absence of blacks in universities is largely misleading.
The majority of foreign students study science and engineering. They remain in the United States filling junior positions, particularly in engineering departments that without them would have to close and jobs in industries that until the most recent economic downturn would have been crippled without them. 
 Yes, the foreign students receive a disproportionate share of teaching assistantships, but as the National Academy of Sciences reported in 1988, the costs are offset not only by their becoming productive members of our society but also by their having been educated at the undergraduate level by their home countries.
There are genuine problems regarding foreign students, ranging from the sticky question of quotas at most research universities to the moral questions raised by brain drain. Is the United States prospering at the expense of third world countries whose best students come here and remain, thereby making it impossible for a developing country to harness its intellectual capital?
The problem of underrepresentation of blacks in Ph.D. programs is a disaster for this country. Minorities will in time become the majority. If they are not a sizable part of our well-educated population, the country will lose its capacity to innovate and to be economically competitive.
The issue is not being ignored, but more money, talent and a national effort are required. There are programs to increase the numbers of minorities prepared for graduate school. In 1991 the National Science Foundation awarded grants of $30 million for this purpose to six universities -- Alabama, California-Irvine, Arizona State, Jackson State, Texas A&M and Puerto Rico. These cooperative grants are establishing networks with industry, community colleges and other institutions to identify minority undergraduate students for science, engineering and mathematics, the graduate fields from which they are largely absent.
However, by linking the absence of black and minority Ph.D.'s to the presence of foreign students, we run the risk of initiating policies to limit the access of foreign students without guaranteeing the success of black students. Last year, the education of foreign students netted the United States some $4 billion, according to the Department of Commerce. Those profits should somehow be invested in educating our own citizens.
During the 1980's more than 20,000 Taiwanese and South Koreans educated in United States graduate schools returned home to better employment opportunities. We can no longer count on 60 percent of foreign Ph.D.'s to remain here to occupy the teaching positions that will abet the education of larger numbers of minority students. We must use the accomplishments of one group to make possible those of the other. The situation demands cooperation, not confrontation.
 
DOROTHY S. ZINBERG
Lecturer in Public Policy, Center
for Science and International
Affairs, Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., April 22, 1922

HEADLINE: 'Value' Joins the Vocabulary of Wine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
After decades of using mystique, prestige and cachet to pitch their products, some of the nation's wine makers have lately learned a new word: value. And those who have learned it best are selling more wine even while the industry is in its worst depression since Prohibition.
Value, of course, has always been in the eye of the oenophile, but most agree that it applies to a wine, costing $7 to $10 a bottle, that can give customers a taste that usually costs $12 to $16. The strategy behind such wines, which has been time-tested in many other industries, is to push up sales volume by keeping costs low.
 
Making Cutbacks
 
 Some wineries have cut back on the sales forces that call on the specialty shops and are marketing directly to large supermarkets and warehouse stores. Others have reduced their advertising, preferring instead to concentrate on getting a wine enthusiast publication's highest possible rating, which can be worth much more in sales. Still others are slicing their profit margins, a tacit concession that the premium prices they charged had little to do with the cost of making their product.
Whatever the tactic, the result gives wine drinkers a taste they like, even if it gives the purists fits.
One leading value vintner is Kendall-Jackson Vineyards of Santa Rosa, Calif., which became the fastest-growing winery in the last 10 years by offering a noticeably sweet chardonnay that sells for $9 a bottle. The taste irks the critics but pleases customers whose regular beverage might be white zinfandel, or even Pepsi.
The slight sweetness is "what the American palate preferred to have," said Jess Jackson, a San Francisco lawyer who created the brand in 1983. "Our goal is to broaden the consuming public, to bring neophyte people to wine. I'm making wine for the consumer, not the wine writers."
It must be working: Kendall-Jackson's shipments grew 22.6 percent in 1991, to 705,000 cases, of which 70 percent was the winery's Vintners Reserve chardonnay.
"Not me, but people are saying, 'If you're not between $7.99 and $9.99, you're not in the premium wine business today,' " said Stephen Cousins, president of Racke U.S.A., which owns Buena Vista and other premium wine brands. "When you get under $10, assuming you have a good bottle of wine, it's magic."
Retailers agree. "Customers are very comfortable with that price," said Wilfred Wong, general manager of the Ashbury Market, a San Francisco store known for its wine selection. "All the big guys are making better wines to hit the $10 price point."
 
Success Near Seattle
 Few wineries acted earlier or more decisively than Stimson Lane Wine and Spirits in carving out a niche as a self-proclaimed "value winery" -- one that markets wines that are praised by critics but cost just $7 to $10 a bottle.
Based in Woodinville, Wash., a Seattle suburb, Stimson Lane owns the Chateau St. Michelle and Columbia Crest labels in Washington.
Like other wineries that have learned the value lesson well, Stimson Lane is reporting double-digit growth in cases shipped annually even as the wine industry as a whole slogs through its sixth year of decreasing shipments.
Indeed, the overwhelming success of a few large brands, like Clos du Bois, Kendall-Jackson and Beringer contradicts reports of an industry in decline. Measured in dollars, rather than gallons shipped, wine sales have increased in the last five years.
To sell well, a value wine has to receive quality scores comparable to those given higher-priced wines in such enthusiast publications as The Wine Advocate and The Wine Spectator.
"For $9 to $10 and discounted to less, you're getting an awful lot of character and quality," said James Laube, a senior editor at The Wine Spectator. "It doesn't take people long to say, 'These are as good as those other wines that cost a lot more.' "
 
Quality and Pricing
 The new move to sell Lexus wines at Honda prices concedes what many wine drinkers have long suspected: the high price of premium wines has little to do with actual production costs. And as the free spenders of the 1980's give way to the value-conscious oenophiles of the 1990's, success for a wine company means marketing a good wine at a reasonable price.
A unit of UST Inc., the leading producer of snuff and other smokeless tobacco products, Stimson Lane, which also owns the Villa Mount Eden and Conn Creek wineries in California, created Columbia Crest in 1985 specifically for the $7 to $10 category. Columbia Crest has grown from shipping just 12,000 cases that year to 383,000 cases in 1991.
Backed by a wealthy parent company, Stimson Lane had the capital to build a $37.5 million winery for the brand, and to invest in an aggressive advertising campaign featuring Jeff Smith. He is a best-selling cookbook author and host of "The Frugal Gourmet" cooking show on public television.
"The key was America did not need another wine brand, so we worked very hard to create a unique sales proposition," said Allen C. Shoup, the president of Stimson Lane. A former cosmetics marketing executive, he has also worked for the giant E.& J. Gallo Winery in Modesto, Calif.
"We attempted not to leave anything to chance, and treated each component as if a mistake would be critical," Mr. Shoup said.
 
A High-Rated Red

 
 Columbia Crest sells mostly chardonnay, the most popular white varietal. But merlot, a red similar to cabernet sauvignon, but softer, really established the winery's reputation for value. Columbia Crest merlot retails for $10 and is frequently discounted.
Despite their disclaimers about putting consumers first, successful wine makers all court the press. Many go so far as to tailor blends to please the palates of influential critics like Robert Parker. While the circulations of Mr. Parker's newsletter, The Wine Advocate, and its rival, The Wine Spectator, are relatively small, the publications are closely read by the distributors and retailers who make the first decision to buy a wine. They know that a score of 85 or above is a guaranteed sellout; scores in the 70's send a wine to the close-out bins.
"The first question I asked our wine maker was, 'What do you need to make a chardonnay that will consistently get good ratings?' " said William Hambrecht, president and chief executive of the Belvedere Winery in Healdsburg, Calif., as well as co-chief executive of Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment banking firm. The answer to his question was $300,000 for new French oak barrels, an amount that ultimately swelled to $1.2 million in new capital equipment.
It paid off. With a suggested retail price of $7.99, Belvedere's 1990 Alexander Valley chardonnay got 86 points and "wine of the month" in the February issue of The Wine Advocate. "That's worth a hundred salesmen," said Mr. Hambrecht, who reduced costs at Belvedere by eliminating all but one of the marketing staff members.
"In the wine business, marketing is just a euphemism for discounting to distributors," he said. With no discounting, and only minimal advertising, Belvedere sales are up 52 percent this year.
Newcomers like Belvedere and Columbia Crest are not the only ones pursuing the value niche; so are many of California's most venerable producers. The Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, the oldest in California, recently lowered prices so that all of its nonreserve wines retail for less than $10; sales in the first quarter of 1992 were up 24.5 percent. Rodney Strong Vineyards, established in Santa Rosa in the early 1960's, says shipments are up 40 percent this year through March, driven by its line of $7 to $10 Sonoma County varietals. Fetzer Vineyards of Hopland, Calif., has always been known as a value brand.
Using new sales outlets is another part of the drive to push value wines.
"A very important part of the story today is new distribution that allows value to get to people," said John Fisher, a principal with Hambrecht & Quist who specializes in winery deals. "That's basically the warehouse clubs."
While customers get better wine at lower prices, the major wineries profit from increased sales volume and market share. The losers are medium-size wineries that lack the economy of scale to compete in the new market, and whose wines are not distinctive or rare enough to command super-premium prices. Burdened with heavy debts on equipment and vineyards and unable to raise prices, many face bankruptcy.
On the other hand, many small prestigious wineries with loyal followings are still selling all the wine they can make at $25 a bottle or more. But such wines had better deliver, said Theodor Baseler, Stimson Lane's vice president. Consumers will not long tolerate $30 wines that only provide $10 experiences.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
ACCORD IS OUTLINED ON MOVES TO HELP THE NATION'S CITIES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Trying to demonstrate that a beleaguered Washington establishment is responding to the Los Angeles riots, the White House and Congressional leaders today announced broad agreement to enact measures that they said would bring relief to American cities.
Democratic and Republican officials said a consensus was emerging on a set of programs that amounted to a few billion dollars nationwide. They include "enterprise zones" that offer tax incentives for creation of businesses in blighted neighborhoods, new efforts to drive out drug dealers and expand social services in poor neighborhoods, and enhanced job-training programs. 
 To provide immediate relief to Los Angeles, the White House said Mr. Bush would declare an emergency that would allow Congress to make an exception to current budget rules and provide $300 million in emergency assistance to the city and to individuals who lost property in the rioting.
 
Loans for Small Businesses

The emergency measure would also make avalable $300 million to $500 million in Small Business Administration loans. The House may vote on the proposal, which would increase the Federal deficit, as early as Wednesday.
The announcement, made after a White House meeting between President Bush and lawmakers from both parties, was accompanied by promises of cooperation and talk of urgency. But there was no agreement on details of the programs, most of which have long been under consideration, or on how to pay for them, apart from a new promise by Mr. Bush to oppose a tax increase.
Mr. Bush said, "The American Dream is hindered by too many obstacles: unsafe cities, slow economic growth, an out-of-date education system and dependency-creating government programs." He said the measures announced today qualified as a "radical" program of change. They included proposals not yet passed by Congress, although they were suggested some time ago.
Today's events carried strong elements of political expediency and symbolism. They seemed at times to devolve into a contest over who would seem the most responsible and concerned, as Republicans and Democrats come under intense pressure on domestic issues from a restive electorate.
The Democrats' surprisingly conciliatory stance seemed to mask an effort to pressure Mr. Bush on their own concerns, including a crime bill that would strengthen gun control and a permanent extension of unemployment benefits, in return for supporting him on policies like enterprise zones.
The Republicans seemed intent on shaping a response to the riots without risking alienating the conservative wing of their party with large new programs or, most threatening to the White House, a tax increase.
The White House took the moment to announce that the Republican leadership had agreed on a proposal to extend unemployment benefits for a third time, from July 4 until next March 6, although the White House said there was still wide disagreement with Congressional Democrats over permanent changes to the unemployment compensation system.
 
Most Proposals Repackaged
 Some new proposals were outlined today. But for the most part, both the Democrats in Congress and the White House repackaged as an emergency plan for the nation's cities proposals that were presented as recently as last month as ways to lift the economy.
Today's meeting was the first session on domestic policy this year between Mr. Bush and Democratic leaders. Under pressure from Congressional Democrats, it included Representative Maxine Waters, the Los Angeles Democrat who had strongly criticized Mr. Bush's response to the rioting and was ignored by the President last week during his visit there.
"I'm extremely encouraged," Ms. Waters said. "This is a time when both sides of the aisle must rise above partisan politics in the interest of the country. The viability of this country is at stake, and we must work together to try and get some solutions that will deal with those problems."
Mr. Bush is resubmitting his urban programs to Congress and has said his visit to Los Angeles convinced him his approach was correct. On Monday, during a visit to Philadelphia, Mr. Bush was confronted by residents who said his proposals were, as one put it, "a drop in the bucket."
 
No Money to Spare
 Clearly anticipating this sort of criticism, Mr. Bush began saying soon after the Los Angeles rioting that cities should not expect a lot of Federal money. This is in part because Mr. Bush's proposals center on familiar Republican trickle-down theories, like enticing businesses to inner cities instead of giving money to residents, and in part because Mr. Bush does not have money to spare.
Here are the President's proposals to help cities:
*Spending $500 million to drive drug dealers and violent criminals from blighted neighborhoods and create job-placement and other social programs.
*Spending $1 billion to help residents of low-income public housing buy their homes.
*Setting up zones in which businessmen would not be taxed for profit from their investments. White House officials said they had no reliable way of saying how much Mr. Bush's existing proposal in this area, which would create 50 such enterprise zones over five years, would cost and that he wants to expand it to permit an unlimited number based on criteria that have yet to be set forth.
*Putting into effect the President's existing proposals to improve schools, known as "America 2000." They include greater choice of schools and more flexibility for districts to spend Federal dollars.
*Relying on the President's existing $680 million plan to combine job-training programs under a single umbrella.
*Adopting changes in welfare rules that would give states the option of permitting those on the Aid to Families with Dependent Children to accumulate $10,000 in savings and assets without being taken off the program. The current limit is $1,000.
On Monday, Congressional Democrats promised to support enterprise zones and called on Mr. Bush to support spending $3.6 billion on additional public works projects, extend unemployment insurance to workers who do not currently qualify and back their crime bill, including extensions of gun control and the death penalty.
After today's meeting, Speaker Thomas S. Foley said: "I think there has been a commitment to see if we can in the coming days work out a cooperative series of legislative initiatives. I think we've pledged to work together to that effect."
But Isabel Sawhill, senior fellow of the Urban Institute, questioned the approach being taken by both sides.
"It is natural to be a little suspicious that this is all a reaction to Los Angeles that will be somewhat short-lived and is engineered to appear responsive in an election year," she said. "You have to ask why didn't we do this before? Or why aren't we doing it a little more carefully and with some assurances that it will do some good?"

HEADLINE: Arabs Want to Discuss Refugee Return Issue

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: OTTAWA, May 12

 BODY:
Arab delegates to a Middle East meeting on the Palestinian refugee question said today they would defy an American request that they not raise the matter of the right of Palestinians to return to homes they left when Israel was created in 1948.
The issue has prompted Israeli delegates to boycott the talks, which begin here on Wednesday. They object to the participation of Palestinians from outside the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. 
 Israel is also boycotting talks on economic development, which began in Brussels on Monday, because of the participation of Palestinians from outside the territories. It is taking part in Washington talks on arms control, in Vienna discussions on the sharing of water resources, and in a Tokyo session on environmental problems.
Jordan's chief delegate to the refugee talks, Jawad al-Anani, said today that the State Department had sent a message to Arab delegations, asking them not to bring up the question of Palestinians' right of return or compensationfor loss of property.
The Israelis' fear that the discussions would focus on the matter intensified when the State Department said today that the United States backed the principle of return.
set forth in United Nations Resolution 194.
Today Margaret D. Tutwiler, State Department spokeswoman, asked whether Washington still supported the resolution, responded: "The United States has supported General Assembly Resolution 194 since it was adopted Dec. 11, 1948. We continue to support it."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Halt Food Aid Program for Lebanon

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12

 BODY:
The United States has decided to discontinue food aid to Lebanon at a time when this country is suffering through its worst economic crisis in five decades, officials associated with the aid program said today.
The United States Agency for International Development has informed the Lebanese Government and charitable institutions that food aid will be stopped at the end of this year, said the aid officials, who did not want to be identified further. As many as 185,000 families have been receiving American food aid for several years. 
 Lebanese officials, who are trying to form a new government to replace the cabinet forced to resign last week because of bread riots, would not comment today on the decision. The switchboard at the United States Embassy did not answer.
 
400 to Be Dismissed
 The food sent by the American aid program has been distributed in all parts of Lebanon by a charitable institution known as Save the Children. The institution will now have to dismiss nearly 400 Lebanese workers employed in its food distribution program, the aid officials said.
There was no explanation for the move or its timing. A press release issued today by Save the Children said that more families have been applying for food aid because of the sharp rise in prices of essential commodities in Lebanon after the national currency lost more than half of its value in the last three months.
Each month, recipient families have been given $35 worth of basic food like lentils, rice, beans and vegetable oil. The amount is half the average monthly salary of those families. Save the Children distributes 22 metric tons of food commodities annually in all parts of Lebanon, mostly directed toward especially needy groups such as children and the elderly.
Food grants are the only aid Lebanon has received from the United States in the last seven years. The State Department maintains restrictions on travel of United States citizens to Lebanon and still has a ban on Lebanese airline flights to the United States.
Germany and the European Community are withholding all aid to Lebanon until two Germans held hostage by a Shiite Muslim group are released.
A report in the Beirut daily An Nahar said today that Lebanon is being deprived of all foreign aid because it has been boycotting the regional Middle East peace talks. Lebanese delegations have participated in direct negotiations with Israel, but officials here say the regional meetings are premature in the absence of tangible progress in the direct talks.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Decision Made After Study
WASHINGTON, May 12 (Special to The New York Times) -- A spokesman for the United States Agency for International Development said today that the decision to phase out the food program in Lebanon came after an assessment about the effectiveness of the project made over a period of more than two years by Save the Children.
The spokesman, J. D. Deming, said, in contrast to information provided by officials in Lebanon, that 25 percent of the program would be phased out by the end of the year, and the rest during 1993.

HEADLINE: Efforts Intensify to End Newspaper Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
As more incidents of violence and vandalism hampered deliveries of The New York Times, efforts intensified yesterday to chart a way out of the increasingly bitter weeklong confrontation pitting The Times and a news distributor against the delivery union.
At an emotional meeting of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity last night, a packed hotel ballroom of cheering union members unanimously appointed three "go-betweens" to try to find an accord with The Times, which the union views as the key to resolving the dispute. 
 But despite the clear eagerness for peace, there was also a demonstration for war, as union members chanted, "Shut them down, shut them down," referring to The Times.
After a Federal District judge on Monday threatened heavy fines against the union, delivery disruptions outside the city abated yesterday for the second day, Times officials said. But the disruptions spread for the first time to parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, where many papers were undelivered or delayed.
Twelve of 31 Metropolitan News trucks picking up papers at The Times's plant on West 43d Street in the early hours yesterday were found disabled in the trucking bays with punctured tires, delaying or preventing delivery of 240,000 of 290,233 copies of the paper bound for the East Side of Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn, said a Times spokeswoman, Nancy Nielsen.
 
Distribution Improves
 But distribution out of warehouses in New Rochelle, N.Y., and East Farmingdale, L.I., were 95 percent of the normal level, Ms. Nielsen said. On Sunday, the deliveries from the two locations were 30 percent of the normal level, The Times said. But by Monday, that had climbed to 92 percent, Times officials said, although some retailers disputed that figure.
In a further effort to curb the delivery disruptions and the violence, a New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday granted the news distributor's request for a preliminary injunction against union members picketing the two warehouses, said Jerold Glassman, a lawyer for the distributor, the Imperial Delivery Company.
The order by Justice Alfred M. Lama, which is valid for 30 days and was served on the union late last night, bars the pickets from causing property damage, inflicting physical injury or interfering with Imperial's operations. The justice limited the number of protesters at each warehouse to 12 and ordered them not to picket within 215 feet of the warehouse entrances.
The union meeting earlier yesterday was the first since the rejection last Wednesday of a long-range contract approved earlier by the union's leadership. The meeting, at the Ramada Inn on Seventh Avenue at 32d Street, was described as an informational session, but was widely seen as crucial in pointing the way toward a possible settlement.
The three men chosen at the meeting as "go-betweens" are John P. Kennedy, president of New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union Number 2, which has a particularly close relationship with the drivers; Barry Feinstein, the head of Joint Council 16 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which oversees all teamster locals in the area; and Michael M. Connery, a lawyer at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, who is working on behalf of unions in the effort to find a buyer for The Daily News.
A parade of other union leaders pledged to offer all legal support for the drivers.
John M. O'Brien, deputy general manager for The Times in charge of labor negotiations, said last night that The Times "was certainly willing to listen to anyone who has a solution to this, and we will talk to them."
If the conflict cannot be quickly resolved and the replacement of more than 200 union drivers becomes permanent, a settlement could become far more difficult and might spread labor strife in the industry.
The dispute is tied to the sale of the assets of four wholesale distribution companies: two to Arthur E. Imperatore, owner of Imperial, and two to The Times. The Times's purchase is still pending. Under the law, the new owners are not bound by previous labor contracts.
An agreement had been reached with the union's leadership, but the membership rejected it last week by a 57 percent majority. Mr. Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking and real-estate entrepreneur, then began using new drivers in place of the 267 union drivers who boycotted the distributorships he was purchasing: Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle and Newspaper Distributors Company in East Farmingdale. He has vowed not to deal any further with the union.
The Times, which had contracted to buy the assets of two other wholesale distributors -- the Newark Newsdealers Supply Company and the Metropolitan News Company, which deliver in New Jersey and New York City -- has said it is considering assigning its purchase agreement to Mr. Imperatore if the union refuses to agree to economies like reductions in overtime that would cut some yearly incomes to $40,000 from $80,000. In exchange, the rejected contract offered job security and other benefits.
Early yesterday, leaders of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella labor group representing all unions at The Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, met inconclusively in the absence of The Times and Imperial, which said their presence would serve no purpose prior to the driver's membership meeting.
As the maneuvering continued yesterday, the Connecticut office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had opened "a full field investigation" into the reported abduction at gunpoint on Saturday of an employee of Mr. Imperatore's.
The employee, Munir Fahreddine, a foreman at Imperial's Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle, said a gunman forced him out of his car near his home in Danbury and into a van with three other men, who roughed him up and held him overnight before releasing him near Pawling, N.Y., Sunday morning. Milt Ahlerich, special agent in charge of the New Haven F.B.I. office, said the complaint had been judged credible.
In other acts of disruption reported yesterday by Times officials, shortly before 5 A.M. a tractor-trailer heading to the East Farmingdale warehouse was intercepted on the Long Island Expressway by three cars that waited in the breakdown lane. The drivers then chased the truck and one with a rifle or shotgun forced the truck driver to stop and get out, the company said. Ms. Nielsen, the Times spokeswoman, said the incident was not reported to the police because neither the driver nor three security guards following him could identify the assailants or their cars.
The newspaper also reported unusually frequent tearing of the paper on the presses at its printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J., and the smashing of a truck windshield at the New Rochelle warehouse. The union has disavowed acts of violence.
Federal District Judge Pierre N. Leval ruled Monday night that the deliverers' union was in contempt of court for disrupting deliveries and ordered fines of $100,000 for every hour the daily paper was delayed. He also set a court hearing for Wednesday on the newspaper's application to impose the penalties.
Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, said yesterday that he was "tremendously heartened" by Judge Leval's ruling on fines but said that because of it, further acts of "violence and intimidation" were "almost unbelievable."
He said such acts would have "adverse short-term consequences" for the paper and its readers but that "in the long run it will severely damage, perhaps destroy, the drivers' union."

HEADLINE: U.S. Summons Ambassador To Yugoslavia Over Bosnia

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The United States recalled its Ambassador from Yugoslavia today and said that Washington would seek "strong collective action against Belgrade's aggression against Bosnia."
But the Bush Administration stopped short of suggesting any specific steps that could put pressure on the Serb militias who have dismissed all mediation efforts in their armed drive to prevent Bosnia-Herzogovina from achieving full independence or on the Government and Serbian-led Yugoslav Army command in Belgrade, which have backed and armed the irregulars. 
 In announcing that Ambassador Warren Zimmermann had been summoned home for consultations, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the United States was acting in concert with the European Community, which declared Monday that its members were recalling their ambassadors.
But in Europe as well as here, there seems to be no move to raise the level of response beyond the cautiously diplomatic. More active measures such as imposing economic sanctions or a show of force to defend Bosnia have apparently been ruled out for now because of concerns over the unpredictable consequences of such actions.
 
Use of Sanctions Doubtful
 The Yugoslav Army is a relatively large and powerful force that could not be easily suppressed. Moreover, Belgrade could parry an attempted boycott by having its effect fall most harshly on non-Serbian populations like the nearly 500,000 ethnic Hungarians living in Serbia or the even larger numbers of Albanians. Finally there is no assurance that pressure on the Serbs in Serbia will have great effect on the Serb militias in Bosnia. .
Earlier this year, when Yugoslavia was slipping into chaos, several European officials suggested at a March meeting in Brussels of the North Atlantic Cooperation Council, an extension of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, that NATO might consider creating a role for itself in conflicts in the formerly Communist countries of Eastern Europe or the new nations of the former Soviet Union. But a consensus, shared by Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d, emerged that it was "too early" to take such a step.
A meeting of the European Community Foreign Ministers decided on Monday to recall the European Ambassadors from Belgrade and demanded the withdrawal of Yugoslav Army forces from Bosnia-Herzogovina. The European Foreign Ministers also decided to suspend Yugoslavia from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 52-member organization promoting democratic principles and human rights.
Today, the organization backed off from a full suspension, choosing instead merely to suspend Belgrade from participation in discussions concerning Yugoslavia until the end of June.
 
U.S. Follows European Lead
 The United States first called for the suspension of Yugoslavia from the European security conference, then declined to push the issue. The Bush Administration had also first suggested the withdrawal of ambassadors, but then waited for the Europeans to take the lead. The United States also followed Europe in April in recognizing the independence of three breakaway former Yugoslav republics -- Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzogovina.
In keeping with the low-keyed style of the Bush Administration in recent regional crises -- in sharp contrast to the international campaign organized against Iraq in 1990-1991 -- no high-level United States official has made a public statement in recent days about the situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Secretary of State Baker, who made several trips to Yugoslavia over the last year to seek pledges of nonviolence, has not publicly condemned the fighting in Bosnia.
Miss Tutwiler today described the Serbian leadership in Belgrade as being "in clear and continuing violation of all C.S.C.E. principles." She said that reports from Marrack Goulding, the United Nations envoy in the region, indicated that over a million people had become refugees from the fighting in Bosnia-Herzogovina.
"All of us have done whatever we can to try to influence a cessation of this constant hardship and tragedy and disruption in people's lives," Miss Tutwiler said. "It is a real tragedy."
Miss Tutwiler said that Ambassador Zimmerman's last duties today would be to try to assist in getting humanitarian assistance to people without food and medicine. She said that relief convoys were being blocked from reaching most seriously affected areas.

HEADLINE: F.B.I. Agents Raid Casinos On 5 Indian Reservations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHOENIX, May 12

 BODY:
Acting on day-old Government rules, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided casinos at five Indian reservations across Arizona today and seized about 750 electronic game machines.
At four of the reservations, the raids were carried out with little incident. But at the Fort McDowell Yavapai Reservation, outside nearby Scottsdale, about 100 Indians used three dozen or so pickups, big earth-movers and other vehicles to surround eight trucks that were preparing to take away game machines from the parking lot of the casino there. 
 The blockade by the Indians, who appeared to be unarmed, trapped not only the trucks but also dozens of F.B.I. agents. The standoff lasted five hours and was not broken until Gov. Fife Symington negotiated an agreement with Clinton Pattea, the Yavapai tribal chairman at Fort McDowell.
 
Provisions of Accord
 Under the agreement, which the Governor said had been approved by United States Attorney Linda Akers, Federal agents removed the tractors of the Government trucks from the Fort McDowell parking lot, leaving the trailers and their load of 400 game machines for a 10-day cooling-off period. During that period, Mr. Symington will negotiate with reservation leaders about the possibility of their continuing to use the game machines, which are by far the casino's biggest money-makers.
The Governor also promised to speed state unemployment payments to the hundreds of Indians put out of work by today's raids.
At issue is a 1988 Federal law that permits Indian reservations to offer gambling in states that allow wagering outside the reservation. But the kind of gambling allowed on the reservations is limited to the kind offered outside, unless tribal leaders can persuade state officials to the contrary.
In Arizona, the state government has not been so persuaded. As a result, Government rules that took effect Monday bar two types of gambling that have proved popular on the reservations. One involves electronic machines that resemble card games, the other so-called pull-tab machines that dispense lottery-type slips.
Reservation casinos typically offer only two other kinds of gaming -- poker played man-to-man, not against the house, and bingo -- and neither is anywhere near so popular as the machines. Gilbert Jones, vice chairman at the Fort McDowell Reservation, said today that the casino there had brought in $19 million since October, 80 percent of it from the machines.
Indian leaders contend that without the revenue, social programs on the reservations will suffer. Asserting that the tribes are sovereign nations and fearful that the new rules would lead to more raids, several tribes around the country filed suit against the regulations in Washington last Friday.

HEADLINE: Slight Rise In Producer Price Index

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Producer prices crept up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Government said today. Economists said the report showed that the Federal Reserve had room to cut interest rates again to perk up the slowly recovering economy.
The Producer Price Index, which also went up by two-tenths of 1 percent in March and in February, has risen so far this year at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of just 1 percent, the Labor Department said.
"One reason the inflation rate is so low is the sluggish economy," said Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a banking company in Minneapolis. "I think the Fed will recognize this and take appropriate action as soon as possible."
 
Consumer Data Due Today

 
 Analysts predict the Fed will wait to act until it sees if the low inflation figures are confirmed by the Consumer Price Index, which is scheduled to be released Wednesday.
"We will see further progress in reducing inflation in the C.P.I.," said Lyle Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
That would ease any fears that another move to cut interest rates, which have been coming down steadily for more than a year, would overheat the economy and stoke inflation.
Mr. Sohn contends the central bank should be aggressive and move for cuts of half a percentage point in both the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for loans, and the discount rate, which the Fed charges banks for loans.
Many economists maintain that such a move by the Fed would persuade banks to cut their prime lending rates by half a point. Many business and consumer loans are pegged to the prime.
Most banks' prime rates are at 6 1/2 percent, although Chemical Bank in New York, the nation's fourth-largest, cut its rate to 6 1/4 percent after the Fed's most recent push, on April 9, to lower the Federal funds rate to 3 3/4 percent from 4 percent.
The Labor Department said the core rate of wholesale inflation, which excludes the volatile prices of food and energy, also rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in April. Goods at the intermediate level rose one-tenth of 1 percent, and crude prices were up three-tenths.
 Wholesale food prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April after dropping five-tenths in March. Energy prices advanced by five-tenths last month, mainly because of increases in the price of refined oil products; they had shot up 1.2 percent in March. Some economists expressed concern about the rise in energy prices.
 "It's a good number," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University, referring to the overall index. "But there are some special circumstances."
 
Gasoline and Heating Oil

 
 He noted that gasoline prices rose by 1.4 percent last month, after gaining 1.1 percent in March. Heating oil was up 4.6 percent in April, after advancing two-tenths of 1 percent in March and 16.2 percent in February.
 But other economists said the rise in energy prices should not deter Fed policy makers from easing credit.
"Energy is clearly not something that can be rectified by monetary policy, and they should not be concerned about it," said Mr. Gramley, a former Fed board member.
Michael Boskin, chief economic adviser to President Bush, said he thought the Fed was prepared to lower interest rates if inflation remained under control and the recovery appeared to falter.
 
Bond Prices Head Up
 "They have the opportunity and the will to do something extra if necessary," Mr. Boskin told reporters in Paris, where he was at a meeting.
Inflation-sensitive Treasury bond prices surged on the producer prices report, with the 30-year issue up more than half a point, cutting its yield to 7.86 percent, from 7.88 percent Monday. Stock prices fell, however, as investors awaited the consumer price report on Wednesday.
 Recent data show that business activity is gradually picking up speed, which would traditionally argue for the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee to hold the line on interest rates. The committee is scheduled to meet next Tuesday.
 But economists said the Fed needed to insure that the recovery took hold and did not falter, as it did last year. They added that the tepid 2 percent annual rate of economic growth recorded in the first quarter was not enough to accomplish that.

HEADLINE: BELGRADE SHOCKED BY EUROPEAN MOVE

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 12

 BODY:
Despite weeks of being warned that it could not continue with the effective dismemberment of Bosnia and Herzegovina and escape diplomatic and economic sanctions, the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Government appeared somewhat surprised today by the moves taken by the European Community and the United States to begin the process of isolation by withdrawing their ambassadors from Belgrade.
An official Yugoslav statement claiming that Western governments were guilty of "bias" against Serbia in designating it as the main culprit in Bosnia was not issued until late today, more than 24 hours after the European Community's foreign ministers announced that they were pulling out their envoys. 
 The Belgrade Government's statement made no reference to the withdrawal of Warren Zimmermann, the United States Ambassador, although the Government had been told of the American move earlier in the day.
 
Serbia Is Indignant
 The ambassadors' withdrawal was about the least threatening measure the Western nations could take. But instead of relief that nothing more concrete was announced, and that economic sanctions apparently will be further delayed, Serbia was indignant.
A senior Foreign Ministry official, Branko Brankovic, even suggested that the Western nations were "opening the door to Islamic fundamentalism in Europe," a reference to the contention among hard-line leaders of Bosnia's Serbs, who are Orthdox Christians, that in fighting a civil war with the republic's Muslim Slavs they are battling for religious survival.
Apart from overlooking the fact that the Serbian effort to seize control of much of Bosnia has also pitted them against the republic's Croats, who are mostly Roman Catholics, the statement by Mr. Brankovic reflected the degree to which historical passions have inflamed Serbia's policies.
Reflecting on this, diplomats here said that even if economic sanctions were adopted, as the United States and the European Community have threatened at various stages of the Serbian offensives in Croatia and Bosnia, there was no certainty that Serbia would relent in its determination to entrench separate territorial strongholds for Serbs in the two neighboring republics.
For now, the European Community has held open the possibility of sanctions by instructing the European Commission, the body that administers the community's affairs, to look at what sanctions could be applied if Serbia fails to end its military offensive in Bosnia and to support the community's efforts to draw all three ethnic groups into agreement on Bosnia's future as an independent state.
Diplomats said that a number of measures available to the European nations, including banning Yugoslav truck traffic and closing European airports to Yugoslav aircraft, could have a major effect on Serbia, although probably not enough to cause a collapse of its weakened economy.
 
Greece and Macedonia
 One reason that tougher actions have been deferred is that steps like closing European borders to Yugoslav trucks would require unanimous approval by all 12 community members, and one of them, Greece, has aligned itself with Serbia in its diplomatic confrontation with Europe.
The Greek position is partly the result of its dispute with another breakaway Yugoslav republic, Macedonia, which wants to take its independence under that name. Greece contends that the name belongs exclusively to its own province of Macedonia.
The United States, which has maintained its own range of minor economic sanctions against Serbia, could also close its airports to Yugoslav aircraft, cutting off scheduled Yugoslav Airlines flights to New York. But with the total two-way trade between the two countries amounting to about $1 billion, about 5 percent of Serbia's total trade, the impact of American sanctions would be limited. In any case, diplomats said, an American decision to apply sanctions was "still some way off."
 
The New Federation
 For the time being, the Serbian anxieties appear to be focused mainly on whether the Western nations will recognize the new truncated Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro proclaimed last month. Without recognition, the new Yugoslav federation could find itself excluded from a wide range of international organizations to which the former Yugoslavia belonged, including some, like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, that are of major importance.
The difficulty of isolating Serbia was illustrated by the decision today to suspend Serbia from taking part in discussions on the Bosnian issue at the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe, a 52-nation organization that met in Helsinki. The decision, effective until the end of June, was made only after several days of diplomatic maneuvering to overcome the objections of Russia, which had effectively vetoed the move. Diplomats said that Russia, whose historical links with Serbia have been reviving since the collapse of Communism, could pose similar objections to excluding Serbia from other international bodies.

HEADLINE: Bush Plans to Join Other Leaders At Earth Summit in Brazil in June

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
As expected, President Bush said today that he would join more than 100 other world leaders and attend the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro next month.
"Today's environmental problems are global and every nation must help in solving them," Mr. Bush said in a statement. "As the U.S. has demonstrated over more than two decades, protecting the environment and encouraging economic growth can go hand in hand." 
 Mr. Bush's decision came after months of internal Administration debate. For many months, Mr. Bush has been criticized by Democratic members of Congress, environmentalists and his likely Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, for not embracing the Earth Summit and its ambitious envrionmental goals.
Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado said the President "reflexively responds to the politics of an old world order while preaching the need for the new."
Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, who has become an expert in environmental matters, criticized what he called the Administration's "policy of photo opportunities and symbols instead of real commitments."
 
Treaty on Climate Change
 Mr. Bush said in the statement that he decided to go to the summit conference after top aides negotiated a treaty last weekend on global climate change that aims at, but does not set specific timetables for limiting emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases.
White House aides said the President was advised to refrain from attending until conditions more favorable to United States industries were worked out.
"Once the President committed to go he ran the risk of being presented with demands we would find unacceptable," said William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, explaining the strategy. "The climate change treaty that we got owes a little bit at least to a desire that the President would attend and a concern on the part of other governments to make sure that the treaty language would be helpful to get him to Rio."
Environmentalists said the treaty is a weak, but not worthless step toward stabilizing the output of gases they argue are rapidly warming the earth. Liz Barratt-Brown, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington said that much more aggressive steps would need to be taken to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other pollutants to prevent dangerous ecological disruptions.
 
U.S. Given Wide Latitude
 The President's top environmental advisers, though, said the treaty set in motion a global process for stabilizing concentrations of gases at levels that were produced in 1990. The treaty also gives the United States wide latitude in deciding how to achieve those levels without injuring industrial development, Administration officials said.
The Earth Summit, expected to be the largest gathering of world leaders ever, takes place in Rio from June 3 to June 14. The White House said today that the President's schedule had not been set. Mr. Reilly said the President was likely to attend the conference on June 13 to sign the climate change treaty and a separate treaty to preserve species that is under negotiation in Nairobi, Kenya.

HEADLINE: Radical Overhaul Proposed In System of Child Support

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Despite a season of bitter partisanship, two of Congress's most divergent members today proposed a radical change in the way the country collects child-support payments from absent fathers.
Most experts agree that the current system is deeply flawed and that it contributes to a variety of urban problems, including escalating welfare rolls and children living in poverty. 
 But while many proposals have been advanced to change the system, none have been embraced by such an unlikely alliance as the one offered today by Representative Thomas J. Downey, a liberal Long Island Democrat, and Representative Henry J. Hyde, an Illinois Republican who is one of Congress's staunchest conservatives.
The proposal met with praise from many liberals today, skepticism from the White House and attacks from some conservatives.
 
Bipartisan Approach
 "I am here to demonstrate that Republicans and Democrats can work together," said Mr. Downey, who has been working on the proposal for more than a year. Several months ago he approached Mr. Hyde, who has long had an interest in child-support issues.
"Both of us are appalled by what we see today, the disintegration of the American family and the havoc this has wrought on millions of innocent children," Mr. Hyde said.
Their plan would transfer responsibility for all child-support collection from states to the Internal Revenue Service. And it would also guarantee that the Government make a minimum payment of $2,000 a year for a mother with one child if it failed to collect from the absent father. The maximum per family would be $4,000.
The proposal would also create 300,000 new public service jobs to give unemployed fathers a way to make their payments.
Mr. Downey estimated that the stepped-up enforcement could increase the $11 billion now collected in child support to as much as $35 billion a year. He predicted a substantial drop in poverty and dependency as a result. Mr. Hyde said the plan echoed traditional conservative themes by holding fathers responsible for their families.
The lawmakers estimated the cost of the proposal at $5 billion to $10 billion a year. They plan to introduce it as legislation early next year.
Gail Wilensky, a domestic policy adviser to President Bush, said the White House would consider supporting a small pilot project if the funds came from cuts in other social spending. But she criticized the notion of a Government guarantee, saying it might discourage fathers from paying.
Other conservatives said the plan would discourage single mothers from working or getting married. "It's the worst single welfare proposal I've ever seen in my life, bar none," said Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington.
 
Disintegration of Family
 In calling for the plan, Mr. Downey emphasized the sweeping and perhaps irreversible changes in family structure that have occurred over the past generation. In 1960, 9.1 percent of American children lived in single-parent families; by 1990 that figure had grown to 24.7 percent.
Of the approximately 10 million women raising children by themselves, 42 percent have never been awarded child support from a state court.
Many women are reluctant to identify the father, particularly since child-support payments can be used to reduce welfare benefits. But collection remains a big problem even when state courts get involved.
Some fathers deliberately evade payment, often by moving to another state. Others have little or no earnings and find themselves unable to pay.
Only 51 percent of the women with court-orders collect the full amount they are owed. Another 24 percent get less than they are owed, and 25 percent receive no money from the father.
The Downey-Hyde plan would leave responsibility for identifying fathers with the states, but provide new money to do so. Only mothers who cooperated in identifying fathers would be eligible for the guaranteed benefits.
 
Federal and State Roles
 States would determine the initial amount a father was expected to pay. The Internal Revenue Service would be responsible for collecting and distributing the payments, through a payroll deduction system much like the one used to collect taxes. In addition, the plan offers new job-training services for fathers with low incomes.
Mr. Downey said the proposal was carefully put together to include work incentives for women on welfare. If they stayed on welfare, their grants would be reduced by the amount the Government paid or collected, so there would be no net income gain. But if they worked, they could keep both their earnings and the child-support amount.
It was Mr. Hyde, the conservative, who resorted to the visionary language more often used by liberal child advocates. "The social costs of the current system can't be calculated," he said. "We've seen some of it in riots, in lives wasted from the moment they're conceived."
