HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Virgin Megastore to Enter U.S. Market in a Big Way

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Richard Branson, the 41-year-old British entrepreneur, said yesterday that he planned to open the largest record store in Los Angeles next fall in the first United States venture for his fast-growing Virgin Megastore division.
"It will be three times as big as that of our nearest competitor," he said of the store, which is to in a shopping mall on Sunset Boulevard. 
 The store will have 30,000 square feet of space, compared with the 10,000-square-foot Los Angeles store of his major rival, H.M.V, a major British retailer also known as His Majesty's Voice.
The Virgin Megastore division already has 30 stores in Britain, the European Continent, Australia and Japan. Founded in 1971 when Mr. Branson was 20 years old, the Megastore group has expanded rapidly in the last two years, with most of the growth on the Continent and in the Far East.
Its store in Paris on the Champs-Elysee has more than $125 million a year in revenue, which Mr. Branson said represented one of the largest amounts in retailing for 30,000 square feet of space.
As with his other stores, Mr. Branson said, the one in Los Angeles will consist of groups of smaller shops specializing in such styles as rock, jazz and classical. It will also sell books and games and have a restaurant.
Mr. Branson, who attended a lunch with editors and reporters at The New York Times yesterday, also gave further details of his plans to establish special trains on the tracks owned by British Railways to feed the London flights of his airline, Virgin Atlantic Airways.
He said that the British Government had already approved the right for his company to lease tracks from the Government-owned railroad and set up a competing service. He added that he was talking with Electra Investment Trust, a large investment group in Britain, to help with the financing.
 
Railway Amenities
 The trains will be patterned after the service on Virgin Atlantic planes, having such amenities as computer games in seats, stand-up lounges and special food service provided by attendants. Virgin has competed with the major airlines by offering business-class fliers service similar to first class but at business-class prices; it also offers more creature comforts to economy-class fliers.
One of Mr. Branson's goals is to be able to provide express trains to London from such cities as Glasgow, Edinburgh and Newcastle, with travel times close to those available through current plane service in Britain.
Virgin Atlantic at this point has no way of bringing travelers to London from other parts of Britain for its flights, which depart from London to such big cities as Newark and Tokyo. The rail service, he said, would help to feed Virgin's expansion to new destinations like Johannesburg, Chicago and San Francisco.
Mr. Branson is flush with cash since he recently sold the Virgin Music Group, a record company, for $880 million to Thorn EMI P.L.C. His share of the sale was $540 million.
That does not mean, however, that he is ready to expand wildly. He prefers that his empire, which also includes hotels and computer games, stays small enough to keep tabs on, and that he keep its individual companies small enough so that the employees know one another.
Reaching into his pocket, he drew scraps of paper on which he had made notes on his Virgin Atlantic flight Monday night, jottings that illustrate his attention to the minutiae of his operations. He noted, for instance, that business fliers wanted their complimentary travel booties given out about a half-hour after takeoff because they want to go to sleep soon after they board. He found that some of the caps on the free bottles of scented oil were sometimes loose. And he found that some business fliers wanted cash instead of the free ticket for the miles they had racked up traveling on Virgin.
 
The Romance of It All
 A challenge, Mr. Branson said, was to keep some of the romance alive in working for an airline, an important element in maintaining the morale of the 8,000 employees at Virgin. To help, he said, the airline tries to hire people who have not worked for other carriers -- except in the more technical jobs, like pilots, many of whom come from Virgin's archrival, British Airways.
He also allows the staff to participate in decisions affecting them, such as bringing 500 flight attendants together with a group of designers in a hangar and allowing them to design their own uniforms. And he said he sought out good hotels for his traveling employees.
"There should be romance," he said. "Often, airlines forget that."

HEADLINE: INCREASE APPROVED IN FEES BANKS PAY TO INSURE DEPOSITS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Defying heavy pressure from both the Bush Administration and the industry, Federal regulators voted today to raise the premiums that banks and savings associations pay to their insolvent insurance funds and to make fundamental changes in the way those premiums are assessed.
The 3-to-2 decision by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would raise premiums an average of 22 percent starting in January. And for the first time since 1934, when the initial fund was set up in the wake of the bank collapses of the Depression, weaker institutions would pay a bigger increase than stronger ones. 
 In an effort to encourage prudent banking practices, Congress last year gave the regulators until 1994 to end the 58-year-old system of having all banks pay the same rate.
 
Impact on Consumers
 The increase, which the Administration had hoped until the last minute to be able to block, would have a broad economic impact, making banking more expensive for customers, who will have to pay more for loans and receive lower yields on deposits.
It would also hurt the stockholders of about 14,500 banks and savings associations, reducing the industry's after-tax earnings by more than 4 percent. Some of the premium costs are also borne by taxpayers, because institutions are permitted to write off a percentage of their premium payments on their corporate taxes.
Supporters of the increase say it is intended to protect confidence in the economy by strengthening the insurance fund, which is deeply in the red and at its lowest level since its creation during the Depression.
 
More Big Losses Expected
 William Taylor, the chairman of the insurance corporation, said that the bank insurance fund lost about $11 billion last year, giving it a deficit of about $7 billion that it has had to borrow from the Treasury, and that even greater annual losses could be posted in the next two years. The proposed changes would raise an additional $1.25 billion annually.
The increase, to an average of 28 cents for every $100 in deposits from the current 23 cents, is expected to be approved after a 60-day comment period. The weakest banks, those with the least capital and the most problem loans, would pay an additional 3 cents for every $100 in deposits, and the strongest would pay 3 cents less.
Regulators said that the new risk-based system may take longer to put in place, but that any delay would not postpone the premium increase.
The bank insurance fund, which stood at $18.3 billion six years ago, has been battered by the failures of 885 banks since then, costing more than $26 billion. While assessments have nearly tripled, from 8.3 cents per $100 just three years ago to the current 23 cents, they have failed to keep pace with the devastation of the industry.
The dissenting votes on the premium increase were cast by the Treasury Department's representatives on the board: T. Timothy Ryan Jr., head of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and Stephen R. Steinbrink, Acting Comptroller of the Currency.
Mr. Steinbrink said in an interview afterward that he supported a 4-cent increase, but that the board's approval of 5 cents, bringing in an additional $250 million, "was not justified."
After the board appeared to be moving toward a 4-cent increase, Mr. Taylor said that would not be enough, and two other members, C. C. Hope Jr. and Andrew C. Hove Jr., joined him to support the 5-cent raise.
Mr. Taylor's term expires in February, and the premium increase, one of the most important regulatory decisions this year, had put him squarely between Congress and the Treasury. Today's decision was in clear defiance of the industry and the Bush Administration, which appointed Mr. Taylor less than a year ago.
 
Tough Political Fight
 Mr. Taylor, who has told associates the increase was the most difficult political fight he has fought, said that in recent months the industry had shown some signs of improvement, primarily because of favorable interest rates, but that it was too soon to conclude that troubled banks had worked out their problems with real estate loans.
"I would prefer to be here lowering the premium," he said at the packed board meeting today. "But if we were to overestimate the problem and take in too much money, it would be the first time in a long time. The information in front of us is overwhelming, and it's responsible for us to do what's right and increase the premium.
"We're trying to close a widening gap between revenues and expenses, a reasonable business principle, a reasonable government principle and one that shows strength rather than weakness."
 
One Grim Forecast
 A report by the F.D.I.C. staff stated that "as bad as the past five years have been in terms of insurance losses, the next two years could be even worse." It said a rate of about 50 cents would be needed to prevent the fund from deteriorating further. The agency has said it expects 200 banks holding $80 billion in assets to fail this year, at a cost to the fund of about $14 billion.
Industry groups had complained that the increase was unnecessary and harmful, and had pressed the five board members in the last few days to postpone a decision until after Election Day. They have also said the F.D.I.C. projections are too pessimistic, noting that so far this year the Government has seized only 51 banks holding $16.1 billion in assets.
"Raising premiums will do more harm than good at a time when the banking industry and the economy are beginning to show signs of strength," said Alan R. Tubbs, president of the American Bankers Association and head of the Maquoketa State Bank in Maquoketa, Iowa.
Officials at the American Bankers Association said the premium increase would have a small impact on customers at some institutions, and a much larger impact at others, depending on the markets and financial condition of each bank.
 
Congressional Reaction
 The increase was supported by several important lawmakers, who have sought higher assessments to avoid an embarrassing repeat of the huge taxpayer bailout of the nation's savings and loans.
"The F.D.I.C. has taken a much-needed step toward protecting taxpayers and depositors," said Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee. "The industry must shoulder this burden, not the taxpayer."
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and the head of the House Banking Committee, called the increase "the minimum that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation could do to keep the bank insurance fund afloat."
The theory behind the new risk-based insurance system is that it would reward the best-managed institutions and deter other banks from risky lending, just as private insurance is thought to work in other industries.
 
Some Delay Is Possible
 It has been widely supported in principle for years, but putting a plan into effect has always proved nettlesome. Some regulators said today that the plan might not be ready to carry out by January, in which case the premium increases would still take effect.
Under the proposed change, banks would be ranked in one of nine categories. The rankings would be based on a bank's level of capital and on a more subjective supervisory judgment.
Capital, which is the owners' interest in an institution, is an important indicator of financial health because it provides a cushion to absorb losses.
The supervisory considerations include the results of examiners' reports, public filings on performance, and other information available to the regulators.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
He Doesn't Call Them Dirty Deals

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Many entrepreneurs have tried to pull off emissions-trading deals under the acid rain provisions of the Clean Air Act of 1990. Apparently the first to be successful, with the agreement between the Tennessee Valley Authority and Wisconsin Power and Light, is a small Washington-based investment banking firm, Clean Air Capital Markets, established by John B. Henry 2d shortly after passage of the act.
Mr. Henry, 43 years old, said in a telephone interview that his approach was different from many competitors, who were acting as consultants. He is an investment banker, paid only if a deal is signed. He did not disclose the fee for the T.V.A.-Wisconsin deal, but said he and his partners had spent more than $1 million "establishing the franchise," or setting themselves up to arrange such deals. 
 The size of the potential market is huge; by Mr. Henry's calculation, if all the emission reductions were achieved by trades -- which is unlikely -- the value would equal one-third the capitalization of all the companies on the American Stock Exchange. "We're not shooting mice here," he said. "It's an elephant hunt."
 
Making Them Cringe
 Mr. Henry and others in the field cringe at the idea that utilities are buying the right to pollute. "Utilities are buying clean air," he said. No utility would rely exclusively on allowance purchases, rather than cleaning itself up, he said; for one thing, that would be politically impossible.
But if buying allowances is cheaper than cutting emissions, then utilities should buy, to help hold their rates down, he said. Electric rates increased by environmental requirements are like a regressive tax, Mr. Henry believes, falling more heavily on the poor.
A second such deal was announced yesterday by Wisconsin Power; the company said that in addition to T.V.A., it was also selling allowances to the Duquesne Light Company, with headquarters in Pittsburgh. Mr. Henry was not involved in that deal.
Mr. Henry, a graduate of Columbia Law School, describes Clean Air Capital Markets as his second environmental company. From 1981 to 1990 he was chief executive of Crop Genetics International, an agricultural biotechnology company traded over-the-counter.
Clean Air Capital Markets' vice president is Ernest G. Ellingson, formerly in charge of strategic planning at Georgia Power. The company's lawyer is Andrew D. Weissman, who specializes in air pollution law.
While economists have hailed the emissions trading concept, utilities, which are inherently conservative, have been slow to warm to the concept. "They have an extraordinary bias to on-system compliance, cleaning up your own system," he said. One reason, he said, is that each utility has a fuel department, which would handle the arrangements if the company chose fuel-switching, an engineering staff that would negotiate with companies that install scrubbers or other pollution control equipment. But, he said, "generally there are no constituents inside for buying compliance outside your own system."
But buying allowances is the most conservative option, he argued. "What a scrubber really is, is a decision to buy a 30-year stream of allowances," he said, meaning that the scrubber would generate emission reductions for that long. But if the scrubber went into service in 1995 and ran until 2025, he said, that committed the utility to that option for all those years. If the price of allowances declines in future years, he said, the scrubber would look like a bad buy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John B. Henry 2d, who established the investment banking firm Clean Air Capital Markets. (Clean Air Capital Markets)

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off On Weak Demand for Loans

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down for the week ended today, The Bank Rate Monitor said in its most recent survey.
Frank J. Barkocy, a senior vice president and bank analyst at Advest Inc., said that because of a weak demand for loans, many banks were flush with cash and had no need to increase rates to lure new depositors. When rolling over certificates of deposits, banks have been able to offer rates at about half the level they were two years ago. 
 "The result has been some depositors moving their money into more liquid demand deposits, with mutual funds having offered one of the best alternatives since there are so many," Mr. Barkocy said, noting that the low interest rates were especially hard on depositors living on fixed incomes.
"There are funds that offer the safety of principal as well as those with some risk advantages, but a blend of positioning makes the most sense.".
At the Treasury's auction of new three- and six-month bills on Monday, interest rates declined slightly. The weekly auction is seen as a good barometer of what many banks will pay depositors in the weeks ahead.
At the auction, the average rate on a three-month bill slipped a basis point, to 3.64 percent, and a six-month bill fell 4 basis points, to 3.74 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Metropolitan-Area Banks
 Yields at New York area banks were down, but the decline was not severe. The average money market account was off a basis point, to 3.49 percent, and three- and six-month C.D.'s were down an average 2 basis points, to 3.55 percent and 3.71 percent, respectively.
In the latest week, commercial banks and savings banks were both down similar amounts, with commercial money market accounts and three- and six-month certificates all off 2 basis points. The average money market account was at 3.22 percent, while the three- and six-month certificates were at 3.38 percent and 3.46 percent, respectively.
Savings banks, meanwhile, cut their money market accounts a basis point, to 3.76 percent, and their three- and six-month C.D.'s 2 basis points, to 3.74 percent and 3.96 percent, respectively.
The largest cuts in yields among the New York banks were at the Republic National Bank of New York, which lowered the yield on its money market account by 26 basis points, to 3.30 percent, and the Bank of Tokyo, which lowered its three- and six-month C.D.'s by 16 basis points, to 2.93 percent and 3.05 percent, respectively.
For 20 large banks outside the New York market, yields fell further. A money market account slipped 2 basis points, to 3.36 percent, and a six-month C.D. was down 4 basis points, to 3.71 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Predicts Slow Decline in Trade Deficit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The Bush Administration predicted today that the United States trade deficit would gradually decline this year, although it conceded that a severe economic slowdown in Europe and Japan could jeopardize the forecast.
In its semiannual report to Congress on trade and exchange rates, the Administration said recent trade statistics suggested a continuation of a gradual improvement in the deficit, especially given growing demand for United States products in Latin America. 
 "However, prospects for further declines in the trade deficit are subject to particular uncertainty this year given the cyclical situation in both the United States and the other major industrial countries," the report said.
The report said a slow economic recovery in the United States would contribute to lower imports from overseas.
It noted that the merchandise trade deficit had dropped in 1991 for the fourth consecutive year, to $74 billion, from $108 billion in 1990. While imports fell $8 billion, to $490 billion in 1991, exports grew by $27 billion, to $417 billion.
Unless offset by economic conditions in the United States or in Japan and Europe, "the pattern of recent monthly data is consistent with a continuation in 1992 of a gradual downward trend in the trade deficit, perhaps to the $65 billion range from $74 billion in 1991," the report said.
Because of weakening economies in Japan and Europe, the pattern of exports has shifted to Latin America and East Asia, where many nations have been experiencing strong growth.
"One-third of the increase in exports went to Latin America, and this area replaced Europe as our fastest-growing market," the report said.
The report also accused China for the first time of manipulating its exchange rate, resulting in a large trade surplus with the United States.
Three previous reports attributed China's trade surplus primarily to causes other than exchange rate manipulation.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
NBC Likes Young Viewers, Judging From Its Fall Plans

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
IF NBC needs a theme to promote its prime-time schedule for 1992-93, "Young at Heart" might do.
The network has embarked on a much-discussed effort to bolster its advertising revenues by attracting younger viewers, consumers aged 18 to 49, for whom marketers yearn because they spend more freely and are more likely to try new products or change brands. 
 Toward that end, the new NBC fall lineup, to be announced a week from tomorrow, will replace mainstay series like "The Golden Girls," "Matlock" and "In the Heat of the Night," which appealed to older viewers, with shows more along the lines of newer comedies like "Seinfeld" and "Blossom," which draw high ratings among younger audiences.
Some advertising and media executives, tongues firmly in cheek, labeled NBC's efforts "granny dumping," after the practice by which people abandon older relatives requiring long-term care. Though not doubting the desirability of younger demographic groups, or NBC's pursuit of them, they wonder if NBC, as it plays catch-up with rival networks, is trying to do too much at once.
"You can't change that much of a schedule in one year and expect success," said Jon Mandel, the senior vice president and director of national broadcast at Grey Advertising Inc. in New York, referring to the dreadful mortality rate for new series.
Executives also took issue with the way NBC has handled the change. Even the syndicated columnist Erma Bombeck mocked the network for chasing after "high-spending consumers" like her thirtysomething children, members of a demographic group "whose first words were not 'Daddy,' but 'Do I have to use my own money?' "
Arnie Semsky, the executive vice president and director of media and programming services at BBDO Worldwide in New York, praised NBC's strategy, but added, "Maybe their positioning was incorrect," referring to the abrupt cancellations of the series not renewed.
"They are obviously not bad shows," he added, "or they wouldn't have been picked up by CBS and ABC." CBS said it would take "The Golden Girls," to be revamped into "Golden Palace" following the departure of one cast member, Bea Arthur, and "In the Heat of the Night." ABC said it would schedule "Matlock" as a midseason replacement during 1992-93.
NBC, of course, sees the path it has taken as the right one.
"We respond to what our advertisers are looking for," said Larry Hoffner, the executive vice president of sales in New York. "And we have found that some of these shows, as they get more mature, attract an older audience that is not as desirable to advertisers.
"It's like wearing an overcoat in July. It may be a nice overcoat, but it doesn't fit the season."
Preston Beckman, NBC's vice president of program planning and scheduling, said that while the network's goal remained "to appeal to the widest possible audience," the canceled series "were appealing, almost exclusively at this point, to adults 55 and older."
"The perception that we're not interested in anyone older than 55 is not true," he added. "The general pattern is, as we've seen with 'Seinfeld,' is that when ratings increase because of 18- to 49-year-olds, more 50-plus viewers join in, too."
Fueling NBC's intent is an economic issue apart from the network's advertising concerns. The canceled series not only appealed to older viewers, but were themselves older programs, meaning that the licensing fees NBC paid to their producers to run them exceeded fees for new series.
"Are we getting the right value for our programming dollar?" Mr. Hoffner asked. "And what goes into that is what we can sell it for."
In focusing on younger viewers, NBC has joined ABC, which has long aimed programming at them, and the fledgling Fox network, which has found success with shows aimed at viewers aged 12 to 24.
CBS, which supplanted NBC in first place during the 1991-92 season, has traditionally emphasized series appealing to older viewers, like "Murder, She Wrote," though it, too, has been seeking younger audiences with offerings like "Northern Exposure."
"Most of what's sold on TV are products and services used by younger families," said Alan Wurtzel, the senior vice president of marketing and research services at ABC in New York. "They consume a lot of packaged goods."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Busy Trading; Drop Against Yen Is Sharp

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined in hectic trading on world currency markets yesterday, registering its biggest losses against the Japanese yen.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $335.30 an ounce, off $1.40 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.70 an ounce to a late bid price of $334.60. 
 Analysts said the dollar had initially been weakened by a Government report showing wholesale prices edged up a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in April. It was the third straight month that the Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures inflation before goods reach consumers, posted a modest gain.
The market interpreted the report as painting a favorable backdrop against which the Federal Reserve could cut interest rates to spur a sluggish economy.
The fresh data on wholesale prices "got the ball rolling on the downside for the dollar," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Comments by Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford accelerated the move. Speaking before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Mulford said the Group of Seven industrialized nations must cooperate closely in foreign exchange trading.
"It sounded like he was championing the G-7 to support the yen against the dollar," Mr. Donney said. A stronger yen would help correct Japan's growing trade surpluses, he said.
Traders interpreted Mr. Mulford's comments as a sign that the Fed would prefer a much lower yen, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
The dollar sold off sharply against the yen, tumbling more than 2 yen and through the important support level of 131.00 yen, which in turn spurred even more technical selling.
"It was a crazy day for the dollar and the yen," Mr. Flanagan said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 132.60 yen, down 0.57 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 130.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 130.55 yen, down from 133.00 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8135, from $1.7935 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.8135 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.7945.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6230 German marks, down from 1.6390; 1.5035 Swiss francs, down from 1.5255; 5.4460 French francs, down from 5.5095, and 1,222.00 Italian lire, down from 1,233.25.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fixing Prices For Virtue's Sake?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
IS it O.K. to fix prices in pursuit of a good cause? If so, who gets to decide which causes are good enough?
These questions, rarely joined outside law school classrooms, are the nub of the Federal antitrust suit against the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that is set for trial in June. And many observers, it is safe to say, will be torn between gut admiration for one of America's great institutions of learning and a nagging sense that only governments should be allowed to fix prices. 
 Last year the Justice Department charged that the eight Ivy League universities and M.I.T. had fixed the "price" of scholarship benefits by using a common formula for calculating financial need and agreeing not to offer scholarships based on merit.
Without admitting guilt, the Ivies consented to abandoning the practice. But M.I.T., angered by the attack on the university's reputation and worried that a settlement would inspire private antitrust suits by aggrieved students, decided to go to court.
There is no real argument over the facts. M.I.T. was indeed one of 23 elite colleges that met each year to hammer out a common student-aid policy. Nor, apparently, is there much dispute over some of the consequences.
The need-based formula spread aid to a large number of students. In M.I.T.'s case, $20 million was budgeted to offset all or part of the tuition of some 60 percent of the undergraduates. The agreement also eliminated the temptation to bid for the most desirable candidates for admission -- namely, minority students with good prospects, and exceptionally gifted students.
But beyond this point, M.I.T. and the Justice Department sound as if they are talking about different cases. M.I.T. cannot imagine why the antitrust division cares how a nonprofit institution with a proud record of academic excellence and racial diversity chooses to distribute its charity. The Government, for its part, sees M.I.T. and the Ivies as businesses that have increased fees to customers almost twice as fast as consumer prices have risen over the last two decades.
When the suit was announced in May 1991, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh asserted that students were entitled to the full benefits of price competition -- "just as they would in shopping for any other service." What other business, countered M.I.T., would not even try to recover its expenses from the customers? Full tuition, the university notes, is just half the $30,000 average cost of a year's education.
The one place where the argument is joined is over the impact of collusion on the cost of attending one of the schools involved. The Justice Department's economic consultant, Keith Leffler of the University of Washington, argues that some of the savings achieved in the absence of competitive bidding for students surely must have been diverted to other uses -- anything, say, from faculty salaries to carpeting for administrators' offices.
But M.I.T.'s consultant, Dennis Carlton of the University of Chicago, argues that the elite 23 never used their market power to such selfish ends. And he employs high-powered techniques to buttress his point. His statistical-regression analysis attempts to tease out the sources of variation in average net tuition -- posted fees, less financial aid -- among some 225 colleges during the late 1980's. Various measures of academic quality, exclusivity and regional income seemed to have a large influence on college charges. By contrast, membership in the group that colluded on scholarship aid mattered not at all.
It is not yet known whether this conclusion will withstand hostile scrutiny in the courtroom. In the view of Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business, the statistical analysis is almost beside the point.
Suppose the Big Three auto makers colluded to raise prices on luxury cars, and pledged to plow the profits into something deemed socially valuable -- say a cheap, fuel-efficient Toyota-buster. Would we want the Justice Department to look the other way, Mr. White asks.
To Mr. White and Steven Salop, a Georgetown University economist, who was co-author of an analysis of the antitrust case in the Summer 1991 issue of the Journal of Economic Perspectives, the real economic sin was procedural. If a ban on merit-based aid is good public policy, they argue, the policy should be made by the Government -- not by colluding universities.
Nonetheless, a loss in court could cost M.I.T. dearly if students followed with suits to recover part of their tuition. And if there is one thing almost everyone who has followed this case agrees on, it is that the universities should not be penalized for past aid policies that were never hidden from the Government. If collusion on scholarship aid was bad for society, Mr. Salop asked, "why did it take 15 years for the Justice Department to intervene -- years in which the colleges dug themselves into a treble-damages nightmare?"

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup: Secret C.I.A. File Shows Agents Followed Oswald Before 1963;
Budget Amendment

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat sponsoring the budget-balancing amendment proposal with the widest support in Congress, told the House Budget Committee today that the amendment was needed to force the White House and Congress to get serious about eliminating the deficit.
In his first testimony on the amendment since he began a new push to get it passed, Mr. Simon said, "It forces us to make the painful choice that candidly neither political party is willing to make right now." 
 Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, repeatedly asked Mr. Simon how the amendment would suddenly make Republicans and Democrats agree on how to reduce the deficit, after they have been unable to agree for more than a decade.
He pressed the Senator on what specific measures he would take to balance the budget. Mr. Simon said that unspecified tax increases and spending cuts would be needed, and that cutting the $281 billion military budget could provide most of the savings.
He said he thought the amendment might come to a Senate vote in the next two weeks. "I think we have a good chance, but I'm not predicting it will pass," he said, although many other lawmakers say the amendment will probably pass this year.
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, also criticized the amendment, saying it would restrict Washington's flexibility to use fiscal policy to counteract recessions.
He voiced fears that lawmakers would use their vote for the amendment as an excuse not to get serious about reducing the deficit until the states ratify it years from now.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
The passing of Marlene Dietrich brings to mind a scene I witnessed about 25 years ago when, fresh from Oklahoma, I moved to New York. This particular afternoon I was outside Saks Fifth Avenue, waiting for the traffic light to change, when -- gasp! -- I spotted the magnificent Marlene. Though glamorous as ever, she went virtually unrecognized, no doubt because of her get-up -- cowboy gear, from Stetson hat to Tony Lama boots. 
 One fellow did sidle up beside her, stared in awe for a second or two and said, "Pardon me, but aren't you Marlene Dietrich?" Dietrich eyed him coolly, smiled slightly, stuck her thumbs in her holster and spoke.
"Yup," she said. Then she crossed the street and headed west. ROBERT MITCHELL

 	 	 		. . .	 	The place: 51st Street between First and Second Avenues.
Time: Just the other day.
Action: Frances P. Glassner walks past a store with a large sign on the window. The sign reads:
ZELDA THE PSYCHIC. SEES ALL. KNOWS ALL.
PREDICTS THE FUTURE. COME IN FOR A READING.

"Where have you been?" she asks. "And what have you been doing?"

 	 	 		. . .	 	ONION
 Coiled in circular perfection
 and giving off an aroma to
 send your taste buds into euphoria . . .
 I peel this onion.
 The colors, magenta and white,
 excite the gourmet in me.
 Were its color blue, I would
 slice it with indifference; drop it
 into soup, or just an ordinary stew.
 But magenta and white surely deserve
 a more delectable brew!
 Call Bon Appetit, ask their
 opinion:
 "What can I do
 with this wonderful onion?" DORIS KLEIN

 	 	 		. . .	 	The scene: Caldor's bookstore in Old Greenwich, Conn. Closeup of Audrey Orenbach, browsing, searching for Julia Phillips's book on Hollywood, "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again." It takes a while, but she finally finds it. It's displayed in the Diet and Health section.

MARX (KARL) IS NOW IN ECONOMICS.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Among recent vistors to New York were Janos and Rebecca Wilder of Tucson, Ariz. Mr. Wilder, the owner and chef of the Tucson restaurant that bears his first name, had come to town to attend the James Beard Awards ceremony celebrating all aspects of cooking in America (he was a nominee in the Southwest division).
High on the Wilders' must-do list was dinner at Le Cirque. Mr. Wilder phoned the almost-always-packed restaurant, and reservations were made for 9:30, the earliest time available. When the day of the dinner arrived, the couple wondered if they might be able to switch to a more convenient hour. Mr. Wilder called again, this time explaining that he, too, was in the restaurant business and that perhaps Le Cirque could accommodate him and his wife with an earlier reservation.
The voice at Le Cirque said please hang on. A minute or so later, the voice was back on the line with the good news that, yes, an earlier dinner time was indeed available.
"Thank you," said Mr. Wilder. "What time?"
"9:15," the voice said.

SLEEP DISORDER CENTER

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 470 words

HEADLINE: The War Democrats, 1992 Style

 BODY:
There's no blaming unreconstructed cold warriors in the Pentagon or the Administration now. It's Democrats in Congress who are throwing away the future to protect the past. By insisting on spending billions to build unneeded weapons, they are protecting a few defense jobs but retarding the healthy development of as many permanent, non-defense jobs.
By propping up outmoded producers, they are keeping resources from flowing to products the country needs and the world wants. By preserving pet programs in their districts, they reflect the worst in reckless parochialism instead of challenging President Bush for the lead in redefining national priorities. 
 So far this session, the Democratic Congress has illustrated precisely how not to cut defense spending.
It failed the first test -- re-allocating resources from defense spending to domestic needs. That requires removing the cap on domestic spending imposed by the 1990 bipartisan budget agreement. Otherwise Congress has little incentive to cut defense dollars, since any savings would go to deficit reduction, not to domestic needs. But threatened with a White House veto, Democrats knuckled under and left standing the wall between defense and domestic spending.
House Democrats may settle for a second-best solution: setting aside $1 billion for defense conversion. But they have yet to say how they would spend the money. If carefully targeted on investment in non-defense research and development, retraining and job placement, the result could be of some benefit for laid-off defense workers and the country. That makes more sense than wasting the money on unneeded weapons -- which is just what the Democrats are mostly doing.
They are providing the votes the Pentagon needs to protect weapons like the Stealth bomber; so what if the billion-dollar B-2 can't evade radars as well as advertised? The 15 planes already being built aren't enough for key Democrats; they tentatively approved a 16th last year, and now a House subcommittee wants to buy four more -- at over $1 billion each.
Even more shamefully, Democrats are trying to restore funds for weapons that even the Pentagon is prepared to cut, like the Seawolf submarine. The Senate voted to build two more of them, and the House one more.
Proponents contend that the difference between closing down the Seawolf assembly line and building two more subs amounts to "little or no money." Since when is $2 billion little or no money? And that does not include billions more to man, exercise and maintain the subs once they are built.
To pay for Seawolf, the Democratic majority in the Senate did cut funding for Star Wars defenses. But such savings would be better set aside for domestic needs. Otherwise, these latter-day War Democrats will sacrifice the peace dividend.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 311 words

HEADLINE: Record School Construction

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
A record $10.7 billion was spent on public school construction and renovation last year in a building boom that reflects continued efforts by school districts in the United States to replace or restore aging school buildings.
The 1991 total, the seventh year in which school construction spending was higher than the year before, represented a 10.7 percent increase over the $9.7 billion spent in 1990, according to a soon-to-be released annual construction survey of the nation's school districts by American School and University magazine. 
 "The need is still there and the buildings are still falling apart," said Joe Agron, the editor of the magazine, in explaining the continuing spending increases on school buildings despite the nearly two-year-old recession.
The Midwest showed the largest increase in construction spending, with $1.5 billion last year as against $1.1 billion in 1990. The Northeast also showed an increase, to $607 million from $554 million in 1990. But the Southeast continued to have the largest slice of construction spending, $2.8 billion, off slightly from the $2.9 billion it reported in 1990.
The magazine attributed last year's increases partly to school districts' using bond money that was approved by voters in the 1980's, when the economy was stronger. Many school districts held that money in reserve but are now using it to repair deteriorating school buildings.
The magazine, which sent out surveys to all 15,600 school districts in the nation and received responses from 18 percent of them, said the construction growth also stemmed from continuing efforts by school systems to replace their aging buildings.
Half of the nation's 110,000 school buildings were erected 30 to 40 years ago and have seen little significant repairs since then, the American Association of School Administrators said last November.

To pay for Seawolf, the Democratic majority in the Senate did cut funding for Star Wars defenses. But such savings would be better set aside for domestic needs. Otherwise, these latter-day War Democrats will sacrifice the peace dividend.

HEADLINE: Record School Construction

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
A record $10.7 billion was spent on public school construction and renovation last year in a building boom that reflects continued efforts by school districts in the United States to replace or restore aging school buildings.
The 1991 total, the seventh year in which school construction spending was higher than the year before, represented a 10.7 percent increase over the $9.7 billion spent in 1990, according to a soon-to-be released annual construction survey of the nation's school districts by American School and University magazine. 
 "The need is still there and the buildings are still falling apart," said Joe Agron, the editor of the magazine, in explaining the continuing spending increases on school buildings despite the nearly two-year-old recession.
The Midwest showed the largest increase in construction spending, with $1.5 billion last year as against $1.1 billion in 1990. The Northeast also showed an increase, to $607 million from $554 million in 1990. But the Southeast continued to have the largest slice of construction spending, $2.8 billion, off slightly from the $2.9 billion it reported in 1990.
The magazine attributed last year's increases partly to school districts' using bond money that was approved by voters in the 1980's, when the economy was stronger. Many school districts held that money in reserve but are now using it to repair deteriorating school buildings.
The magazine, which sent out surveys to all 15,600 school districts in the nation and received responses from 18 percent of them, said the construction growth also stemmed from continuing efforts by school systems to replace their aging buildings.
Half of the nation's 110,000 school buildings were erected 30 to 40 years ago and have seen little significant repairs since then, the American Association of School Administrators said last November.

NEEDLES FOR ADDICTS: CLEAN, LEGAL AND FREE
For the first time in two years, drug addicts will be able to legally get free clean needles in New York City as a group of public and private agencies try to measure whether such programs would slow the spread of AIDS. The new effort, markedly different from a previous one, will use community workers to seek out addicts on the streets to distribute needles and offer access to social services and drug treatment. HEADLINE: American Vehicle Sales Down 0.3% in Early May

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks fell three-tenths of 1 percent in early May. But the sluggish results included a hopeful sign for the Big Three, which grabbed a larger share from Japanese transplant producers.
The nine foreign and domestic auto makers operating North American assembly plants sold 130,408 cars from May 1-10, a 2.9 percent drop from a year earlier. Sales of light trucks assembled in North America rose 3.9 percent, to 87,497. from last year. Over all, vehicle sales reached 217,905, compared with last year's sales of 245,871. 
 Percentage changes were adjusted for the length of the period, which had eight selling days this year versus nine selling days last year.
 
No Recovery in Showrooms
 "Economic recovery has failed to make an appearance in dealer showrooms," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association.
The seasonally annual rate of car sales in early May was 5.7 million, down from 6.1 million in late April and slightly ahead of the 5.4 million rate a year earlier. The slow selling rate has been stalled at the current level since August, but auto makers have been building more cars because retail dealers were liquidating inventories last year and, therefore, were not ordering from auto makers.
"One silver lining is that domestic companies are getting a bigger share of the market," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "But if the rate doesn't pick up there may have to be a slowdown in production later in the year, mostly at plants assembling light-truck models."
The General Motors Corporation sold 62,882 cars in the period, a drop of 1.8 percent. G.M.'s Chevrolet division was the biggest loser, posting a 28.1 percent drop in car sales and an 11.9 percent drop in light-truck sales. Pontiac, with strong sales of the new Bonneville and Grand Am models, posted a 35.9 percent increase.
The Ford Motor Company sold 39,332 cars, an increase of 2.8 percent.
The Chrysler Corporation, which announces sales only once a month, sold an estimated 11,550 cars, down 5.5 percent, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
 
Big Three's Share
 But the large Japanese auto makers were hit much harder. The Honda Motor Company's car sales of models produced in North America fell 15 percent, to 8,310; the Toyota Motor Corporation sales fell 8.3 percent, to 5,160, and the Nissan Motor Company's car sales fell 44 percent, to 1,099.
Consequently the Big Three's share of the market for domestically built cars rose to 87.2 percent from 85.3 percent, while the sales from Japanese transplants fell to 12.8 percent from 14.7 percent
Some retail dealers said the rising prices of imports compared with American brands and the perception that American brands had substantially improved quality had had an impact on consumer choice. "We used to sell 50 Saabs and Porsches a month, now we're selling 10," said Jim Henderson, general manager of Major Cadillac-Pontiac-Saab-Porsche in Kansas City, Mo.
G.M's sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, fell 10.4 percent, to 31,416. Ford light-truck sales rose 8.6 percent, to 31,380. Ward's estimated Chrysler's truck sales at 21,950.
Nissan, which makes more light trucks in the United States than other Japanese auto makers, posted a 36.7 percent decline in sales to 1,297.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Advance Only 0.2%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Inflation moderated in April as declining food and clothing costs and slower gains in housing and transportation held consumer price increases to a slim two-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said today.
The modest gain in the Consumer Price Index -- the most widely used measure of inflation -- should give the Federal Reserve room for another cut in interest rates, economists said. 
 The increase followed an unexpectedly sharp five-tenths of 1 percent rise in March, but economists view that as an aberration in an otherwise nonthreatening price front.
"It looks like we have developed a real stable inflation rate," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. "It's relatively moderate across the board."
So far this year, the index has risen at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.3 percent, about the same pace as the modest 3.1 percent rise for all of last year.
 
Possibility of Fed Action
 Helped by the moderate inflation level, the Fed has been pushing interest rates lower for the last year and a half. But with the recovery looking like one of the weakest in 50 years, many economists think it is only a matter of time before the central bank acts again.
"I should think that the Fed could ease," Mr. Ratajczak said.
Such a move by the Fed could induce banks to cut the prime lending rates they charge their best customers by a half-point from the 6 1/2 percent level most now have.
The department's report supports other evidence of a benign inflation rate that economists say reflects the country's sluggish, uneven effort to recover from recession.
The biggest restraint on price rises has been the minimal wage gains workers have eked out in today's tight job market, which has limited their purchasing power, economists said.
"The reasons for the low inflation rate are readily apparent -- slack in labor markets and diminished inflationary expectations in the wake of three years of slow growth," said Gordon Richards, an economist with the Washington-based National Association of Manufacturers.
In a separate report, the department said the average weekly earnings of United States workers, after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors, fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, their third monthly decline this year. Over the last 12 months, real earnings have risen only at an average of 3.1 percent.
Excluding food and energy costs, which can vary widely from month to month, prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in April after a five-tenths of 1 percent gain in March, the department said. In the last 12 months, this so-called core inflation has risen 3.9 percent.
Today's report showed food prices falling one-tenth of 1 percent last month, reflecting sharp declines in fresh fruit and vegetable costs, which were down 1.1 percent. In March, total food prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Clothing and cleaning prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, reflecting earlier-than-usual store markdowns. In March, prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Housing Costs Slowing
 Increases in overall housing costs slowed to one-tenth of 1 percent last month from four-tenths of 1 percent in March, while transportation price increases slowed to five-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Energy prices rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent last month after climbing six-tenths of 1 percent in March.
New-car prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent following a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in March, leaving them 2.3 percent above their level a year earlier.
Medical care cost increases, which nearly always exceed gains in other areas, moderated slightly, rising five-tenths of 1 percent in April and in March after heftier gains earlier this year. Since April 1991, medical care costs have soared 7.9 percent.
The over all index stood at 139.5 over its 1982-84 base, meaning a basket of consumer goods that on average cost $100 between 1982 and 1984 cost $139.50 last month.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Reichmann Troubles Roil Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 13

 BODY:
Canadians used to break down the wealthy into three categories: the rich, the superrich and the Reichmanns.
The Reichmann family business, Olympia & York Developments, is the world's largest real estate developer, having altered skylines throughout Canada as well as in New York and London. But in March it ran out of cash, and fear is rippling through many corners of the Canadian economy. 
 The commercial real estate market is paralyzed, the stock market has fallen and many companies are finding it hard to borrow cash. Some hospitals, schools and cultural institutions that the Reichmanns have showered with millions are wondering whether the largesse is now at an end.
The situation has looked so grave that the Bank of Canada, the nation's central bank, has been maneuvering behind the scenes to insure that Canada's banks, which have extended an estimated $3 billion (Canadian) to Olympia & York, can weather the crisis.
While Canadian bank regulators say that the banks could withstand an Olympia bankruptcy, the Bank of Canada has been pursuing an aggressive easing of short-term interest rates, even at the risk of igniting inflation, with the nation's benchmark Bank Rate now down to 6.78 percent.
The uncertainty over Olympia's fate "adds to the economic malaise and sense of gloom," said Tom Hutchinson, chief Canadian economist for MMS International, a financial information service in Toronto, adding, "It's one of the negative influences out there that are making consumers keep their wallets zipped and could delay the recovery substantially."
 
Destroying an Image
 Yet some analysts believe much of the potential impact may have already been discounted. "The Reichmanns might lose control of their company, but this need not necessarily have grave implications for the economy," said David J. Marshall, president of the North American Economist of Toronto, a financial information service. "What it could mean is that the positive image of Canada as the home of aggressive, well-managed family firms with good, solid financial structures -- this image is blown out of the water."
For its part, Olympia has been negotiating for the last few weeks with dozens of creditor banks, seeking more favorable terms, moratoriums on payments due and fresh money for completion of several projects. The banks have provided some short-term loans -- far less than the Reichmanns sought -- and have been cool thus far to the brothers' ideas, including an offer of a 20 percent stake in the family business in return for concessions. Some bankers wryly questioned what the attraction was of owning a fifth of a company whose debts exceeded, by some counts, its assets.
On Thursday, the Reichmanns face a deadline on First Canadian Place, their 72-story white marble skyscraper in the heart of Toronto's financial district. Olympia & York owes $17 million in interest, and was granted a grace period by its bondholders, who warned that if payment were not made this week, they might foreclose.
John Ing, president of Maison Placements Canada Inc., a local investment house, warns of "ripple effects" if Olympia's buildings, some of the most expensive real estate in North America, are seized by banks and bondholders and then sold into an already depressed market.
At the Toronto Stock Exchange, the "Reichmann factor" is also blamed for the depressed state of prices, which are nearly 20 percent below the record highs of August 1987, even as the New York Stock Exchange has been reaching highs.
 
Rattled Confidence
 Banks have been particularly hard hit, with investors in bank stocks worried about loans to Olympia. Indeed, before the markets recovered Monday, fears of bank losses had wiped $7 billion from the value of the banks' stocks. That is more than twice the generally accepted estimate of their total loans to Olympia and provides evidence, analysts said, of the extent of rattled confidence.
Over the last two months, the market has clipped nearly $800 million from the common stock value of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the country's second-largest bank. The bank is believed to have Olympia loans with a value of $700 million to $1 billion.
The National Bank of Canada, the smallest of Canada's Big Six banks, with some $300 million to $500 million of Olympia loans, has seen its common stock value drop by more than $300 million.
Fears of how many dominoes will fall have increased difficulties for companies trying to raise money, especially in the market for commercial paper, where large companies trade i.o.u.'s for short-term cash.
"Commercial-paper investors are especially sensitive to credit quality these days," said Ihor Kots, managing director of the Canadian Bond Rating Service of Montreal. "The tone of the market is impacting those companies tending to see weakening profitability."
 
Some With Problems
 Among companies that have had trouble in the market or reduced their commercial-paper programs are the Trizec Corporation Ltd., a real estate company partly owned by the Reichmanns, with $11.9 billion of property in Canada and the United States, including the Hahn Company of San Diego, a builder of shopping malls. Besides the Reichmanns, the brothers Peter and Edward Bronfman own a controlling 40 percent block of Trizec.
Other companies that have had problems in the commercial-paper market include: Bramalea Ltd., a Toronto-based property company controlled by Trizec; Gulf Canada Resources of Calgary, Alberta, a leading oil company controlled by the Reichmanns, and Markborough Properties Inc., a Toronto-based property company unrelated to the Reichmanns.
Smaller businesses are complaining that the commercial banks, to offset possible losses on their loans to Olympia, are raising fees, tightening credit availability and making life harder for the little guy.
Catherine Swift, vice president of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, said, "I've got calls from members who said, 'This banker squeezed me for a thousand,' and yet, we hear about billions and tens of billions being loaned to O.&Y. without them even looking at their financial statements."
The Ontario provincial government and the federal Government in Ottawa seriously weighed stepping in with guarantees for Olympia but feared a political backlash. Neither could reconcile a special bailout of the wealthy family with recent budget calls for generalized belt-tightening.
Their decision against intervention was made somewhat easier by Michael Mackenzie, the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, who said that Canadian banks could survive a "meltdown" of Olympia. He defined meltdown as entering into the Canadian equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States.
While the situation is serious, Mr. Mackenzie said, it "would not inflict a mortal wound on any of the banks or institutions in our system."
A collapse of Olympia would probably shave a few more cents from the Canadian dollar, which is now trading around 83 cents (United States), down from near 90 cents late last year.
The Reichmanns have always been a close-knit family. Samuel, the patriarch, had a thriving poultry business in Hungary before World War II, and his three sons were born in Vienna. The brothers -- Albert, 62 years old; Paul, 60, and Ralph, 57 -- grew up speaking German, Hebrew and Hungarian. Their father chose the Austrian capital as a better point for central European distribution.
The family fled to Paris after the 1938 Anschluss and after time in Madrid and Tangier arrived in Toronto in the 1950's. Samuel died in 1975; his wife, Renee, died two years ago.
Under the sons' leadership, with Paul as the chief strategist, the family turned a Toronto tile-importing company into the vast Olympia & York empire with interests in real estate, oil, financial services and timber.
 
In Modest Circumstances
 Despite their great wealth -- it remains unclear how the family's personal fortune has been affected by Olympia's difficulties -- the brothers live in relatively modest circumstances in north central Toronto. It is a district of leafy, tranquil streets and comfortable homes and gardens, but is not one of Toronto's most exclusive or fashionable places to live.
The brothers, who are Orthodox Jews, picked the area because several synagogues are within walking distance.
The family generally keeps a low profile and has not been active in politics. But in philanthropy, it cuts a huge swath.
"The Reichmanns are not the sort of people who boast about their charitable works," said Michael de Pencier, president of the Key Publishers Company, which publishes Toronto Life magazine. "But they have quietly contributed enormous amounts of money to our society -- many, many millions in recent years."
Among them, he said, were $3 million to Sunnybrook Hospital, $2 million to the University of Toronto and more than $1 million to the Sick Children's Hospital.
 
End of Charity?
 But contributions may be drying up. The Toronto Jewish News reported last week, for example, that Kolel Avreichim, or the Institute for Talmudic Study, is no longer receiving Reichmann donations. The newspaper said a charitable trust of Olympia had provided most of the school's $1.1 million annual operating budget.
The brothers, their wives and other family members sit on the boards of the Reichmann enterprises, which currently have no outside directors and no requirement to open their books -- except to negotiate with their creditors.
A younger generation of Reichmanns is being groomed. The heir apparent is Philip Reichmann, eldest of the brothers' 14 children and the son of Albert. Philip is senior vice president and is in charge of retail leasing at First Canadian Place. He has also worked on the retail operation of the Reichmanns' World Financial Center in Manhattan.
Among those expected to share responsibilities with him are Frank Hauer, who is married to Paul Reichmann's daughter, Rachel. He is senior vice president, property administration, at Olympia and has been working on the company's huge office project in the London docklands, Canary Wharf. Philip Reichmann and Mr. Hauer are in their early 30's.

HEADLINE: With Eye on Riots, Dinkins Announces Loan Plan for Poor Areas

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Spurred by the upheaval in Los Angeles, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a new program yesterday to provide loans and subsidies for the creation of businesses in poor sections of the city.
Although the Neighborhood Retail Development Program was planned well before the outburst of fury after the Rodney G. King verdict, Mr. Dinkins said in a written statement yesterday that "In the wake of the tragedies in Los Angeles, we realize more than ever how acute the need is for the city not only to build housing and not only to build retail strips, but to help build neighborhoods." 
 The program will be tested in three Brooklyn communities -- along Broadway in Bushwick, Rockaway Avenue in Brownsville and Mermaid Avenue in Coney Island.
The program was designed by the city's Economic Development Corporation. The corporation's president, Carl Weisbrod, said that from Monday the city would begin seeking proposals from developers who want to create commercial strips on city-owned property in the target areas.
At the same time, the city is setting aside $7.5 million in construction subsidies and Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banks are making construction loans available at the usual commercial rates.
Permanent financing for the construction loans will be provided by the Community Preservation Corporation, a private consortium of banks. The permanent loans will be guaranteed by the State of New York Mortgage Agency. Because the loans will be guaranteed by the state, they will be bought by the city employees pension funds.
Herbert Eisenberg, the district manager of Community Planning Board 13 in Coney Island, welcomed the program. "We have been trying for many years to get commercial development," he said. "The dollars are here. The spenders are here, and they have to go outside the community to go shopping."
In Brownsville, Jeannette Gadson, district manager for Community Board 16, said: "I am just ecstatic about this, because families need shopping and they need recreation and infrastructure. This new program at least addresses part of that in terms of retail stores."

HEADLINE: Mandela Presses Dinkins Not to Lift City Sanctions

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A mayoral delegation returned from South Africa yesterday with a letter from Nelson Mandela urging Mayor David N. Dinkins not to lift New York's City's economic sanctions until an interim government is established in South Africa, associates of Mr. Mandela and city officials said yesterday.
The letter is critically important to Mr. Dinkins's decision because the Mayor, who has been under increasing pressure from big business and banks in New York to move quickly on the sanctions, has steadfastly maintained he would take his cue from Mr. Mandela, the African National Congress president. Mr. Dinkins was to meet with the delegation last night and will make an announcement this afternoon about the city's policy, aides said. 
 City officials said Mr. Dinkins was expected to map out what sanctions the city would lift in response to specific reforms in South Africa if an interim government that includes blacks and other minorities is established there. The Mayor, who has been reviewing the city's sanctions against companies doing business in South Africa, has said he favors keeping some sanctions that affect the South African military. His aides would not discuss details yesterday.
City officials said the Mayor's announcement was timed for the day before the opening of the second round of talks today among South Africa's 19 political parties -- the Convention on a Democratic South Africa -- that many United States and South African officials believe will produce an agreement on a government. Mr. Mandela and other A.N.C. officials want the Mayor's promise to lift sanctions to use as a bargaining chip in the talks.
 
New York 'Is Crucial'
 "I think Mr. Mandela knows New York City is crucial in this," said a high-ranking mayoral aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
New York has the toughest anti-apartheid sanctions in the country; its decision to lift sanctions would send a strong message to other municipalities with similar laws, especially because it would carry the imprimatur of Mr. Mandela, according to State Department officials and anti-apartheid advocates.
"New York City's sanctions are meaningful because there are major corporations that find them inconvenient," a State Department official said. "The A.N.C. would be giving a signal" to the entire United States.
Though the city can bring to bear direct pressure on companies with contracts, it has greater influence with other states and municipalities, said William Moses, an analyst with the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington. Other large cities like Los Angeles, Boston and Chicago, as well as states like Massachussets and California, will watch New York carefully, he said.
Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, who led the delegation, refused to speak to reporters about the trip last night. Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's chief spokesman, also declined to comment on what steps the Mayor would outline today. "Nothing has been decided as of yet," he insisted.
 
Mandela Will Send Signal
 In talks with Mr. Mandela, the city delegation sought to find out whether New York should lift sanctions when an agreement on an interim government is announced, which could happen this weekend, or whether it should hold off until the government is established, which could happen this summer, city officials and associates of Mr. Mandela said.
Mr. Mandela responded that Mr. Dinkins should wait for his signal, the officials said.
On Sunday night Mr. Lynch and three other mayoral aides quietly left New York and flew to Johannesburg to discuss with A.N.C. officials the best time to lift the sanctions. The trip was not announced and no reporters were invited, partly because it involved negotiations that could affect the city's investments. Besides Mr. Lynch, the delegation included Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain, Corporation Counsel O. Peter Sherwood, and David Scott, a Board of Education staff member.
The group met with Mr. Mandela and Walter Sisulu, the A.N.C. deputy president, at the Congress's headquarters in Johannesburg on Monday and Tuesday.
Under a 1990 local law, the city is prohibited from contracting with companies or banks with business ties to South Africa. The city also ranks banks according to how much they have done to encourage the end of the apartheid system of racial segregation and gives its business to those with the highest ranking. In addition, the city has avoided investing the $43.1 billion in pension funds that it controls in companies that do business in South Africa.
Combined, the city's sanctions have considerable influence, especially with large banks seeking city business or companies like International Business Machines Corporation and 3-M Corporation that would like to bid on lucrative city contracts.
"The city's sanctions have had real bite," said Jennifer Davis, executive director of the Africa Fund, an anti-apartheid monitoring group. "The city's sanctions have been the most effective in the country, especially controls on banks."

HEADLINE: Gorbachev, in New York, Warns Yeltsin on Social Instability

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
The former Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, broke his silence about his Kremlin successors yesterday, saying the Russian Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin had "carried its reforms to the edge" and needed corrective steps to avoid a social "explosion."
Without mentioning Mr. Yeltsin by name, Mr. Gorbachev warned that greater social safeguards were needed at home to fight inflation and the plummeting standard of living if political instability is to be contained. 
 The former Soviet leader stressed that while he endorsed the "thrust" of the Yeltsin reforms, he felt obliged to criticize their "tactics" since the same reactionary forces that went after him in last August's coup were waiting once more in Moscow for social pressures to reach the breaking point.
"We have to make sure they do not raise their heads again," Mr. Gorbachev declared in an address to the Economic Club of New York.
"The government of Russia has carried its reforms to the edge," he said. "If it goes over the edge, there can be a certain explosion."
 
'Corrections' Needed
 He stressed that while he was rooting and working for the cause of Russia's success in reaching democracy and the free market, "I believe it is necessary to make corrections in order to support reform."
His words were the first in his showcase American fund-raising tour to reflect on the stewardship of President Yeltsin, his onetime political rival and critic. Mr. Yeltsin delivered Mr. Gorbachev from the hands of the coup plotters, then pressed him to resign last December as the Soviet Union collapsed into a loose commonwealth of gravely troubled independent republics.
Until this speech, Mr. Gorbachev had not talked of events in post-Communist Moscow as he made daily speeches and appearances across the United States in his campaign to raise funds for his new private Gorbachev Foundation based in Moscow and San Francisco.
In response to a question of whether he harbored ambitions to resume Kremlin power, Mr. Gorbachev told the club's luncheon gathering at the New York Hilton that he had no plans "to seek any kind of public or state office," but that he would remain in public life in his new role as head of a foundation devoted to political and economic progress in Russia and the world at large.
 
Lack of Detail
 The Gorbachev Foundation already is monitoring the affairs of the new Commonwealth of Independent States as part of its research interests, but there has been little serious speculation in Moscow about Mr. Gorbachev's ever returning to real power.
In some ways, his criticism and advice to the reform-minded Yeltsin Government echoed Mr. Gorbachev's incumbency. Then, his own numerous economic reform plans came to naught as he hesitated and retreated in the face of dire warnings of social upheaval from colleagues in the Communist establishment. The last two years of his power were marked by elaborate announcements promising free-market innovations, but then costly compromise in the final power struggle in the Kremlin between party reactionaries and reformers.
His luncheon criticism also was notable for the lack of detail in his prescriptions, beyond urging that salaries be increased to deal with Russian inflation and that social-welfare protections also be bolstered. The Yeltsin Government has pursued both causes to a degree, within an overall plan to contain government spending and prevent fresh inflationary spirals.
Mr. Gorbachev, who hired and dismissed a platoon of free-market Cabinet strategists in his final two years, offered a warning in his speech about allowing academic theoreticians the final say in Russia's journey toward the free market. This seemed a pointed criticism of the cadre of young free-market planners hired by Mr. Yeltsin.
 
Condemns Anti-Semitism
 "Let us see life as it is," Mr. Gorbachev said, calling for a willingness to readjust away from theory. "I think you know that better than I do," he declared, and the club's crowded luncheon of more than 3,000 corporate executives applauded loudly.
Last night, Mr. Gorbachev repeated his previous condemnation of anti-Semitism, in receiving the Benjamin Cardozo Democracy Award from Yeshiva University's School of Law. Mr. Gorbachev, whose foundation received an honorarium of $100,000 from university trustees for the brief address at the Pierre Hotel, said, "Anti-Semitism is one of the worst manifestations of national chauvinism."
He welcomed improving relations between Russia and Israel as a result of Moscow's liberalized emigration policy and he appealed to the American Jewish community for support for Russia.
Mr. Gorbachev spent much of his day on economic affairs, drawing rousing Wall Street cheers in the morning as he appeared on the rostrum at the New York Stock Exchange and surveyed the normal trading havoc below. In remarks to exchange members, Mr. Gorbachev pitched for fresh investment in Russia, particularly in the form of factories with new products for restless consumers.
In response to a question, Mr. Gorbachev said there was little grounds for fearing that China might become a new threat for Russia or other nations. "Hegel said, 'When someone is asleep, you shouldn't wake him up,' " he declared lightly. But then, after the audience's laughter died, he said the Chinese Government actually seemed to be moving toward responsible reforms and presented no cause for worry.
