HEADLINE: Seeking Limits to a Drug Monopoly

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Congress is trying -- once again -- to rein in the profits that some companies are making on "orphan drugs," pharmaceutical products aimed at diseases affecting relatively few patients.
Backers of an amendment to the Orphan Drug Law have proposed that once an orphan drug reaches $200 million in revenues, it would lose the special tax breaks and seven-year monopoly protection that the Government grants companies to produce specialized drugs presumed to have only a limited market. 
 The proposal for a $200 million revenue limit has focused the debate over how much of a head start on profits is necessary to induce a company to make an orphan drug. Biotechnology and other pharmaceutical companies are split over the amendment, which will come before the antitrust and monopolies subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee early next month.
Some companies, like Novo-Nordisk, a $1.6 billion international pharmaceuticals concern based in Denmark, want to compete with companies that have monopolies. They say that $200 million is more than a sufficient inducement.
Others, however, like Genentech, a California biotechnology company that is one of the leading makers of drugs classed as orphans, are fiercely defending the act as it stands, even though they once opposed it. Genentech has spent millions of dollars in lobbying and has warned that suffering patients will be prevented from getting certain drugs if the act is amended.
The White House, which pocket-vetoed a somewhat different effort in 1990 to open the orphan market to limited competition, is threatening to veto this amendment, too. The White House Council on Competitiveness says that this amendment, like the 1990 one, will not provide enough incentive for manufacturers, which will make the United States less competitive in world markets.
 
Charges of Abuse
 There is widespread agreement that the tax breaks and monopoly status that Congress granted to orphan drugs in 1983 have worked: about 60 orphan drugs have been developed for 74 illnesses.
Before the law was passed, few drugs had been available to treat the approximately 20 million people in the United States who suffer from some 5,000 rare diseases. "If it were not for the act," said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, who is one of the authors of the amendment, "many of these drugs would never have been manufactured."
But he, along with Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, one of the sponsors of a version of the amendment now before a House committee, have complained that some drug companies are abusing the protections. Various patient groups have raised similar complaints.
These critics contend that the companies are making inordinate profits by charging very high prices. And they say the companies are using the law to protect rare-disease drugs that also have large markets as treatments for other, more common illnesses. The original law placed no limits on the profits a company could make or on the price it could charge.
 
Support for the Amendment
 Some industry executives say the proposed limit is reasonable, even generous.
A $200 million limit would allow a drug to bring in about $25 million to $30 million in sales annually for seven years and rank among the world's 100 biggest sellers -- and still be entitled to the protections for orphan drugs, said Henry Penner, president of Novo-Nordisk of North America. The limit simply means that after a period of profitable monopoly, the normal rules of free competition would apply, he said.
His company is eager to enter the market for human growth hormone, a treatment for dwarfism that is currently has orphan-drug protection. Two companies, Eli Lilly and Genentech, now make the product by different methods. And it has brought in more than $580 million in sales, at a cost to patients of between $10,000 and $30,000 a year.
"Human growth hormone is not an orphan," Mr. Penner said. "There were five or six companies that wanted to develop this drug. You have to begin to question what kind of products really need the incentive under the act."
In fact, figures supplied to Congress by pharmaceutical companies show that $200 million in revenues more than cover all research costs for the top-selling orphan drugs. And Congressional committees have concluded that the same holds true for all of the orphan drugs now on the books.
 
'Like Wildcatting in Texas'
 Few, if any, companies are disputing those findings. But some are arguing that $200 million would not necessarily cover costs beyond research and development, and allow for a substantial profit as well.
And a profitable return on their total investments is what the companies are asking for, said Henri Termeer, the chief executive of Genzyme, the Massachusetts company that makes an orphan drug known as Ceredase.
"It's like wildcatting in Texas," he said. "If there was a cap on how much you could make, you wouldn't get people to drill all the dry holes they need to drill in order to come up with the few winners that carry the company."
If orphan-drug privileges expired at $200 million in revenues, Mr. Termeer said, his company would not have developed Ceredase to treat a metabolic disorder known as Gaucher's disease.
If a disease is costing society hundreds of millions of dollars, he argues, and a company creates a drug to solve the problem, why should the company's return be limited?
 
A Defense of Profits
 Some orphan drugs will still be developed if the amendment is passed, Mr. Termeer added, but others may not be. He said that the profits were not outrageous, because the costs of researching, developing and making the drugs are often so high.
Genentech's general counsel, John P. McLaughlin, offers another argument against the revenue cap. The industry needs the hope of potential blockbuster sales to cover costs and get investors interested in financing the drugs, he contends.
Both Genzyme and Genentech are fighting the amendment in Congress.
Representative Waxman said the rewards should not be so lavish: "The Orphan Drug Act was designed to provide modest incentives for research on drugs, with little or no prospect of profit, because the diseases they are designed to treat are so rare. Where there is a prospect of striking it rich, that alone ought to be an adequate incentive to do the research, and the Orphan Drug Act just isn't necessary."
 
Limits to Patents
 Traditional drugs that win patents are entitled to 17 years of patent protection, during which a company is not required to license a drug to anyone else. Since many years are typically eaten up by the patent process and regulatory approval, however, the typical time left for selling the drug without competition is about 10 years.
Some orphan drugs are patentable, but many others are not, if they are natural substances or chemicals already in existence.
Architects of the original law say that when they wrote it they realized that it was theoretically possible that companies would try "salami slicing" tactics -- using the orphan-drug protection while selling the same product for much broader uses. But since lawmakers were unprepared for the scale of abuses, they say, no protection was written into the legislation. In fact, only about a dozen companies are usually cited as serious abusers of the law.
Senator Metzenbaum and his allies offer evidence that the law has backfired. They say that 3 of the 100 top-selling drugs in America, and 2 of the 5 top-selling drugs made by biotechnology companies (the chief category of companies getting into the orphan drug business), are now classed as "orphans" -- getting special monopoly status at the same time they are earning big revenues.
But the economics are somewhat murky. While it is clear that research and development of drugs is costly, the actual amount of these costs is less certain. Senator Metzenbaum charges that some drug companies have given Congress misleading and highly inflated estimates of their research and development costs.
Genentech, for example, told Congress at a recent hearing that its research and development costs for human growth hormone were $320 million. But company executives testified in court several years ago that the actual research and development cost was only about $45 million.
Even if the cost of using venture capital was added to the earlier figure, it would not approach the amount now claimed by the company, say Congressional critics like Mr. Waxman.
Genzyme, maker of Ceredase, has told Congress that its research and development costs were about $50 million to $70 million. But the amount it reported in Securities and Exchange Commission filings is closer to $30 million.
 
Companies Cite Other Costs
 The companies do not deny the gaps. They say, however, that the larger figures include not only direct research costs but also the costs of buying out their business partners, as well as outlays for advertising and marketing.
The buyouts may legitimately be considered part of the cost of research, they say, because the investors -- which in many cases are shell corporations run by the same executives and use the same researchers -- supplied them money used partly for research, along with marketing and other expenses.
But Daniel G. Bergstein, a venture capital lawyer at Paul Hastings, Janofsky & Walker in New York, said such financing approaches went beyond normal accounting practices. "If you say it fast, it might play," he said. "But it really is disingenuous. They are actually counting both their R. & D. costs and other costs such as buying out their partners."
The Senate subcommittee is expected to adopt the amendment in early June. But the opponents are likely to bring their arguments to the floor in the House and Senate -- and then to rely on the White House, once again, to stand up for their cause.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rose 0.9% In April

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Retail sales climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, essentially offsetting a March decline that was bigger than first thought, Commerce Department figures showed today.
The report unsettled some economists who saw it as a sign that the budding recovery might have begun to wilt, but it reassured others that sales climbed, albeit from a lower starting point. 
 Two other reports today had a similar split effect on analysts. The Labor Department report on the Consumer Price Index proved more reassuring than not, as it showed that prices rose just two-tenths of 1 percent last month, confirming the belief that inflation remains subdued. But auto makers said sales in the first 10 days of May were down three-tenths of 1 percent, a performance seen as disappointing. [Page D2.]
Taken together, the reports seemed to various analysts to be likely to nudge the Federal Reserve closer to another cut in interest rates.
 
Fed to Meet Next Week
 The Fed on Friday is to issue its monthly report on industrial production and rate of operation, followed on Tuesday by a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, its main policy-making body. Some analysts believe the Fed will wait until its meeting to act.
Since consumer prices are a lagging indicator -- one that generally moves after the economy at large -- much of the attention today went to retail sales, a current gauge that accounts for one-third of the nation's economic activity.
Although the nine-tenths of 1 percent April rise was more than expected, this was only because of a sizable downward revision for March that turned what had been a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent to a decline of a full 1 percent.
Among those disappointed by the sales numbers was Campbell Harvey, an associate professor of finance at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business. "We're not seeing the strength in the consumer sector that we saw at the beginning of the year," Professor Harvey said.
 
Expected Easter Effect
 With the benefit of favorable timing for Easter, sales should have been significantly better even allowing for the negative effects on shopping of the Chicago floods, he asserted.
At least a modest further easing by the Fed is imminent, he predicted.
The Commerce Department makes allowances, not always accurately, for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences in retail sales but does not do so for price changes.
Alan C. Lerner, a top economist at the Bankers Trust Company, took a more optimistic view of the sales figures. "They show the consumer is still moving along in a positive way," he said, adding that he believed the Fed would probably back away from further easing until the employment report due in early June.
To Norman Robertson of Pittsburgh's Mellon Bank, the sales results were so-so, reflecting a consumer sector still burdened by debt and concerned about jobs. "It's just about holding its own," Mr. Robertson said, citing a group of retail categories in which spending is mostly discretionary and that shows declines for both March and April following strong gains for the first two months of the year.
He said today's reports did little to change the odds of Fed action, which he said remained 50-50 for a cut during the next month.
Sales grew last month to $158 billion, with durable goods advancing 1.9 percent and nondurables three-tenths of 1 percent.
Automotive dealers enjoyed a 2.6 percent gain and merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes did even better, posting a 2.8 percent gain. But the other major durables category -- furniture, home furnishings and equipment -- suffered a 1.5 percent decline, roughly wiping out their March increase and a possible first sign of weakness in housing-related goods.
Without the automotive group, total retail sales rose just four-tenths of 1 percent. Auto sales themselves, analysts at C. J. Lawrence noted, have been much weaker in number of units than in dollar terms. The report from auto makers today on their early May sales showed a generally sluggish industry, but one automotive analyst did see a bright spot in the fact that American car companies were getting a bigger market share.
The automotive sector also accounted for most of the downward revision for retail sales in March.
Among nondurables, four of the main categories posted increases, while two fell. Sales rose 1.6 percent at apparel and accessory stores; eight-tenths of 1 percent at gasoline service stations, mainly because of higher prices; seven-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores, and five-tenths of 1 percent at food stores.
Restaurants and bars saw business fall off another 1 percent while stores selling general merchandise had a four-tenths of a percent sales decline.
Over all, said Kathleen Stephansen and Jade Kim of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, retail sales last month were only eight-tenths of 1 percent higher than than the first-quarter average. They saw this as "a somewhat disappointing performance," especially when adjusted for inflation.

HEADLINE: Trade Talks With Chile Are Planned

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it would seek to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Chile after a free trade pact with Mexico and Canada is completed.
American officials say that establishing a bilateral free-trade pact with Chile could be the first step toward setting up a free-trade bloc with all of South America. 
 Administration officials hope the agreements with Mexico and Canada will be ratified by Congress and signed by the three nations sometime this year.
Chilean officials said they were hoping that Washington would agree to begin negotiating such a pact immediately, but American officials said they were worried that beginning negotiations with Chile could complicate the efforts to establish the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico.
 
Less Likely to Worry Congress
 Congressional staff members said they doubted, however, that a free-trade pact with Chile would worry Congress the way talks with Mexico have. They said that because Chile is so much further away than Mexico, it does not raise the same intense fears that companies will close American factories and transfer those operations to Mexico.
After President Bush met today with Chile's President, Patricio Aylwin, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson said, "Both governments want to pursue free-trade negotiations as quickly as that is feasible."
 
Protecting Foreign Investments
 American officials say Chile has been singled out for a free-trade deal because it has already lowered tariffs and enacted laws protecting foreign investments, making it easier to negotiate a trade pact with it than with almost all other Latin American nations.
One Administration official said, "The question is when, not whether, an agreement will be negotiated with Chile."
At a ceremony on the White House South Lawn, President Bush said, "Today Chile gives hope to an entire hemisphere. With market-oriented reforms, you've led by example."
Mr. Aronson praised Chile, noting that since 1985 it had averaged growth of 6 percent a year and that its jobless rate has fallen to 4.8 percent, its lowest level in 17 years.
"We are engaged in consolidating our reborn democracy," President Aylwin said. "We are not asking for help but for understanding and cooperation."
Last year the United States raised its exports to Chile to $1.58 billion, which included such products as computers, mining machinery and telecommunications equipment. Chile's exports to the United States, principally fruit, copper and fish, came to $1.3 billion last year.
The White House said it would seek to negotiate the free-trade agreement with Chile on a fast-track basis.
The Administration has to notify Congress officially before starting such negotiations, and Congress has 60 days to veto it before talks begin.

HEADLINE: Republicans Pressed on Plans for Cuts

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 13

 BODY:
With only five days left for Gov. Jim Florio to sign or veto a sales-tax rollback, the Republicans had promised to explain today their goals for the next fiscal year and how they would deal with a growing state budget gap.
Instead, after using two meetings to blast away at Mr. Florio, calling him the "Harry Houdini of state government," Republican leaders found themselves jousting with reporters about when they would offer specific fiscal plans. 
 "Not every New Jerseyan woke up today wondering if this would be the day for Republican cuts," the party's state committee chairman, Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, said at a news conference rife with testy exchanges. "You have to be patient. You are going to hear the other shoe, and it will be loud and resounding."
Mr. Franks said the Republicans would unveil their budget plan within a couple of weeks, though Mr. Florio has said he will not sign the rollback bill, which would lower the sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent, unless the Republicans first specify what cuts they intend to make to compensate for the $610 million in revenue it would cost.
 
Haunted by Promises
 The unusually harsh exchanges at the news conference point to the many pressures the Republicans are facing as they try to make good on campaign promises to roll back taxes, cut spending and reduce the size of government.
With Mr. Florio facing a Monday deadline for action on the rollback bill -- he is expected to veto it -- and with Republicans facing possible defections that would make an override impossible, the party's leaders tried to badger the Democratic Governor into siding with them.
"As a candidate for governor in 1989, Jim Florio said that our state did not have a revenue problem, it had a spending problem," Mr. Franks said. "Today, we ask the Governor to remember those words and join with us in supporting the Republican plan to address the spending problem, which, if left unresolved, will permanently disable our state. Sign the sales-tax cut today and work with us to bring spending under control now."
Campaigning on a promise to reduce taxes if they were elected, Republicans crushed Democratic candidates in last November's general election, winning a 58-to-22 majority in the Assembly and a 27-to-13 advantage in the Senate. Their two-thirds majorities in both houses gave them the power to override any veto by Mr. Florio and, in effect, to supplant many of his policy ideas.
After only four months in power, the Republicans are hearing a public clamor for action. But miscalculations, policy differences among their leaders and a freshman class of legislators who have proved to be unusually independent have so far neutralized the Republicans' advantage.
 
Avoiding Assessment
 They have staked much of their credibility on passing the sales-tax rollback, but Mr. Franks would not speak on the politics of the issue, only of the economic harm that he said would befall the state if the tax is not reduced.
"It would be a tragedy if we missed this opportunity," he said. "We would be missing a key opportunity for future growth."
Republican support for a veto override on the tax rollback seems solid in the Assembly, but party members have said that there may be as many as six holdouts in the Senate, where even one lost vote would mean defeat.
The Florio administration further complicated the Republicans' budget-cutting plans last week when the State Treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, announced a $342 million budget shortfall for this fiscal year and a $310 million shortfall for the one that begins July 1, which he blamed on lower income-tax revenue. Mr. Crane proposed steps to close the gap, many of which require the support of the Legislature.
The chairmen of the Legislature's Budget Committees, Senator Robert E. Littell and Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, issued written statements today that they described as responses to the revenue shortfall. But neither commented directly on the Democrats' proposals, and neither offered alternatives. Each simply blamed Mr. Florio for the shortfalls.
About two hours later, Mr. Franks joined the fray at his news conference. "Over the past two years, Governor Florio has become the Harry Houdini of state government," he said, "inventing one trick after another to disguise massive overspending. Two years and $5.6 billion in new taxes later, Governor Florio has yet to deliver a realistic fiscal blueprint for our state."
Mr. Florio did not respond, leaving that job to his Democratic colleagues. "Somebody really should figure out a way to tell the Republicans that the campaign is over," the Senate Democratic leader, John A. Lynch, said in a statement. "This insistence on rehashing campaign cliches won't do after voters gave them a mandate to govern."

HEADLINE: Campbell's Net Up 19.8% In 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 19.8 percent in the third quarter. But analysts said much of the gain came from cost-cutting, not real growth.
William Leach, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the quality of Campbell's earnings was far weaker than the reported gain indicated. "How they got there was not entirely satisfactory," he said. 
 Analysts said earnings improvement came from keeping down expenses and a lower tax rate. By cutting costs, Cambpell's has reported a string of strong quarterly results, but Mr. Leach said yesterday, "This probably marks the end of the 20 percent gains."
Third-quarter profits increased to $91.5 million, or 36 cents a share, from $76.4 million, or 30 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales rose 3 percent, to $1.54 billion, compared with $1.49 billion last year.
 
Full-Year Earnings Estimates
 Based on yesterday's results, Mr. Leach slightly reduced his full-year earnings estimates for Campbell's to $1.87 a share.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Campbell's shares slipped 75 cents yesterday, to $33.625.
The company said frozen food sales were down substantially for the quarter as a result of heavy price competition in the category. Earnings were also lower because of heavy marketing support behind the national introduction of LeMenu New American Cuisine dinners and the introduction of other new products in the Swanson line.
David W. Johnson, president and chief executive of Campbell, said, "This was a very good quarter considering the recession and generally drab competitive results." He said the company's soup business grew strongly in the United States, Canada and Britain. Soup volume in North America gained 11 percent, bolstered in part by the acquisition of Sanwa Foods.
"We continue to spend aggressively on both advertising and promotion to support a wide array of new product initiatives," Mr. Johnson said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Decline In Reverse of 3-Week Trend

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down in the latest week, with tax-exempt yields falling for the first time in a month.
In the week ended Monday, the yields on tax-exempt money funds were down after rising steadily the last three weeks. Analysts at Donoghue's said greater demand for fixed-income securities had lowered interest rates throughout the market, driving prices there higher and yields lower. 
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's, said the demand for tax-exempt securities could be seen in the flow of $1.2 billion into the funds, pushing total assets up to $94.8 billion.
The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell by 12 basis points, to 3.12 percent, while the simple yield dropped a like amount to 3.07 percent. In the same period, the lagging 30-day compounded average yield and simple yield, both increased by 7 basis points, to 3.08 percent and 3.04 percent, respectively. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios had increased by one, to 53.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 4.33 percent, while the equivalent for those in the 31 percent tax bracket is 4.52 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Calvert Tax-Free Reserves/Money Market Portfolio offered the best return, at 4.01 percent. The fund's distributor is the Calvert Group of Bethesda, Md.
 
Taxable Funds
 In tracking taxable money market funds for the week ended Tuesday, Donoghue's reported that assets were up $340 million, to $491.4 billion. As institutional assets grew by $2.3 billion, to $164.1 billion, retail assets declined by $2 billion. Analysts said the narrow yield spread between taxable funds and tax-exempt funds had favored the tax-exempts.
The average seven-day taxable compounded yield fell 5 basis points, to 3.57 percent, and the simple yield dropped 4 basis points, to 3.51 percent. For the 30-day compounded average, the yield was 3.63 percent, down 5 basis points, with the simple yield down a similar amount to 3.57 percent.
The Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series repeated as the best performer, with a return of 4.35 percent, down 3 basis points from its best yield last week. The fund is distributed by the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparsion, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of the money funds, stands at 3.46 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a broad decline yesterday as traders weighed whether the latest economic data would prompt the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates.
Gold prices were higher after falling in Asia. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $335.60 a troy ounce, up 30 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold added $1 an ounce to a late bid price of $335.60. 
 The United States currency initially strengthened on a better-than-expected report on retail sales. The Commerce Department said sales rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, but that followed a 1 percent decline in sales the previous month, more than double what had previously been reported.
Analysts said traders paid less attention to a separate report pointing to modest inflation. The Government said consumer prices rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Still, analysts said they believed the Fed would move soon to cut interest rates, a move that is bearish for the dollar. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston, said selling increased after reports that German union workers rejected a wage settlement.
"It raised the prospect of another rate hike there," he said, which would further hurt the dollar. The dollar fell in busy trading, closing at its lows for the session.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 130.30 yen, down 2.30 yen from Tuesday's finish. In London, the dollar closed at 130.40 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.60 yen, down from 130.55 yen on Tuesday. The dollar has not closed at these levels against the yen since early March.
In London, the British pound was unchanged at $1.8135. In New York it cost $1.8275 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.8135.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6090 German marks, down from 1.6230; 1.4795 Swiss francs, down form 1.5035; 5.4005 French francs, down from 5.4560; 1,210.75 Italian lire, down from 1,222.00, and 1.2040 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2060.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame L.B.J.

BYLINE: By Joseph A. Califano Jr.; Joseph A. Califano Jr., a lawyer, was President Lyndon B. Johnson's Special Assistant for Domestic Affairs.

 BODY:
Abraham Lincoln was President more than a century ago, and a Republican, so the Administration couldn't blame the Emancipation Proclamation for the riots in Los Angeles. Instead, the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, and President Bush laid much of the blame on Lyndon B. Johnson and his domestic programs.
Asked to identify which programs the Administration was talking about, Mr. Fitzwater snapped, "I don't have a list with me." Which could be on the Administration hit list? 
 Surely Head Start was not one. Mr. Bush has adopted that Great Society program as one of his favorites. Since the Administration claims a devotion to having people stand on their own two feet, we can assume it was not talking about training programs like the Job Corps, the Vocational Education Act or the college work-study program, which helps the less affluent work their way through college.
I doubt the man who aspires to be our Education President had in mind the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, which provides billions of dollars to schools with concentrations of poor children; the Higher Education Act, which provides loans and scholarships to those who have the brains and will, but not the wallets, to get into college, or the adult literacy program, which he has embraced.
Perhaps the Administration was talking about the Teachers Corps or Vista (Volunteers in Service to America). Those efforts were intended to get college graduates to volunteer (at $75 per month) to give the poor a hand up in education and work skills. They do sound like Gov. Bill Clinton's domestic peace corps; they also fit neatly into Mr. Bush's call for volunteerism.
Maybe Mr. Fitzwater had in mind the Voting Rights Act, which opened the polls to blacks (and later Hispanics) and helped elect thousands of local and county officials aross the South and a number of big-city mayors. These voters and officeholders are overwhelmingly Democrats.
Mr. Fitzwater's other targets may include the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned job discrimination against minorities and which the Administration has sought to gut and used to feed white resentment in a soft economy. Maybe he's aiming at the Fair Housing Act of 1968, which L.B.J. pressed Congress to pass as a constructive example of hope in the wake of the riots that followed the assassination of Martin Luther King.
It is unlikely Mr. Fitzwater was criticizing the National Housing Act of 1968. It created the National Housing Partnership to attract the private sector into building low- and moderate-income housing by making it profitable, privatized the Federal National Mortgage Association and offered the poor a home ownership program. That is down the center of the Reagan-Bush alley.
The Aid for Dependent Children program was a 30's idea, so Mr. Fitzwater couldn't have had it in mind. President Johnson, like Mr. Bush, criticized its damage to families. L.B.J. pressed Congress in vain to drop the rule that a jobless husband must leave the house so his wife and children could get benefits.
Could Mr. Fitzwater have been talking about L.B.J.'s economic policies? When President Johnson got Congress to cut taxes in 1964, he didn't serve most benefits up to the rich so they could eventually trickle down to the rest of America. He kept the tax fully graduated. He used revenues from the expanding economy to increase minimum Social Security benefits and finance Medicare (thus lifting millions out of poverty) and to finance education, job training, Medicaid and other health programs that helped halve the number of Americans living in poverty. The last 12 years have seen that proportion double.
What seems most likely is that the Administration didn't know what it was talking about -- historically, ideologically or economically. L.B.J. left plenty of mistakes to learn from and successes to build on. Can't we start learning and building?

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: Pay of College Graduates Is Outpaced by Inflation

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Two labor economists reported yesterday that the pay of most college-educated people -- once thought to be exempt from the wage stagnation that has afflicted Americans for more than 15 years -- had failed since 1989 to keep up with inflation.
The findings, published by the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research organization that often supports Democratic candidates, suggest that as many high-paying jobs vanish from the workplace, a bachelor of arts degree is becoming less of a ticket to a rising income -- a conclusion that other economists said was probably accurate. 
 "Unless we create more jobs, the college-educated are going to crowd out the people below them," said Janet L. Norwood, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute and until recently the Commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The college-educated can at least go down, but the people below them have nowhere to go."
The study, by Lawrence Mishel, research director at the Economic Policy Institute, and Jared Bernstein, an economist there, found that among the college-educated, average pay continued to rise at a faster pace than inflation in the last three years only for black women with bachelor of arts degrees and all men and women with at least two years of postgraduate study.
"Black women, educated and uneducated, are becoming the prime wage earners in black America," Mr. Mishel said.
But for most Americans, a marked slowdown in the national economy, starting in early 1989, has pulled down wages. This is true not only for high-school-educated factory and clerical workers, whose pay, adjusted for inflation, continues to shrink, but also now for the educated. Indeed, the gap between high school and college graduates, which averaged $5.40 an hour in 1973, was $5.97 an hour in 1991, with the college-educated employee averaging $16.69 an hour, after adjustment for inflation, and the high school-trained worker $10.72. That makes a college degree still an advantage, although a diminishing one. The degree commanded $17.55 an hour in the late 1980's.
Many reasons are offered by economists and sociologists for the newly evident decline in the pay of the college-educated. Prominent among them are the white-collar layoffs in recent years in banking, on Wall Street, in real estate and retailing, and among middle-level managers in many industries as companies adjust to a weak economy, falling sales and hard-to-get price increases.
The Bush Administration argues that recent wage problems are a result of the recession that may now be giving way to a mild recovery. But most economists argue that if the recovery remains so mild that it keeps the economy as weak as it was in 1989 and 1990, before the recession set in, then the wages of the college-educated are likely to continue to suffer.
"You need economic growth far stronger than it has been in recent years to reverse the trend in declining wages," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard University labor economist.
Until 1989, the average hourly earnings of people with a four-year college education had risen over a 10-year period by a total of 2 percent, after adjustment for inflation. Over the next three years, 1.6 percent of this gain was lost, the study found -- a loss that Mr. Mishel and Mr. Bernstein attributed in part to white-collar layoffs and to raises that were less than the average annual rise of 4.6 percent in the Consumer Price Index since 1989.
"If you look around Government, where college-educated people are employed in huge numbers, explosive pay raises during the 1980's have tailed off in recent years," said Thomas Plewes, Associate Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
All Wages Fell
 Commenting on the findings, Frank Levy, a labor economist at the University of Maryland, said, "The new trend is striking not so much because the college-educated gained so much ground in the 1980's, but because the bottom fell out of wages for the less educated."
Whatever the reasons, the reversal for the college-educated, combined with a continued fall in inflation-adjusted incomes for people with only a high school diploma, or less, means that average hourly wages for all the nation's workers fell by nearly a percentage point from 1989 through 1991, on top of a 2.7 percent loss for the 1979-89 period, the study found.
Mr. Mishel and Mr. Bernstein are among the first to analyze recently released Bureau of Labor Statistics data covering income trends through 1991, a recession year. Among other things, they broke down wage and benefit data into hourly compensation rather than weekly or annual earnings, to filter out income from extra hours worked and to pin down what Alan B. Krueger, a Princeton labor economist, calls the cost of a unit of labor.
Their findings also contradicted another widely held perception: that employer-paid health and pension insurance had continued to rise in the late 1980's, after adjustment for inflation. While these outlays did go up during the decade, they were roughly the same on average at the end of 1991 as they were in 1987, the study found.
"The general wisdom has been that medical and pension costs are going up faster than wages are falling," Mrs. Norwood said. "But it is hard to break out insurance categories, as this study tries to do, because employers list insurance costs together."
 
Latest Documentation
 Bill Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential candidate, has publicly cited studies illustrating the gap that has developed between the incomes of the wealthiest Americans and those of the rest of the population. The Economic Policy Institute's findings are the latest to document the wage stagnation for people below the highest incomes.
A Census Bureau study, released earlier this week, reported that the percentage of full-time workers earning less than a low-income $12,195 annually, or $6.10 an hour for a 40-hour week, had risen sharply in the last decade. Other studies show that thousands of entry-level jobs for new college graduates evaporated during the recession that began in July 1990.
From World War II until the early 1970's, the incomes of most Americans, whether they were janitors or executives, rose faster than the annual inflation rate. As a result, the constantly rising standard of living generated a sense of national well-being that began to dissipate by the 1980's -- except for the 20 percent of the population at the high end of the income scale, who escaped the stagnation, and in particular the wealthiest 1 percent. College graduates are prominent among the top 20 percent.
An upturn in inflation-adjusted income that appeared to be developing in the mid-1980's failed to materialize, and by early 1989, when the nation's economic growth slowed to 2 percent a year or less, incomes had stagnated again, although college graduates had appeared to be exempt. The upshot is that median hourly wages, adjusted for inflation, for all workers, whatever their education, fell from $11.12 an hour in 1989 to $10.99 an hour last year.
The wage problem for the college-educated coincides with the onset, in early 1989, of a slowdown in the growth of the nation's economy, or gross domestic product, to an annual rate of 2 percent or less, from 2.5 percent or more since 1983. That raised the issue of whether a mild recovery now projected by the Bush Administration and most economists -- one in which the economy grows at an annual rate of 2 percent to 2.5 percent this year -- would be enough to generate new jobs. "It is not clear that people will feel better off if the economy turns up a bit," Mr. Levy said. "People are catching on that beneath the ups and downs in the economy, wages have remained flat."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Education and Earning Power" shows change in average hourly wages by education, adjusted for inflation, in percent for periods from 1979-1989 and 1989-1991. (Source: Economic Policy Institute, based on Bureau of Labor Statistics figures.) (pg. B12)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Communists in Laos Steer Economy By Capitalist Lights, Not the Red Star

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENTIANE, Laos

 BODY:
"Socialism remains the goal," said the former official, one of the old guard of Laotian Communism who began the struggle against France in the 1940's and continued it from mountain caves in the north and during the heavy United States bombardment until they took over this country in 1975.
"When will Laos be socialist?" he asked with a shrug. "It may take 20 years, 50 years, maybe 100. I don't know." 
 The former official, the companion at arms of President Kaysone Phomvihan, insisted that his name not be used because the interview at his home had not been officially arranged. Laos still strictly regulates the activities of the rare visiting correspondent.
For the time being this small country, one of the world's least developed, has done away with the outward trappings of Communism and opened its economy to investment and trade by Laotians and foreigners. Last year it removed the word "socialism" from its national motto and replaced it with "prosperity."
On the national emblem, the hammer and sickle was removed, then the five-pointed Communist star; finally both were replaced by a revered Buddhist shrine. "Showing the hammer and sickle today is illegal," says the Deputy Foreign Minister, Soubanh Srithirath.
 
Economy Settles Down
 The openness to new investment has helped reduce inflation from 76 percent in 1989 to 10 percent last year, to stabilize the currency, and to increase annual growth in the gross national product to 4 percent last year despite a severe drought and the total loss of assistance from the Soviet Union and its former allies.
But Mr. Soubanh Srithirath, who is regarded as one of the most open-minded of the younger leaders, still adamantly defends the maintenance of a one-party state, as did the aged revolutionary and all officials questioned during a 10-day visit. All did so in almost identical phrases, indicating that heavy-handed indoctrination continues, even of top officials.
Khamsay Souphanouvong, who is the Acting Minister of the Economy, Planning and Finance, is a son of Prince Souphanouvong and a founder of the Communist Party. He defended the ban on opposition parties.
"The people know the ability of our party to lead them," he said in an interview. "They see who represents their interests. It is not we who impose ourselves on the people. They impose leadership on us and want no other party."
The paradox of a country that has reverted to capitalism while maintaining a rigorously Communist state was recently illustrated in a fashionable French restaurant here.
Mr. Khamsay Souphanouvong's cousin, Prince Panya Souvanna Phouma, was eating lunch with friends. The Prince, an international businessman and son of Souvanna Phouma, the American-backed Prime Minister who led the struggle against the Communists, was in town to look after his investment in tourism.
 
Little Tolerance for Pluralism
 In contrast, three officials who late in 1990 advanced the idea of broadening the nation's politics and who condemned the corruption that has been a product of free enterprise, have been held without trial since. The three, who are being detained in a remote and primitive mountain province, Houaphan, are the former Deputy Minister of Science and Technology, Thongsouk Saisangkhi; the former Deputy Agriculture Minister, Latsami Khamphoui, and Feng Sakchitthaphong, a senior Justice Ministry official.
Western diplomats said aid-giving countries had regularly pressed the Government on the detentions but had not made assistance conditional on the men's release.
Eight officials and military officers of the pre-1975 Government also remain in exile, without their families, in Houaphan; they are the last of thousands who were transported there for harsh "re-education" in 1975.
"Re-education was necessary for security and national defense," said the former revolutionary leader, who met privately with a reporter. "But we did one thing wrong -- we kept people there too long."
He contended that only Laotians who had fled the country were urging creation of opposition parties and "so-called human rights."
"They do it to disturb our Government and our security," added the ex-revolutionary, who still occupies an important public post.
The Constitution that Laos adopted last August, after 16 years without one, enshrines the leading role of the Communist Party in Article 3, and in Article 5 places Parliament and "all organs of state" under the "principle of democratic centralism." This is a Leninist doctrine that bans opposition to leadership decisions. Both provisions remain targets of dissidents struggling against Communist rule.
 
A Thousand Shops Bloom
 However tight the political fetters, Laotians in Vientiane and the few other major towns, all along the Mekong River, are living in an economic environment that recalls the pre-Communist days. In the markets and along the main streets, small shops of all kinds thrive. Soup and fruit vendors line streets. Consumer electronics goods fill rows of shops in the Central Market in Vientiane, which was built with American aid when the United States underwrote most of the economy.
But most consumer goods, even food, are imported from Thailand. The road system of Laos is so poor that Thai towns on the opposite bank of the Mekong supply Laotian needs more efficiently than could cumbersome transport within this country. A senior international economic official estimated the Thai share of the consumer market at 80 to 90 percent. In addition to controlling most trade, Thai investors are the most active in accepting the open invitation to foreign capital.
The Deputy Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, Bountiem Phitsamay, said investment committed so far amounted to more than $300 million in 180 authorized projects, most backed by Thais. He and Mr. Khamsay Souphanouvong, at the Economics Ministry, said there was no reason to worry that Thai influence might become overbearing, and there is no ceiling on the share of total investment by one country.
Such confidence is not shared by all Laotians, particularly because Thailand holds the key to access to this landlocked country. Vietnam has not lived up to hopes that its ports might reduce Laotian dependence on Thailand for transit.
But after years of fluctuating tension, Thai-Laotian relations have grown warm, and Bangkok has pleased its smaller neighbor by reducing transit and customs rates.
The bustling economic life of the towns tends to make many foreigners forget that a large share of the population of perhaps four million still lives on a subsistence economy and is barely included in a modern economic process.
A visit to remote Houaphan and Xiengkhouang provinces showed very few manufactured or Thai goods in the local markets. The former revolutionary said that those living largely from the products of their own toil make up about two-thirds of the population.
 
Capitalism? 'No Comment'
 He said that the transformation of a subsistence economy had proved impossible under the all-out socialism, collectivization and state management of everything that was introduced in 1975, and that the leadership had thus been forced to return to earlier methods.
"Some people say Laos returned to capitalism," he said. "Is it true? I make no comment."
Whatever the present system is called, international economic officials and diplomats give the Government high marks for its realism in adopting non-Communist economics. "In most of the world we need to cajole and threaten," an official of a lending organization told a diplomat. "Here they can't get enough of our advice."
But despite the great economic freedom, when an adviser sent by the French Treasury drafted a decree late in April stipulating the qualifications for certain accounts, it was returned to her with a reminder that she had "forgotten" to include Communist Party membership among the requirements.

HEADLINE: Cease-Fire Brings Bit of Calm but No Confidence to Sarajevo

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 13

 BODY:
A tentative calm settled today over Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, after Serbian leaders who have pressed a military offensive across the republic responded to Western diplomatic pressure by announcing a five-day cease-fire.
The artillery, mortar and rocket fire that has rattled Sarajevo for much of the last month was mostly stilled after the cease-fire went into effect at 6 A.M. The calm was broken only sporadically thereafter by gunfire from Serbian positions in the hills above the city. 
 Reporters in Sarajevo said that residents emerged from their houses for the first time in days, with some pausing to sip coffee at sidewalk cafes or to buy chocolate and other snacks from street vendors. Although truce violations were reported in other contested towns and villages around the republic, the violence appeared to be at its lowest level in 10 days.
But in Sarajevo, which has seen a succession of cease-fires disintegrate rapidly, there was little confidence that an end had come to two months of fighting has taken at least 1,300 lives and left as many as 700,000 people homeless.
There were reports from Sarajevo of widespread dismay over the United Nations' decision to withdraw about 200 of the 300 representatives it has in the city. The move, announced in New York, deepened the sense of isolation stirred by the evacuation on Tuesday of the last members of the European Community's military observer team. The International Committee of the Red Cross has considered withdrawing as well, but said it would remain for the time being.
 
Sign of Action by Belgrade
 Although the United Nations pullback seems likely to reduce the already slim influence that its representatives have on the warring sides, diplomats in Belgrade said that they were encouraged by signs that the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Government isfinally responding to demands that it seek to restrain the Serbs in Bosnia.
The self-proclaimed parliament of the Bosnian Serbs approved the unilateral cease-fire at a meeting in the northern town of Banja Luka on Tuesday, less than 24 hours after Western governments took their first serious step to punish the Belgrade Government for what they view as a Serbian bid to dismember Bosnia.
The 12 nations of the European Community announced on Monday that they were withdrawing their ambassadors from Belgrade, a move followed on Tuesday by the announcement that the United States Ambassador, Warren Zimmermann, would also depart. With a simultaneous decision by the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to bar Belgrade's representative from its deliberations on Yugoslav problems, the pullback of the ambassadors suggests that Western nations are moving from talk to action to constrain the Serbs.
There appears to be no collective resolve to move to the tougher option of economic sanctions, but the reaction of the Belgrade Government suggested that it recognized the dangers. The Yugoslav Government denounced the diplomatic reprisals as "one-sided," but added that it was being punished for the actions of Bosnian Serbs over whom it had no control.
"They are masters of their own fate," Belgrade's Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, told reporters. "Even if we want to influence them, we cannot do it."
But signs have been accumulating for months that Radovan Karadzic, the hard-line leader of the Serbian Democratic Party, the political arm of the Bosnian Serbian militias, closely co-ordinates his actions with Belgrade.
For example, Mr. Karadzic and his associates also announced that they were creating an army for Bosnian Serbs. They said the new force would absorb Yugoslav Army soldiers who remain in Bosnia after the army completes a planned "withdrawal" on May 19.
Since Belgrade contends that 80 percent of the Yugoslav Army troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina are Bosnian Serbs, the announcement means that a force of at least 30,000 men with tanks, artillery, multiple-rocket launchers and large stocks of ammunition will make a nominal change of colors and continue fighting for the Serbian cause.
The Bosnian Serbs said the cease-fire was conditioned on the resumption of the European Community's talks on the future of Bosnia. The community suspended those talks on May 2.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Riding past burned-out wreckage from last week's fighting, a resident of Sarajevo took advantage of the relative calm brought by a new cease-fire. Reacting to Western pressure, the Serbian-led Government called for a five-day cease-fire in war-ravaged Bosnia and Herzegovina. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Europe Proposes Taxes on Fuels Tied to Warming

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 13

 BODY:
Sharpening its differences with the United States on environmental policies, the European Community proposed today that a high energy tax be imposed on all forms of fuel to limit pollution and global warming.
The proposal, which is one of the community's most ambitious fiscal and environmental moves so far, appears to be intended as the calling card the 12-nation group will present at the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro next month. 
 So far, the step takes the form of a recommendation by the community's Brussels-based executive commission and will require approval by the 12 community member nations as well as the European Parliament before it becomes law.
But, suggesting that the proposal may also be used as a bargaining position at the Earth Summit, the commission proposed that the new tax only be adopted if Western Europe's major trading partners -- the United States and Japan -- adopt a similar measure.
Under the proposal, European governments would levy a tax on fossil fuels -- coal, oil and gas -- and all other forms of energy except that produced by sun, waves or wind. It would be introduced in 1993 at the rate of $3 per barrel of oil, or its equivalent in other fuels, with the tax rising by $1 per year to reach $10 in the year 2000.
By driving up fuel costs, the plan aims to force users to become more efficient and save energy, one of the main objectives of the current European rethinking of its economic and industrial policies. Community studies argue that with existing technology, energy efficiency can be increased at little extra cost by 25 percent. The proposed taxes will be highest for the dirtiest form of energy, coal, followed by oil. Taxes on natural gas would be the lowest and biomass fuel would be exempted.
The proposal, which has been studied and debated for more than two years, forms the basis of the community's strategy to slow pollution and global warming. The group has committed itself to keeping emissions of gases tied to global warming at 1990 levels. The United States has balked at setting such targets, which has caused a longstanding deadlock between American and European negotiators preparing a treaty to slow global warming.
If the European Community takes no measures, experts say that its emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, would be 12 percent higher by the year 2000. It hopes to achieve half of the needed cutback through the proposed "energy taxes" and the rest through other measures. The community is responsible for 13 percent of of global carbon dioxide emissions.
But the plan, formally announced in Strasbourg today, was unlikely to satisfy everyone. There has been bitter opposition from industrialists who assert that such additional taxes will hamper their competitiveness. That was the main reason why the community executive today said the tax would not be levied until major trading partners took the same step.
Officials said that would increase pressure on the United States, Japan and others to accept concrete measures to limit their emissions. But privately, officials said environmental ministers and politicians would press hard for the European Community to adopt their plan even if others did not make such moves.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Back to Politics as Usual, Parties Dispute Urban Plans

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Only a day after President Bush and Congressional leaders met to display a spirit of bipartisanship in dealing with the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots, Republicans and Democrats returned to their normal political maneuvering today and demonstrated that they remained far apart on urban policy.
Mutual appeals for unity began to fray even as Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders moved ahead with modest programs. Mr. Bush announced a $600 million loan package to finance the rebuilding of businesses and homes in riot-damaged areas of Los Angeles, and the Democrats moved to advance an additional $822 million emergency appropriations package to the floor for a vote on Thursday. The package would also provide aid for areas of Chicago affected by the collapse of a tunnel and subsequent flooding. 
 The help Mr. Bush announced today came in addition to $600 million in loans and grants from the Small Business Administration and the Federal Emergency Management Administration. White House officals also said that those loans might be increased by $200 million.
But the Administration and Democratic leaders were pulled in opposite directions by their respective constituencies in closed-door meetings through the day. Republican House members told four senior Administration officials that they would not tolerate an initiative that raised taxes or increased deficit spending. Hours later, Democratic mayors told Congressional leaders that nothing short of a vast new aid program would prevent rioting.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic House leader, appeared to distance himself from Mr. Bush's approach to urban policy, which emphasizes tax incentives for businesses to invest in inner cities and loans to low-income families to purchase the public housing units they live in.
"There's a great deal of difference between our agendas," Mr. Gephardt said after meeting for two hours with the Democratic mayors.
And only days after the Administration backed away from comments made by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, who said the riots resulted from failed social programs of the 1960's, Vice President Dan Quayle made similar remarks. He told reporters in Japan, where he is holding three days of talks with leaders, that welfare programs backed by the Democratic Party "basically practiced and preached the idea of dependence, and dependency has created inertia, lack of drive, lack of self-help."
Keeping the public focus on his renewed interest in urban affairs, Mr. Bush went to one of Baltimore's poorest neighborhoods today for a previously scheduled visit to a medical clinic to discuss health insurance. But instead of focusing on health care, Mr. Bush announced that the Administration would make the $600 million available in South-Central Los Angeles for low-interest loans for housing and small businesses.
In a speech to health care workers, Mr. Bush said the loans were "good news for the people who lost homes and jobs as well as the owners who lost businesses due to the unrest out there, and it's one way we can underscore the fact that we are serious about helping Los Angeles recover."
Democratic leaders and a group of urban lawmakers met to begin constructing a legislative strategy for the weeks and months ahead after consulting with the mayors. The lawmakers decided to weave a jobs program costing $2 billion to $3 billion into Mr. Bush's proposals and said they also wanted to construct a more ambitious long-term policy to overhaul the welfare system and augment Federal financing for job training.
"The marching orders are to work something out with the Administration in the short term," said Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico. "And then in the longer term, we work on the fundamental urban ills."
The loans announced by Mr. Bush would be provided to banks and savings associations in California by the Federal Home Loan Bank system, a taxpayer-backed enterprise that was created by Congress during the Great Depression to make housing more affordable. The lower interest rates would then presumably be passed on to customers.
As the President made his announcement, the White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, the budget director, Richard G. Darman, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and Attorney General William P. Barr addressed the House Republican caucus to request support for the Administration's urban strategy.
Republican lawmakers praised Mr. Barr's call for a $500 million program to root out gangs from communities before delivering new social services. But they described the messages of the other officials on proposals for urban enterprise zones, privatization of public housing and education change as lackluster and imprecise. Several members spoke critically, warning that they could not support programs that would significantly raise either expenditures or taxes.
 
'The Wrong Message'
 "There's resentment from the rural areas," said Representative Bill Lowery, Republican of California, who added that "a large number" of Republican lawmakers were warning that the Administration was about to "send the wrong message that urban terrorism brings Federal largesse."
Meanwhile, Congressional leaders heard a very different message from 10 Democratic mayors, including David N. Dinkins of New York. The mayors delivered a report to Democratic leaders today declaring that unless Washington moved quickly to reverse "10 years of neglect," cities throughout the country would be forced to cut public payrolls and services severely.
"No one is on our side," said Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, as Mr. Gephardt looked on. "While it was Los Angeles in flames, it could have been any city in America."
Democratic lawmakers said the mayors pressed the leaders to use a meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House next week to push for sweeping new urban programs. Mr. Bush has said he will resist expensive new programs.
Despite statements by some Republican lawmakers earlier this week that Congress would enact legislation to aid urban areas within a few weeks, Mr. Fitzwater said today: "It will be three to four weeks before we get a good read on whether we have a good bill. We have to see what the strategy is on the Hill."

HEADLINE: Boston Journal;
The Young Are Given A Refuge In Music

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 8

 BODY:
Like many other young people in urban areas, Sanettra Ferguson, 17 years old, and Michael Thompson, 18, have seen their share of drugs and guns, and they have watched their friends die in street violence.
Unlike their peers, the two have found a refuge from the gangs and drugs that have invaded city schools and neighborhoods: music. 
 They spend three afternoons a week writing lyrics, composing songs and recording them in a studio apartment near their East Boston high school.
Miss Ferguson and Mr. Thompson are among more than 60 young people who have been recruited by Music Mobile, a free program in East Boston that is open to all Boston students 8 to 18 years old.
The nonprofit program was begun last year by two East Boston residents, Madeleine Steczynski and Bob Grove, who quit their jobs because they wanted to do something more meaningful.
Their idea is for the young people to use music as a vehicle to discuss their problems and come up with solutions.
Ms. Steczynski, an aspiring musician, had worked full time for a Cambridge architect and Mr. Grove, a professional musician, had worked as a computer systems consultant. Music Mobile was financed out of their pockets, but they are hoping that with grants and community donations, the programs will be self-supporting in two years and provide them with a modest living.
"We wanted the kids here to have an outlet where they could develop their artistic talent and do something positive for the community," Ms. Steczynski said. "We also wanted to encourage understanding among people whose paths might not normally cross."
Members of the Music Mobile reflect a wide range of ethnic and economic backgrounds, as do their audiences at the schools, hospitals, senior citizen homes and city parks where the group performs.
"We are also hoping that the messages in their music will make their way to other communities as the kids play their tapes for their friends and families," Mr. Grove said.
Most of the songs deal with the young people's experiences on the streets. One of the most telling songs, composed by a group of 24, is called "We've Had Enough." These are the words in one verse:
 
We've had enough of what's bad in our lives
We've had enough of drugs, guns and knives
Now we're going to turn it around,
because music is something new that we've found.
Community leaders have hailed the program as a positive addition to a neighborhood that has been exploited in the name of the city's transportation needs, namely its airport.
Over the years, several recreational areas and many homes have been lost to an expanding Logan Airport, which now occupies two thirds of East Boston.
Once an island, East Boston is now connected to the city by two harbor tunnels. Yet residents here, known as Easties, still consider themselves separate from the city.
Because of their isolation, young people in East Boston have fewer artistic opportunities than those in other areas of the city. In addition, music programs have become less available in the schools over the years because of financial cutbacks.
"A lot of these kids have nowhere to go after school," said Mark Sarro, a program supervisor at Harborside Community School here. "Music Mobile is keeping them off the streets."
Community leaders also praised Music Mobile's efforts to promote understanding among cultures, particularly in East Boston, where Central and South Americans, Southeast Asians and blacks have transformed what was once primarily an Italian-American section.
Miss Ferguson suggested that she and fellow members of Music Mobile might be able to bridge the gaps between different cultures. "People are open to music," she said. "It's something we all share."
As their songs attest, they also share a desire to improve race relations. In a rap song called "Life in the City," another group composition, they say:
 
Now -- it's not too late
to alleviate -- all this hate
'cause city life -- ain't always great
let's collaborate -- make a better fate.

She and co-founder, Bob Grove, helped a high school student, Gloribell Mota, record a song. (Sarah Putnam for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Panel Told of Fraud in Rural Housing Program

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Scores of developers who built rental housing for the rural poor with subsidized loans and Federal tax credits have reaped huge profits and in many cases have added to those earnings by diverting project funds to their personal use, Government investigators told a House subcommittee today.
The program under scrutiny, the Farmers Home Administration's rural rental housing program, for which the Government has spent $12 billion in the last 20 years, is so marked by fraud that 64 criminal investigations related to it are now under way in 31 states, the investigators said. 
 They also said truly needy rural residents who qualify for assistance under the program may be shut out of apartments because people who do not qualify are gaining admittance by lying about their income.
 
Cash Down Payment if 3%
 The investigators, witnesses before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, are from the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, and the office of the inspector general at the Department of Agriculture, the parent of the Farmers Home Administration.
The program on which they gave testimony provides Government loans to build, purchase, repair and operate multifamily housing projects for low-income tenants in rural areas. The loan usually covers 97 percent of a project's cost or value; the developer puts up a cash down payment of only 3 percent.
The loans have subsidized interest rates of only 1 percent, and developers also qualify for Federal tax credits. In addition, rents for tenants can be subsidized by either the Farmers Home Administration or the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
A G.A.O. analysis of three projects financed under the program found that even in the absence of fraud, the developers had realized returns on their initial cash investment of 780 percent to 970 percent in the first year. Officials of the Farmers Home Administration acknowledged that returns of that magnitude were excessive and generally typical of the program, the accounting office said.
 
'Instant Millionaire'
 "With a $92,000 investment in two projects, an Fm.H.A. developer can become an instant millionaire," said Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee.
On top of those large typical profits are added earnings that are frequently reaped through fraudulent or otherwise abusive activities, the investigators said. The accounting office said examples of such activities were inflated construction costs and diverting project funds to the developer's personal use.
The Agriculture Department's office of inspector general has been uncovering such abuses for years, the accounting office said, with the result that 35 indictments and 26 convictions have been returned against developers and project managers since 1987.
"Fraudulent and abusive activities exist because sufficient internal controls and trained staff are not present or available to detect and prevent these activities," said Judy A. England-Joseph, one of the G.A.O. investigators who testified today.
Another witness was La Verne Ausman, the head of the Farmers Home Administration, who said that the problems were being spotlighted largely through the inquiry of the agency's own inspector general and that officials were acting to strengthen the management of the program.
But Mr. Dingell, the subcommittee chairman, said that in one recent case a supposedly trustworthy developer in Alabama had admitted to fraud totaling $500,000 only after watching a preacher on late-night television.
"I applaud the impact of this television preacher," Mr. Dingell said, "but regrettably I do not think Fm.H.A. can depend on the good Lord alone to activate the guilty consciences of too many of their corrupt developers."

LENGTH: 557 words

HEADLINE: The Los Angeles Law: Use It

 BODY:
Stirred by the Los Angeles riot, politicians grope for ways to create jobs for angry inner-city residents. Jack Kemp, the Housing Secretary, pushes to give tax breaks and regulatory relief to companies that put their plants in ghettos. Two Democratic Senators, Paul Simon and David Boren, propose giving public sector jobs rather than handouts to long-term welfare recipients.
Though the sponsors deserve credit for groping, their proposals are neither new nor particularly practical. But Congress need not despair. It has already enacted a law that can give hope, and work, to alienated poor people in wastelands like south-central Los Angeles. It is called the Family Support Act of 1988 and all it needs is the money it was meant to have from the start. 
 Enterprise Zones: Three dozen states have tried them, without notable success. Tax breaks and regulatory waivers cannot compensate for the danger of doing business in areas of extremely high crime, extremely low skills and miserable public services.
There's no evidence that such zones, even if backed by Federal tax breaks, would generate many start-up businesses. They could, however, attract business from nearby neighborhoods, perhaps also poor. But no matter how they work, before long all legislators would want some of the subsidy for their districts -- quickly dissipating the money. That's what happened with the Model Cities program of the Johnson and Nixon years.
Guaranteed Public Employment: Cutting off welfare grants to able-bodied malingerers certainly sounds like sensible public policy, but ultimately it's not credible. Congress won't punish the children of sluggards and drunkards who don't show up for work, any more than it will deny them food stamps and let them starve.
The idea of creating huge numbers of public sector jobs runs smack into a contradiction. If the jobs are meaningful -- building bridges, rehabilitating homes -- then the workers must be trained and, if organized labor has its way, paid prevailing wages. That's hugely costly in dollar terms. But if the only creatable jobs are menial, like many CETA jobs in the Carter years, that's politically costly: taxpayers become enraged.
The problem often for alienated, jobless people in the inner cities is not that there aren't jobs. If that were the problem, transportation or relocation subsidies would be the answer. The problem is that many aren't equipped, emotionally or educationally, to hold stable jobs. They need training. They need help finding work. And once they find it, they need child care and medical insurance.
These are exactly the goals of the 1988 Family Security Act, sponsored by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. But Congress has appropriated only $1.5 billion a year in matching funds, nowhere near the $6 billion needed. And states, strapped by recession, have had to let the Federal funds sit unused. No wonder the law's impact has been disappointing.
It could be encouraging. A California study by the respected Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation shows that where the law has been used, welfare rolls and outlays are both down. The gains aren't huge but head in the right direction. In short, there already is a Los Angeles law. More Federal financing would mean more saving, in dollars and lives -- and not just in Los Angeles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
