HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Riots' Ground Zero: Street of Hopelessness

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 141

 BODY:
At the crossroads where the violence began with a racial beating two weeks ago, and where it came full circle with a showy arrest before dawn on Tuesday, the return to the routines of life today seemed a sign of returning hopelessness.
Surrounded by burned-out buildings, the people who live here spoke with anger about a society that writes them off as hoodlums and gangsters and responds with more arrests to what they see as their cry for help.
 
Onset of Violence
 "If you're a poor person, nobody listens to you," said Charles Johnson, 55 years old, as he boarded a bus to his work as a house builder. "I know it's my neighborhood that's burning, but if I've got to do this to make you listen, I've got to do it. A lot of people are crying out, reaching out." 
 What they found, in the single most visible response to the riot, was a huge police presence on the block that was the scene of the first beating, a raid of two houses here, and the parading of some of the young men of the neighborhood before television cameras as the villains of the day.
Not everyone here is a gang member. Not everyone here likes Damian Williams, who was arrested personally by Police Chief Daryl F. Gates himself. But many people here said they shared with Mr. Williams a sense of victimization by the system. These are the people the nation has seen in miniature through the eye of a helicopter, dancing in victory as they beat and clubbed a white man they pulled from his truck at the start of the rioting on April 29.
But viewed from the sidewalk on a quiet morning, the people who live near the intersection of Florence and Normandie Avenues can be seen walking their children, tending their rose gardens, making repairs on their cars.
In dozens of conversations with people around the block, residents voiced little sympathy with the police. Although a number condemned the recent looting and burning and gang violence, a picture emerged of a community at war with its peacekeepers.
This morning, as daily life took on its normal rhythms, there was a strong sense of injustice over a legal system that many people here say favors white people at the expense of blacks.
"We always end up in jail; we do a little something and we go to jail for a long time," said Anthony Dawson, 20, an unemployed high school dropout whose life is dedicated to spraying his nickname, "Punker," on freeway signs.
 
Double Standard Is Seen
 "It's not like the white people," he said. "They just railroad the black people for some crazy reason, like we are animals or something."
Like others interviewed today, he drew a parallel between the acquittals of four white police officers in the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King, a motorist, and the arrests on Tuesday of four black men in the beating of the truck driver, Reginald Denny, who was released from the hospital today.
"If it was white people, they wouldn't be so hard on them," he said.
Some people asked why so much attention was being paid to the beating of a white man by blacks and so little to the 58 people who were killed during the rioting, most of them black and Hispanic people.
Some asked why the vivid videotape of the beating of Mr. King, a black motorist, on March 3, 1991, was not enough to convict the white policemen, but the videotape of their black neighbors was taken to be such conclusive evidence. The questions were echoed throughout the diverse black community here.
"If they convict the boys, you can see all hell break loose," said George Hammond, 51, a monitor at a halfway house for prison inmates. "How can they say those four officers are innocent and these four are guilty? Why is Chief Gates out there making arrests now? Why didn't he walk Officer Powell to jail?" He was referring to Laurence M. Powell, one of the four police officers who beat Mr. King. "It seems like there are different ways of doing things, depending on whether you're black or white."
Eddye Melaragno, 59, a retired elementary school principal, who is also black, said: "At least one child is killed every week in South-Central and they don't even call the F.B.I. One white person is hit, and they call out the force. It's a double standard."
Ms. Melaragno said: "This is making people schizophrenic. You can't approve of violence, but you can't approve of what the Federal Government is doing either."
Explaining why she had stopped working in South-Central Los Angeles, she said, "Simply, I couldn't stand the depression, coming down and watching people fail, seeing kids go through school and knowing they're not going to make it."
Here in the heart of the South-Central section, some of Mr. Williams's neighbors on 71st street have enclosed their lives in their small bungalow-style houses in an attempt to blot out the despair and the violence outside.
"I just try to keep my own business to myself," said Willie Mae Ben, 60, who has seen this street transformed from poor and quiet to poor and violent.
"When anything goes on, I just stay in my house watching TV," she said as she tended the garden outside her small, pristine house. On the night of April 29, it was the fires in her own neighborhood that she watched on television.
Just down the street, with its carefully tended rose gardens, Mr. Williams's mother, Georgina Williams, a nurse, said, "If my son is going down the street, as God is my eyewitness, when he sees someone picking through the trash can, he comes home and asks me for money to give to them."
A deeply religious woman, she said she felt no bitterness, but only love for Chief Gates, and she offered a prayer for him to recite: "Oh, God, in the name of Jesus, come into my heart and save me. Forgive me for my sins. You hear me, Devil, I'm through with you. I'm through with sin."
At the bus stop, on the corner where her son is accused of having beaten Mr. Denny with a brick, a neighbor, Jason Thomas, said Mr. Williams was a well-known gang member. "He was a guy that was respected by the people in the neighborhood for not being a coward," said Mr. Thomas, 18. He said Mr. Williams participated in gang activities like drive-by shootings and drug dealing, adding, "That's what all the younger kids look up to."
But as violent as such people may be, he said, it is the police who strike fear into his neighborhood. "When you go out in the street, the old people say, 'Watch out for the police,' " Mr. Thomas said. "They don't say, 'Watch out for the guy on the corner.' "
At Fred and Deryl's Auto Body Shop, a group of men talked in ever louder voices of this crossroads in the city's history.
"We're like a dog on a chain," said Deryl Curl, 23, a co-owner of the shop. "You hit us with a stick and you step back, and you hit us with a stick and you step back again, and finally that chain is going to break and you've got a frightened dog in the corner."
"What's he going to do, stand up and fight for himself or keep on letting the police hit him in the head, beat him with a club," he said, evoking images of the videotaped beating of Mr. King that are also images of reality for many of the young men who live here. "Ain't no justice being done when white men can beat up on a black man and it's O.K., but not when black men beat up on a white man," he said, pacing back and forth in an excess of energy.
"And all they do is say to you: 'Stop rioting. Be peaceful.' " he said.

HEADLINE: White House on Conflicting Paths As It Agrees to Protection for Owl

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The Bush Administration issued a plan today to restrict logging on 5.4 million acres of ancient forest that is home to the northern spotted owl, but at the same time it moved to narrow the protection for endangered animals and plants.
The complicated and contradictory actions came after years of scientific study and angry political struggles in the Pacific Northwest over the balance between economic development and the preservation of rare species on Federal land. 
 Even as it moved to preserve the owl and comply with the Endangered Species Act by making its plan public in Portland, Ore., the Administration moved on two more fronts here today to attack the 19-year-old law and allow more logging in the Pacific Northwest. The Administration is sending the clearest signals yet that it hopes to weaken the act's prohibition against considering economic factors when weighing the fate of endangered species.
In effect, the Administration put itself in the unusual position of complying with the strictest environmental law as it sought to undermine it. Today's moves in Washington to allow logging were largely symbolic, at least in the short term, because Federal judges have already barred logging in most of the ancient Northwest forests pending lawsuits filed by environmental groups. Moreover, any effort to change the Endangered Species Act is likely to founder in Congress, where support for it is strong.
 
A Day of Maneuvering
 Today's maneuvering began here today when a specially convened Cabinet-level committee voted 5 to 2 to waive the requirements of the endangered species law and allow logging on 13 federally owned tracts of timberland in Oregon that total 1,700 acres.
It was only the second time since the Endangered Species Act was passed in 1973 that the committee had waived the requirements, and the first time since 1979, when the panel approved a dam in Wyoming after developing a plan to build an artificial wetland for the endangered whooping crane.
After the 5-to-2 vote today, the Administration proposed an amendment to the Endangered Species Act that would offset the plan released in Portland and allow logging on about two million acres.
In a report accompanying the proposed amendment, the Interior Department acknowledged that its enactment virtually insured that the owl would eventually disappear across much of its range. The amendment also proposed to alter the endangered species law by allowing economic considerations to be taken into account when loggers want to cut trees on land that is home to the owl.
Administration officials would not explain why they took all three actions at once, and what message they intended to send. The timing took supporters and critics alike by surprise.
Mark Rey, executive director of the American Forest Resource Alliance, a timber industry group in Washington, said: "What happened today is symbolic of why the act doesn't work. You have to go through all these byzantine procedures and processes to get to the point where you can make a decision which makes little difference."
 
To Die in Congress?
 Democratic leaders said the amendment proposed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. to allow timber cutting on two million acres is almost certain to die in Congress after it is introduced next week by Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican of Washington.
"The tragic result of the Lujan plan would be the extinction of the spotted owl over large parts of its range," said Representative Bruce Vento, a Minnesota Democrat who is co-sponsor of a proposal that would ban logging on almost nine million acres.
The plan released in Portland could take effect within 60 days if Congressional legislation is not enacted or it is not challenged in court. The plan was prepared in large part by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, a unit of the Interior Department. All Federal agencies are required by the Endangered Species Act to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service if any of their proposed actions would damage the habitat of endangered or threatened species. Putting the plan into action will depend in large part on the Fish and Wildlife Service's allegiance to it, officials at the Interior Department said.
Mr. Lujan said today that he intended to uphold the plan, which he said would cost 32,500 workers their jobs, even as hoped to change the endangered species law with his Congressional proposal. "We can preserve and maintain the owl at less than half the cost in jobs," said Mr. Lujan.
The Endangered Species Act is up for renewal this year, and it is not clear whether it will be strengthened or weakened by Congress.
Environmental leaders argued that Mr. Lujan was vastly overstating the number of jobs that might be lost. They said that automation, the timber industry's move from the Northwest to the South, and changes in how logs are handled -- tens of thousands of trees are exported each year from the Northwest instead of milled into lumber -- contributed to the loss of almost 30,000 jobs in the 1980's. They said neither President Ronald Reagan nor President Bush complained about those lost jobs, nor has the Bush Administration ever estimated how many new jobs would be created in the tourism, fishing, and other industries if the forests were protected.
"What the Administration did today shows a callous disregard for the law and a cynical play for votes," said Jim Owens, a director of the Western Ancient Forest Campaign, an environmental group in Washington.
The Administration's action today followed more than a decade of struggle between the timber industry and environmentalists over the fate of the great forests of spruce, Douglas fir and redwood that once stretched in a green band from Northern California to the Canadian border. From 1960 to 1990, almost four million acres were was logged in Oregon and Washington.
 
A Natural System in Decline?
 Environmental scientists became alarmed, arguing that the biological health of the ecosystem was in decline and that more than 100 species of plants and animals that once lived in abundance in the forests were threatened with extinction. Timber industry employees and executives scoffed at the warnings and contended that the big trees, most of them on Federal ground, were a national resource that supported thousands of families and provided lumber for construction.
In July 1990, the northern spotted owl was designated a threatened species that required the Government to take special action to save its habitat inmillions of acres of old forests. The identification of the owl touched off lawsuits by environmentalists who charged that the Interior Department and the United States Forest Service were not protecting the owl or its habitat.
When court orders in 1991 barred the Government from cutting the timber, timber industry workers, industry executives, and community leaders appealed to the White House for help. Administration officials have previously expressed misgivings about the Endangered Species Act, saying it has been misapplied to block economic development. Not until today, however, has the Administration
taken direct action to weaken the law.
One of the actions today was protested by William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency who is one of seven members of the Endangered Species Committee, popularly known as the "God Squad" because it has great power over whether a threatened species survives or dies. Mr. Reilly joined with another member, Tom Walsh, the general manager of the Tri-County Metropolitan Transportation Disrict in Portland, in voting against exempting the Government.
In voting for the exemption, Mr. Lujan joined Edward R. Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture, Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council on Economic Advisers, Dr. John A. Knauss, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and Michael P.W. Stone, the Secretary of the Army.

(Associated Press) (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Asks U.S. Congress to Seize 'Historic Moment' and Aid Russia

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev pleaded for economic recovery aid for Russia before the leaders of Congress today, hearing warm personal praise but no guarantee that special help will be forthcoming.
"This is a historic moment and a historic opportunity," the former Soviet leader declared, addressing Senate and House members in a special gathering in Statuary Hall. "It should not be allowed to slip by." 
 With the Administration's aid proposal thus far stalled in the face of considerable opposition and preoccupation with domestic issues, Mr. Gorbachev arrived as something of a revered private citizen intent on some difficult election-year lobbying.
Speaking as the Kremlin leader who helped end the cold war and presided over the collapse of the Soviet Union, Mr. Gorbachev said Russia would soon face a deepening of its post-Communist crisis as higher energy prices took hold at the most critical point of the democratic and free-market changes being attempted by Moscow.
 
'Most Difficult Stage'
 "We're now at the most difficult stage of these reforms," Mr. Gorbachev said. "In fact, we still haven't reached the bottom of the crisis. The peoples of Russia are courageously bearing up under these burdens."
The shape of long-term Russian-American relations could be at stake in Congress's decision on the need for urgent aid now, he cautioned. He made a particular point of stressing that, for all the cold war polemics, "the Russian people never felt hostility toward the American people."
"When Russia emerges from the present crisis, the national memory will forever remain cognizant of the magnanimity displayed by Americans at this moment of difficulty," Mr. Gorbachev declared after predicting a rich free-market future for Russia and other former Soviet republics, one that he said early allies would best be able to share.
On the eve of his return home from a two-week tour of the United States, Mr. Gorbachev heard himself welcomed warmly by Congressional leaders as a historic figure who had won the faith and affection of the American public in his campaign to achieve large-scale nuclear disarmament and thereby allow his nation to attend to its tattered economy.
But the praise did not immediately translate into votes for the Russian aid proposal that is stalled in Congress. After Mr. Gorbachev's speech, the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, called his plea for aid "impressive." But Mr. Gephardt said: "We're a long way from having the climate to pass it. We have urgent economic needs in the United States."
The Bush Administration proposed participation in a multinational package estimated by proponents at $24 billion in loan guarantees and aid.
The estimated United States share of the package would be $4.35 billion, mostly in increased loan authorizations. It would also offer cash in sharing in a multinational fund totaling $6 billion to help stabilize the ruble. Mr. Gorbachev has been emphasizing the urgent need for this in his American speeches by cautioning that Russia's coming rise in energy prices will likely be the most critical test yet of the ruble's survivability.
There has been little immediate enthusiasm for the aid package in Congress, which is wary of voting aid for foreign countries while constituents at home struggle through an election-year recession. Congressional leaders offered no promises on passage of the aid package after the former Soviet leader's speech.
A crowd of about 400 lawmakers and aides gave Mr. Gorbachev a standing ovation after his speech in which he also predicted ever closer American-Russian relations in an ever more shifting global scene.
Mr. Gorbachev departed Congress for a private White House dinner and other stops, with the measure's fate remaining unclear. In the House, some Democrats have been talking of trying to make it part of a legislative trade-off with the Administration to secure liberalization of unemployment benefits.
Mr. Gorbachev's speaking in the smaller Statuary Hall rather than the main chamber was a reflection of the fact that he no longer has any state power and that Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin will visit here next month and be accorded more elaborate protocol.
Mr. Gorbachev said tonight at a news conference that contrary to upstaging Mr. Yeltsin's appearance, he thought he had contributed to his cause by explaining Russia's needs to the American public. He repeated that he would continue to support his old political rival so long as he is pursuing democratic reform.
Beyond the aid plea, Mr. Gorbachev's address seemed an exercise in his new role as proprietor of the private Gorbachev Fund, for which he has been enlisting affluent American patrons during his tour. His love of speaking on wide-ranging global themes was evident as he presented an overview of his impressions of post-Communist world politics.
He urged Russia and the United States to take special efforts to see that the four republics of the former Soviet Union with long-range nuclear weapons carry out the Soviet-American strategic nuclear disarmament treaty. The danger no longer was in a feared superpower exchange, he said, "but rather that control over these weapons will be lost" to smaller nations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, were greeted last night by President Bush and his wife, Barbara, before a private dinner at the White House. Also on hand were Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, right, and his wife, Susan, and Brent Scowcroft, rear, the national security adviser. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gap Net Rose 11% in Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Gap Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose nearly 11 percent. The company has fared better than many others in the recession, though it has been unable in recent months to match the strong sales rate it had in 1991.
The Gap, based in San Francisco, said its earnings rose to $45.3 million, or 32 cents a share, for the period ended May 2, compared with $40.9 million, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable quarter of 1991. Sales rose 20 percent, to $588.9 million from $490.3 million. 
 The Gap said it was satisfied with the results, especially because its first-quarter profit for 1991 was 93 percent higher than its earnings in the similar 1990 period. But Wall Street, whose support of the Gap has wavered in recent months, was unhappy with the first-quarter results. The Gap's shares lost $3.625 yesterday, to $37.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Some investors bailed out of the Gap's shares after the company said it was unlikely to keep up the pace of sales and earnings growth it had in 1991. The company, known for its moderately priced casual wear, is still considered one of the top retailers by securities analysts, however.
At the end of the latest quarter, the Gap operated 1,236 stores -- 850 Gap, 151 Banana Republic and 235 Gap Kids outlets -- compared with 1,130 last year.

HEADLINE: Filing Is Expected to Affect Banks More Than Property

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Office rents, building prices and bank balance sheets in the United States already reflect such a weak property market that the bankruptcy filing of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. is unlikely to cause much further harm, real estate and banking experts said yesterday.
But the filing is more likely to affect several major New York banks than the area's real estate investors, some experts said. 
 Lawrence J. White, a New York University professor of economics, said he expected the news to damage the prices of bank stocks. "It knocks a big hole in the balance sheets," he said.
But Frank R. DeSantis Jr. a banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that the Chemical Banking Corporation and Citicorp had already recognized likely losses on their Olympia & York loans.
"They both absorbed O.& Y. in the first quarter," he said. "Clearly there will be lost interest. But I don't think this is going to be that material."
Citicorp has loaned Olympia & York or its subsidiaries about $500 million, Mr. DeSantis said, and Chemical has loaned about $250 million. J. P. Morgan is also a lender.
"They've been playing hardball," he said, explaining that if the banks feared serious losses from Olympia & York's problems, they would have been far more flexible in negotiations to reorganize the company's debts.
Banking analysts said that Canadian banks, which have extended an estimated $3 billion to Olympia & York, have already suffered far more than their American counterparts. Their shares have fallen sharply as Olympia & York's financial condition worsened, dragging the entire Canadian stock market down.
Had Olympia & York, New York's largest commercial landlord, filed for bankruptcy two years ago, the effects might have been cataclysmic, experts said. But real estate values are already low enough to cushion the impact of the company's fall.
In the United States, meanwhile, the New York Stock Exchange has been setting new highs, although New York's commercial real estate has not recovered. Anthony Downs, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that in the New York office market, "The disaster was already so widespread that this doesn't hurt much more."

HEADLINE: City Council Gives Horses Freer Rein

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
After intense lobbying by the horse-drawn carriage industry, the City Council voted yesterday to allow carriage drivers to operate their rigs around much of Manhattan and not just through Central Park.
The vote, to amend a 1989 law that restricts the carriages to the park for most of the day, followed months of battling that pitted the tiny carriage industry against animal lovers and those who feared that expansion would create traffic hazards. 
 After the 32-to-18 vote by the Council, aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was leaning toward vetoing the amendment, which would also expand the carriages' hours of operation. To override the veto, the supporters of the amendment would need the votes of two-thirds of the Council, or two votes more than the amendment received yesterday.
 
A Raucous Debate
 In a raucous debate before the vote, Council members invoked George Washington, Edmund Burke and Rodney G. King. They weighed the relative hazards posed by dog and horse droppings. And they scrambled to assert their credentials as lovers of animals, the Irish (who own or drive many of the carriages) and jobs.
Supporters and opponents of the amendment packed the gallery of the Council chamber, cheering their champions and booing and hissing their foes. After the vote, one woman in the gallery stood and stuck her tongue out at the carriage-driver camp.
Several Council members said they hoped that the same energy that went into yesterday's debate would be applied to issues affecting greater numbers of New Yorkers. There are only 68 city-licensed horse carriages in New York City.
The amendment was hotly debated because animal-rights advocates had made it a test of Council members' concerns for animals, while supporters of the amendment contended that the survival of the horse-carriage industry was at stake.
In addition, Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Democrat from Queens, suggested that some opponents of the measure were biased against the Irish.
That prompted many Council members to go to great lengths to emphasize their support of the Irish. "I love the Irish," declared Israel Ruiz, a Democrat from the Bronx, once he finished describing how much he liked riding horses. "I have a lot in common with the Irish."
Noach Dear, a Democrat from Brooklyn and a sponsor of the amendment, said that he owed the Irish a great debt because they had supported the founding of the state of Israel. He also confessed that though he did not own a cat or a dog, he was sympathetic to animal-rights causes.
Councilwoman Mary Pinkett, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said she supported the amendment out of concern for both horses and the carriage drivers' jobs. "If these horses are not working," she said, "they become dog food."
Carriage drivers said they were delighted with the vote. "Tonight I come to work very happy," said John Vallona, a 22-year-old Italian immigrant, as he stood beside his carriage on Central Park South last night.
Patrick McIlroy, an Irish immigrant who was helping harness a horse at the Bicentennial stable on West 37th Street, said, "Business has definitely been hurt, especially with the recession. It doesn't help when you have people trying to take the bread away from your table."
 
More Appeal to Tourists
 The carriage drivers say they can increase their earnings with longer hours and increased areas of operation because this would have more appeal to tourists and others who hire the carriages. To out-of-towners enchanted with the city, to couples enchanted with each other, a ride in a horse-drawn carriage is as much a part of the New York experience as that first glimpse of the Statue of Liberty or that first trip to the top of the Empire State Building.
The lopsided vote surprised both supporters and opponents of the amendment, who were uncertain of the outcome going into yesterday's debate, although it is extremely rare for a bill, once passed by a Council committee, to fail on the floor.
Kathryn E. Freed, a Democrat from Manhattan who opposed the measure, said: "There was a lot of pressure. Some people switched at the last minute." She said Mr. McCaffrey's raising of the Irish issue contributed to the pressure.
Aides to the Mayor did not detail his objections to the amendment. "The bill is under review, but he casts a negative eye toward it at this moment," said Martha Hirst, the Mayor's chief legislative representative. "He's simply saying, 'I'm coming down on the side of restricting the horses.' "
A veto of this amendment would be the Mayor's third, and the first of legislation passed by the expanded City Council.
Horse-drawn carriages are now restricted to Central Park during daytime and forbidden to operate at all during the weekday rush hours of 7 to 10 A.M. and 4 to 7 P.M. They are excluded from midtown from 7 P.M. to midnight.
The amended law would shave an hour off each of the rush periods, forbidding the carriages to operate from 7 to 9 A.M. and from 4:30 to 6:30 P.M., Monday to Friday.
Under the amended law, the carriages could roll throughout Manhattan, with some exceptions: They could not operate from 7 A.M. to 12 midnight between 42d and 23d Streets and Third and Ninth Avenues. On most afternoons and evenings, the carriages would be banned from the area bounded by 42d and 57th Streets and Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Avenue, and from the area bounded by 60th and 65th Streets and Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.
The 1989 law doubled the fare for a carriage ride to $34 for the first half-hour and $10 for each additional 15 minutes. That fare is unchanged by the Council's vote.
The lopsided vote surprised both supporters and opponents of the amendment, who were uncertain of the outcome going into yesterday's debate, although it is extremely rare for a bill, once passed by a Council committee, to fail on the floor.
Kathryn E. Freed, a Democrat from Manhattan who opposed the measure, said: "There was a lot of pressure. Some people switched at the last minute." She said Mr. McCaffrey's raising of the Irish issue contributed to the pressure, as did what she called lobbying and public-relations efforts by a group called Putting People First.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Census Reveals a City of Displacement

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
A grim statistical silhouette of poverty and displacement is emerging from new Census Bureau data, which show the inner-city black population of Los Angeles jostling for living space with a vast inflow of Hispanic and Asian immigrants.
This pattern, occurring across the Los Angeles basin, is strikingly evident in the neighborhoods of South-Central Los Angeles that exploded in violence and flames two weeks ago. 
 Always poor, most of these areas became poorer over the past decade as middle-class and working-class black families fled westward to areas like Inglewood, whose middle-class white residents were in turn moving elsewhere.
 
Poverty and Change
 Since the 1965 riots in the South-Central neighborhood of Watts, the language spoken in the poorest neighborhoods has begun to change from English to Spanish and newly arrived Asians have bought neighborhood commercial establishments.
"If you take the past 27 years, I would challenge you to find any other place of equal poverty that has experienced such dramatic economic and demographic change," said Alan Heslop, a senior research associate at the Rose Institute, a demographic research firm in Los Angeles.
An examination of four census tracts, each of which has 4,000 to 7,500 people, shows that they share one characteristic: swift and overwhelming demographic change. Of the four, three are in neighborhoods of South-Central Los Angeles that were overtaken by violence on April 29 and 30. The fourth is in Inglewood, a separate municipality bordering South-Central Los Angeles that is home to many middle-class blacks and was less affected by the rioting.
Among the half-million residents of South-Central Los Angeles, one person in three lives in poverty. By contrast, the national poverty rate in 1989, the year covered by the Census figures, was 12.8 percent. Among California's 29.9 million people, the rate was 12.5 percent.
But a pattern found in many major urban areas is duplicated here. As the statisticians focus more closely on the Los Angeles basin, the rate begins to climb: among the 3.5 million residents within the borders of the city of Los Angeles, the poverty rate in 1989 was 18.9 percent.
 
Heavy Immigration
 As poverty became more concentrated in the city, immigrants poured in at such a rate that half the population was bilingual and 38 percent were born outside the country. One Los Angeles resident in five entered the United States in the 1980's; in California as a whole, the comparable rate is one in nine.
Immigration pushed the proportion of the city's Hispanic population from 27.5 percent in 1980 to 40 percent a decade later. During this period, the Asian population nearly doubled, the city's white population increased by 1.3 percent and its black population decreased by 3.5 percent.
The census tracts analyzed below, chosen with the advice of Javier Menjares, a demographer with the Southern California Association of Governments, are not exact microcosms of the communities around them, but they offer clear snapshots of what happens to communities when normally glacial demographic changes surge through like a tornado.
 
The Heart of Koreatown
 Census Tract 2124, where census takers counted just fewer than 7,200 people in 1990, lies north of the Santa Monica Freeway. Five years before the Watts riots, this 72-acre area several miles above the center of the 1965 disturbances was 98 percent white; by 1980, one person in four was Asian, one in three was Hispanic. By 1990, 72 percent of the population of this corner of what is now called Koreatown had been born outside the country. More than half of the current residents are Hispanic; one-third are Asian.
"The areas where Asians have congregated tend to be rental, lower-income," said Leroy Hardy, also a senior research assistant with the Rose Institute. Indeed, nearly 90 percent of the housing units in the census tract are rental.
The unemployment rate for the area, 4.8 percent in 1980, was nearly 10 percent in 1990, compared with 8.4 percent for the city as a whole.
The pattern of school enrollment and educational attainment for the area, however, has not shifted nearly as much as the racial mix. In 1960, when it was a working-class white neighborhood, about 54 percent of the residents above the age of 25 had completed high school; the figure now is 49 percent.
 
Watts
 Between 1960 and 1990, one-third of the black population of Census Tract 2427 left this predominantly black community. From 3,352 blacks in 1960, the tract lost 175 blacks by 1970, 600 more by 1980, and 350 more by 1990.
The shrinking of the black population was the least of the changes. An area whose population was 17.7 percent Hispanic in 1980 took in at least 500 immigrants over the 1980's. An Hispanic population that numbered 565 in 1980 grew to 1,720 people in 1990 -- 45 percent of the population of Census Tract 2427.
Vacant housing, which represented 8.2 percent of the housing stock in 1980, declined to 4 percent in 1990. But the area's economic profile improved only slightly; a 1979 poverty rate of about 45 percent was measured 10 years later at 38 percent.
 
Florence and Normandie
 The intersection where the rioting began April 29 is one of the centers of the decaying sprawl of South-Central Los Angeles, but statistics show it to be better off than many of the surrounding neighborhoods. Relatively speaking, that is. If the neighborhoods of South-Central Los Angeles have a poverty rate of 32.9, this tract stands out with a poverty rate of only 21.4 percent in 1989. That was a marked improvement over 1979, when the rate was nearly 30 percent.
At the same time, more Hispanic people were moving in and the number of people living in each household was increasing. A decade ago, the census tract's population of 6,622 people was 88 percent black; that figure dropped to 73 percent by 1990, while the total population counted dropped to 6,300 in 1990.
Hispanic people, who can be of any race, increased from 10 percent of the population to nearly 28 percent.
In 1980, 29.9 percent of all the households in census tract 2374 were headed by women; 38.2 percent were married-couple households. By 1990, both the percentages had declined slightly; the number of "non-family" households grew.
 
Inglewood

What happened to the black residents who left Watts and Florence-Normandie in the 1980's? While blacks were emptying out of those areas, Inglewood, a middle-class community just west of the city line near South-Central Los Angeles, was losing its white population and gaining black homeowners.
During three decades of metamorphosis, the population of Census Tract 6007 on the border of Inglewood and Los Angeles first contracted, going from 6,540 people in 1960 to 3,904 people in 1980. It then grew to just under 5,000 people in 1990. Three decades ago, 98 percent of the population was white; in 1990, 84 percent of the residents were black.
But over the 1980's, demographic factors reflecting stability all improved as the neighborhood completed its racial transformation. Homeownership peaked in 1990 at 70 percent; in 1960 it had been 62 percent. In 1960, two-thirds of the area's residents had high school diplomas; in 1990, the figure was 87 percent. The poverty rate in 1990 was 6.3 percent, up from 3.8 percent in 1980.

HEADLINE: Subway Felonies Decline In First 3 Months of Year

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Serious crime in New York City's subways continued to decline significantly during the first three months of this year, the transit police reported yesterday.
The police said that felonies declined by 13.9 percent in January, February and March compared with the first three months of 1991. Sharp reductions were recorded in most categories of serious crime, including robberies, assaults and larcenies. 
 The release of the crime figures came the same day that leaders of the transit workers' union announced that the membership had overwhelmingly approved a new contract.
Felonies on the subway have been declining for 18 straight months, the transit police said. In 1991, 15 percent fewer felonies were committed on the subway than in 1990.
 
More Arrests Credited
 Michael F. O'Connor, the transit police chief, contended that more aggressive policing strategies had contributed to the decline in crime. He said that the police were arresting more people and that they were concentrating not only on serious offenses but also on crimes like fare evasion and disorderly conduct.
There are also 700 more transit police officers than there were in January 1990, said Albert W. O'Leary, a transit police spokesman. Because of Mayor David N. Dinkins's Safe Streets, Safe City program, there are now 4,300 transit police officers, compared with 3,600 officers two years ago, Mr. O'Leary said.
Chief O'Connor said the additional officers and the department's aggressive tactics had produced a significant increase in arrests for crimes in the subway system. During the first three months of this year, the transit police arrested 9,443 people, for offenses ranging from homicide to fare evasion. During the first three months of 1990, 5,386 people were arrested for subway crimes.
Between January and March of this year, there were 1,558 robberies in the system, 32 percent fewer than the 2,278 robberies reported during the first three months of 1990, the transit police said. There were 257 assaults between January and March of this year, compared with 335 assaults during the corresponding period in 1990.
There were four rapes and six homicides on the subway during the first three months of this year, compared with six rapes and seven homicides during the comparable period in 1990.
 
Contract Is Approved
 In a related matter, the transit workers' union said New York City's 32,000 subway and bus workers have overwhelmingly approved a new 38-month contract.
The leaders said they believed that the strong support for the pact in the mail balloting, which was conducted over the last two weeks, indicated little backing within the union for a call by a dissident group for a job action during the Democratic Convention in July.
By a vote of 17,147 to 2,507, the transit workers ratified a contract tentatively approved two weeks ago by the union's executive board and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. In March, the union's rank and file had rejected a contract proposal by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1.
The reconfigured contract called for a 2 percent raise, retroactive to May 1, 1991, when the last contract expired; a 2.5 percent raise on Sept. 1, and an additional 2 percent raise on May 1, 1993.
The M.T.A. had said previously that the new pact would not increase its labor costs and would not require an increase in the $1.25 bus and subway fare.
The first contract, which was approved by the M.T.A. and the union's board in January, entailed a 4.5 percent increase this year and an additional 2 percent raise next year. It also featured a one-time payment of $1,000 to cover inflation since last May.
Sonny Hall, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, attributed the overwhelming approval of the revised pact to two factors: the removal of the $1,000 payment, which many workers had opposed because it would not be used in the calculation of future raises and pension benefits, and a better effort by union leaders in selling the package to the membership.
 
A Different Choice
 But union leaders also probably influenced the outcome of the vote by changing its terms. In the first vote, in March, the leaders asked members whether they approved or disapproved of the contract. This time, the leaders offered a different choice: members were told to choose between the revised contract or binding arbitration.
One of the union's dissident groups, called New Directions, had advised members to take neither choice and instead to write in "none of the above." Mr. Hall said that only 23 such write-in votes were cast.
"We're pleased as punch," Mr. Hall said of the results.
"It just shows that transit workers can disagree with leadership," he said, "but that when leadership sits down and debates with them, they can listen and respond."
Mr. Hall had contended for months that the contract was the best he could obtain in the midst of a severe recession. After the members rejected the first proposal, the union's medical benefits fund came close to bankruptcy. Mr. Hall had threatened to call a strike if his members lost some medical coverage, although he never specified when he would ask workers to walk off their jobs.
Approval of the revised contract means that members will retain existing health benefits, union and transit officials said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger;
Clinton Offers National Education Plan

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 14

 BODY:
Saying that the struggle to improve economic and social conditions in America has been impaired by failing to make education a top priority, Gov. Bill Clinton today called for a renewed commitment to schools and job training.
In a speech delivered at a distressed public college in East Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton outlined an education plan that called for Federal college tuition assistance, job training for high school dropouts and graduates who choose not to go on to college and legislation that would allow parents to choose which public school their children will attend. 
 "We know we have real gaps in American education," he said. "Opportunity gaps and responsibility gaps which are more important to our national security today than the missile gap that played such an important role in the Presidential election of 1960.
"The education opportunity gaps between ourselves and the rest of the world and among our own people are immense."
 
New National Goals
 Mr. Clinton said his administration would set new education goals, including a plan to increase high school graduation rates to 90 percent of enrolled students, "meaningful" national examination standards for students and teachers and increased Federal spending on programs to reduce class size and expand preschool opportunities.
His remarks today, which were essentially a repackaged version of the education speech he has delivered at schools and colleges throughout the country this year, featured sharp partisan attacks on President Bush.
As has become Mr. Clinton's habit in the weeks since he began transforming his campaign into a general election effort aimed at stressing the failures of White House policy, he faulted the Administration for not living up to promises Mr. Bush made as a candidate in 1988 and during an education summit with governor's in 1989.
"America needs an education President who shows up for class every day, not just once every four years," he said. Mr. Bush, he said, has cut funding for bilingual education, job training, literacy programs and college aid.
"The President's education plan amounts to a form of trickle-down education that won't help America anymore than trickle-down economics has helped us in the 1980's," he said.
Mr. Clinton's speech was received warmly by the audience of several hundred students and administrators at East Los Angeles College, a two-year school where recent tuition increases made the audience especially receptive to his assistance proposal.
Mr. Clinton also used the opportunity to link his education proposals to the problems of inner-city crime that have preoccupied elected officials and California voters since the Los Angeles riots.
Recalling a 1989 visit he made to a South-Central Los Angeles school, the Arkansas governor said the students he talked to then "were most worried about being shot going to and from school."
"Those kids are now in ninth grade," he said. "I have often wondered in the last few days, after what happened here, how many of them wound up in gangs, whether they looted, whether they're still alive. . . . We need to make something of the lives we're wasting."
 
Tuition Plan Is Popular
 Mr. Clinton's most popular proposal, judging by the applause he typically gets from audiences around the country, is a plan to replace the existing Federal student loan programs with a program that would allow any student to borrow money for college if the student promised to repay the loan either by committing to pay a small percentage of income over a period of time or by agreeing to join a national service program as a teacher, police officer or other public servant for reduced pay.
Such a plan, his aides have estimated, would cost about $8 billion by its fourth year. Mr. Clinton has said he would pay for this and other priority programs -- including health care and deficit reduction -- by instituting cost controls and trimming defense spending.
Mr. Clinton drew heavily upon his experience as governor of Arkansas and parent of a 12-year-old public school student to illustrate his commitment to improving education. Recalling his own education, he said he had used loans and scholarships and had worked six jobs to go to college and law school.
"What bothers me so much about America today is that there are so many people who are being left out of that opportunity channel," he said.
Mr. Clinton repeated his call for allowing parents to choose the public schools their children should attend, an approach he has championed in Arkansas. But he said he "unalterably opposed" the proposal favored by the Bush Administration that would allow parents to use vouchers to send their students to private schools if they wished.
 
A Bad Time for Cuts
 "Now is not the time to further diminish the financial resources of schools when budgets are being slashed by states all across America," Mr. Clinton said, "when the Federal Government has restricted its commitment to education."
Mr. Clinton has delivered formal speeches on foreign affairs, economic policy and the environment to stress the substantive differences between his campaign and the President's and to try to put behind him the constant discussion of character questions that had dominated his campaign.
He said he did not want to spend the bulk of his speech today blaming Republican administrations for the failures in education. But in the end, he was unable to resist taking repeated aim at President Bush, who declared during the 1988 campaign that he would be the "education President."
Of his own education reform package, Mr. Clinton said: "I'll work day and night to get it passed, unlike our current President, who often proposes and then leaves it to someone else to dispose or not to act at all."

HEADLINE: Jackson Journal;
Again, Hope Fails at a Shopping Mall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., May 14

 BODY:
When the Jackson Mall first opened more than 20 years ago, it was the most celebrated monument to retailing in Mississippi. Shoppers from as far as Alabama and Louisiana flocked here to the department stores and trendy boutiques of what was then the largest mall within a 400-mile radius.
But today the 53-acre mall, in what is now the city's black community, is mostly shuttered, its vast parking lot empty, a symbol of the decay that plagues the nation's inner cities. A plan that would have converted at least a part of the Jackson Mall to industrial use recently collapsed amid a debate that had economic, political and racial overtones, and that, to many, underscored this community's deep racial polarization. 
 As larger malls developed in more affluent sections of the city, the Jackson Mall slowly died. By the mid-1980's, the major anchors, J. C. Penney Company, Woolco and Gayfers department stores, pulled out. The smaller retailers quickly followed.
Last fall, Thomas H. Espy, an entrepreneur whose past ventures had ranged from funeral homes to a company that made grass seed pellets for cattle, announced plans to convert the mall's old Woolco store into a latex-glove plant. Mr. Espy, the 47-year-old brother of Representative Michael Espy of Mississippi, said the plant would employ more than 200 workers within two years and pay an average of $7.40 an hour. Mr. Espy had raised $3.3 million of the $7 million start-up cost.
But the Hinds County Board of Supervisors, by a 3-to-2 vote along racial lines, overturned a bond issue that had been approved by a previous board. The three white supervisors opposed to the bonds said the county had no business guaranteeing start-up ventures with taxpayer money.
Mr. Espy, who is black, said the board was too blinded by his color to help create decent jobs in this economically troubled part of a county.
"I feel I'm the victim of discrimination," he said. "And I believe that if I had been a white businessman the factory would have been open for business by now."
Mr. Espy was not alone in bemoaning a missed opportunity. The Jackson Redevelopment Authority, the city's urban renewal agency, had predicted the plant would have attracted more business to the site.
"Other companies were responding when they thought the glove factory would be set up at the mall," said Lloyd Montgomery, director of the agency. "For a moment it had sparked something, and people seemed to be interested in moving their projects to the mall."
But Hershel Wilbourn, a supervisor at the time of the vote earlier this year, said the plan was rejected because, "we didn't feel we could obligate taxpayers that way."
Mr. Wilbourn said the bond issue "isn't about race at all," but rather about "trying to make sensible economic policy."
But many blacks here say the county board has often given tax breaks and other incentives to business ventures. "The fact of the matter is that race plays a prominent role in the affairs of this city," said James Covington, president of the Central Mississippi Minority Business Development District. "In this case it is keeping the city from going forward."
Mr. Espy said he plans to pursue his project 90 miles north in Grenada, Miss., where he said local authorities are pursuing a similar bond issue. As for Jackson, he said: "I did everything I thought I was supposed to do. I raised the money. I did the paperwork. I jumped through all the hoops. If I, the brother of a United States Congressman, can't get this done, what chance does the average black businessman have?"

HEADLINE: Dinkins Set To Lift Curbs On Pretoria

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that at the request of Nelson Mandela, New York City is prepared to lift sanctions against South Africa, provided that the country establishes an interim government that will draft a new constitution for a new nonracial Government.
Mr. Dinkins's announcement, which came after a mayoral delegation returned Wednesday from a three-day trip to South Africa, gives support to the African National Congress at a time when it is holding talks over the setting up of such an interim government. And it allows the Mayor to try to address business executives who have been pressing him to lift the sanctions, which prohibit the city from contracting with companies that do business in South Africa. 
 Mr. Dinkins insisted yesterday that he did not send the delegation to South Africa to allay concerns of local business interests. He said the A.N.C., of which Mr. Mandela is president, had asked New York City to go to South Africa to clarify its position on sanctions now that an interim government appeared to be at hand.
Yesterday Mr. Dinkins made public a letter that the delegation brought back with it, in which Mr. Mandela said that as soon as the interim government was established, "we will issue a call to you and other heads of government who have helped our cause to assist in building our economy."
"We have much in common," he added. "It is for this reason that we invited you to send a delegation to meet with us during this critical period to discuss reintroduction of trade and investment from the people and corporations in your city as soon as we have an interim government."
 
Lynch Explains Invitation
 Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, who led the delegation, said yesterday that the A.N.C. had issued its invitation to insure that there would be no delay in the lifting of sanctions once the A.N.C. requested it. New York is one of more than 130 American cities that have maintained sanctions despite the lifting of Federal embargoes by the Bush Administration. Because the city's sanctions are the strictest in the country, any decision to lift them is expected to be followed by other governments.
Mr. Lynch said: "Once the interim government is established, the A.N.C. will be a part of it and that government will have to deliver something to the people in terms of economic help, so there cannot be any delay in lifting sanctions and that's why they asked us there to confirm our position."
Donna Katzin, director of South Africa and International Justice Programs for the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, agreed. "There will be great expectations for the new government and the economic aid provided by the lifting of sanctions will be vital," she said.
Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that he would ask the City Council and city pension systems to end all current sanctions on doing business in South Africa, except those that apply to munitions and weapons-making companies. Those would be retained until the South African military and police forces were brought under the control of the people, the Mayor said.
 
Holtzman Has a Reservation
 City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, who as a trustee of the city's pension funds has a vote on whether to end sanctions, said in a statement yesterday that she believed they should not be lifted until there was one person, one vote in South Africa. But Ms. Holtzman said that "if the A.N.C. signals that it wants the lifting of sanctions when an interim government of national unity is installed, then I will give very careful consideration to such a proposal." The city, which controls $43 billion in pension funds, has avoided investing them in companies doing business in South Africa.

HEADLINE: Businesses' Inventories And Sales Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Businesses increased their sales by five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Government said today. But they also built up their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent, which puzzled some analysts.
If the stockpiling was voluntary, it could reflect optimism over the economy by businesses replenishing their shelves. But if it was involuntary, it could mean a lack of customers, causing goods to pile up. 
 'It's either very good news or very bad news," said Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities in New York. "If firms are confident about the future, if they believe the new surge in consumer buying is for real, then it is a good sign.
"But if firms misgauged demand and wound up with inventories they didn't really want," he added, "then this is going to force cutbacks in production and either push us back into recession or keep the recovery very weak."
 
Key Ratio Unchanged
 The inventory-to-sales ratio in March was 1.49, unchanged from February but down from 1.51 in January. The ratio means it would take 1.49 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the March sales pace.
The Commerce Department said business sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $547.9 billion, although the pace was slower than the 1.5 percent advance in February, when sales increased to $545.4 billion. Sales last fell in December.
But inventories crept up to a seasonally adjusted $816.3 billion after remaining unchanged in February. Businesses let their stockpiles fall in January after a four-month buildup.
Samuel D. Kahan, an economist with Fuji Securities in Chicago, said the inventories-to-sales ratio at 1.49 was "still relatively low." Fuji economists have said the ratio jumped to 1.74 during the last recession in 1981 and 1982.
The Commerce Department said sales by both manufacturers and wholesalers rose in March -- up nine-tenths of 1 percent at factories and 1.3 percent at the intermediate level -- but retail sales slumped 1 percent.
Still, the department reported on Wednesday that retail sales apparently bounced back nine-tenths of 1 percent in April.

HEADLINE: The Prime of 'Wall Street East';
A Renaissance May End Downtown Brooklyn's Dark Ages

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The time passed long ago when the streets of downtown Brooklyn bustled with trolleys and elevated trains, when the Dodgers had their business office at Montague and Court Streets and when Brooklynites, in fedoras and white gloves, swarmed the penny arcades, stately theaters and grand old department stores like Namm's and Frederick Loeser's.
But now, after decades of deterioration turned it into a gritty, fading remnant of itself, downtown Brooklyn has regained a bit of the verve that, to some, once made it the center of the center of the world.
 
A New Business Hub
 
 Even as New York City reels from a recession that has stalled projects and left an office glut in Manhattan, a flurry of construction projects -- worth $2.5 billion in all -- has given downtown Brooklyn a revived identity as the city's third business hub, after Wall Street and midtown Manhattan.
Modern towers have etched new pinnacles in the borough's aging skyline, and stores and restaurants have opened in the canyons below. The streets rattle with new construction and stir with thousands of new workers. Amid the shabby shops, dilapidated buildings and rubbly lots that remain, downtown Brooklyn has begun to assume a sleek corporate air.
"When they told me I was coming to this store, I thought, 'Huh, Brooklyn,' " said Paul Hinksman, manager of the Au Bon Pain restaurant that opened this month in MetroTech. "I didn't expect this. It's almost Manhattanish."
In a borough that has always struggled under the long shadows from across the East River, the redevelopment, anchored by MetroTech, a $1 billion commercial and academic complex, has been heralded as nothing short of a renaissance.
As Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said, "The dream of a whole new downtown is being created."
 
Weighing the Costs
 While few people oppose the revival, it raises many of the issues that have confronted cities across the country as they try to address changes in industry and manufacturing and stanch the flow of corporations to the suburbs.
Some people wonder if the revival's costs, in tax abatements and other incentives from the city, have been too high. The city has spent $166 million in capital improvements in the downtown area since the mid-80's, and MetroTech incentives alone were $329 million.
Others fear that the influx of new workers will increase congestion. And there is worry that a polished corporate downtown, with all its new jobs, might leave the rest of the borough behind.
"You do have to ask the question of who benefits from this," said John H. Mollenkopf, a professor at the City University of New York's Graduate Center who has studied the politics of urban renewal. "What is the benefit to the Farragut Houses, right next door? What is the benefit to Fort Greene? Are there going to be positive impacts on the neighborhoods around it or is it just a commercial enterprise?"
 
An Alternative to New Jersey
 The budding new downtown was conceived a decade ago to not only to revive a beleaguered area, but to create an alternative for corporations thinking of moving back-office operations to New Jersey or Connecticut or beyond.
With its proximity to Manhattan, its confluence of transportation links and its cheaper costs, downtown Brooklyn -- bounded loosely by the approaches to the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, and Atlantic Avenue and Court Street -- was in many ways a natural location for a new hub.
But the projects' developers and borough officials, backed by City Hall and a 1983 study by the Regional Plan Association, envisioned something even greater. They dreamed of creating a high-technology center for financial and information services that would rival Silicon Valley in California -- one that could even lure foreign investment.
The nucleus of this new downtown -- called "Wall Street East" in radio commercials produced by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company -- has been MetroTech, a four-million-square-foot project created by a partnership between the city's Economic Development Corporation, Polytechnic University and a developer, the Forest City Ratner Companies.
It is far too early to tell how successful the redevelopment will be, but after years of fits and starts caused by resistance and litigation, uncertainty and recession, results have begun to appear.
In 1989, Morgan Stanley & Company moved into 19-story Pierrepont Plaza, the first office tower built in Brooklyn since the 1950's.
A year later, the Securities Industry Automation Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York and American Stock Exchange, moved its headquarters into the first new building in MetroTech.
In 1991, Livingston Plaza, a 12-story, 500,000-square-foot building, opened and is now the headquarters of the New York City Transit Authority.
Since then, three more buildings have opened in MetroTech, including Polytechnic's $42 million library and research center in January and a 23-story tower that in February became the new headquarters for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
Chase Manhattan Bank, lured to choose Brooklyn over New Jersey by a $234 million incentive package, the city's largest ever, has begun moving the first of 6,000 workers into one of the two buildings it will occupy there.
 
More Projects in Works
 Even as the Manhattan real estate boom of the 1980's has gone bust, with vacancy rates in midtown hovering between 15 percent and 20 percent, 95 percent of MetroTech has been leased. And in recent months, two other major projects have received big boosts.
The Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced in February that it would be the anchor tenant in Renaissance Plaza, a 31-story office tower with a Hilton Hotel as its base. For many, the Hilton, downtown Brooklyn's first major hotel to open since the 1930's, will be the final validation of Brooklyn as a business and commercial center.
And last month, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced that he would spend $7.8 million to jump-start Atlantic Center, an interminably stalled $530 million retail and housing development on top of the Long Island Rail Road Terminal at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues.
"It's like a tidal wave," the Borough President, Howard Golden, said. "It just took off, and it has not stopped yet."
In all, the $2.5 billion being invested in redevelopment is going to about five million square feet of new office space that has already drawn 5,000 new workers to downtown Brooklyn. By the end of the decade, officials predict, there will be 30,000.
 
'Spillover' Effect Seen
 While the developments may never return downtown Brooklyn to its former eminence, they have begun to transform it.
The streets around MetroTech are cleaner, and the new workers keep them bustling through the day and into the evening. In the 84th Precinct, which covers the downtown area as well as Brooklyn Heights, felony crimes, including robbery and assault, fell 23 percent from 1989 to 1991 -- a decline Deputy Inspector Jeremiah Quinlan attributed to the vastly greater number of people.
As boosters and developers have always predicted, the large developments have had a spillover effect on nearby downtown businesses. Several new shops have opened along Willoughby Street and in Fulton Mall, the sometimes struggling shopping strip just south of MetroTech, and others have spruced up their stores.
Moreover, Mr. Golden said he would allocate $500,000 in his borough budget for the new fiscal year to install scores of colorful, stranger-friendly road and street signs (which James Gardella, an aide to Mr. Golden, called "an antidote to the saying that 'only the dead know Brooklyn' ").
While the costs of the redevelopment have been high, City Hall contends the benefits of keeping companies like Chase far outweigh them. But a mayoral task force committee recently criticized the city for devoting nearly three-quarters of its capital budgets for economic development in the city to downtown Brooklyn while Manhattan's offices stand empty.
In the neighborhoods around downtown Brooklyn, the redevelopment has raised different concerns.
Carol Locke, an English teacher who lives in Boerum Hill, said the new towers, with their sleek corporate look, have made the area overly dense and replaced or overwhelmed many older buildings, which had given the downtown a certain historic romance.
"There's not too much to be romantic over anymore," Ms. Locke said.
She and other residents also fear that the projects will drive up rents and property costs and that the influx of workers will further congest the streets and overwhelm the subways and buses.
Residents' biggest concern, though, is that downtown Brooklyn will become an isolated bubble, shut off from the rest of the borough.
In part to avert such criticism and in part to satisfy the agreements they struck to win incentives from the city, the newly arrived companies have proposed job-training, work and scholarship programs for Brooklyn students.
"We want to go beyond the look of the area," said John V. Scicutella, the vice president of operations and systems for Chase, which, when it completes its move to MetroTech will become the borough's largest private employer. "We want to get to the guts of it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The renovation going on in downtown Brooklyn is so extensive that many are calling it a renaissance. It is embracing new stores and towers, and smaller details as well. A cement bench was sanded yesterday in the Fulton Mall. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. B1)

Roger Kahn
 64 years old ... Author of "The Boys of Summer" and a forthcoming book about baseball and integration in New York City.
 "It was a nice place to take a girl on Friday night. Movies came to Brooklyn a week after they opened at the Paramount in Manhattan. If you were hopelessly in love, you might take a girl to Manhattan. If it was casual, you'd take her to a neighborhood theater. But if it was somewhere in between -- you'd take her to the Brooklyn Paramount."
 
Harold L. Fisher
 81 ... lawyer, former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, treasurer of the Democratic Party of Kings County.
 "On Court, on Montague, on any of these streets, everybody knew everybody. It was a small town except with a big-town atmosphere.
 If I had a cold, the phone would start to ring. People knew I had a cold and they wanted to know what they could do to help. Now if you die, nobody knows.
 
Jerry Lawson
 47 ... singer with The Persuasions, an a cappella group formed in Brooklyn in the 1960's.

Map: "Brooklyn's Emerging Hub"
 
Commercial Prjects
 1. Pierrpont Plaza -- A 19-story office tower, completed in 1989. Primary tenant is Morgan Stanley & Company. Other tenants include Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Royal Bank of Canada.
 2. Livingston Plaza -- A 12-story, 500,000-square-foot office building, completed in 1991. The new offices of the New York City Transit Authority.
 
In Progress
 3. MetroTech -- A $1 billion commercial and academic complex on a 10-block, 16-acre site that is to include eight new and three renovated buildingss. Five buildings are complete or nearly complete. Brooklyn Union Gas Company moved its headquarters to One MetroTech earlier this year, and Chase Manhattan Bank has begun moving 6,000 emloyees int the first of two MetroTech buildings. Ten MetroTech, three blocks from the main complex in a rebuilt candy factory, will soon house offices of the Internal Revunue Service and the State Department of Motor Vehicles.
 
In Planning Stage
 4. Renaissance Plaza -- A $200 million, 31-story hotel and office tower. A Hilton Hotel will occupy the first seven floors. In February, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office Signed a 20-year lease to become the principal tenant, clearing the way for construction, expected to begin this summer.
 5. Atlantic Center -- A $530 million, two-million-square foot office, retail and housing complex on a 24-acre site above the Long Island Rail Road Terminal. The project includes a supermarket and more than 400 units of low-rise, moderate-income housing. Last week, Mayor Dinkins pledged $7.8 million to jump-start the long-stalled project, and developers say construction could begin within 12 months.
 6. 90 Sands Street -- A 30-story, 500-room hotel, being built by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, better known as the Jehovah's Witnesses. The hotel, for visitors to the church's downtown Brooklyn headquarters, is expected to open next year.

HEADLINE: New Claims For Jobless Benefits Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose by 10,000, to 424,000, in the week that ended on May 2, the Labor Department said today, reflecting the fragile state of the economic recovery.
The running four-week average of new filings -- viewed as a more accurate gauge of the labor market -- also rose for the first time since late March, to 411,500 from 409,500. 
 Economists said the figures were disappointing, since they had expected initial weekly jobless claims to fall to 410,000 in the latest reporting week.
"I think these numbers tell us we have a fragile recovery at best in the works," said Anthony Chan, senior economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc. He said the rise in the four-week average was "consistent with the inflation data."
"It's telling us the recovery is subdued," Mr. Chan said. "It's not a gung-ho recovery."
 
Stocks Decline on the News
 The stock market declined broadly after the report, as investors apparently reached the same conclusion. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.10 points, to 3,368.88, and declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The report also influenced the credit markets in early trading, sending prices of most securities up, because a slack economy would give the Federal Reserve room to ease credit further. But traders were more restrained later, because analysts tended to minimize the report's significance, saying it had been distorted by the Los Angeles riots. [Page D15.]
The Labor Department said it had revised its figure for initial claims in the week that ended on April 25 downward to 414,000 from the 415,000 reported previously.
It said the biggest increases in new claims in the week that ended on May 2 had been reported by North Carolina, New York and California. California said its unemployment claims had risen to 3,475, partly because its offices were closed for one day the week before.
The jobless situation may have been even worse than the report showed, because California also estimated that 2,600 people would have claimed jobless benefits in its 13 local offices in South-Central Los Angeles, but were unable to do so because the offices were closed for two days during the riots.
 
Fed Official Disappointed
 Lawrence Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve, told reporters before addressing a House Banking subcommittee that he found the report on jobless claims disappointing.
The Labor Department said North Carolina, with 5,578 new claims, had cited layoffs in its textile, apparel and furniture industries. New York cited service industry layoffs that contributed to its 4,954 new jobless claims. Michigan said its 2,485 new jobless claims resulted from layoffs in the auto industry.
Officials in Massachusetts, Illinois, New Jersey and Wisconsin reported decreases of more than 3,000 in new jobless claims.
The department said 14 states had reported increases, 37 declines and 2 no change.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 23.10, to 3,368.88, on Jobless Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market declined broadly yesterday after the Government reported yet another rise in initial claims for unemployment benefits.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.10 points, to 3,368.88.
Declining issues outnumbered advances by 1,180 to 549 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Volume on the Big Board came to 200.4 million shares, up from 175.9 million in the previous session.
 
Expecting Slow Recovery
 The market reflected expectations for a slow economic recovery. Recent economic data show little threat from inflation, which should help stocks, but offer little hope for enough economic growth to stimulate investors.
Reaffirming that sentiment, the Labor Department said yesterday that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose to 424,000 for the week ending May 2. It was the second straight weekly rise. Some economists had forecast claims at 410,000, down from 415,000 in the previous week.
In addition, many investors were apparently putting off buying stocks, speculating that the Federal Reserve might ease rates again as insurance against a backslide in the economy. Such a cut could help stock prices.
Another negative for the market is that while the Dow set a record closing high of 3,397.58 on Monday, it only briefly passed the 3,400 mark. And other, broader market indexes have not matched the Dow's performance, which adds to the downward pull, market analysts said.
 
Gains for Inventories
 Even the good news of better-than-expected business inventories did not support the market. The Commerce Department said yesterday that inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent, above the one-tenth of 1 percent that economists had forecast.
The Nasdaq composite index slid 5.92 points, to 576.46. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.72 points, to 227.72, while the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.96 points, to 391.79.
The most actively traded issue on the Big Board was Advanced Micro Devices, down 1 7/8, to 15 5/8, after a rival company said it would cut prices on an advanced computer chip.
Other active issues included the Gap, down 3 5/8, to 37 1/4, after analysts lowered the company's 1993 earnings estimates, and the Limited, down 1 1/8, to 21, on poor earnings, released earlier this week.
