HEADLINE: At the Bar;
A small claim turns into a brouhaha over welfare, individual rights and judicial freedom.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
The fight between Judge Eugene Kenny and Debbie Rivera began in a Jersey City courtroom. Then it went before the state's Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz. From there it moved to the airwaves, to the newsstands and to the supermarket checkout counter. Now it is once more back in court, this time in Newark.
Along the way, a small claim against a Union City check-cashing store has grown into an allegory about welfare, individual responsibility and judicial freedom. Ms. Rivera, a 27-year-old unwed, unemployed mother of three, has become a symbol of the underclass. And Judge Kenny, who spent his long legal career in obscurity, has become a folk hero -- first in New Jersey and now through the unlikely auspices of The National Enquirer, thoughout the country. 
 Round 1 of the case took place in March 1991, when Ms. Rivera appeared before Judge Kenny in the small claims section of Hudson County Superior Court. She said she had been shortchanged $340 when cashing her welfare check, and that unless things were righted, she and her children faced eviction.
The 76-year-old Judge Kenny, who had retired six years earlier but was recalled to help reduce court backlogs, ruled against Ms. Rivera. But he did not stop there. Instead, for the next five minutes he lambasted her: for having children out of wedlock to increase her welfare payments, for not holding down a job, for living off the largesse of state taxpayers. "People are being inundated around here, taking care of all these children," he said, reducing Ms. Rivera repeatedly to tears. "Money doesn't come out of the sky, does it? I'm getting fed up with it. A great many people are fed up with it, too."
"It was humiliating," Ms. Rivera recalled. "I've never gone through anything like that in my life." So she began Round 2, filing a complaint with court officials. When Judge Kenny refused to apologize, and after hearing a tape recording of the hearing, Chief Justice Wilentz directed that Judge Kenny be re-retired. That brought a howl from Judge Kenny.
"One of the great evils of the Age in which we live is the lack of Spine in those in authority," he wrote. "Are the Judges of New Jersey to be nothing but a collection of Wimps and Caspar Milquetoasts?"
In an interview, Judge Kenny stressed that he bore Chief Justice Wilentz no ill will. "He snatched me from obscurity and made me famous," he said. "But all you have to do is mention the word 'racism' and they go into orbit mentally."
For Judge Kenny, such interviews have become a way of life. In Rounds 3 through 6 he spoke to The New Jersey Law Journal, The Star-Ledger of Newark, The Record of Hackensack and the Asbury Park Press. In 7 through 21 he appeared on 14 television and radio talk shows, sometimes jointly with Ms. Rivera. His rhetoric got hotter. "Here's a woman who would climb into bed with anybody with a pair of pants on and have kids; she's good for another five or six," he told one questioner.
Judge Kenny has been blessed with all the blue ribbons of celebrity. People stop him on the street. Oprah called. He got a death threat. He has received a scrapbook full of letters, calling him a breath of fresh air, touting him for the Supreme Court.
"Thank you, thank you, thank you, for verbalizing what millions of people feel in their hearts," wrote Willard Andrews of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Another note came from Mrs. Henri Bendel. "Someone finally spoke out," she wrote from Sutton Place South. "Thanks. Hope you don't have to pay too great a price." A third letter was perhaps most representative. "I am 100 percent in agreement with your position on Debbie Rivera," this man said. "Chief Justice Wilentz has rocks in his head."
Then, in May 1991, The National Enquirer came calling. Judge Kenny, a Reagan Republican who still likes his Masses in Latin, is not your everyday National Enquirer reader. "I used to laugh when I saw their headlines -- 'ELVIS FOUND ON THE MOON,' " he said. But when an Enquirer reporter asked, he vented his spleen still more. His splenetic comments were promptly repackaged into a first-person article, replete with terms like "free ride," "lazy," "deadbeats" and "leeches."
"JUDGE LASHES BACK AFTER HE'S AXED FOR SCOLDING UNWED MOM," the raucous tabloid shrieked. Round 22.
In her defense, Ms. Rivera has said she has been unable to find work and receives some support from the father of one of her children. She said that the hubbub -- particularly the ridicule to which her 12-year-old daughter was subjected by her classmates -- forced her to move out of Jersey City.
But The National Enquirer article was too much. Now, with the help of Neil Mullin, a lawyer from West Orange, she is suing both Judge Kenny and The National Enquirer for libel and invasion of privacy.
Round 23, in Essex County Superior Court, has not yet been scheduled.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls for Federal Effort To Contain Health-Care Costs

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
In an address aimed as much at the Presidential candidates as at the medical school graduates sitting before him, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday called on the Federal Government to contain health-care costs and provide universal medical insurance.
At a Carnegie Hall ceremony, he told graduating members of the New York University School of Medicine's class of 1992 that the nation's poor, elderly and unemployed would never receive adequate health care unless the Government intervened. "Even if they did all New York State is doing, states acting alone could not tame the health-care monster," he said. "It is no longer a question of choice. We must have a national plan." 
 In a speech thin on details, Mr. Cuomo made clear he was primarily concerned with outlining issues he would like the Presidential candidates to address this summer.
 
Agenda for Debates
 But aides said Mr. Cuomo was also trying to set the agenda for coming Albany debates on health-care policy. In January the Cuomo administration plans to propose a package of bills to expand primary care for the urban and rural poor, said Michael J. Dowling, the state's director of health, education and human services.
In his speech yesterday, Mr. Cuomo said the Federal Government could control medical costs by capping health-care charges, just as New York State sets top rates hospitals can charge for most services.
In addition, costs could be contained by simplifying and computerizing billing systems and by avoiding "excessive" use of expensive advanced technologies, he said.
Accusing private health insurance companies of denying coverage to "poor people who get poor-people diseases," he said the Federal Government should provide insurance to anyone who could not get it otherwise.
Mr. Cuomo urged the graduates to consider careers as general practitioners in inner-city and rural areas instead of training to be specialists. "Reform will happen with or without the support of the doctors," he said. "But reform of the system won't work as well as it could unless you, the doctors, are actively involved."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Easing Is Seen as Less Likely

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mostly lower in slow trading yesterday, as chances faded for any reduction soon in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board.
The reason the market shifted its opinion about an imminent Fed move was a report late yesterday showing that money growth surged in the week ended May 4. 
 The report, issued by the Fed, showed that all three monetary aggregates posted big increases. The money measure that the Fed tracks most closely, M-2, rose by $9.8 billion, reversing declines recorded over the previous two weeks.
With the latest rise, M-2 growth is now back above the 2.5 percent level, which is the low end of the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent for the year.
Traders and Fed watchers have been paying close attention to the weekly money numbers recently, largely because last month the Fed cited weak money growth as the reason for its most recent cut in short-term interest rates.
 
No Easing Seen Before June
 Yesterday's spurt in money growth "eliminates the possibility of any easing before early June," said David M. Jones, a senior vice president and economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, primary dealers in government securities.
The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet in Washington on Tuesday. While an immediate move to cut rates now seems unlikely, Mr. Jones and other analysts expect that at the meeting the committee will give the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, the leeway to cut rates further, should conditions warrant.
"The F.O.M.C. will give Greenspan the discretion to ease," predicted Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. That is particularly likely, Mr. Liro said, if money growth falls below its target levels again or fresh evidence emerges that the economy is fading.
Mr. Jones added, "The fear the Fed has is that if they don't keep money within their target range, it raises the possibility that the economy will go into another sinking spell, as it did last year."
 
Signal on Federal Funds Rate
 The Fed, whose open market operations on Wednesday heightened speculation that the central bank may be on the verge of lowering short-term rates, did nothing yesterday to encourage such thinking.
Instead, analysts said the Fed sent a strong signal that its target for the overnight Federal funds rate remained at 3.75 percent: the central bank added reserves to the banking system when the Federal funds rate was trading at 3.8125 percent.
"The Fed clearly indicated that funds are still at 3.75 percent," one trader said. "If anybody doubted it before, they shouldn't any more."
Despite the Fed's signal, expections during most of the session remained strong that the Fed would move soon to cut short-term rates. Traders said that demand for shorter-term notes and bills was strong for most of the day.
But price gains that had been in place were wiped out after the money-supply figures were released.
During early trading, prices of most securities were somewhat bolstered by an unexpected rise in initial unemployment claims during the week ended May 2. The increase was the second in succession, but analysts tended to downplay its significance because of the riots in Los Angeles.
Indeed, Mr. Liro and others said the effect of the riots on claims data would probably make interpretation of those figures difficult for the next several weeks.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10117/32 , down 9/32 , to yield 7.86 percent, compared with 7.84 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 1012/32 , down 5/32 , to yield 7.34 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 101, down 2/32 , to yield 6.63 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/2, up 1/32 , to yield 5.10 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged late yesterday, after being lower for much of the session.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.58 percent in late trading, unchanged from Wednesday. And six-month bill rates were also unchanged, at a late rate of 3.68 percent.
In the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said activity was light and prices of most issues were unchanged.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Tax Credits of $8.5 Billion Received by 22 Drug Makers

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The General Accounting Office said yesterday that 22 American drug makers received $8.5 billion in Federal tax credits in the 1980's under a plan designed to increase employment in Puerto Rico. But, the report said, the tax credits were more than double the amount the companies spent on employee payrolls in Puerto Rico.
The report by the Congressional agency, in addition to raising questions about the wisdom of the tax-credit program or its application, is expected to add fuel to Congressional attempts to limit the steep increases that have been made in recent years in prices of prescription drugs. A tax credit exempts business income from taxation. 
 The G.A.O. said the pharmaceutical companies received an average of $70,788 in credits per employee in Puerto Rico in 1987, for example, compared with an average of $10,593 granted other industries. The reason is that other companies hire more employees in proportion to the tax credit. The average credit per employee in the electrical and electronics industries, for example, was $16,450, the report said.
 
Proposal to Reduce the Credit
 Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, and Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, said the report provided a clear illustration of the validity of their proposal to reduce the Puerto Rican tax credit for companies that raise drug prices faster than the general inflation rate. Prescription drug prices rose by 3 percent in the first quarter of 1992, while the Consumer Price Index rose 1 percent, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, said the Pryor bill would "change free-market incentives that have caused the pharmaceutical industry to flourish." The tax credits, he added, "have provided a powerful stimulus" for Puerto Rican development, which has benefited both the island's economy and the mainland's.
Spokesmen for the drug industry did not dispute the numbers in the report, but they said that the picture was incomplete and that the tax credits had helped the Puerto Rican economy as Congress intended. They said the G.A.O. analysis had omitted an estimated 4.7 additional jobs per employee, which the drug makers said were indirectly supported by pharmaceutical industry spending.
 
Johnson & Johnson Leads List
 The G.A.O. report said that Johnson & Johnson had the largest tax savings, an estimated $1.12 billion in credits for the 10 years. SmithKline Beecham was next with $987 million, followed by Abbott Laboratories, $860 million; Pfizer, $759 million; Upjohn $750 million, and Merck $749 million.
It added that Pfizer, with 500 employees in Puerto Rico, had tax savings of $156,400 per employee in 1989, followed by Merck, 953 employees and $110,493 per worker in credits; American Home Products, 1,000 employees and $80,600 per worker; Eastman Kodak's Sterling Drug unit, 350 employees and $77,143 per worker; Bristol-Myers Squibb, 1,440 employees and $74,097 per worker, and Upjohn, 775 employees and $58,452 per worker.
"This G.A.O. report proves that we squander billions of precious tax dollars on an industry which needs little help from the Federal Government," Senator Pryor said, citing 11 years of strong profits in pharmaceuticals. Senator Cohen said the Puerto Rican investment credit "has become a tax incentive that rewards the spiraling escalation of drug prices."
 
Effort for the Pryor Bill
 Mr. Pryor, who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Aging, and Mr. Cohen, the ranking Republican on the committee, plan to press for approval of the Pryor bill, committee aides said. The Senate voted in March against passing the measure as an amendment to the tax bill.
Commenting on the G.A.O. report, Pfizer said it now "employs over 700 people in Puerto Rico, and for each one of these employees it is estimated that four additional jobs have been created." Pfizer said its average payroll cost per employee was about $41,000, including nonstaff employees. The company added that it had invested $90 million in Puerto Rico in the last three years.
Merck said that in addition to its 950 employees in Puerto Rico, it had 400 contract workers there, so the average tax credit per employee would be $86,000, not $110,493.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds as Traders Focus on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded yesterday against most major currencies in light trading as the markets continued to focus on the outlook for interest rates.
Gold prices ended higher after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338 a troy ounce, up $2.40 from Wednesday's close. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $337.35 an ounce, up $1.75. 
 Currency traders said technical factors were largely responsible for giving a slight boost to the dollar after Wednesday's selloff. But they said the markets remained concerned about the state of the nation's money supply and the interest rate outlook here and in Germany.
 
Rise in Money Supply Reported
 After the close of most currency trading yesterday, the Federal Reserve reported that the money supply had risen a larger-than-expected $10.5 billion during the week that ended on April 27. That compared with an increase of $5.9 billion reported for the previous week.
"Everyone is focusing in on interest rates now," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. "The feeling is that they will go lower" if the money supply shows weakness.
A drop in rates would hurt the dollar, because dollar-denominated securities would become less valuable to investors.
Traders dumped dollars on Wednesday on speculation that the Fed might lower rates because inflation remained mild. The Government reported on Wednesday that the Consumer Price Index had risen a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the same as the month's Producer Price Index.
Concerns about higher German interest rates, because of continued labor unrest in that country, also worked against the dollar, traders said.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 129.87 yen, down 0.43 yen from Wednesday's price. It was quoted later at 130.20 yen in London and 130.15 yen in New York, up from 129.60 on Wednesday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared with Wednesday's levels. Sterling fetched $1.8215 in London, up from $1.8135, and $1.8215 in New York, down from $1.8275.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6115 German marks, up from 1.6090; 1.4730 Swiss francs, down from 1.4795; 5.4125 French francs, up from 5.4005; 1,213 Italian lire, up from 1,210.25, and 1.20295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20395.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Issues Entwined, Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE explosion of violence in Los Angeles and its spread to other cities have done what economic arguments and moral preachments had failed to do: force the nation's attention on its festering problems of race, poverty and jobs.
What sort of explosion will it take to make the nation see that it cannot neglect its international responsibilities? America cannot choose to deal with either its domestic or its international problems; the two are bound together in this post-cold-war era. 
 Thus far, the peace dividend is being paid in lost jobs and incomes in many countries. Theoretically, there is no reason that this must be so: a peace dividend should permit a nation to spend more on welfare-enhancing consumer goods and services and on productivity-raising investment. But that happens only if a nation's workers are prepared and trained to take new jobs and if a reallocation of financial resources helps create those jobs.
In the absence of such shifts of human and physical resources, strong economic pressures to maintain high military spending, and to sell weapons wherever buyers can be found, will continue.
The dangers of both nuclear and nonnuclear proliferation are fed by economic interests. The United States has just imposed a two-year ban on exports to a Russian arms agency and to the Indian Space Research Organization because of a transfer by Russia to India of sensitive technology with military applications.
At a meeting in New York this week, Andrei I. Kolosovsky, Russia's Deputy Ambassador to the United States, said this transfer of military technology was for peaceful purposes. But he added that Russia would continue to make "normal military sales" to other countries, just as the United States, China, Israel, Czechoslovakia, Sweden and others were doing.
Mr. Kolosovsky attributed Russia's continuing high rate of military spending to its "military-industrial complex," using the same phrase President Dwight D. Eisenhower employed in his farewell address. The diplomat said that his country's military-industrial complex achieved its strength through its efficiency and its ability to create jobs and earn foreign exchange and capital.
Nevertheless, he said, it is crucial for the world to achieve "a general curbing of military sales" to ease tensions between nations and to further economic development.
The United States showed just how this could be done after World War II. It slashed military spending and stepped up private domestic investment, while aiding the war-ravaged countries. And the world economy entered the longest and strongest period of economic growth in history.
The situation that confronts the United States and the rest of the world today is radically different from the one it faced at the end of World War II. The United States itself is not in a position to supply the kind of capital that it once did, nor are Germany and Japan. And even as a new world economy emerges, new disintegrative threats are evident: the struggle for resources, especially oil; national and ethnic strife unleashed by the breakup of the Soviet Union, and the danger of a splitting apart of the world trading system.
America has assumed the leadership role in fighting to preserve the open world trading system that it largely created after World War II. In its efforts to liberalize agriculture, it is trying to open the world up not only to its own agricultural exports but also to those of Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union and the third world.
The outcome of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations will determine whether the world economy keeps moving forward or breaks into hostile trading blocs.
The collapse of the Soviet Union resulted from economic and political failures, rather than from direct military actions by its enemies. In the post-cold-war environment, threats to any nation's economic interests are being seen as a greater danger than threats to its territorial integrity. But even if the dangers of territorial conquest have diminished, other dangers persist, such as local or regional wars, ethnic and nationalistic violence, terrorism, spreading drug use, environmental hazards that could poison the human race and the possibilities of an economic collapse that could sow political revolutions and wars, as economic breakdowns have done in the past.
Maintaining an adequate defense of United States national interests will continue to provide significant costs on the Federal budget, even after making relatively optimistic assumptions about the reduced Soviet threat and the negotiation of future arms control agreements. A stable world order will require a strong military power capable of enforcing contracts and keeping the peace, although security, as we have learned, does not depend on military strength alone. A lasting peace will depend on strengthening the economy, both at home and abroad.

HEADLINE: Senate Kills Liability Limit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The Senate today rejected a 10-year effort by manufacturers and other business groups to limit the ability of consumers to collect punitive damages in cases involving faulty products.
On a 53-to-45 vote, the Senate turned down a measure by Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, to establish nationwide standards on how much consumers can recover in suits against manufacturers. 
 It was unclear what effect the Senate vote would have on further attempts to change the nation's product liability laws; some senators said they had voted against the measure on purely procedural grounds, while others had opposed it on the merits.
Republicans tried to attach the measure championed by Vice President Dan Quayle to a Democratic bill that would require states to let people register to vote when they apply for driver's licenses, unemployment benefits or welfare.
The measure would deny a plaintiff the ability to collect all the pain and suffering damages from a manufacturer of a faulty product if other factors were involved in the mishap.
It would also eliminate the contingency fee system in which lawyers agree to represent plaintiffs in product liability suits for a percentage share of any settlement or jury award. Plaintiff consumers would have to pay the legal costs of defendant manufacturers if they lose the case after rejecting an earlier settlement offer.
Supporters contended the measure could reduce manufacturers' insurance and other costs by hundreds of millions of dollars a year and make their products much more competitive in world markets.
Opponents, led by trial lawyers and consumer groups, said there was little evidence that juries had awarded plaintiffs unreasonable damages in such suits. But, they said, the measure would intimidate victims into giving up their constitutional right to have a jury hear their case.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Decline at Hanson

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, May 14

 BODY:
Hanson P.L.C., the British industrial conglomerate, said today that its second-quarter net profit fell 20 percent despite a sharp rise in sales.
The company said it earned 227 million, or $395 million, in the three months that ended March 31 compared with 285 million a year earlier. Sales rose 18 percent, to 2.4 billion, or $4.11 billion, from 2 billion a year earlier. 
 Earnings per share came to 38 cents per American depository receipt, compared with 48 cents in the quarter last year. A.D.R.'s are securities traded on American exchanges representing shares in foreign companies.
Hanson's American operations include SCM Chemicals, Peabody Coal, Beazer, Farberware Cookware and Gold Fields Mining.
Lord White, chairman of Hanson's North American operations, said: "Recently we have begun to see some signs of recovery in North America. But we anticipate this process will be slower than in other recent recessions and we remain cautious in our production planning until more concrete evidence of a sustained upturn occurs."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
The two most important weeks of the spring auctions in New York ended on Wednesday night, and the mood was one of great relief. Given the current economy, things could have been worse -- much worse. After the slump of the last 18 months, the market for Impressionist, modern and contemporary art -- the bread and butter of both Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's largest auction houses -- began inching its way back to life. While total sales were less than the auction houses' estimates, the number of new bidders and the enthusiasm in the salesrooms showed a marked change since the November sales.
"It came as almost a shock," said Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York. "But the message is clear: it's still a delicate market. Buyers are looking hard at estimates. And people must not be too optimistic about prices' rising in the near future. The same low figures must continue." 
 While buyers eagerly fished for bargains, many star works sold for strong prices. At the Impressionist and modern sales, dealers were as surprised as the auction-house experts as they watched works by artists like Chagall and Miro, Toulouse-Lautrec and Renoir -- the first to be dumped when the market crashed in 1990 -- sell at or above their estimates. "Many were fresh to the market and came at good prices," said Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's. Highlights of the week included: successful estate sales, a new interest in contemporary artists who made their reputations in the 1980's, excessive prices for works on paper and marginal interest in works that had only recently been on the market.
Totals for the last two weeks showed Christie's running almost $11 million ahead of Sotheby's. Christie's spring auctions made a total of $74.4 million, which was less than its pre-sales estimate of $80.5 million. Sotheby's made $63.4 million, well below its low estimate of $79.7 million. While neither house did as well as it had hoped, experts at each contend that in a poor economy, estimates are especially hard to gauge. After the shaky sales in November, it was difficult to predict exactly where the market stood.
"There's still money out there," Mrs. Brooks said. "American collectors -- some old, many new -- created the enthusiasm for buying." At the sales of Impressionist and modern art, American collectors were major buyers.
At Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday evening, sales totaled $33.8 million. Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art was in two parts. On Monday evening, the collection of the interior designer William A. McCarty-Cooper was sold in an auction that totaled $21.5 million. The next evening, Christie's featured a general sale of Impressionist and modern art, which fetched $30 million.
Gone are the days of the $82.5 million picture of 1990. In the last two weeks, when an entire auction made $33.8 million, as Sotheby's did on Wednesday night, the sale was considered a success.
The highest price paid this spring was $7.7 million for Braque's "Studio VIII" from the William A. McCarty-Cooper collection, which was sold at Christie's on Monday night. But that was an exception. In November anything more than $1 million was a hard sell, but now there is active bidding for works that fetch about $2 million. At Christie's sale on Tuesday, Chagall's "Bouquet of Flowers," from 1937, was the most expensive picture. It sold to Scharf Fine Art of Manhattan for $2.8 million, just above the low estimate of $2.5 million. Sotheby's priciest painting was Renoir's "Portrait of Jean Renoir," which an unidentified South American collector bought for $2.3 million.
Gone are the speculators who made news in the 1980's, furiously snapping up what one dealer described as "pretty colors across a crowded room." This spring the salesrooms had a different feeling. They were full, but by no means as packed as they were in the boom years. The social voyeurs and movie stars, who made auctions into television spectacles five years ago, had vanished. Instead, serious collectors and world-famous dealers gathered to watch, to bid and to buy in a bargain-hunter's paradise. "It felt like sales in England in the 50's," said Michael Findlay, who heads the department of Impressionist and modern art at Christie's. "The auctioneer knew every face in the room."
But in the discreet 90's, both auction houses' telephones were in constant use. Buyers no longer wanted to be seen. Indeed, Sotheby's and Christie's shop-at-home service became the favored way to buy art. Telephone bidding wars occurred in every sale.
"Buyers were black and white," said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads Sotheby's department of contemporary art. "If they wanted something, they went after it hammer and tong." If they didn't, bidding ground to a halt.
Enthusiasm and price were inextricably bonded. With the exception of a few stunning works, buyers tended to stop bidding at the auction house's low estimate. And estimates at both houses were substantially lower than they had been six months ago. Now David Nash, head of Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern art, estimates that price levels have sunk back to what they were in 1985-86.
One problem that auction houses face coming out of a slump is finding good properties. Few sellers willingly put works on the block. As a result, the auction houses had to rely on getting property or consignments from sellers who needed to liquidate their art assets.
This spring, estates helped bring to the market works that hadn't been up for sale for 30 to 40 years. "Estates give us flexibility that's important in this economy," Mr. Burge said. Since estates usually have high taxes to pay, auction houses have the luxury of putting unusually low reserves on works of art. (The reserve is the minimum price, agreed upon by the seller and the auction house, at which a work of art will sell.)
By far the splashiest estate sale was at Christie's on Monday night, when important works from the collection of William A. McCarty-Cooper were on the block. Mr. McCarty-Cooper, who died last May at the age of 53, was the companion and adopted son of Douglas Cooper, the world-renowned authority on Cubism. Besides the record-breaking Braque, more than 45 exceptional works on paper by artists including Picasso, Braque, Gris and Leger were up for sale. Many went for high prices. Picasso's "Man With a Lollipop," estimated at $600,000 to $800,000, was sold to an unidentified American collector for $968,000. "If these drawings had gone in a bull market, they would have gone for 10 to 20 percent higher," Mr. Findlay said. "They brought out the real hard-core collector."
It was a strong spring for drawings. At Sotheby's, two interesting drawings' collections fared well. Those belonging to Sidney E. Cohn, a New York labor-relations and entertainment lawyer who died last summer, sold for high prices on Wednesday evening, as did 15 Impressionist drawings in the same sale that until recently belonged to the Manhattan dealer William Acquavella. Although many came with high estimates, bidders were not intimidated. Matisse's "Seated Woman in a Romanian Blouse With Embroidered Motifs," with an estimate of $800,000 to $1 million, was sold to an unidentified bidder for $1.1 million.
 
Distress Sales
 The casualties at the sales were works that had come on the market not so very long ago. In this category was "La Loge," by Renoir. This 1874 work depicting Nini, a Montmartre model, sitting in a box at the opera with Renoir's younger brother Edmond, was on the block at Christie's Tuesday night. The work was last at auction at Christie's in New York in May 1989, at the height of the Impressionist market. Hermann Schnabel, a German collector and fertilizer manufacturer, bought it for $12.1 million. This time around, Christie's estimated it would bring $6 million to $8 million. But bidding stopped at $5.2 million, and the work went unsold.
Buyers came from all over the world this spring. There was even some Japanese bidding, something that had totally disappeared last fall. Besides activity from American collectors, Europeans, South Americans and Mexicans did their share of shopping. At Christie's and Sotheby's, both British-based, electronic boards at the head of salesrooms translate currencies during the bidding. Christie's electronic board has room for only six currencies. Traditionally, they always have shown British pounds, French francs, Swiss francs, Deutsche marks, lire and yen. This spring, Mexican pesos were added, reflecting the arrival of Mexicans in the market.
What was dropped to make room? The pound.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
It Gets Bigger, Weirder and Tenser

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Sex, Death and God in L.A.
Edited and with an introduction by David Reid
Illustrated. 356 pages. Pantheon Books. $23.
"In the strange new post-modern imperium we live in," writes David Reid in the introduction to this new anthology, "Los Angeles, at the very least, has become the American city the world watches for signs and portents." 
 Given the riots that rocked Los Angeles in the wake of the Rodney G. King verdict, those words seem especially prescient. Indeed, "Sex, Death and God in L.A." includes several essays that help illuminate the racial and class tensions that have been escalating recently in Los Angeles.
The Los Angeles in these essays is a vast and troubled megalopolis, a city in which "the imagination of disaster," as Mr. Reid calls it, is less a literary conceit than a mirror of a daily reality, defined by racism, crime, unemployment and rampant alienation. It is a Los Angeles that stands in shocking contrast, like a grainy black-and-white photo juxtaposed with a lush color lithograph, to the Los Angeles depicted in this volume's other pieces -- pieces that dwell on a more popular image of the city as La-La Land, home of movie stars, new-age gurus, crackpots, hustlers and wannabes.
The selection of essays in "Sex, Death and God in L.A." is so eclectic that one suspects that Mr. Reid wants to startle the reader into an appreciation of the city's shocking diversity. Ruben Martinez's fierce, poignant portrait of a Hispanic community stands in sharp contrast to a satiric portrait of Hollywood by Jeremy Larner that will remind readers of Michael Tolkin's novel "The Player." Similarly, Eve Babitz's tart, funny piece about encounters with "yoga jocks" and tango aficionados is juxtaposed with a tough yet lyrical memoir by Lynell George, an L.A. Weekly writer who reminisces about growing up in a neighborhood where "best friends played fatal games with loaded guns" and students in junior high school "went to more funerals than weddings."
In one of the book's more timely essays, Mike Davis, the author of a critically acclaimed study of Los Angeles titled "City of Quartz," provides the reader with a quick, devastating portrait of a part of Los Angeles, ravaged, in his view, by both deindustrialization and mindless redevelopment.
Unemployment among the city's blacks, Mr. Davis points out, has risen by nearly 50 percent since the early 1970's. Jobs were lost not only to the recent wave of factory closings, but also to the rise of "a third-world sector within the regional economy, based on the minimum-wage labor of immigrants without citizen rights."
"With 78,000 unemployed youth in the Watts-Willowbrook area," Mr. Davis goes on, "it is not surprising that there are now 145 branches of the rival Crips and Bloods gangs in south L.A., or that the jobless resort to the opportunities of the burgeoning 'crack' economy."
According to Mr. Davis, Los Angeles "makes no contribution from the general city revenue for social programs for the poor" and has instituted "no housing planning or social policy" to accommodate the rapid influx of new low-wage residents. In the last decade, a million immigrants have moved into older black and Chicano neighborhoods, he says, and as a result, "a dense, continuous ring of slum housing" has sprung up around Downtown Los Angeles.
In a very different sort of essay, the architectural historian Thomas S. Hines argues that the city's "spirit of experimentation" has helped foster "pioneering manifestations of architectural thought and practice" in Los Angeles.
"Four highly vulnerable concepts," he explains, "best categorize this development: first, the idea of 'Craftsman' or 'Mission Modernism' as epitomized in the work of Irving Gill; second, the concept of 'Romantic Modernism' as exemplified primarily in the Los Angeles buildings of Frank Lloyd Wright"; third, "the idea of Machine Modernism, or as they liked to call it, 'Rational Modernism,' as illustrated primarily in the work of Richard Neutra," and fourth, "the movement that some have labeled 'Mineshaft Modern' or 'Deconstructivist' as exemplified in the work of Frank Gehry and his school."
Though Mr. Hines's essay provides a succinct and accessible introduction to these architects' work, he frequently veers away from the subject of their impact on Los Angeles. A similar discursiveness characterizes Mr. Reid's own essay on religious movements in the city, which is filled with lengthy digressions about Krishnamurti and Aimee Semple McPherson.
In finishing this volume, the reader can't help but wish that its scope were broader, its reach a little longer. One misses older pieces of fiction -- by Nathanael West, Raymond Chandler, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Christopher Isherwood -- that capture the mood of the city; and one wonders why pieces by more contemporary writers like Joan Didion, Leon Bing (the author of "Do or Die," a chilling portrait of gang life in Los Angeles), the architectural historian Reyner Banham (the author of "Los Angeles: The Architecture of Four Ecologies") and the historian Kevin Starr (the author of "Inventing the Dream: California Through the Progressive Era") weren't included as well.
As far as it goes, however, "Sex, Death and God in L.A." is a provocative and involving book -- the sort of book that makes you want to read more about Los Angeles, the sort of book that compels you to think about the mind-boggling disparities -- social, economic and cultural -- that exist within the boundaries of Los Angeles and so many other American cities.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Letter From Germany

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
Bill Clinton will not be happy to hear what German political and business leaders say about him. Nor will George Bush be thrilled.
German thinking on these two men is almost a non sequitur: We still very much need U.S. leadership, presence and strength. We're worried about America sinking economically and turning inward. We don't think Bush will do anything to turn this situation around. But we're against Clinton. 
 Yes, Germans prefer the familiar devil. They are also profoundly grateful for Mr. Bush's support on reunification.
But Mr. Clinton comes to the Germans with two big strikes against him. First, they fear he will bring the Carter foreign policy team back to Washington. Jimmy Carter's international record may look better in retrospect to Americans, but most European and Asian leaders still see his tenure as the dark ages of American naivete. Second, they see Democrats as protectionists. To Germans, mistakenly, Bill Clinton equals Representative Richard Gephardt, the symbol of Democratic get-tough trade policies.
The only thing even well-informed Germans know -- and like -- about the Arkansas Governor's world view is his aid program for the former Soviet Union. As for Ross Perot, they regard him as a King Kong cartoon, a peculiarly American figure who inspires terror or amusement.
As much as Germans fret about America, they worry far more about themselves. Germany has rarely managed internal turmoil as well as its Western neighbors, and it is going through a particularly difficult patch at the moment with labor strikes.
For centuries, the Romans fought to keep the German barbarians at bay. Now the "barbarians" are struggling to fend off latter-day "Romans" from Eastern and Southern Europe who they feel will plunder their homeland. Political leaders ineffectually try to navigate between the public's sense of guilt and anger about these foreigners. Meanwhile the situation ripens for right-wingers who simply want to throw the aliens out.
As explosive, and far more complicated, is the absorption of 17 million eastern Germans. Bonn has undertaken the largest welfare program in history. The commitment is to bring Easterners to economic parity in a decade. Its American equivalent would be lifting the bottom 20 percent of society to middle-class status by the year 2000.
The enterprise will be heartening and ugly. Karola von Braun, a Berlin political leader and niece of the rocket scientist, tells this story of exploitation. Businesses are firing blue-collar West Berliners and hiring East Berliners at about half the salary. New jobs at lower wages are also going eastward. No one feels good about this; neither easterners working for less than their counterparts, nor westerners losing jobs.
The culture clash makes economic matters worse. United Germany remains two Germanys. For 40 years, the West went democratic. Meantime, tens of thousands of East Germany's political elite continued Nazi-like ways as Communists. Even now they occupy the choicest apartments in eastern Berlin and eastern Germany and hang like a dark cloud over their countrymen. These nasties are justly hounded by former dissidents, idealists who also harangue western Germans with unwanted cries of justice and equality.
And the western Germans are paying the huge equalization bill -- by borrowing and going very deeply and dangerously into debt. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has only recently begun to acknowledge that he underestimated the costs. But neither he nor other politicians have the stomach to raise taxes or cut spending.
German pols flee from facing their voters with hard choices with the same deer-like agility found now in almost every Western democracy. "We have no federal or state elections for 18 months, so there is a slight possibility of doing something in this time," explained Otto Lambsdorff, the brash and formidable leader of the Free Democratic Party. "But then we have 19 elections in one year, and nothing will be accomplished." A melancholy observation about elections and democracy.
Leaders fear voters' greed and ignorance; and voters are losing confidence in their leaders' ability to govern. This is the real danger in Germany and elsewhere. Thus democracy doth make cowards of us all.

LENGTH: 1749 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
The Hand That Shakes Digital Up

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 14

 BODY:
At the Digital Equipment Corporation, the financially troubled computer maker, power struggles have long been a way of life. But if the clash involved Kenneth H. Olsen, Digital's founder and president, the outcome was always a foregone conclusion.
Last year, John Rose, a 16-year Digital veteran who spent several years leading the company's catch-up efforts in the personal computer market, was stunned to discover that Mr. Olsen had created a competing group that was pursuing a vastly different strategy for the company. 
 In fact, the group was proposing that a personal computer designed and built in Taiwan would become Digital's predominant personal computing product. Mr. Rose tried to start discussions about what the right approach for the company might be, but he was rebuffed by Mr. Olsen.
"I never got to go before the executive committee," said Mr. Rose, who left Digital in March.
The episode was quintessential Digital under Mr. Olsen, who has a penchant for squaring off competing activities to spur innovation. "If you don't have competition pressuring you, you just won't move," Mr. Olsen said.
For decades, that strategy has worked. But after a total of $400 million in losses over the last nine months -- the worst financial performance by the company in its 35-year history -- the spotlight is casting the Olsen style in a different light.
Among the more puzzling developments were two major restructurings in three months. Now many people are questioning whether the 66-year-old Mr. Olsen knows what is needed and whether he is an obstacle rather than a catalyst for yet another recovery at the company.
Mr. Olsen, intent on bringing Digital out of its malaise, is angry, at his management as well as the press and stock analysts, for quizzing him on what is going on. He is reportedly delivering long, angry sermons at executive committee meetings and threatening to sell Digital to General Electric if things do not get better.
 
Widespread, Complex Problems
 Many Digital executives say the company's problems are widespread and complex. The company has solid products but is paralyzed by a lack of a clear strategic direction and strong management. Morale is low, with impending personnel cuts: 10,000 jobs have already been eliminated and up to 15,000 more will go starting July 1.
On top of that, many customers have become confused by too many products and shifting messages from the company about its commitment to important strategies and products.
"In the 1980's Digital had a clear message," said Stephen Smith, a computer industry analyst at Paine Webber in New York. "These days they are throwing a lot of balls in the air and seeing if they can catch one. They've gone from one architecture to multiple architectures, from a single operating system to multiple operating systems. They seem rudderless right now, and customers are very confused."
The company's board, which has never openly opposed Mr. Olsen, is concerned over the financial situation and is paying close attention. Within the last few weeks, John F. Smith, Digital's senior vice president of operations, presented a new cost-cutting plan to the board.
In addition, the company has been without a chief financial officer for several months since James Osterhoff left in frustration last year. One internal candidate said the board had pushed for an outside replacement. Mr. Smith said such a replacement would be named in a few weeks. So far, the company has narrowed the field to two outside candidates.
 
Loss of Talented People
 Mr. Olsen's autocratic style has caused dozens of talented people to leave the company over the years, but as revenue and profits grew, outsiders did not much care.
But some Digital managers say his intimate scrutiny keeps the senior management focused on internal politics rather than on the competition, which is grabbing chunks of Digital's markets in work stations and mid-range systems.
In a recent interview, Mr. Olsen said that two years ago he recognized that the company was too caught up building computers and not solving needs of customers.
The poor economy and a misplaced focus on what the customer really wants are to blame for Digital's falling revenues, he said. "We were selling computers, while the customers wanted solutions to business problems," he said. "You can see at DECworld that we've addressed that."
At DEC World, the company's impressive three-week exhibition of its wares that is winding up Friday in downtown Boston, is a showcase of the company's innovative technology and solid product line.
To outsiders, Mr. Olsen gives his usual assurance that all is well within Digital. The former research engineer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who co-founded Digital with $70,000 in borrowed cash, has displayed an uncanny knack for pulling Digital out of wrenching dilemmas in the past while single-handedly guiding the company to become a $14 billion international giant, the nation's No. 2 computer company. More than once, Mr. Olsen has withstood calls for his resignation only to emerge stronger than ever.
 
Drop in Business Brings Big Loss
 "Business doesn't have to drop very much in order cause a big loss," Mr. Olsen said. "This is something people -- often analysts of all people -- don't fully understand. If you make 10 percent profit and your business drops 10 percent, you've wiped the whole thing out."
To return to profitability, Mr. Olsen is pushing for change. Digital is whittling away at its number of product offerings, trying to make selling easier for its sales force and simpler for its customers. Also, portions of Digital's sales force will soon be receiving some commissions as an incentive, a dramatic change from the company's longstanding policy of paying salespeople straight salaries.
But is it enough to get Digital back on track? Mr. Olsen says organizational shake-ups are good for the company, but insiders point dejectedly to a growing list of recent high-level Digital departures, especially William D. Strecker, former vice president of engineering and leading player in shaping product strategy. In the most recent reshuffling -- the company's second in three months -- Mr. Strecker lost another power struggle with Mr. Olsen.
Though he remains at Digital in the new post of chief of technology, Mr. Strecker is no longer leading the company's technical development. Mr. Olsen said this was good time for Mr. Strecker, who is 48 years old, to take some time off and figure out what he wanted to do. Mr. Strecker declined to comment on the matter.
Mr. Strecker is understood to have opposed Digital's move into mainframe computing three years ago, which Mr. Olsen championed. Digital's VAX9000 mainframe reportedly cost more than $1 billion to build, arrived late to the market and has been a financial disaster for the company.
Mr. Strecker reportedly pushed hard for Digital to form an alliance with Apple Computer last year, but Mr. Olsen opposed such a move. Apple eventually made an agreement with International Business Machines Corporation instead. Mr. Strecker, believing Digital needed a key alliance with a major player in desktop computing, then pushed hard for the agreement recently completed with Microsoft Corporation.
Digitial insiders say Mr. Olsen strongly opposed that alliance, too, but that Mr. Strecker refused to back down. The alliance was officially signed in April, with Mr. Olsen happily introducing Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, to the crowd at Digital's DEC World exhibition two weeks ago. The hard push toward Microsoft cost Mr. Strecker his engineering job, his associates say. "The Microsoft deal was the straw that broke the camel's back," said one executive.
Digital's problems appear to be as complex and confusing as its legendary matrix organization, in which layers of management disseminate mountains of data seeking consensus within Digital. All of this takes time and can be derailed by a word from Mr. Olsen.
To Mr. Olsen, "I have a simple set of management rules."
"I set up everything so that it runs automatically without me," he said. "When things run ideally, I have nothing to do. And then in those areas which aren't working well or need changes, I am not at all embarrassed to get involved in great detail, extreme detail when that is what is necessary to solve a particular problem."
He insists that the huge jobs cuts resulted from more efficient methods of building and servicing products and had nothing to do with the recession. "These are not jobs that will ever come back," he said.
Mr. Olsen refuses to make company policy based on newspaper articles or consultants' opinions. "I always have a model of the company or portion of the company I'm working on and am clearly going in a direction," he said. "It always takes longer than I expect, because changing people takes longer than I think it would."
Mr. Olsen said those within the company who were disgruntled were only those like Mr. Rose who left after the showdown on Digital's personal computer strategy. "When you get into trouble is when people want to hang on to the way we used to do things," he said. He said that one failure at Digital was not moving managers around enough to learn how to be senior executives.
Mr. Olsen insisted that he was not possessive about Digital. "It's a professional job," he said. "It's never been my company. From the start, we said we will only run it as long as we're the best."
Most Digital employees remain intensely loyal to Mr. Olsen. William Johnson, vice president of marketing, said that although there had been delays in the introduction of products, particularly one that links computer systems, he did not blame Mr. Olsen.
"We were a year and a half late offering a TCPIP product," Mr. Johnson said. "That wasn't Ken's fault. That's what he pays me for. When I look at our senior staff, it's very formidable, but I can't think of anybody, inside or outside, who could take over who is as dynamic as Ken is."
Mr. Olsen said he had no intention of turning over the reins to anyone else. Critics say he has effectively blocked any rising stars within Digital from gaining broad enough management skills to replace him.
Whether Mr. Olsen is able to lead Digital out of its current morass remains to be seen. Critics say it will be a difficult task. Mr. Olsen remains upbeat. "We've lived through many recessions," he said. "This is just one more."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 882 words

HEADLINE: FLIGHT OF HAITIANS SUDDENLY RESUMES

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREAT ABACO ISLAND, the Bahamas, May 15

 BODY:
Haitians have suddenly resumed the flight from their country aboard small boats in numbers that surpass the surge seen in October in the aftermath of a violent military coup.
With an average of almost 250 people a day being plucked from the seas off Haiti in recent weeks, the number being temporarily housed at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba has risen to about 8,500, from a low of 2,000 in March. On Wednesday, one of the busiest days yet, 903 Haitians on 11 rickety vessels were plucked from the seas. 
 When relatively few Haitians were found at sea in March, officials thought the exodus had crested. But now, exasperated officials see new urgency in diplomatic efforts to restore Haiti's elected Government.
Diplomats from the Organization of American States are to meet Sunday in the Bahamas to discuss Haiti.
Officials seeking to explain the resurgence in refugees point to the dramatic deterioration of living conditions in the island nation, in large part because of a hemisphere-wide trade embargo imposed last November to punish the coup leaders.
Some officials also complain that while the Coast Guard has stopped Haitian vessels from reaching the United States, a sizable portion of those picked up have been admitted to pursue grants of asylum, thus encouraging many others to risk the voyage.
Others stress the calm seas and favorable winds, which may encourage more Haitians to risk voyages in often frail and leaky boats. The authorities say that they have no estimate of how many have drowned and that none have made it to the mainland of the United States.
In an interview on Thursday, a senior State Department official estimated that the combined costs of the settlement at Guantanamo and the Coast Guard's interdiction had risen to over $60 million since the Sept. 30 coup. Immigration officials said their costs stood at over $6 million.
"The level of exasperation is high," one immigration official said, "not simply out of frustration with the results but because this is beginning to cause a serious money crunch. The figures are rising rapidly, there is no end in sight and none of this is budgeted."
In order to handle the latest surge, the Immigration and Naturalization Service recently sent 40 staff members to Guantanamo to determine which Haitians would be allowed into the United States.
In addition to budgetary problems, the flight of Haitians has fueled tensions between the agencies involved.
Facing criticisms and lawsuits in the United States from advocates for the refugees, the immigration service has sharply increased the number of Haitians it qualifies to pursue claims for political asylum. Close to a third of the 29,000 Haitians who have fled since the coup against the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide have been approved for entry into the United States.
 
Defining 'Political Refugee'
 State Department officials say the high ratio of Haitians being allowed into the United States is acting as a magnet, encouraging others to claim political persecution and flee their country.
"We feel the rate of those being screened in does not reflect the reality," said a senior State Department official. "These numbers are extraordinary and are out of line with the situation on the ground in Haiti.
The official said the State Department had stepped up its efforts to monitor human rights in Haiti, citing a survey of 2,000 Haitians who had given political motives for their flight but had been returned to Haiti. There was "no evidence that these people are political refugees," the official said.
The Pentagon has also begun to chafe under the refugee burden, complaining that the use of the Guantanamo base was a source of friction with the Cuban Government and an unsustainable strain on the resources of the base and the Coast Guard.
 
Coast Guard as Magnet
 Both immigration and State Department officials complain that the Coast Guard, by setting up a battery of ships just over the horizon from Haiti, have encouraged the exodus.
"They have gone from being a deterrent to becoming a magnet," said one official, who said the extremely flimsy boats now being used suggested that the refugees expected to be picked up quickly.
In order to relieve the pressure on Guantanamo and further discourage the exodus, officials from several agencies said new thought is being given to encouraging another country to set up a processing center for Haitians.
 
Other Forms of Pressure
 At the same time, the United States is stepping up diplomatic pressure on Haiti's provisional Government to accept an international settlement that would set the stage for the return of the Father Aristide as President. The provisional Government, backed by the military, has rejected such a settlement and has ruled out Father Aristide's return.
At the meeting Sunday of the Organization of American States, diplomats say, the United States and other countries will urge harsher measures against Haiti's leaders, including a restriction of air traffic, a tightening of the trade embargo aimed especially at oil sales and a request to European nations that they also halt trade with Haiti.
Officials concerned that such measures might also speed the flight of refugees say increased humanitarian assistance may also be required.

HEADLINE: EMPIRE IN TROUBLE;
Big Canadian Developer Trying To Confine Bankruptcy Damage

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
After fighting a losing battle to avoid bankruptcy in Canada, Olympia & York Ltd., the world's largest real estate developer, pressed its lenders yesterday to allow it to keep control of its prized properties in New York and London.
Olympia & York's strategy is to try to retain as much of its empire as possible to lay a foundation for a restructured and financially viable company, all accomplished without the complexities and risks of a lengthy bankruptcy proceeding in the United States, which could take control of Olympia & York out of the hands of the Reichmann family of Toronto. 
 In London yesterday, Olympia & York's directors met with bankers to seek assurances that the ill-fated Canary Wharf development in London, a $3 billion office and retail project, would not be forced into the British equivalent of a bankruptcy liquidation.
For now, bankers said, they would not try to seize the complex, which is under construction, and would continue to provide money for work on the site near the London docklands. "No one is taking a precipitate action at the moment," one banker said. [Page 38.]
As financial markets awoke yesterday to the news that Olympia & York had finally succumbed to bankruptcy in Canada, stock markets in London, Toronto and New York calmly accepted what many people had viewed as an inevitable step in the closing chapter in the late 1980's real estate crisis. [Page 39.]
Falling real estate prices, which began years ago in Houston and Dallas, and rolled across the country to Boston, New York and Washington, as well as to the west, had claimed the developer, whose sheer strength and wealth had allowed it to withstand the downturn the longest, despite debts of $18.5 billion.
 
Working With Banks
 In the United States, the company is now in the process of presenting long-term plans to each lender on its New York buildings that it hopes will win the support of its principal banks, which include the Sanwa Bank, Nomura Ltd. and Sumitomo Ltd., all of Japan, as well as First National Bank of Chicago and J. P. Morgan of New York.
Among the things it is seeking from the banks are a moratorium on all principal payments on its mortgages on New York buildings, one banker said. The banker said it is also seeking an agreement that the bankers and the company's bondholders will accept whatever income is generated from nearly 23 million square feet of office space in New York City and not move to take possession of the buildings when revenues fall short of the interest payments due.
Olympia & York officials say that values will improve on the New York properties, and that if the banks leave the properties in Olympia's hands, their loans will be repaid eventually.
The company is also one of New York's top taxpayers, and its next property tax payment, about $75 million, is due on July 1.
Olympia & York argues that the value of all its New York properties, which include the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan, exceeds by more than $1 billion the $5.9 billion debt on them. But many bankers are skeptical about property values, after having lived through several bruising years of falling prices during a national real estate recession and because some Olympia buildings have not been appraised in years.
One example is 55 Water Street, between Broad Street and Old Slip. Olympia said in 1986 that the building was worth $742 million, but several real estate experts estimate that it might bring only about $200 million at today's depressed prices. The building is one of the company's biggest problem properties in New York.
"We believe there is net value in the New York portfolio," said an executive of the company who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We could do a Chapter 11 filing, and that would buy time and get us financing, but we do not want to take that route."
Still, some real estate experts were skeptical. "This is a multinational real estate restructuring, and we haven't had one of these," said David Shulman, head of Salomon Brothers' real estate research. "Nobody knows what will happen. They are basically spinning out of control right now."
Olympia & York will also have to persuade the banks to contribute more money to properties that back their loans in New York because in some downtown buildings it must pay for costly asbestos removal and various improvements if the properties are to continue attracting tenants.
Although the company is also trying to avoid a bankruptcy proceeding in the United States for its American subsidiaries, it is trying to take advantage of the more debtor-friendly rules of American bankruptcy law.
Several of the Canadian subsidiaries filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code on Thursday in New York in addition to their filings in Toronto. These companies are the Olympia & York SF Holdings Corporation, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., O.&Y. (U.S.) Development Canada Ltd. and O.&Y. Equity (Canada) Ltd.
The Canadian system, by contrast to that in the United States, is less biased in favor of debtors. By filing first for Chapter 11 protection for five of its main Canadian companies with American assets, Olympia & York hopes to get the American courts to take the lead in the restructuring of its Canadian arm. The Canadian companies that filed for protection in Toronto have a total debt load of $14.9 billion (Canadian), according to the court documents.
 
Falling Prices
 Olympia & York is only the latest and by far the biggest company to fall in a global real estate deflation and credit tightening that began in the Southwest United States in 1986, rolled across the country and eventually spread to Canada, Britain, France and Japan, among others.
Although the Reichmann family of Toronto, which owns Olympia & York, is believed to have enormous stores of wealth safely outside the reach of most of its creditors, their cash crisis, which began earlier this year, represents the fall of the bluest of the world's blue-chip real estate companies.
It was commonly said even after the company initiated a restructuring of its debts and ran to banks across the world for emergency loans that if Olympia & York could not survive this real estate downturn, no developer encumbered with debt was immune.
On Thursday real estate executives saw the fruition of the disaster that many said was planted in the 1980's with huge overbuilding of office space around the world and wildly inflated real estate values spurred by a flood of institutional money bidding up the prices of office buildings.
Although Olympia & York's vast array of office and retail properties in the United States and its Canary Wharf project in London are not in bankruptcy, the fall of the parent company and its entire Canadian arm shows the severity of the problems that have trampled office developers across the world.
 
Disputes Are Feared
 It remains to be seen whether the company can keep its lenders from fighting among themselves and moving separately to seize collateral in the United States, much the way things went in Canada. If that happens, a Chapter 11 filing is a near certainty.
"No one could have predicted the massive downturn that we've seen in this market and in London," said a senior official of Olympia & York who insisted on anonymity. "Look at the natural-resources side, which was designed to be countercyclical to the real estate market because generally when real estate prices go down oil goes up. Who could have predicted that they both would have been on the same roller coaster going down?"
Indeed, a recent study showed that property lenders, by refusing to roll over maturing loans and demanding that borrowers repay, reduced by about $2.4 billion the amount they lent to the industry last year.. Lenders have traditionally allowed developers who are up to date on their borrowings to roll over their loans or have given them an opportunity to refinance with other lenders, but now sharply fewer lenders are financing real estate.
Olympia & York's cash needs are considerable. The estimate for keeping the Canary Wharf project going just through the end of 1993 is $650 million.
"Who could have predicted that the real estate markets worldwide were going to collapse?," the Olympia & York executive asked. "Who knew that the Japanese were going to be out of this business in a year? The world just took directions that none of us could have predicted."
 
The Leading Bank Lender
 Among the main bank creditors who will shape Olympia & York's future are Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the biggest single bank creditor with about $750 million of loans. This bank's hard-nosed dealing with Olympia & York eventually hurt Olympia's ability to keep its Canadian arm out of bankruptcy court and that was surprising to many analysts because for many years the bank had been a staunch supporter of the company.
Paul Reichmann, the chief strategist for the company, was a member of the board of Canadian Imperial and resigned because of conflict-of-interest problems only when the restructuring began. Canadian Imperial blocked several large new loan proposals to the company, demanded that Olympia & York provide recent financial data rather than year-old figures, and aggressively resisted the company's strong-arm tactics.
Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, is a key American creditor in the negotiations and it has a total of almost $500 million outstanding to Olympia & York and its subsidiaries. William Rhodes, senior Citicorp executive who made a name for himself negotiating many of the Latin American debt workouts, is playing a central role in coordinating the moves of some of the bank lenders on New York properties as well as Canary Wharf. Along with Royal Imperial and the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, Citicorp has run many of the creditor meetings.
Among the other banks with large exposures to the company are Royal Bank of Canada; Credit Suisse of Switzerland; Credit Lyonnais of France; Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Sumitomo Bank, both of Japan; Bank of Nova Scotia, Lloyds Bank of Britain, and the National Bank of Canada.
