HEADLINE: ALEXANDER'S SHUTS ALL ITS 11 STORES; PLANS LIQUIDATION

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The death knell rang for another big New York City retailer yesterday as Alexander's Inc. closed its 11 stores and filed for bankruptcy protection. The budget department store company, merchant to successive waves of struggling immigrants since 1928, said it would reopen the stores for a close-out sale, then cease operations.
The company, which has not turned a profit on its retail operations since 1987, will continue to try to sell or lease its stores, some of which occupy prime real estate locations like the one occupied by the flagship store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. 
 Alexander's demise will hurt the New York economy. The 5,200 employees will lose their jobs, and a significant amount of square footage will flood a real estate market already glutted with empty retail space. The Daily News, in which Alexander's was the second-largest advertiser, will also be hard hit.
 
Shift to Real Estate
 Over the last decade, Alexander's managers and owners became more interested in developing the company's real estate and allowed the retailing business to decline, failing to address ever-intensifying competition from new discount stores and price wars that made department-store merchandise less expensive.
At many locations, the Alexander's stores sit in shopping centers where the presence of other large stores may help diffuse the loss. But the damage will be felt strongly in the Fordham Road section of the Bronx, where the Alexander's on the Grand Concourse has anchored a thriving shopping district of smaller shops and ornate movie theaters. Alexander's bought that store, its second, in 1933 and made it the flagship of its chain until the company finally moved into Manhattan in 1963. [Page 27.]
 
Outposts in the Suburbs
 When its customers began moving out of the city, Alexander's moved with them, establishing beachheads in White Plains and Paramus, N.J., offering middle-class shoppers quality goods at bargain prices.
"With its passing, the Bronx loses one of its distinctions, because even though it moved its headquarters to Manhattan, in the minds of many Bronx residents, it was always a Bronx store," said Lloyd Ultan, a professor of history at Fairleigh Dickinson University who has written four books about the Bronx.
The end of Alexander's highlights the extraordinary difficulties the retail industry has had in the New York area. Some of the proudest names in the business have closed in the last decade -- Gimbels, B. Altman and May's, as well as Ohrbach's, S. Klein and E. J. Korvette. Others, including Bloomingdale's and Macy's, filed for bankruptcy, but survived.
"This is not just an individual story about a retailer fallen on hard times but another very sad part of the difficulties of the whole retail scene in New York City," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a division of the Labor Department.
In its heyday in the 1930's, the Alexander's at Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse boasted more sales per square foot than any other retailer in the country. It was one of the last department stores to cater to the needs and wallets of New York's struggling immigrant and working-class shoppers. It served the Jewish, Irish and Italian communities of the Bronx and northern Manhattan until the mid-1960's when the ethnic makeup of the borough began changing.
Its founder, George Farkas, who named the stores for his father, developed the strategy of finding a niche between discount houses selling hardware and housewares and full-service department stores. "Dad went right in between with decor and ambiance, but with style, fashion and price," Robin L. Farkas, the company's chairman, said at the time of his father's death in 1980. "It had not been done that way before."
With the opening of a third store, in White Plains, Mr. Farkas stayed open in the evening, which no other Westchester County department store did at the time.
 
In Decline Since Mid-1980's
 But the company, which sold stock to the public in 1968, has been in decline since the mid-1980's. In its last five years, only when the company sold stores did it have a profit. And sales have dropped to $430 million last fiscal year from $525 million in 1988. Mr. Farkas said losses of the last two years reached $40 million and were expected to continue.
"Alexander's retail business is not viable, and there is little prospect of turning it around," Mr. Farkas said. "It is simply no longer capable of producing the cash flow necessary.
From its unkempt facade to the cheap, no-frills merchandise it sold, Alexander's stood out in the industry, where glitz, glamour and excess predominated.
But in the last decade, the value of real estate increased geometrically, and Alexander's had several pricey pieces of property, including its Roosevelt Field store in Garden City, L.I., and the stores on Lexington Avenue and Fordham Road.
Because high-stakes real estate seemed far sexier and more lucrative than discount retailing, the company neglected retailing. At the same time, an increasing number of competitors -- Kmart, Conway, Conran's and outlet stores -- started chipping away at Alexander's sales.
"For a long time, Alexander's was the alternative to the department stores," said James Posner of Posner Associates, a retail consulting firm. "Now people have lots of alternatives, and Alexander's hasn't given them any reason to continue to shop there."
Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement, "This is a sad day for New York City." Mr. Dinkins said he was particularly concerned about Alexander's employees, "the vast majority of whom are people of color and half of whom are women."
Alexander's stopped paying its bills in March, when it announced that it could not meet some requirements of its loan agreements. Since then, it has received little new merchandise.
In its filing with the bankruptcy court, Alexander's listed assets of $183.7 million and liabilities of $95.7 million. Bankruptcy experts say the value of Alexander's real estate insures that its banks, suppliers and even its shareholders are likely to recoup their losses in the long run.
"The trade creditors are, of course, sad to see another good retailer leave the New York scene, but our expectation is that the suppliers will receive 100 cents on the dollar," said Andrew H. Tananbaum, president of Century Factors Inc., a financing company that is one of Alexander's creditors.
Despite its difficulties, the company's board had opted to keep the stores open while Financo, an investment house, shopped them around. The company's two largest shareholders, who between them own more than 50 percent of the stock, are Citibank and Interstate Properties, a New Jersey real estate developer.
 
Too Little Money Coming In
 But too little money was coming in, and Alexander's filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code early yesterday morning. The company had been expected to ask for bankruptcy protection last Friday, but the company's directors could not agree on a strategy and delayed the filing.
Investors were not frightened by the prospect of bankruptcy. On Thursday, Alexander's stock closed at its highest price in several months: $12 a share. Trading in the stock was suspended yesterday.
But real estate brokers were wringing their hands yesterday at the thought of hundreds of thousands of feet of more retail space added to the already depressed market. In the heady days of the 1980's, Alexander's was the object of desire for developers like Donald J. Trump, the Bass brothers of Fort Worth and Mr. Roth, who bid its stock up to more than $75 in an effort to buy its properties. The battles these glamorous millionaires fought for control of the proudly plebeian store chain were the top subject of brokers' gossip for years.
"Now who needs that real estate?" said Robert Futterman, senior vice president of Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing Inc., a retail real estate company. "When I heard the news first thing this morning, I thought that's the absolute worst thing that could have happened in my market."
The store closings will also swell the ranks of unemployed department store workers in the city. Employment at the city's department stores has dropped 40 percent in the last decade, from 52,000 to 33,000, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The decline has accelerated in five years, when more than 20 percent of the workers in local department stores have lost their jobs.
"I've been involved 34 years in the retail business in this city, and I've never seen it this bad," said Lenore Miller, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. "I don't know where all those people are going to go." Alexander's employees were not represented by a union.
At The Daily News, which is also in bankruptcy, Les Goodstein, vice president of advertising, said the newspaper had been aware of the chain's problems for some time and planned for reduced advertising revenues. "We have budgeted very conservative estimates through the remainder of this year," he said.

HEADLINE: WORKING NIGHTS: A Special Report;
Lives Upside Down to Help a World Go Round

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DULUTH, Ga.

 BODY:
At 11 P.M., or 1 A.M. on the many nights she must work overtime, Allison McClure stops at her mother's house to retrieve her 3-year-old daughter, Mia, take her home and put her back to bed. Then she packs Mia's bag for nursery school, does the ironing, cleans house and takes a shower. "I'm in bed by 3 or 4," she said during her 9-to-9:30 P.M. "lunch" break at a mail processing center.
Then she gets up at 6:45 A.M. "I get her up. I fix her breakfast, I feed her and I take her to school. I'll lie down for about an hour and a half, and then I'm up. Any business I have to do, I try to fit in between then and the time I have to be at work at 3." 
 Ms. McClure is a shift worker. Thirty years old, paid around $30,000 a year, she is hard at work for the United States Postal Service when most people take it easy or sleep. Because of her personal obligations, she said: "I never sleep eight hours. Sometimes you get tired, so you have to push yourself."
She has jet lag without the jet, and she has it all the time.
Ms. McClure and millions of others who work unconventional hours have become objects of concern to psychologists and occupational-health specialists. While some people, like police officers, nurses and factory workers, have always worked unconventional hours, more and more do now. And among them new strains have developed as two-earner families and single working mothers have displaced one-earner, married-couple families.
Typically, statisticians define shift workers as people who spend less than half of the daylight hours on the job or who work some hours in the morning and some at night. Others put in long, dawn-to-dawn shifts or rotating schedules -- days one week, nights the next. Growth in shift work, like the growth in part-time and temporary jobs, is a part of a sea change in the labor force that has to accommodate a global economy that runs around the clock.
Shift work accounts for a quarter to nearly half the jobs in the fastest-growing occupations. It is built into 8 of the 10 occupations that the Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts will add the most workers in the next decade: sales clerk and cashier in stores, nurse, nursing aide, truck driver, janitor, waiter and fast-food worker. Shift work, of course, also breeds shift workers. They work in convenience stores, supermarkets and gas stations that stay open long after dark to serve other people who work long after dark.
No one knows just how many shift workers there are. The last time it looked, in 1985, the Census Bureau found 20 million, or a fifth of the work force. It counted them again last year, but the results will not be reported until later this year.
Donald I. Tepas, an industrial psychologist at the University of Connecticut, said, "Our society is demanding more and more round-the-clock operation at all levels, from the working-class blue-collar guy to doctors in hospitals and financiers."
 
The Burdens
Too Little Sleep, Too Many Cares
 Occupational-health experts find that shift work exacts a toll beyond just losing sleep. Years of research, assembled in a recent study of shift work and health by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, show that shift workers typically suffer from insomnia and chronic fatigue. They have more trouble with their health and dispositions than other workers, more marital problems, more strains rearing children.
Night workers, the study says, complain inordinately of gastrointestinal disorders, including peptic ulcers. It says that pregnant shift workers, according to some limited research, suffer more miscarriages, premature births and lower birth weights than women who work regular hours.
The Congressional study says the health effects of shift work become more acute with age, raising concern about the baby-boom generation, which is now the largest part of the work force and whose oldest members are approaching 50. Timothy H. Monk, director of a University of Pittsburgh program that studies workers' hours, said he wondered how employers will manage with older, less malleable workers, "when they don't have enough young people to shuffle."
Many foreign governments regulate shift work, but in the United States, neither the Government nor the institutions that support workplace regulation, like labor unions and advocacy groups, have fully addressed the issue.
 
Grogginess Can Be Deadly
 In the interest of public safety, Federal agencies regulate shift work in public transportation and in a few other areas, like operating nuclear power plants, where a groggy employee can endanger a community. But no one protects the community when a groggy employee hits the road for home.
For many people, shift work is all they can find. But for others, it holds some advantages. It permits couples with young children, for example, to hold two jobs, with one working while the other is home.
Night work also often pays more than day work in the same job. In addition to base pay of about $10 to $16 an hour, postal workers get a 10 percent bonus for hours they work between 6 P.M. and 6 A.M.
 
The Workplace
Dazzling Light In Sea of Dark
 Ms. McClure's mail-processing center, 33 miles north of Atlanta, provides a window on one of the nation's larger concentrations of shift workers. It is a 643,000-square-foot, single-story building surrounded by fields and trees at the end of a rolling suburban road. At night it looks eerily alive, with its truck-loading bays, largely windowless walls and parking lots basking in white artificial light. It is a glistening, modern factory in all respects except that it doesn't make anything.
About 1,700 people work there, and 1,400 of them are shift workers, starting their jobs sometime between 2 P.M. and 1 A.M. Thanks to their toil, many letters mailed in Atlanta one day can be picked up, processed, loaded in trucks and delivered the next day.
Of nearly 200,000 postal employees assigned to mail-processing work nationwide, Phillip Tabbita, an official of the American Postal Workers Union in Washington, estimated that 75 percent work afternoons and nights, up from about half in the 1960's.
David C. Lamb, the head of human resources, procurement and finance at the processing center, said the work "is all predicated on service standards."
"Our last collections are between 4 and 6," he said, "which means we really can't start until after that time."
 
Second by Second
 Inside the building, the people like Ms. McClure, Kathy Sanders and Kenneth Beasley sit at sorting machines that shoot letters past their brows at a mesmerizing rate of one per second.
In that second, the workers must read the letter's ZIP code and tap the last three digits on their keyboards, dispatching the letter to the appropriate delivery bin. Some workers say they periodically nod off or lose their rhythm and start making errors.
For workers here, the greatest stress occurs in trying to meet the daytime demands of their families -- caring for children or preparing meals that they often cannot be home to eat. Ms. Sanders, 32, usually works from 5 P.M. to 1:30 A.M. During her 9-to-9:30 break she was having lunch -- popcorn. She has two boys, 4 and 1. Her husband is a road manager for entertainment groups, so he is away a lot.
"I have kind of dozed off at the wheel going home, but only when I have to work until 3:30," she said. "I like the hours because they're convenient for getting my kid to school and picking him up. But I don't get to spend any time with him other than on the weekend."
 
The Workers
Relationships Are Worn Down
 Donna Jones, the divorced mother of a daughter, 3, and a son 16, seems a happy, spirited woman, darting about the lunch room. But she feels the pressure. "My little girl has hair to here," she said, touching her hip. "I try to keep it braided. My son, it was bad for him. He used to beg me every day, 'Momma, quit the job. You don't have to have a job.' I told him, 'This job is keeping you in the jeans you're wearing.' "
Ms. Jones said her marriage was solid until she started working nights. Her husband worked for the Postal Service, too, from 4:30 A.M. to noon. She was getting home then about 7 A.M. He would want to talk as soon as he got home, she said, and she would want to sleep. "He still wanted me to be like I was before, making meals, taking the kids to school. It was hard."
No one monitors changes in family relationships here, but clearly the work is murder on marriages. "When young women come here to work," said Mr. Beasley, a steward for the postal workers' union, "you know what the older women say? They say, 'Honey, if you've got a man, you're not going to have him long.' "
Mr. Tepas, at the University of Connecticut, said that among the groups he has studied the percentages of night-shift workers who are divorced, separated or single are higher than for other workers.
 
Life as a 'Zombie'
 Catherine Skolte, 24, got divorced last October. Before, she would get home at 9 A.M. She said that if she was beginning her two days off then, her husband, who worked regular hours, wouldn't let her sleep. "I'd get stuck staying up 24 to 36 hours," she said. "I would be a zombie. When I would decide to get a rest, he'd get mad."
The workers' health problems are insidious. Alana Farino, who works from 10 P.M. to 6:30 A.M. on the letter-sorting machine, said her eyesight is beginning to fail. Deborah Peterson, who works with her, said she is getting asthma, perhaps from paper dust. Michele Barr, a 25-year-old sorting clerk and an asthmatic before she started working here, said her asthma attacks are more frequent now.
Some people drive themselves to exhaustion. Tom Ditzenberger, 45, works from 3 to 11:30 P.M., driving an electric cart here, and, like some other workers, he has another job. He delivers The Atlanta Constitution to about 250 homes.
"It takes me an hour to get home," Mr. Ditzenberger said. "Normally I get a cup of coffee, sit down, watch the news, set my alarm, lie down on the couch, snooze if I can and get up at 2.
"I leave at 2:30, go to the warehouse, put the papers in plastic bags and I'm on the road by 4. I'm done by 5:30, and by then I'm really out of it. I turn the phones off, close the curtains and go to sleep. I'm up by 11:30." He said he took the second job so he could pay for his truck.
Linda Brown, the nurse at the center from 2 P.M. to 10:30 P.M, said: "They're throwing their bodies completely out of kilter. I see a lot of people walking around in a fog."
Lancy Rocker, the nurse who follows Ms. Brown on what the workers call the "zombie shift," said she sees a lot of workers with stomach problems. "They have real short patience," she said.
 
The Inner Clock
Trying to Fight Ancient Rhythms
 Research supports much of what the nurses and the workers say. Mr. Tepas cited two studies he had done, one of 1,400 Midwestern urban employees of a variety of industries and one of 2,000 employees of factories in small Midwestern towns.
"People who work at night sleep less than anybody else," he said. "On their days off, they cannot make up the loss. We call it chronic sleep deprivation, or sleep debt."
David R. Liskowski, who directed the Office of Technology Assessment project, says shift workers are sabotaging powerful biological processes that are controlled in part by the rotation of the earth. The brain, in response to changing amounts of light and dark, instructs the body to start cooling off at night and warming up at dawn. It commands changes in digestion, breathing, the heartbeat, sleeping, waking and the secretion of hormones.
The cycles of day-to-day changes are known as circadian rhythms. And shift work, like flights across time zones, can upset the rhythms, sending conflicting messages about when to sleep and when to stay alert.
 
Vital to the Economy
 The Congressional study said shift work in the United States is almost entirely undocumented, as well as unregulated. But because shift work is vital to the economy, Mr. Tepas said, "The issue is not whether it should be done but how to do it right."
Some countries restrict the hours people can work at a stretch at night. They mandate extra hours of rest after a long stretch of night work or allow breaks for a nap during a shift. In France, the Government pays 50 percent of a night worker's cost of equipping a home to block out daytime intrusions. Australia requires an extra week of vacation for night workers.
 
The Adjustments
Making the Best Of Odd Hours
 Many postal workers here say what troubles them most is drowsiness driving home. Kathy Wasson, 41, said she is content and healthy now working 3:30 to midnight. Once, on a shift starting at midnight, she fell asleep driving to work.
She slammed into the back of a pickup truck, wrecking her car. She suffered only bruises.
It is close to impossible to find anyone who truly likes the latest shifts, those beginning after 11 P.M., but some say they thrive starting work in the afternoon. They tend to be single or married to people who keep similar hours. They like beating the crowds and shopping when most people are asleep or at work.
A few workers on even the latest shifts say they have found ways to keep families intact and bodies sound. They say they do it by paying heed to their circadian rythms. Biologists say the rhythms can be adjusted to make night people of day people, particularly when they sleep in dark rooms in the day and work in bright light at night.
 
Fooling One's Body
 Rick Harris, a 45-year-old supervisor of the letter-sorting teams, said 20 years in the Air Force taught him that self-control is needed. "I learned in Vietnam that you can fool our body clock for maybe 24 hours," he said. "But you have to discipline yourself."
On weekends, Mr. Harris said, he stays up most of Saturday, when he arrives home around 7 A.M., to be with his wife, who works days during the week, and their children, who are 7 and 12. He goes to bed at 8 P.M. and sleeps 12 hours. Then on Sunday, before his biological clock can put him on a daytime cycle, he starts working back into his weekly routine.
"I go to bed at 5 P.M., take a nap and get up at 10," he said. "I get on my computer until 2 or 3, and then I go back to bed." He sleeps another 12 hours and is then ready for dinner with the family and the start of his shift at 10 P.M. "You have to put your priorities right," he said.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Officer Will Be Tried Again Over Taped Beating

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 15

 BODY:
Sixteen days after violent racial disorders broke out over the acquittal of four white Los Angeles police officers on most charges in the beating of Rodney G. King, a judge today ordered one of the officers to stand trial again on the single unresolved charge in the case.
He left open the crucial question of where the trial would be held, but strongly hinted that he preferred to return it to Los Angeles. 
 The judge, Stanley M. Weisberg, who presided over the original Superior Court trial in suburban Simi Valley, said he granted the District Attorney's request for a new trial for the officer, Laurence M. Powell, mainly on the ground of the evidence presented at the first trial. That included a videotape of Mr. Powell delivering most of the 56 baton blows that struck Mr. King, who is black.
 
Simi Valley Trial
 "Based upon my view of the evidence presented in the just-concluded trial," he said, "I find that the interests of justice require that there be a second trial in the case of People v. Powell." The trial must begin by the third week of July unless both sides agree to a delay.
The jury acquitted Mr. Powell on April 29 on two counts, assault with a deadly weapon and falsifying a police report, but deadlocked 8 to 4 in favor of acquittal on a third count of assault "under color of authority." If convicted, he faces up to six years in prison.
Today's ruling opened yet another chapter in the stormy case that has convulsed this, the second largest city in the nation, and rocked police departments nationwide since the amateur videotape of the beating was broadcast in March 1991. The case became the focus not only of charges of excessive force by police officers against blacks but also of whether American courts are colorblind.
Legal experts said that the trial judge had the discretion to approve or deny a new trial after any mistrial, but that a judge would be particularly inclined to order a new trial in a serious or high-profile case. Requests for retrials are usually denied only in minor cases and when the original jury was strongly leaning toward acquittal. The District Attorney's office said that it would be very unusual for the Superior Court to deny a request for a new trial.
In the first trial, after the state's Second District Court of Appeal granted a change of venue away from Los Angeles, Judge Weisberg moved the trial to Simi Valley in Ventura County, a conservative suburban area where a jury that had no black members stunned the city and nation by acquitting on almost all charges. The verdict set off rioting that left 58 dead and nearly $1 billion in property damage.
Judge Weisberg's ruling appeared to have eased the tensions that have been smoldering for two weeks here since the police, the National Guard and Federal troops put down the wave of arson, looting and killing that followed the verdict. "To retry Powell is a beginning of a vindication of the wrong," said Patricia Moore, a black City Council member in Compton, a city adjoining South-Central Los Angeles that was also swept by rioting. "Some mechanism needed to be in place to ease the pain and disappointment. He's going to be retried. That says a lot for the system."
At a news conference after the hearing, District Attorney Ira Reiner, in a tough fight for re-election, said the prosecution strategy would be "essentially" the same, relying mainly on the videotape. He declined to say whether the prosecutors would call Mr. King as a witness. He did not testify at the first trial.
Mr. Powell's lawyer, Michael P. Stone, said he doubted his client could get a fair trial anywhere in California in the aftermath of the riots and the widespread publicity, much of it deriding the jury. "Getting a fair trial in the state of California is going to be problematic," he told reporters. "Getting a fair trial in the county of Los Angeles is next to impossible."
Judge Weisberg has been criticized for moving the original trial to Ventura rather than a large urban county demographically similar to Los Angeles. In court today, he bridled at suggestions that the court or jury was responsible for the rioting.
"A single criminal trial cannot cause or solve the major social and economic and other social problems that exist in society," he said. "It's not the function of a criminal trial, a single criminal trial, to deal with such issues, and a trial cannot solve those issues."
From the bench, Judge Weisberg cited several factors influencing his decision to order a new trial, including the likelihood of different trial tactics, witnesses and arguments, and the lack of what he called the "distraction" of the three other defendants and the charges against them. But "over and above that," he cited "the nature of the evidence that was presented to the jury in the just-concluded trial." He did not mention it, but it was assumed he was referring to the videotape.
 
Questions on Location
 The big legal question is whether the judge can move the second trial back to Los Angeles County. On July 23, 1991, the appeal court ordered it moved because of political turmoil in Los Angeles. It cited a dispute between Mayor Tom Bradley and Chief of Police Daryl F. Gates, efforts by the Police Commission to remove the Chief, and pressure for a vote on a city charter amendment limiting the Chief's term. Judge Weisberg said at the time that he selected nearby Ventura County, which is only 2 percent black, largely for reasons of convenience and costs.
The change-of-venue order remains in place. While Judge Weisberg clearly has the authority to move the trial to another county besides Ventura or Los Angeles, trial lawyers said today it was unclear whether he could move it back to Los Angeles. Judge Weisberg scheduled a hearing for May 22 for the lawyers to argue whether the court has the authority to transfer the case back. He noted that the political situation had changed since last year and that the vote on the charter amendment would take place on June 2, well before the new trial could begin.
He also asked prosecution and defense lawyers to discuss whether the recent publicity over the rioting had been so widespread that it would affect the court's ability to select a jury in any county.
California law allows a judge to set aside an order to change venue on the ground that the conditions that required the change "no longer apply."
 
Fair Trial in Los Angeles?
 Charles R. English, a criminal defense lawyer with the Santa Monica firm of Chaleff, English & Catalano, said that he knew of no precedent for a case like this. If the judge rules that it can be heard in Los Angeles, he said, the defense could appeal, arguing that it violated the appeals court ruling and that even under new circumstances the defendant could not get a fair trial here.
When the change of venue was first ordered last year, a number of other counties were considered, including urban ones like Alameda, which contains the heavily black City of Oakland.
Mr. Reiner, the District Attorney, said that he thought a jury could be found here and that the second trial would be prosecuted by the two lawyers who lost the first one, Alan S. Yochelson and Terry L. White. He said their loss was "a reflection of the point of view of that jury" rather than any prosecutorial short-coming in what many lawyers have described as an open-and-shut case.
"I hope they do as good a job as the first time," he said. "They did a superlative job."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new trial was ordered yesterday for Laurence M. Powell, above, on the only unresolved charge in the case of the beating of Rodney G. King in Los Angeles. In granting the request of the District Attorney, the judge left open the question of where the trial would be held. (Associated Press)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

CLOSEOUT FOR ANOTHER RETAILER
The death knell rang for another major New York City retailer as Alexander's Inc. closed the doors at its 11 stores and filed for bankruptcy protection. The budget department store company, merchant to each wave of struggling immigrants, said it would reopen the stores for a close-out sale, then close for good. Its demise will have a significant impact on the New York economy: about 5,200 people will lose their jobs and the vacant stores will enter a real estate market glutted with empty retail space. Page 1.
 
Tremors in 11 neighborhoods. Page 27.
 
NEW YORK CITY
DINKINS REJECTS OVERHAUL OF SHELTERS 
 Mayor Dinkins effectively rejected the sweeping overhaul of the city's troubled shelter system recommended by a mayoral commission, saying his administration would study its key proposals over the next 18 months. He did endorse other ideas from the commission, including a pilot rental subsidy program for 200 homeless families and a heavier reliance on nonprofit groups to run shelters. Page 1.
 
FACE TO FACE WITH THE MAYOR
With their battling deputies out of the city, Mayor David N. Dinkins had what was described as an "upbeat" meeting with Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez as they grappled with several budget issues that have strained the relationship between them. While nothing was firmly resolved on the fiscal questions, Mr. Fernandez seemed to appreciate the chance to make his case directly to the Mayor. Page 27.
 
LANDLORDS GUILTY OF BIAS
A Federal jury has found two Brooklyn landlords and a Brooklyn realty company liable for discrimination against black and Hispanic renters, in a suit that lawyers said could make it easier to prosecute racial steering cases. Page 26.
 
REGION
 
A BOND PLAN FOR NASSAU
Torn, like many other local governments, between adopting crippling service reductions or wrenching tax increases, Republicans and Democrats in Nassau County have reached a consensus to do neither: they want to sell up to $100 million in bonds instead. Nassau's deficit-borrowing plan would be the largest in the state since the Municipal Assistance Corporation sold $5.4 billion in bonds to bail out New York City during the 1970's. Page 29.
 
LAYOFF TROUBLES IN YONKERS
Garbage went uncollected and police calls backed up in Yonkers today, apparently as a result of a work slowdown to protest layoffs of city workers. Even more workers would be laid off under a new budget presented by Mayor Terence Zaleski that would reduce the city work force to its lowest level since 1985. Page 29.
 
ELECTION DAY, INDEPENDENTS' DAY?
A Swiss nanny's first statements about the fire that killed an infant in her care, statements that the defense is trying to suppress, were instrumental in leading to her arrest on charges of arson and murder, a detective testified at a pretrial hearing. Page 29.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush on Tightrope in Pittsburgh, Juggling Politics and Compassion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, May 15

 BODY:
President Bush collected $350,000 in political donations at a lunch with wealthy supporters today, then sped several blocks to a nearby slum for a show of Presidential concern about the inner city.
The juxtaposition of the two meetings, barely five minutes apart, served to underscore the balancing act that the President must perform in an election year, hoping to present a compassionate response to the urban problems symbolized by the Los Angeles riots, while at the same time seeing to political necessities. 
 Meeting with community leaders in Pittsburgh's Hill district, where unemployment exceeds 40 percent and the drug trade is rampant, Mr. Bush was told, politely but urgently, that the neighborhood desperately needs more Federal spending on social programs.
Mr. Bush assured the dozen or so leaders that their comments had made him "more sensitive" to the cities' needs. Signs that a sprinkling of protesters waved along the Hill district streets said as much. "What took Bush so long to get here?" said one.
 
'We're Trying Very Hard'
 Asked about that perception, the President said that the poor "are not looking for blame," adding, "They want to get something done, and we're trying very hard." Mr. Bush's stop in Pittsburgh was divided between a 90-minute meeting with supporters who paid $1,000 a plate to dine and shake hands with the President, and an hourlong meeting with about a dozen ministers, civic officials, anti-poverty workers and one local barber.
Mr. Bush sought to bridge the two occasions by abandoning his standard speech for fund-raising events, which attacks Congress as the source of most national ills, and talking instead about inner-city zones with tax incentives to encourage business development, Federal job training programs and policies that would expand home ownership.
The day's most moving words came not at the fund-raising event but at the later meeting in the Hill district. There, a well-dressed mix of black civic leaders and white bureaucrats gave Mr. Bush brief lectures about the Federal effort to rehabilitate drug-ridden neighborhoods.
The last speaker was a Hill district barber, Napoleon Buice. In a halting voice, he told Mr. Bush: "There's people out in the Hill. There's drug addicts out in the Hill, that need help. And there are intelligent boys out there who don't have any hope."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeted supporters yesterday at a luncheon at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. The event raised $350,000. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Exits on a Kennedy Theme

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 15

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev completed his two-week tour of the United States today with a renewed plea for aid to Russia and praise for the United States as a nation that faced its own problems and set an example for the world.
The former Soviet President's last two public appearances were heavily laden with tributes to President John F. Kennedy, who he said had led the way to an end to the cold war in 1963 with his disarmament speech at the American University. 
 At a luncheon at the John F. Kennedy Library, Mr. Gorbachev said he had been impressed during the national soul-searching over urban policies by Americans who let their "thoughts go out to those whom the American dream, for the moment, has passed by."
"As long as this society can remain dissatisfied," he said, "as long as it does not give in to complacency, we can remain confident that America will overcome its difficulties."
He made the same point again later, before a flight back to Russia tonight, at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, where he also praised the "longstanding American tradition to be responsible to the hardships of other people and other nations."
"Russia needs support," he added, asking for American assistance, as he had Thursday in a speech to Congress.
 
Praise From Senator Kennedy
 Mr. Gorbachev's tributes to President Kennedy were a constant theme. At Harvard he said the United States perhaps needed "a John F. Kennedy and his legacy." At the library he said Kennedy had inspired his own disarmament efforts. There he was introduced by the late President's brother, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
Senator Kennedy said the cold war had finally come to an end with the demolition of the Berlin wall. "The defining moment for our time," he said, "and perhaps for our century came on that historic day in November 1989 when Mikhail Gorbachev said, 'Let the wall come down.' "
Mr. Gorbachev told the 300 guests, from Boston's worlds of business, politics and academia and from the Kennedy family, that President Kennedy's disarmament speech on June 10, 1963, had amounted to a "serious intellectual breakthrough."
He quoted Kennedy as saying then: "Peace need not be impractical and war need not be inevitable. Contacts among nations need not be transformed into an exchange of threats."
Mr. Gorbachev said those comments pointed the way to the end of the cold war even though, he said, Kennedy himself was somewhat inclined to that period's philosophy of "total confrontation."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John F. Kennedy Jr., left, presented a book on constitutional law by his sister, Caroline, to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, right, at the John F. Kennedy Library yesterday in Boston. Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis stood next to her son, and talked to Raisa Gorbachev through a translator, at rear. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: EMPIRE IN TROUBLE;
Teetering Giant Worries New York City Officials

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Olympia & York is New York City's biggest commercial landlord and one of its top taxpayers, and while none of its New York buildings are included in the Canadian bankruptcy filing, the real estate empire's troubles have raised shivers at City Hall.
The company's next property tax payment, about $75 million, is due on July 1, and city and Olympia officials said they were exploring whether some or all of that payment might be delayed, and what the conditions might be. For example, under a new payment schedule, Olympia could pledge that if it failed to make payments it would not contest efforts by the city to take possession of the properties involved, though the city would far sooner collect taxes than own real estate.
 
Quietly Exploring Options
 For weeks, Olympia & York's top New York executives and city officials have been quietly exploring how the city might help a company it had relied on for $142 million in property taxes last year -- 2 percent of the city's total. The possibilities range from rescheduling payments to creating new tax incentives that could help Olympia and other landlords with holdings in Lower Manhattan. 
 "Olympia and York is a very important property owner in the City of New York, and a very important taxpayer, and as a result the city would want to be as helpful as it possibly can under the circumstances," Barry F. Sullivan, the Dinkins administration's new Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development and the former chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, said yesterday.
Unlike some other big New York landlords, Olympia is not delinquent on any of its property taxes, but in the depressed real estate market, not all of its buildings generate enough cash flow from rents and other income to meet expenses. Senior city officials said the company had put out feelers in January, asking what would happen if its payment arrived late.
Both sides refused to elaborate on their talks, and city officials said it was not clear how much flexibility the law and sound practice would allow. They also stressed that their ability to help was limited by the complexity of Olympia's holdings, concerns about whether the United States subsidiary might also have to file for bankruptcy protection in the United States, and whether City Hall could end up competing with Canadian creditors for claims on Olympia's New York properties.
Olympia's top New York executives, John E. Zuccotti and Meyer S. Frucher, have long experience dealing with city and state government. Mr. Zuccotti is a former first deputy mayor under Abraham D. Beame, and Mr. Frucher was president of the state authority that oversaw the development of Battery Park City and is a longtime adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Zuccotti did not return a telephone call yesterday, and Mr. Frucher declined to comment. They had breakfast with Mr. Sullivan on Wednesday at the Vista International Hotel in Lower Manhattan, across the street from Olympia's World Financial Center complex, to review the situation.
Besides rescheduling tax payments, Olympia could be helped if the city reshaped its Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program to provide tax breaks to landlords in the Wall Street area who renovate their property. More than three-quarters of Olympia's buildings are in Lower Manhattan.
The city has also been studying whether tax incentives should be granted to owners who convert office property in Lower Manhattan to residential use. While none of Olympia's buildings would qualify, the company could benefit if excess office space were removed from the market.
Finally, some city officials said, the city could lease space for some of its own offices in Olympia buildings near City Hall. In the last two years, the city has taken advantage of the depressed market to find premium office space at favorable rents.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Building owned by Olympia & York at 55 Water Street in New York City. (Ed Quinn for The NeW York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan to Aid New Market Economies

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 15

 BODY:
Japanese leaders told Vice President Dan Quayle today that after months of coaxing by the Bush Administration, they would lend and invest as much as $400 million in private enterprises in Eastern and Central Europe. But Japan again refused to send substantial aid to the former Soviet republics until four disputed islands are returned to Japanese hands.
Japan's announcement came at the end of a four-day visit here by Mr. Quayle, a trip intended to repair the damage from President Bush's ill-fated trade mission to Tokyo in January and refocus attention on a "global partnership" between the two countries. While both sides declared the trip a success, they also conceded that the most vexing economic issues facing the two countries were deliberately kept off the agenda. 
 The package Japan announced oday included as much as $300 million in loans and $100 million for equity investments in new businesses in Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania. The United States has committed $1.34 billion to the region this year. According to the State Department, $589.6 million of the American aid is in grants, while $747.8 million is in the form of loans or other assistance.
 
A 'Turning Point'
 Mr. Quayle hailed the Japanese plan as a "turning point" in efforts by the United States and Japan to coordinate aid outside Asia. "Eastern and Central Europe is about the farthest place from Japan as you can get," he said this morning at a breakfast meeting with American correspondents based here. "They have no cultural, they have no historic ties." Yet Japan, he said, has come to recognize that the region has been "much of the catalyst" for democratic changes around the world.
Nonetheless, Japan's contribution is bound to fuel the growing unease here that "global partnership" really means that Japan finances international initiatives for which Washington has run out of money.
Mr. Quayle faced many questions along those lines during his stay. And he repeatedly denied that the Bush Administration's vision for the post-cold-war alliance between the two countries was to use Japan as a silent dispenser of cash.
"If the conventional wisdom in Japan is that global partnership means Japanese dollars and U.S. leadership, it is wrong," he said. "Prime Minister Miyazawa doesn't believe that, I don't believe it, and President Bush doesn't agree with it."
Nonetheless, Japanese officials said today that until several months ago they had little intention of providing such large-scale funding to Eastern Europe. But the United States began pressing for a major contribution, and the negotiations grew particularly intense with the approach of Mr. Quayle's visit, his fourth since becoming Vice President. "Everyone wanted a big score," a member of Mr. Quayle's entourage said.
Japan continued to hold out on the question of aid to Russia and other former Soviet republics, despite growing criticism from France and Germany that Japanese intransigence could doom the effort to convert the republics to viable market economies. In a sharply critical speech at the United Nations earlier this month, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said that Japan must "assume a larger share of the West's common responsibility" to assure that the reforms take root.
Mr. Kohl's comments clearly irritated the Japanese, who are trying to get the Group of Seven major industrialized nations to press the Soviet Union to return what it terms the "Northern Islands." The islands, part of the Kurile chain, were seized by the Soviets in the last days of World War II, and arguments over their ownership have prevented the signing of a formal peace treaty.
Mr. Quayle reiterated American support for Japan's claims, but neither endorsed nor criticized Japan's tactic of withholding aid, saying it was "an internal Japanese decision."
The ostensible purpose for Mr. Quayle's trip was to commemorate the 20th anniversary of Okinawa's reversion to Japan, after it was taken in one of the last and bloodiest battles of World War II. Japan seized upon the anniversary as a chance to reaffirm the security relationship between the two countries. Mr. Quayle, who is well liked here and has visited Japan more than any other senior official of the Administration save for trade negotiators, picked up on the theme, scarcely even mentioning cars, closed markets or any of the other issues that dominated Mr. Bush's visit.
 
A Piece of Advice
 At one point, however, Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, could not resist adding a jab on the topic, asking Mr. Quayle to tell American companies that they should spend less time complaining to the White House and more time investing in Japan. Mr. Quayle did not argue with him, Japanese and Americans present at the meeting said.
And while Mr. Bush was joined in January by automobile executives who railed against impediments to entering the Japanese market, Mr. Quayle met up with Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, and other Nixon Administration officials who oversaw the return of Okinawa.
Mr. Quayle also announced that the United States would return to Japan 590 acres of Okinawan territory that is currently used for American bases on the island, where two-thirds of the 56,000 American troops in Japan are stationed. He also said that the United States would cease live-fire exercises on a range in Okinawa that have been the source of local protests, and that the United States would "reinvigorate talks" over the return of additional land, including areas near the port of Naha, Okinawa's largest city.
In a further effort to quell trade troubles, he and Kozo Watanabe, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, announced a "manufacturing technology initiative" under which 100 to 200 American engineers and shop-floor supervisors will travel to Japan to study manufacturing techniques.
"We're coming over here and learning how you do it," he told a group of students on Wednesday at Keio University, one of Japan's leading private universities. "Things have changed dramatically."
Details of the aid plan were scarce today, but Japanese officials said that of the $300 million in loans from the Japan Export-Import Bank, $100 million will be dedicated to Czechoslovakia and $100 million to Hungary. The loans would be extended to government banks and other lending institutions, they said, and then disbursed at commercial rates to small businesses.
About $100 million would flow through the Japan International Development Organization, which mixes the funds of some of Japan's biggest corporations with government money. The organization makes direct equity investments in overseas enterprises, oftentimes including joint ventures.
Japan said its aid would be coordinated with "enterprise funds" from the United States, Government money directed toward private businesses by nonprofit groups, usually headed by American investment bankers.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Climbed 0.5% During April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
Industrial production rose by five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Government said today. It was the third strong advance in a row, and analysts viewed it as the latest sign that the economy had turned around.
"It provides some further evidence that the economic recovery is now becoming established," said Norman Robertson, an economist with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. 
 Lynn Reaser, an economist with the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, concurred, saying: "It's another sign that the economic recovery is taking hold. In contrast to 1991, when the economic recovery stalled in the latter part of the year, it appears that the recovery this year has more staying power."
 
 
Operating Rate Also Rose
 The Federal Reserve report also showed that capacity utilization -- the operating rate of factories, mines and utilities -- rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to 78.7 percent.
The report showed that the growth in industrial production was widespread, "led by a sharp rise in auto production."
Even without the automobile component, output rose three-tenths of 1 percent. Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said that "suggests that the recovery is sustainable, although the pace should be moderate."
The Fed also revised upward, to four-tenths of 1 percent, its initial estimate of March production. That was twice the gain first reported.
Production in April was 2.5 percent above that of April 1991.
Most analysts said the report, together with a big jump in the money supply after two weeks of decline, would almost certainly put on hold any further Fed cuts in interest rates.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's monetary policy panel, meets Tuesday. Before the latest reports, some analysts had predicted it would ease credit further to make sure the economy did not stumble again as it did in 1991.
Following the Persian Gulf war early last year, industrial production rose through the summer, only to level off last fall, then drop through January. It has picked up since.
Production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Output of generally expensive durable goods, including autos, appliances and industrial equipment, was up eight-tenths of1 percent. Production of non-durable goods, like textiles and chemicals, increased three-tenths of 1 percent.
Mining output rose eight-tenths of1 percent, but utility production dropped two-tenths of 1 percent.
The Fed said its industrial production index in April stood at 108.2 percent of its 1987 base, up from 107.6 percent in March.

HEADLINE: Trucker Who Rarely Backs Down

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEEHAWKEN, N.J., May 15

 BODY:
The New Jersey waterfront has a reputation for producing tough guys and rough talk, and a personal fortune approaching one-quarter of a billion dollars hasn't smoothed all the edges off Arthur E. Imperatore.
The 66-year-old trucking magnate, who has emerged as a central figure in New York's newspaper delivery dispute, has a way of going from prickly to generous to prickly in the span of a sentence. "I'm a very hard-nosed guy, but I truly like people," Mr. Imperatore said with a winning smile, just before his voice fell into a growl, "or I truly don't like them." 
 Making money in short-haul trucking required business acumen and attention to detail, assets widely acknowledged as Mr. Imperatore's strengths in an industry noted more for its muscle than for its finesse. But if getting his way meant squaring off on a loading dock with an uncooperative driver or screaming curses jaw-to-jaw with a labor organizer, Mr. Imperatore never hesitated. "The trucking industry," he is quick to remind the uninitiated, "is not to be confused with Sunday school."
 
A Fistful of Incentives
 Many years ago, when he and three older brothers were starting out in business with a small fleet of beat-up trucks, his temper was legendary. Once, confronting employees who were lounging when he thought they should be working, he pelted them with a fistful of coins and a stream of curses. "If you want my money for nothing, take it," he sputtered. "Take it all!"
Mr. Imperatore smiled at those memories and said he had mended his ways. Most of his temper has been reined in by mellowing age and a contemplation of life that he said he had little time for as a young man obsessed with work and success. "I was almost out of control," he recalled during a five-hour interview on the pavements of gritty towns like West New York, North Bergen and Weehawken, the haunts of a lifetime on the New Jersey side of the Hudson.
But anyone who confuses this moderation with softness on issues he deeply cares about, like his clash with the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity, would be cruelly mistaken, he warned.
"I'm a kind of local hero around here," he remarked after stopping to shake hands with a hot-dog vendor and inquire about the man's mother. "The people know I made good in a corrupt industry, and I came out of it with a whistle-clean reputation."
Many people who know Mr. Imperatore were reluctant to be interviewed about him. Even those who consented and had nice things to say refused to be quoted by name.
 
Accused of Being Stalking Horse
 "He's everything he says he is: hard-working, hard-driving and very good to his employees if they produce for him," said a high-ranking industry official. A dissident teamster who also insisted on anonymity said, "He has a reputation of being dictatorial, but he also prides himself on taking care of his drivers."
Members of the deliverers' union contend that Mr. Imperatore, whose Imperial Delivery Service bought wholesale distributors in Westchester County and on Long Island, is a stalking horse for The New York Times. The ultimate aim of the distribution deals, they assert, is breaking the union to clear the way for the opening of The Times's $450 million printing plant in Edison, N.J.
Mr. Imperatore secretly prepared to take over the wholesale operations and quickly moved to dismiss the deliverers' union members after they rejected a labor contract offered by Imperial that would have reduced the union's power and virtually eliminated overtime pay.
Union drivers picketing Mr. Imperatore's distribution centers in New Rochelle, N.Y., and East Farmingdale, L.I., said the replacement drivers hired to continue delivering The Times were non-union "scabs" Mr. Imperatore recruited months earlier from as far away as Oklahoma and Texas.
Imperial's purchase of the two operations legally ended existing labor contracts and allowed the company to build a new work force.
 
'They Could Never Push Me Around'
 The rise of Arthur Imperatore, the man in the middle of this bitter dispute, is a classic rags-to-riches tale with highly individualistic touches printed in every chapter.
The way he tells the story, he was working as a door-to-door salesman after his military discharge (he was a bomber navigator in World War II who never flew a combat mission) when his brothers started a moving and storage business using Army-surplus trucks. He chided them for spending more time drinking beer than developing the business, and was invited to help run things. Soon he was in charge, and he has been giving orders ever since.
"We've made hundreds of millions of dollars in a nickel-and-dime industry, and it was tough work," he said. "There was no 1980's type of speculation money made here. It was a case of constantly making improvements and never compromising on what's right.
"And I did it by never knuckling under to the thugs; I never compromised with the scum," he said, smacking a fist into a palm for emphasis. "I have a scorching integrity." He fired off a string of blunt words about organized crime figures and corrupt union bosses and added, "They could never push me around."
Mr. Imperatore -- the family name, which he pronounces im-PER-a-tor, dropping the final vowel, is Italian for emperor -- said that after a rocky start in the 1950's that involved wildcat strikes, his principal company, the A-P-A Transport Corporation of North Bergen, has maintained good relations with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which now represents 967 company drivers and loading-dock workers. Most of the rest of the 2,200 employees are nonunion, said Burton Treborg, A-P-A's vice president for labor relations and administration.
Harold Petsch, the business agent of Teamsters Local 617 in New Jersey, which represents the drivers at A-P-A, did not return several calls seeking comment on Mr. Imperatore and his relationship with the union.
A-P-A owns more than 3,500 tractor-trailers and other vehicles and operates 31 freight terminals around the country. Until the recession, the company had a reputation as the most profitable in the industry relative to its revenues, which in 1991 were $150 million, the owner said.
"A-P-A has always had a reputation as a very profitable and highly effective company," said William M. Legg, a managing director and trucking analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons of Baltimore. "They were very conservative in the 1980's and maintained their market while other trucking companies tried to outgrow their infrastructure and got hurt."
Mr. Imperatore said he had enjoyed good employee relations at A-P-A for decades, but added that he knew his entry into New York's tangled newspaper delivery system would probably create sparks.
It happened in a circuitous way. Mr. Imperatore has been leasing trucks to The New York Times since 1985. Without much fanfare, his Imperial Delivery Service bought two wholesalers several months ago: Westfair Newspaper Distributors, which serves Westchester County, N.Y, and Fairfield County, Conn., and the Newspaper Distributors Company, which serves Long Island.
 
Talked With Times About Wholesalers
 Mr. Imperatore said he completed the purchases -- for more than $17 million -- only after informal but extensive talks with executives of The Times. Times officials, he said, took part in introducing him to the owners of the wholesalers and in negotiating his purchase of them.
Walter E. Mattson, the president of the New York Times Company, confirmed much of Mr. Imperatore's recollection of his relationship with The Times. "We had been very happy with the quality of his trucking operations for us and found him to be a man of great integrity who was committed to his employees," said Mr. Mattson. "He was also able to deal with the unions effectively."
The Times Company encouraged Mr. Imperatore when he expressed interest in entering the wholesale distribution business, Mr. Mattson explained, adding, "He was exactly the kind of guy who would be a great addition to the business." The Times, he said, told Mr. Imperatore of an opportunity to buy a Peekskill, N.Y., distributing operation as a start.
Mr. Imperatore formed Imperial Delivery Service and bought the Peekskill company in December 1989. Imperial officials then set about learning the trade and training a work force with the idea that the skills developed there could ultimately be applied to operations elsewhere in the metropolitan area, Mr. Imperatore explained.
In Peekskill, Mr. Imperatore's company signed a contract with Teamsters Local 917, in New York City. The agreement, he said, gave the local jurisdiction over any newspaper operations Imperial conducted within 200 miles, an area that would blanket New York and its suburbs.
In anticipation of his move into New York this spring, he recruited about 125 drivers over the last five months in case he had to replace roughly 260 full-time and fill-in drivers working under the union contract.
Some, billeted at several hotels near the East Farmingdale distribution center, said they were from as far away as Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. Several said they had been unemployed. One driver wore a black T-shirt hand-painted with a drawing of a rig from Arizona. Another said he was a bus driver from Philadelphia.
"I ain't no teamster," said one of the drivers testily in the lobby of the Comfort Inn. "I'm a rebel. We ain't here for no union. I wouldn't ever be here with no union."
 
Childhood Home Behind Fruit Stand
 The trip across the Hudson from an impoverished childhood to the towers of Manhattan has been a lifetime voyage for Mr. Imperatore. One of his earliest memories, he said, was the view from his father's fruit stand on Palisade Avenue at 51st Street in West New York. "I could see them building the Empire State Building, floor by floor, in 1930."
His family, with 11 children, was crammed into an upstairs apartment behind the fruit stand. A brother, Andrew, still lives there.
"Only seven persons could sit in chairs around the table at supper," Mr. Imperatore said. "Some of us had to sit on the ironing board."
Andrew said, "Arthur could never sit still," as his brother's body and trailing voice banged down the stairs after a whirlwind visit. "He could never stop. He was always on the move."
Mr. Imperatore retains considerable energy. He is forever picking up bits of litter on his properties, muttering under and over his breath about a sloppiness he cannot abide and is constantly after his employees to correct. He said his insistence on neatness was part of a strategy to engender respect in the workplace. "Visual surroundings have an impact on people," he said. "Give them a dysfunctional place and they become dysfunctional."
The A-P-A complex is landscaped and spotless. In addition to garages and maintenance sheds, there are an administration building, tennis courts, hobby rooms and a recreation center. The center, which Mr. Imperatore says cost $750,000 in 1973, houses a full-length basketball court, swimming pool and jacuzzi, weight rooms and an aerobics center.
 
'Honest Workman' In Reverent Oil
 In the entrance to the company's nerve center is a shrine-like alcove bathed in soft light that shelters an oil painting called "The Honest Workman." "See that look," Mr. Imperatore said with a nod at the portrait. "We modeled 15 different men to get that look." The expression on the face is something between a Mona Lisa smile and a smirk. "That look says to me: 'Listen, boss. I did a good day's work. And if you don't appreciate it, you know what you can do.' "
Nothing, however, prepares a visitor for the building's executive conference room on the second floor.
"I had it rebuilt three times before I was satisfied," Mr. Imperatore said with a sweep of an arm toward a 16-foot hand-carved table and 10 matching chairs, trimmed in gold and metal-studded leather, standing on an Oriental rug. The walls are covered by gold-trimmed woodwork and rich green Italian silk; a fireplace anchors one end of the room and ornate balustrades the other. Adjoining the room is a glass-roofed atrium filled with plants and a fountain topped by a crouching Venus and, on a lower tier, pipe-playing fauns.
A-P-A's basic principle, Mr. Imperatore said, is that good job performance earns job security.
The company hires only 1 of 50 applicants who go through a long screening, training and probation. For decades A-P-A has subscribed to newspapers in cities where it operates. Articles on arrests are clipped, and the names of suspects go into a cross-indexed computer file. Job applicants whose names turn up presumably begin the hiring derby at some disadvantage.
 
Scrutiny as Intensive As the Vacations
 Drivers and dockworkers who make the grade are brought to North Bergen for interviews with A-P-A's president, Armand Pohan, who is Mr. Imperatore's stepson; Mr. Treborg, and the director of operations. Mr. Imperatore stopped interviewing applicants after turning day-to-day operations over to Mr. Pohan in 1983 and becoming chairman of the board, but he still prides himself on knowing the first names of many workers.
"Nothing comes closer to a marriage than hiring a teamster," Mr. Imperatore often observes. "And it's easier to get a divorce than to try to remove a teamster from a job."
A-P-A has fitted its trucks with recorders that log everything from fuel consumption to stops and starts, measuring performance against company standards. If too many sub-par trips show up on a driver's record, his supervisors may conclude that he is not functioning at the peak level Mr. Imperatore demands. Bad performance can lead to warnings, probation and lengthy arbitration talks to seek dismissal.
Top performers are declared "A-P-A Aces" and get bonuses and other incentives. Sometimes Mr. Imperatore takes the entire staff to places like Las Vegas and the Bahamas.
But he can also be overbearing, and a local joke holds that A-P-A stands for "Always Please Arthur."
Before his venture into newspaper distribution, he spent much time in the last decade planning to build a high-rise "Venice on the Hudson" on a 367-acre tract in Weehawken that he bought in 1981 for $7.7 million. Zoning problems and a weak economy postponed his ambitions and he is using the site as a public recreation area that includes a driving range; his ferry service, which carries 9,000 people to Manhattan daily, and a marina where he docks his 141-foot motor yacht, "Imperator."
Mr. Imperatore has been relatively untouched by stories of scandal. The licensing of his ferries in 1987 came under a cloud when Anthony R. Ameruso, the New York City transportation official, later admitted he had invested in a company associated with Mr. Imperatore's development concern. Mr. Ameruso resigned and was convicted of perjury in connection with his testimony anout the investment. Mr. Imperatore denied any knowledge of the investment.
Local residents who battled the high-rise buildings had mixed emotions about the man who was their adversary.
"He's not someone who sets out to deliberately hurt others, but he's very paternalistic and thinks he knows what's good for everyone," said James Dette, a civil engineer. "He fails to treat others as adults. He wants things done his way."
Ruth Elsasser, president of the Weehawken Environmental Association, said: "He's a very colorful figure who fights hard for what he wants. But in all our fights I never knew him to use underhanded methods."

HEADLINE: ISRAELI CHARGES PRESSURE BY U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 15

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said in a published interview today that the United States was trying to force Israel to yield nearly all the territory it had captured in the 1967 Middle East war.
Other senior Israeli officials have issued similar charges in recent months, including one Shamir aide who said Israel would be returned to the "borders of Auschwitz" if it went back to its pre-1967 frontiers. 
 But this was the first time the Prime Minister made the accusation, although he has criticized the Bush Administration for trying, in his view, to dictate the course of negotiations on Israel's occupied territories in the Middle East peace talks.
 
Finds U.S. More Rigid
 "The United States really wants to return us to the 1967 borders with minor border adjustments," he told the newspaper Haaretz. "The difference between this Administration and its predecessors is that it shows determination in implementing its position, while other administrations trusted that the issues would be resolved in the course of negotiations."
Nonetheless, even though he has complained that the United States had ceased to be an "honest broker" and was tilting toward the Arabs, Mr. Shamir added that "until now they have behaved acceptably" in the talks between Israel and Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians.
Like much of the world, the United States has called on Israel to yield territory in return for guarantees of peace with its neighbors. But it has not suggested that Israel give up every inch of land under its control in the West Bank, Gaza, Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, whose annexation by the Israelis is not recognized by Washington.
 
Cards Close to the Chest
 In any event, Mr. Shamir told Haaretz that he personally was "not capable of surrendering territory," saying that the future of the territories was to be negotiated by his successors. Elections are scheduled June 23, and the outcome is very much in doubt.
"After the violence is stopped and the emotions are calmed a bit, it will be possible to think about an agreed solution," he said. He said he had "all kinds of ideas" about a permanent solution, and added that he had discussed them in the 1980's with George P. Shultz, who was then Secretary of State.
"But I don't want to publicize these ideas," he said, "because if we begin discussing them, we will not achieve any immediate progress."
 
Fragile Relationship
 His remarks highlighted new tensions in American-Israeli relations: This week the State Department reaffirmed its support for a 1948 United Nations resolution that Palestinians say gives them the right to return to Israel and to be compensated for lost or damaged property. The issue is of paramount sensitivity for Israelis of all political leanings, who say that a flood of Arab refugees would overwhelm them and ultimately destroy Israel.
In the interview, Mr. Shamir said Israel should start looking more to Europe for support and not rely solely on Washington, which gives this country $3 billion a year in economic and military aid.
"But Europe still isn't the United States," he said. "From a strategic standpoint, the United States is the only superpower. Europe hasn't reached unity, and it will take time until it does."

HEADLINE: Florio Says He Will Veto Republicans' One-Cent Cut in Sales Tax

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 15

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio said today that he would veto a bill to roll back the state sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent.
His decision sets the stage for a showdown with the Legislature's overwhelmingly Republican majority. An effort to override a veto may be in jeopardy because of weak support among Senate Republicans. 
 "As much as I would like to sign a penny rollback of the sales tax, I cannot sign this one," Mr. Florio said. "We simply have not been given any information. I cannot assure you that the penny rollback would be a good deal, because the Legislature hasn't met its obligation to tell you how you would be affected."
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, intended to make the announcement during his weekly radio address on Saturday, two days before the deadline for action on the bill. His aides gave copies of the Governor's text to some newspapers with the stipulation that the information not appear until after Mr. Florio's taped address was broadcast.
When word of Mr. Florio's plans leaked out to Republicans, among others, the Governor's office lifted the embargo.
Mr. Florio said he would sign the veto on Monday and return the bill to the Legislature with a list of conditions it must meet before he would support a rollback. The conditions include passage of a balanced budget that maintains school aid, homestead rebates, aid to N.J. Transit to keep fares stable and money to municipalities to prevent property tax increases.
The Governor said the Republicans also must promise to stabilize college tuition, provide adequate money to protect the New Jersey Shore and support programs for children, the blind and the physically disabled.
Republican leaders have not disclosed what programs they would cut to cover the revenue losses from the sales tax reduction. That has caused apprehension among the party's rank and file, especially in the Senate, where as many as six Republicans who voted for the bill are wavering in their support of an override.
New Jersey's fiscal year begins July 1. After several missed deadlines, Republican leaders said this week that they would present their budget by early next month.
Mr. Florio had warned the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, and the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, both Republicans, that he would not support the sales tax rollback unless they specified the cuts they intended to make.
Mr. Haytaian announced at the beginning of the week that he would convene the Assembly on May 21 for a session to override a veto. He commands a 58-to-22 majority in the Assembly, where the override is expected to pass easily. The bill to roll back the sales tax passed the Assembly by 54 to 21 on March 23, with solid Republican support.
On Thursday, Mr. Florio invited Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Haytaian to the executive mansion in Princeton, Drumthwacket, to discuss the budget.
 
Response 'on the 21st'
 "Once again they would not say what they plan to cut," Mr. Florio said. "It is sad to say, but the degree of fiscal irresponsibility is startling."
Mr. Haytaian said the Governor would get the Assembly's response "on the 21st."
"The sales tax cut is going to take effect July 1," he told The Associated Press.
But the combative Assembly Speaker had an immediate reaction to Mr. Florio's charge that the Republicans were being irresponsible.
"Has it been responsible for him to present us with a budget three years in a row where the revenue figures are wrong, where we have built-in deficits, where we have one-shot gimmicks to close deficits?" Mr. Haytaian said. "Is that the height of responsibility? I don't think so."
In the Senate, chances of an override are more tenuous, even with a Republican majority of 27 to 13. The rollback proposal passed the Senate on April 2 by a 28-to-1 vote, with a lone Republican, Senator Henry P. McNamara of Wyckoff, opposing it. Most Democrats abstained, but two of them, John H. Adler of Cherry Hill and Raymond J. Zane of Woodbury, sided with the Republicans in voting for the rollback.
Mr. Zane said today that he would not support an override attempt unless the Republicans made public their planned budget cuts and he agreed with them.
Mr. Adler said he was undecided on how he would vote.
"I voted for the rollback when it was presented, and I continue to believe that we really need to downsize the government," Mr. Adler said in an interview. "This particular tax has prolonged New Jersey's recession and it unfairly hurts sectors of New Jersey's people."
If Mr. Zane and Mr. Adler rejoined the Democratic fold on the override vote, the Republicans would have to persuade Mr. McNamara to drop his opposition to the bill and to cajole other Republicans whose support is wavering, party sources have said.
"We will have the votes," Mr. DiFrancesco said today.
To override the veto, the Republicans need 54 votes in the Assembly, 4 fewer than its majority, and all 27 of their votes in the Senate.
Campaigning against a record $2.8 billion tax package that the Florio administration rushed through the Democratic-controlled Legislature in 1990, Republicans pummeled the Democrats in last November's legislative elections. Voters elected Republicans in numbers not only large enough to command the Legislature, but to override Governor Florio.
But as they approach their fifth month in power, Republicans have yet to exploit fully their advantage in numbers, allowing Mr. Florio to outmaneuver them politically on the Legislature's attempt to postpone school elections and to block an increase in the minimum wage to a national record of $5.05 an hour on April 1.
Republicans failed on both of those initiatives because of a rule that allowed the Governor to wait 45 days before acting on legislation. By the time Mr. Florio vetoed the bills the school elections had occurred and workers had already started receiving the higher minimum wage.
"The Republicans feel they have to win the first override," said Stephen A. Salmore, a Republican consultant and a political science professor at Rutgers University. "To have the ability and not be able to carry it out will hurt them. It is not nearly effective to say that we promised, we tried to deliver and mean old Jim Florio didn't let it happen, than to say we promised it and we did it."

He said he plans to veto the bill on Monday and return it to the Legislature with a list of conditions it must meet before he would support a rollback in the tax. Mr. Florio worked in his office yesterday at the State House in Trenton. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)
