HEADLINE: 11 Closings: The Impact Rumbles In Region

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Standing on the Bronx corner where he has parked his hot-dog cart for 14 years, Vassilios Koulikordis had a view of the Alexander's closing that was much too close for comfort.
Early yesterday, he watched a stream of employees -- people who buy his hot dogs, sodas and pretzels -- walk up blankly to the row of metal gates at the store on the Grand Concourse, the anchor to the bustling and healthy Fordham Road shopping center. Some hugged. All were stunned. 
 "I come this morning I see 20 women, women I know by their first names, crying like little kids," said Mr. Koulikordis, a 41-year-old immigrant from Greece. "Today for me it's a very sad day. I see the gates close, it's like a member of my family passed away."
But Mr. Koulikordis's sorrow was not only for his friends. Since Alexander's opened its first store on Third Avenue in the Bronx in 1928, the chain served as a strong commercial magnet in several of the neighborhoods where it dressed generations of immigrants and their children in style.
Even where Alexander's was one store among many, the closing was yet another sign of business gone bad. And merchants who thrived because they were close to one of the 11 Alexander's in the city and its suburbs could suffer after the chain's death.
"Without this store," Mr. Koulikordis said, "I can't survive."
 
'Secondary Impacts'
 Employees, merchants and experts around the region compared the immediate effects of the closing to the rumble of a small urban earthquake. The damage, they said, would not be confined to the 5,200 Alexander's employees who lost their jobs and yesterday were met instead with locked doors and white signs that read: "Closed for Inventory."
"There are secondary impacts," said Herbert Bienstock, professor of labor at Queens College. "The guy who owns the garage on 59th Street in Manhattan; What is this going to do to him? The same is true in Queens and Brooklyn and the Bronx. There are satellite businesses that depend on them -- liquor stores, clothing stores and restaurants."
And in the hearts of some shoppers and longtime employees -- some of whom knew George Farkas, the dapper and savvy founder who named the chain for his father -- the passing of Alexander's meant the passing of an era in New York City.
"They provided their lower-middle-class customers with the sense of being well dressed, of getting fashionable clothes at bargain prices," said Alan G. Millstein, editor and publisher of Fashion Network Report.
 
Ferrer Is Confident
 The closing was also a lightning-quick lesson in the market economy. Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, for example, mourned the passing of Alexander's in one sentence, then in the next acted as booster to the overall health of the 325 stores in the Fordham Road shopping district.
Echoing the hope both of Alexander's management and a number of economists, he said he felt confident that a new tenant would move into the four-story brick store that now advertises in big red letters: "Uptown It's Alexander's."
Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said he hoped the same for the other Alexander's sites. He said he was concerned less about the flagship store at 58th Street in Manhattan than with the sites in Rego Park, Queens, or in Kings Plaza Shopping Mall and Marina in Brooklyn, where merchants are already worried about the future of the Macy's store there.
"I would hope that because all these areas are dynamic shopping and retail areas that there will be retailers that come in and replace or succeed Alexander's," he said. "I suspect some are already in contact with Alexander's."
Some real-estate brokers, however, expressed doubt that the buildings would be occupied immediately. Alexander's has sold stores in the past, but may have more difficulty now because so many retailers are besieged with financial problems of their own.
But all speculation about the closings was muted by shock at how quickly the decision came to close a New York institution. There had been rumors and layoffs, but few realized how near Alexander's was to the end.
At the Green Acres Mall in Valley Stream, L.I., one of three stores outside New York City, customers clutching bags of goods they wanted to return lined up to closed doors.
Hardest hit were the employees, many of whom had worked at Alexander's for decades. Aside from their paychecks, they said they would miss the almost old-fashioned sense of family that the corporation tried to foster from its start. The abruptness was almost worse than the closing itself, they said.
"It would have helped if they told us a month ago -- or at least given us a few weeks' notice so we could start looking for other jobs," said Michael Sobol, a sales clerk from Lynbrook, L.I. "They knew they were going to close down, but wanted us here to the end."
In the Bronx, Mr. Koulikordis, the hot-dog vendor, discussed how his cart has supported his family.
Business was already hurt, he said. By lunch he usually sold as many as five cases of soda. Yesterday at noon he said he had sold only six cans.
His worry prompted him earlier to pick up a red pencil from the cart and scrawl a message on a sign on a metal grate. The sentiment stronger than the spelling, his note read: "I hope your open soon. Hot Dog Man."

HEADLINE: Judge Tells City to Obey Charter And Set Up New Budget Office

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court judge has ordered New York City to create the Independent Budget Office, a city agency mandated three years ago by the new City Charter.
In a decision last Tuesday, Justice Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, rejected the city's argument that "hard economic times" justified withholding financing for the agency. 
 Justice Ciparick wrote that city officials "cannot resort to illegal acts" to avoid complying with the Charter. "The critical point is that their actions violate duly enacted provisions of the City Charter."
The budget office was included in the revised Charter approved by voters in 1989, and was to be operating by Aug. 1, 1990. But Mr. Dinkins has not included it in his budget proposals, and the Council has not appropriated money for it.
The Charter calls for the agency to receive no less than 10 percent of the figure allotted to the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget, which is to receive about $29 million in the next fiscal year.
If the city were forced to create the office, it would mean less money for other city operations in a time of tight budgets.
 
Appeal, Comply or Amend
 Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday that Mr. Vallone had not yet received a copy of the order and that no decision had been made about whether to appeal it. Other options include complying with the order, she said, or amending the Charter.
The ruling was made in a lawsuit brought by the New York Public Interest Research Group and other advocacy organizations. Gene Russianoff, senior attorney for the public interest group, said yesterday that the ruling was a significant victory for the community groups, which support creation of the office as a source of "objective and independent" budget information and analysis. The budget is prepared by the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget and sent to the Council, which has its own budget analysts, for approval.
As the budget has grown and become increasingly complex over the years (a $29.5 billion spending plan has been proposed for the fiscal year that begins July 1), some community groups have complained that it is nearly impossible for those outside government to analyze and comprehend the document. They viewed the independent office as a tool for democratizing the budget process by providing an independent source of budget information.

HEADLINE: Duties Set On Canada Lumber

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
The Commerce Department issued a final determination today that the Canadian Government was improperly subsidizing its lumber industry, a finding that puts further strain on the United States' troubled trade relations with Canada.
The department found that permanent countervailing duties of 6.51 percent should be placed on imports of Canadian lumber, but such duties cannot be imposed unless the International Trade Commission, a United States agency, rules that the Canadian subsidies have injured the American lumber industry. 
 Today's announcement, which is an important step toward permanent duties on imported boards, studs and beams from Canada, will help United States lumber companies compete, but will raise prices for Americans buying new houses.
 
 
Anger in Canada
 The announcement angered Canadian officials and lumber company executives, who said they would press Washington to arbitrate an agreement to the dispute.
"We have always said the whole case is contrived," said Tom Buell, chairman of the Canadian Forest Industries Council, a trade association based in Vancouver, British Columbia. "It's the American consumer who is getting dinged."
But Canadian officials expressed relief that the Commerce Department's call for duties was far lower than the 14.48 percent it recommended in March when it made its preliminary finding of unfair subsidies.
"It should help lower the temperature of this dispute," said Derek H. Burney, the Canadian Ambassador to the United States.
 But, at a news conference today in Washington, Mr. Burney added, "Make no mistake, we continue to believe the case against Canada has no merit."
 
Source of Embarrassment
 Today's decision will be a source of some embarrassment for the Bush Administration, because Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada is scheduled to visit Washington on Wednesday. The Commerce Department was originally scheduled to announce the decision next week, but it moved the announcement forward.
The Commerce Department decision came after months of wrangling between the United States and its largest trading partner in numerous areas, including beer and Japanese-brand cars assembled in Canada.
After months of complaining about low-priced Canadian lumber, the American timber industry applauded the decision, but with reservations. "The final determination on subsidies is substantially below the preliminary one, and to that extent we're somewhat discouraged," said Joseph McCracken, president of the Western Forest Industries Association, a trade group based in Portland, Ore. "But at least they've gone through the process on the merits, and you have to congratulate them for that."
 
 
Economic Damage Is Seen
 Home builders were much less sanguine. "Any duty at this time is bad for home buyers and bad for the U.S. economy," said Robert Buchert, president of the National Association of Home Builders. "If the full amount of the duty shows up in U.S. lumber prices, it will add nearly $300 to the price of a house."
The last step in the process, the final determination of whether there was injury, is scheduled for late June by the International Trade Commission.
Canadian officials said they would seek to establish an arbitration panel under the aegis of the 1988 Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Canada. They are also asking the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization that oversees world trade, to find the American duties illegal.
According to the Commerce Department, the United States imported $2.6 billion in softwood lumber from Canada in the 1991 fiscal year.
 
 
2 Types of Subsidies
 The Commerce Department found two types of subsidies in today's decision. It said that by charging below-market prices for trees cut on public lands, Canadian provinces subsidized their exports by an average of 2.91 percent. The department also found that an additional national subsidy of 3.6 percent came from British Columbia's ban on exporting raw logs from public lands, a practice that forces loggers to sell to local mills.
Canadian officials call this latter finding hypocritical because Washington also limits log exports from Federal lands.
Until the United States decides next month whether to impose a permanent duty, Canadian lumber companies are allowed to post bond showing their ability to pay the temporary duties on their shipments.

HEADLINE: EMPIRE IN TROUBLE;
Huge Project in London Faces Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 15

 BODY:
Canary Wharf, the huge but half-built office project that crowns Olympia & York's global empire, now faces an uncertain future as bankers here consider whether to continue lending money, run the project themselves or bring construction to a halt.
Olympia & York Developments Ltd. persuaded its main construction lenders today not to force the project into bankruptcy for the time being. "No one is taking a precipitate action at the moment," one banker said. 
 The banks also agreed to continue paying out the emergency 21 million, or $38.2 million, that they granted a week ago to enable construction at Canary Wharf to continue until the end of the month.
 
Some Banks Not at Meeting
 But one bank executive cautioned that 4 or 5 of the 11 banks with construction loans to Canary Wharf were not at today's meeting and that their approval was needed for the agreement to hold.
As Olympia & York's largest project, Canary Wharf represents its dream of building a third London business district to rival the West End and the venerable City. Instead, the project has drained the company's financial strength. The opposition Labor Party contends that the ruling Conservatives are planning a de facto bailout by moving many Government offices to Canary Wharf.
Olympia has every reason for wanting to keep the 71-acre project in East London out of British bankruptcy proceedings. Under British law, the creditors would wield much more influence than they would in Canada or the United States. The decision on how or whether to bring Canary Wharf out of bankruptcy or to liquidate it would be largely theirs.
 
'A Harder Sell'
 But analysts and real estate agents said the bankruptcy filings in North America had compounded the project's problems. By underlining Olympia's financial troubles, the filings could make it more difficult to attract tenants. "It has to make it a harder sell," one of Canary Wharf's real estate agents said.
Canary Wharf has lined up tenants for only about 60 percent of the approximately 4.6 million square feet of available or nearly completed office space. The British press loves to dwell on the project's shortcomings, like its still-inadequate road and rail system.
At a morning news conference held on the 30th floor of Canary Wharf's 812-foot tower, Robert S. Miller Jr., a financial adviser to Olympia, said the relatively small number of banks should make it possible to avoid the kind of grab for assets in Britain that forced Olympia to seek court protection from creditors in North America.
 
Banks Evaluating Options
 But bankers said they could change their minds about pushing Canary Wharf into bankruptcy, depending upon how events unfold. "Banks are evaluating all the options in the current situation following the latest move in North America," said Adrian Russell, a spokesman for Barclays Bank P.L.C.
When the 11 banks agreed to lend more money a week ago, they stressed that their purpose was to give Olympia & York and its 100-or-so lenders time to hammer out an all-encompassing plan for dealing with the company's financial problems.
Mr. Miller said that Canary Wharf's bank debts now total about 1.15 billion, or $2.09 billion -- somewhat more than previously estimated -- including 100 million from the European Investment Bank, a European Community institution.
 
500 Million in Loans Covered
 About 500 million, or $909.3 million, is covered by the bankruptcy filing. Those loans, which come from a small group of banks including Canadian Imperial, Royal Bank of Canada and Bank of Nova Scotia, are backed only by guarantees from Olympia itself, meaning that the banks cannot seize Canary Wharf property.
Additional construction loans of 550 million, or $1 billion, are backed by the Canary Wharf buildings. These loans, not covered by the Canadian filing, come from the 11 banks that have also extended the emergency help, including Barclays, Lloyds Bank, Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover, several Canadian banks, Credit Suisse, Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking and Credit Lyonnais.
Desperate to attract new tenants, Mr. Miller and Michael Dennis, the chief executive of Canary Wharf, tried their best today to persuade the public that the North American bankruptcy filings do not threaten the project or brand it a failure. They called the filings "somewhere between a neutral and a positive for Canary Wharf" because, they said, they would give Olympia time to negotiate a long-term debt plan with all its lenders.
 
An Apparent Achievement
 To many visitors, especially those who remember the decaying piers that once dominated the site, Canary Wharf does appear to be a stunning achievement. Nine sparkling office buildings, a shopping complex, and well-appointed walkways and squares now overlook the Thames.
Tenants include Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns, Ogilvy & Mather, the International Wheat Council, the International Sugar Organization, State Street Bank, KPMG Peat Marwick, CNA Reinsurance and Telegraph, the publisher of Britain's largest broadsheet daily newspaper.
Canary Wharf also has commitments from American Express, Texaco, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lehman Brothers International and Credit Suisse First Boston.
The project's main problem is the British recession, which has caused London office vacancies to soar and rental rates to plunge.
 
Juicy Incentives
 The 40 percent vacancy rate at Canary Wharf would undoubtedly be much higher were it not for the juicy incentives that Olympia & York has offered. Real estate agents say incentives like rent-free periods and furnishing allowances have often trimmed in half the official rents of 25 to 35 a square foot, or $45.46 to $63.65. In addition, Olympia & York has been assuming companies' leases elsewhere or even buying their buildings to get them to relocate to Canary Wharf.
Olympia & York executives are hoping that the British Government, which is overflowing its offices in central London, will soon agree to rent large amounts of space at Canary Wharf.
Since the Conservatives were behind the ambitious program to redevelop the derelict docklands, the Labor Party suspects that the Government is planning to pay above-market rates for space to bail out the project. Government ministers say they will do no such thing.
Mr. Miller said today that negotiations with the Government were continuing but that the company was not seeking inflated rents. "The company has not asked for a bailout," he added.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 15.79, to 3,353.09, on Olympia News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market fell broadly yesterday after Olympia & York, the world's largest development company, filed for protection from creditors in Canada and the United States. Banks, which could suffer heavy losses from Olympia & York's troubles, were among the issues hardest hit.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.79 points, to 3,353.09, putting it down 16.32 for the week. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 208.8 million shares, up from 200.4 million in Thursday's session.
Stocks in Tokyo and London also fell on the Olympia & York announcement.
Another factor contributing to the tumble on the broader United States market, analysts said, was the expiration of stock index futures and options.
 
Decline Less Than Expected
 Although many investors were made jittery by the insolvency news, the market in the United States did not fall as far as many analysts had thought it might..
"The market acted extremely well in the face of Olympia & York," said Dudley Eppel, managing director of equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The bond market, meanwhile, rallied on the Olympia & York news and on speculation that the Fed might ease interest rates. Mark Donahoe, managing director for institutional equities at Piper Jaffray Inc., said the bond rally also helped support stocks.
Stock traders, though, shrugged off the latest economic data. The Federal Reserve said industrial production jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the third straight advance. Economists had expected an increase of only two-tenths of1 percent. Investors, many of whom believe the market is overvalued, want signs of real strength in the recovery.
"The market's tired; it's the early summer blahs," said William E. Raftery, an analyst with Smith Barney.
 
Most Active: Citicorp
 The Nasdaq composite index slid 2.03 points, to 574.43. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.41, to 226.31, while the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.42, to 390.37.
The most actively traded Big Board issue was Citicorp, down 37.5 cents, to $19.625. Other bank stocks that were lower on the Olympia & York news were J. P. Morgan, down 62.5 cents, to $55; Chemical Bank, down 50 cents, to $37.50, and Chase Manhattan, down 37.5 cents, to $29.375.
Among other actively traded issues, the Gap Inc. slid $3, to $33.875, after analysts on Thursday lowered the company's 1993 earnings estimates, and Coca-Cola, up 12.5 cents at $43.25.
Among blue chips, International Business Machines slipped 12.5 cents, to $91.625. American Telephone and Telegraph fell 50 cents, to $42.625.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Dips in U.S. Trading; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly lower in domestic foreign-exchange trading yesterday because of technical factors and the growing strength of the German mark.
Gold prices ended higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.70 an ounce, up 70 cents from the Thursday close. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $338.50 an ounce, up $1.15. 
 The dollar was mostly higher abroad, but fell in New York. Germany's central bank was reported to be buying marks to push up German interest rates as part of the country's tight monetary policy, said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer in New York.
Currency traders were also keeping an eye on the shares of banking companies worldwide to see if they were affected by news that parts of Olympia & York had filed for bankruptcy protection, Mr. Simon said. Trouble in banking stocks could prompt central banks to lower interest rates, which generally hurts the value of currencies.
One positive influence on the dollar was a report issued Thursday afternoon that the United States money supply rose by a larger-than-expected amount. That was viewed as lessening the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 130.60 Japanese yen, from 129.87 yen at the Thursday close. Later, in London, the dollar rose to 130.15 yen. But in New York the dollar closed at 129.80 yen, down from 130.15 late Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8185, from $1.8215 late Thursday. In New York, the pound strengthened to $1.8220, from $1.81875.
In Europe, $1 bought 1.6145 German marks, up from 1.6140 late Thursday. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.6105 marks, from 1.6115 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
A Good Mix: Social Action With Profits

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York said Thursday that he was likely to back Nelson Mandela's request that the city lift economic sanctions against South Africa, he was in line with one of the fastest-growing investment trends: using economic muscle to forge social change, as well as earn a good return.
The Mayor released a letter from Mr. Mandela, the president of the African National Congress, saying, "We will issue a call to you and other heads of government who have helped our cause to assist in building our economy," as soon as an interim government is established. Mr. Mandela said he wanted "to discuss reintroduction of trade and investment." 
 That is coming full circle; for many investors, both individual and institutional, the first notion of socially responsible investing came in the 1970's, when the Rev. Leon Sullivan called upon American business and investors to avoid putting money into South Africa because of its policy of apartheid then. And the notion quickly spread to other causes.
Janet Prindle, a partner in Neuberger & Berman, and Farha-Joyce Haboucha, a senior portfolio manager at the firm, who head its Socially Responsive Investment Services, said that a decade ago socially responsive investors were primarily liberals who avoided putting money into stocks of companies that offended them -- either because of products like cigarettes or alcohol or because their plants polluted or because they had poor records in employing minorities and women.
"Today it's not just hippies," Ms. Prindle said. People across the political spectrum are investing according to the dictates of their own consciences, believing that business has the power to bring about changes in society. "Some yuppies want to be corporate good citizens," she said.
One difference now, Ms. Haboucha said, "is that we don't approach it so much from an avoidance position as looking for companies that are really making a change -- leadership."
One such company, Ms. Haboucha said, is Brooklyn Union Gas. Natural gas is environmentally sound, and the company has a strong commitment to employing women and minorities, she said, along with "amazing support for community programs and special handicapped programs," and it developed natural gas vehicles.
Neuberger & Berman, which manages $21 billion of investments, bases its investment decisions first on fundamental analysis, screening stocks for good return on equity, strong cash flow, low price-earnings ratios and other such standards.
Next, individually tailored social criteria are considered for the 15 clients, including individuals and pension funds, with $25 million in the firm's socially responsive investment program. Nationally, such investments have grown to $625 billion from $40 billion eight years ago, according to the Social Investment Forum, a Minneapolis-based association.
"There isn't a right or wrong," Ms. Prindle said. "People have to decide what is most important to them." For example, she said, some investors shun Philip Morris, which stacks up well in financial analysis, because they dislike its beer and tobacco products. Others love it because it has a strong record of employing women and minorities.
Wal-Mart Stores, on the other hand, passes the social criteria with flying colors, but it is trading at too high a price-earnings multiple for the firm to hold it, she said.
Douglas E. Salvati, manager of Shearson Lehman Brothers' Socially Responsible Investing Program, which has $60 million under investment, has among his current holdings: H & R Block; Equitable Resources, a natural gas company; Mylan Laboratories, which makes generic drugs; H. F. Ahmanson, a savings and loan, and Superior Industries International, which makes aluminum wheels for cars.
He cited as companies to watch because they are "pure plays" from an environmental standpoint: Air and Water Technology, Safety-Kleen, Nalco Chemical and Betz Laboratories. However, he is not recommending them at present because they are overvalued by his financial criteria.
Neuberger & Berman's program is for clients who want professional management for portfolios of at least $250,000. The Shearson program is similar with a $100,000 minimum. However, investors with accounts of any size can work with individual brokers to use social criteria.
Ms. Haboucha recommended a book, "Investing for a Better World," from the Council of Economic Priorities in New York, as a good way to learn more. Also, mutual funds like the Evergreen family of funds in Harrison, N.Y., and the Pax World Fund, Portsmouth, N.H., appeal to socially conscious investors.
"Some people are concerned that a social screen will limit investment opportunities," Mr. Salvati said, "but we have not sacrificed diversification, and our performance has been competitive." Both he and the Neuberger & Berman team said they had generally outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 on their equity holdings.

HEADLINE: Nassau Plans to Borrow To Cover Budget Deficit

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 15

 BODY:
Torn, like many other local governments, between crippling service reductions or wrenching tax increases, Republicans and Democrats in Nassau County have reached a consensus to do neither: they want to sell up to $100 million in bonds instead.
Under the plan, the county will ask the State Legislature for permission to borrow up to $100 million for at least five years, shifting the burden of the county's current fiscal problems to future taxpayers, perhaps in a less recession-ravaged era. 
 While 20 other cities, counties and school districts in the state have resorted to deficit financing to pay their bills, Nassau's deficit-borrowing plan would be the largest since the Municipal Assistance Corporation sold $5.4 billion in bonds to bail out New York City during the 1970's.
"Every door you open to get out of this morass or maze, you are confronted by a monster worse than the one you faced before," said Bruce Nyman, a Democratic Supervisor from Long Beach. "This doesn't seem to be getting better. Every time you come up with a solution it makes things worse."
 
The Latest Calamity
 The consensus emerged from private staff meetings during the last few weeks, after the latest fiscal calamity -- a newly disclosed midyear deficit of $130 million in a budget of $1.8 billion -- in a county that is among the wealthiest and most heavily taxed in the nation.
The staff consensus followed months of stormy efforts to fashion political and fiscal solutions to the county's problems in the Board of Supervisors, where, under a weighted voting system, neither party has a ruling majority and government has ground to a halt.
At one point Democrats had sought unsuccessfully to block the Republicans -- who had ruled the county for three-quarters of a century -- from issuing paychecks to political employees. Deals have been announced only to fall apart hours later in bickering and name-calling.
At one point the leader of the Democrats, Lewis J. Yevoli, a supervisor from Oyster Bay, said he would never talk to Joseph N. Mondello, the leader of the Republicans on the board, without a stenographer present. But as the county's problems worsened -- tax receipts fell short, cutbacks saved less than expected -- a small team of budget and fiscal staff members began quiet diplomacy.
 
2-Year Tax Freeze
 The fiscal aides are to present the plan to the Board of Supervisors and the County Executive next week. It would freeze county taxes this year and next, avoid any more layoffs (more than 1 in 10 workers has already been laid off) and stabilize the county's budget for two years.
The board will be given a choice of options to cut the budget further -- including significant employee givebacks. Any remaining deficit up to $100 million -- officials hope to keep it to $35 million to $50 million -- would be made up by deficit borrowing, to be paid back during the next 5 or 10 years. The new borrowing would come on top of the county's current long-term debt of $1.62 billion.
The plan was hailed by both Democrats and Republicans, who have grown fearful of anti-tax sentiment among voters since last November's election.
In fact, much of the current fiscal trouble stems from budget cutting initiated by Republicans on the board. They vowed to slash the size of county government after the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, proposed a budget with a 25.6 percent property-tax increase.
 
Halting Further Layoffs
 But after more than 1,500 full-time and 800 part-time workers were laid off and county legislators faced weekly demonstrations and warnings of catastrophe from county workers, the legislators called a halt to further layoffs, fearing they would cripple county services.
"We are trying to prevent a tax increase next year in this difficult economic climate, without reducing any more services in the county than we already have," said Mario Colleluori, a fiscal adviser to the Democrats and a member of the staff committee.
He said that without any action now, property owners are looking at a tax increase of nearly $300 per home next year. "Supervisor Yevoli is adamantly opposed to any tax increase," he said.
David Vieser, a spokesman for Mr. Gulotta, said: "Everyone is cognizant that the borrowing has to be part of, but not the only exclusive element of, a comprehensive plan to address the county's budget shortfall."
 
Moody's Is Watching
 Officials of Moody's Investors Service, which lowered the rating on county bonds from A1 to A, said they would be watching the move carefully.
Michael Johnston, a vice president at Moody's, said the agency would have serious concerns about deficit financing unless it was part of a "serious plan" to resolve problems.
"It is not the kind of thing we take for granted, especially in the circumstances of the last 24 months, when the performance of the county has been strained at best," he said.
Local business leaders are also wary of the deficit financing plan.
"If it is a multiyear borrowing for a current-year expense, we would certainly oppose it," said James L. Larocca, the president of the Long Island Association. "History shows us those kinds of obligations tend to roll over and over and over."
Mr. Larocca said that instead the county could continue to cut spending to close its deficit.
"It takes political courage to bring government down to the size that the private economy can support," he said.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
Wistful Irish Folk-Rock

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
The Saw Doctors aren't afraid to wave the flag. On Thursday night at Tramps, they sang about arriving in Ireland's County Mayo by boat, seeing "where the ocean kisses Ireland" and wishing they could "stay forevermore." A band sidekick strode onstage with a huge green-and-red (the colors of County Mayo) flag, and waved it while the full house cheered. It was only the group's first song.
From there, the Saw Doctors went on to sing about romance, music and homesickness, with the crowd joining in on songs from the band's album, "If This Is Rock-and-Roll, I Want My Old Job Back" (Solid, released in Ireland). Fans also swayed to waltzes, jumped up and down, climbed on shoulders and collided with one another: slam-reeling. 
 Beloved in Ireland and virtually unknown in the United States, the Saw Doctors sold out two shows at the newly expanded Tramps. The six-man band plays Irish folk-rock with a fondness for 1950's and 60's rock- and-roll, from Buddy Holly to the Beatles. Mandolins and accordions tickle the melodies of rocking reels; in chugging mid-tempo tunes, Leo Moran plays twangy low guitar lines recalling Duane Eddy.
Instead of the politically charged anger of the Pogues (from England), the Saw Doctors offer wistfulness, humor and small-town nostalgia. Their songs cite their roots in Tuam, a town near Galway.
The songs are those of regular guys who are more likely to be romantic also-rans than to find bliss. Davy Carton sings in a reedy, earnest voice, recalling first love or asking, "Why do I always want you?" And the details are homey, self-effacing and proudly local. "N17" is about missing a favorite road; a band member held up a green street sign from home.
A few songs address Irish emigration, suggesting "the Pied Piper's come to Ireland and he's living on the dole." Others touch on the strife in Northern Ireland; the band sings about being "freedom fighters with mandolins," adding, "We're looking for some peace." There's no rancor, no blame.
While some lyrics, like those of "Presentation Boarder," are obscure to non-Irish listeners, most of the songs are good-natured, trim and catchy, and the Saw Doctors perform them with appealing fervor, bounding around the stage. Behind the local color is good-humored resilience and a sense of place that outsiders can enjoy along with the bouncy tunes.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
What Are The Rules, Exactly?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
New York is basking in the glow of celebration and pushing forward. Chicago, on the run for much of its seven-game series with the Knicks, has finally run out of running room.
The defending-champion Bulls have been backed into a corner and if the situation weren't so desperate it would be embarrassing. 
 No one expected the New York Knicks to be playing basketball in mid-May, and certainly no one expected them to be hounding Chicago and actually closing in for the kill in a seventh game on the Bulls' home court.
The most surprised person of all may be Phil Jackson, the Bulls' head coach, who finds himself searching for an escape hatch out of this second-round nightmare.
Judging from comments he made earlier this week following Game 4 in New York, Jackson might also be searching for an alibi to explain the Bulls' failure to put away a team that they were supposed to sweep.
In the midst of the unbridled passion surrounding New York's success, Jackson, hinting that officials had something to do with Chicago's problems, said that the N.B.A. would probably be delighted to have a seventh game involving two of the nation's three largest markets.
What angered the league about Jackson's comments is not that he said that the N.B.A. wanted a seven-game series, but that he suggested that the N.B.A. might actually be conspiring to force a Game 7 by its choice of referees. "I don't like orchestration, it sounds a little too fishy," Jackson said, "but they control who they send as referees."
Dave Checketts, the New York Knicks' president, complained to the league and Jackson was fined $2,500 yesterday for his comments.
The notion that "we wuz robbed" has long been the anthem of disgruntled fans, players and coaches. What makes this compelling is that the head coach of the defending N.B.A champions implied that referees might be involved in manipulating the outcome of a playoff game for economic reasons.
If that is not a direct slap at the integrity of the game, it certainly helps raise doubts about how much of what we watch is spontaneous competition.
Although Jackson's fine was light, he has done himself and the Bulls a disservice. And he has certainly done New York a disservice by suggesting that the overachieving Knicks needed calculated help from N.B.A. officials to push Chicago to the brink of elimination.
At every turn, it seems, Chicago -- and Jackson in particular -- has insinuated that favoritism or in this case, N.B.A. politics, has played a role in New York's success against the Bulls.
For three years, Chicago complained about Detroit's bruising style of play in the playoffs. The Bulls tried the same tactic this year, but when the Knicks kept muscling, Jackson no longer directed his complaints to the officials but at them.
Obviously, everyone makes money from the playoffs, from owners to vendors to parking attendants. The longer each series lasts the better: A dramatic series usually means higher ratings for networks, and higher ratings mean higher rates charged to advertisers.
But would a league conspire to stretch a series for the purpose of milking it for all its financial worth? That would require the cooperation of players, coaches and, as Jackson hinted, officials. Despite what they say about officials, my guess is that most fans feel that referees do about as well as they can under difficult circumstances.
Officiating is a learned craft and a subjective art. On virtually every play, an N.B.A. ref could make a call. There is always some sort of holding, hitting, bumping or three-second violation to chose from.
Maintaining a flow is essential, so what becomes important in officiating is timing. When is a foul a foul? What is good defense? What constitutes brutality? Officials can determine the outcome, and perhaps this is what has frustrated Jackson as he's watched his Bulls get shoved around by a New York team that seems convinced that Chicago cannot shove back.
The Bulls are in a corner, but officiating didn't put them there. They are in a corner because Pat Riley devised an effective system of rotating toward Michael Jordan when he drives, blocking his path, cutting off his passing lanes, keeping him on the perimeter, making him work at both ends of the court.
Chicago is in a corner because the Knicks have tested the depth of Scottie Pippen's resolve and so far Pippen has failed the test.
The Bulls are in a corner because New York has backed them into one. It's a little late in the game to cry foul.

HEADLINE: One Investor's Guide to Making Money

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
After two decades as an investment adviser to the rich, Michael Stolper has developed principles of investing -- and specific portfolios using mutual funds -- that are intended to move middle-income people into the ranks of the affluent.
Aside from the way money compounds over time, which financial experts often call the eighth wonder of the world, there is nothing magic in the approach that Mr. Stolper spells out in his new 266-page book, "Wealth: An Owner's Manual" (Harper Business, $20). 
 Indeed, more aggressive approaches to investing could produce greater returns for people with the time, discipline, knowledge of financial markets and risk tolerance to engage in active portfolio management.
But most Americans have not assembled large portfolios because they lack one or more of these attributes. Mr. Stolper's book can help people overcome these deficits: his advice is readily understandable, and his plans are feasible, provided people have enough self-control to spend less and save more.
Mr. Stolper, 46 years old, received bachelor's and master's degrees in finance at the University of Oklahoma. He worked for six years as a broker at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles before founding Stolper & Company in San Diego.
He said he became convinced that the best way to serve clients was to direct them to professional money managers. Today, he is helping guide more than $3 billion in investable assets for some 400 clients.
"The best thing money is going to do for you is make your life a little more pleasurable and give you some security," Mr. Stolper said. "Time and compound interest are probably far more influential than being sophisticated."
Thus, he recommends two investments -- common stocks and Treasury securities -- and suggests avoiding complicated instruments like collateralized mortgage obligations, options, collectibles and junk bonds. "Most investments that your average adolescent can't get on first pass are probably inappropriate," he said.
In a new newsletter, Mutual Fund Monthly ($49 for 12 issues; the address: 525 B Street, Suite 1080, San Diego 92101), that he started for middle-income investors, Mr. Stolper has put together four portfolios using mutual funds that invest in his favored holdings of stocks and Treasury securities.
The same four appear in each issue of the newsletter, with updated figures on how the funds in each portfolio have performed. Diversification is "the core element in any investment program," he said. "Blending mutual funds provides an additional level of diversification." He said he had chosen exemplary fund managers whose "funds are unlikely to rise or fall at the same pace, a phenomenon that is annoying in bull markets and comforting during periods of declining stock prices."
Despite that disclaimer, the performance of the portfolios in the bull market of recent months has scarcely been disappointing. The most conservative of the four portfolios is one Mr. Stolper calls Sanctuary, because it is intended for risk-averse investors like retirees. If $1,000 had been invested in it on Jan. 1, 1991, it would have grown to $1,227 on April 30, 1992. That is a 22.7 percent return, or 16.6 percent over 12-month period that ended April 30.
His Harvard 2010 portfolio, intended to provide for the college education of a child in 10 to 15 years, would have grown to $1,456, for a 45.6 percent return over the 16 months, or 32.5 percent over the last 12 months.
 
Smallest and Greatest
 The Sanctuary and the Harvard 2010 portfolios showed the smallest and greatest returns, respectively, among Mr. Stolper's four plans.
Mr. Stolper said that the portfolios are "not for action junkies," because "your best investments are the ones that involve the least intervention -- they have a high shelf life." Market timers would disagree, but few people, including investment professionals, are actually able to make the right calls for quick in-and-out trades.
A primary reason for writing the book and starting the newsletter, Mr. Stolper said, was to counter the abundance of what he called irresponsible advice in other publications that promise rewards without risk. Finance does not work that way, but the risks can be limited by balancing one against another.
"Part of what I wanted to communicate was how to integrate consumer finance with passages in life," he said. "Most people want to get to where they can sleep through the night, and if that conflicts with optimal economics, it is time to twist the financial dials" to give a greater sense of security.
The secret to investing in a mutual fund, he added, is to find competent and honest managers "with long histories of repetitive successes."
 
 
 
BRUSHING UP ON FINANCE
 Investing is only one aspect of getting one's financial house in order, and there are many books that can help consumers with this and other aspects of personal finance. Here are some of them.
THE COMPLETE FINANCIAL GUIDE TO THE 1990'S: by Gary L. Klott (Times Books/Random House, $22.50). Covers a host of subjects, including the job market, paying for college and retirement, taxes, real estate, borrowing and investing.
THE PRICE WATERHOUSE BOOK OF PERSONAL FINANCIAL PLANNING: by Stanley H. Breitbard and Donna Sammons Carpenter (Henry Holt, 1988). Now out of print, this is one of the best sources for getting a sound understanding of personal finance.
KIPLINGER'S INVEST YOUR WAY TO WEALTH: by Theodore J. Miller (Kiplinger Books, $21.95). The editor of Kiplinger's Personal Finance Magazine explains the basics of the stock and bond markets and covers such topics as choosing a broker or investing in mutual funds.
HOW TO MAKE YOUR SHRINKING SALARY SUPPORT YOU IN STYLE FOR THE REST OF YOUR LIFE: by Michael K. Evans (Random House, $23). The chairman of Evans Economics, an econometrics advisory company in Washington, provides a basic education for a relatively aggressive approach to investing, one that, with diligence, can pay off.
THE DEAN WITTER GUIDE TO PERSONAL INVESTING: by Robert M. Gardiner (NAL Books, $4.99). The former chairman of Dean Witter Financial Services gives basic explanations for a variety of investments, from the common to the esoteric.
THE BOND FUND ADVISOR: by Werner Renberg (Dearborn Financial Publishing, $24.95). A journalist looks at bond funds, the most popular of the mutual funds.

HEADLINE: Why I'm Not Marching in Washington

BYLINE: By Charles Millard; Charles Millard, Republican-Liberal, is a member of the New York City Council.

 BODY:
New York City should receive more Federal funds. But you will not see me marching in Washington today to make that point.
What's more important is that while the city would benefit from additional Federal finances, its largest problems lie closer to home. With a budget of $30 billion, the city ought to have properly maintained, clean streets -- with more police officers on them -- safe and effective schools and health care for the needy 
 Instead, the city's Department of Transportation, which gets Federal funds, has dug up 14th Street for necessary repairs, hurting businesses and causing congestion, only to announce that, after the work is completed, the Transit Authority will rip up portions of it for other work.
We raise taxes by hundreds of millions of dollars to put more police officers on the streets, but we cut police department civilian personnel, resulting in an increase of officers behind desks. Sanitation department employees work a half day for a full day's pay and get a $17 to $23 bonus because they spend the half day on two-worker instead of three-worker trucks. Our public schools spend nearly three times as much per pupil as parochial schools, yet the parochial schools are safer and provide better education. With this management, when Federal funds are limited, can Washington can really consider our city a good investment. Would you invest in a corporation run this poorly? I wouldn't.
The marchers are likely to point out that the Government's financial contributions to New York City, as a percentage of the city's budget, shrank from 1980 to 1990. But Washington's share of those budgets became a smaller slice of the pie, in part because the city profligately expanded the pie. It added 50,000 employees to the payroll, giving us 575 municipal employees for every 10,000 residents, compared to 344 in San Francisco, 199 in Philadelphia, 146 in Chicago and 145 in Los Angeles.
Critics who say the Bush Administration lacks an urban policy are misguided. It has long recognized that existing approaches are wasteful, and has proposed new ones that invest in people. It wants to eliminate outmoded programs such as job training that provides few marketable skills, and the bureaucracies that surround them. Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has advocated helping the urban poor to own their apartments or manage their housing projects. He has energetically supported the creation of urban enterprise zones, which offer tax incentives to create businesses in blighted areas.
Home ownership, tenant management in U.S.-owned or subsidized housing projects and entrepreneurship in enterprise zones all encourage creativity in business development and provide people with a stake in their community and power to improve their environment. They seek to reduce poor people's dependence on the Government to manage their housing and provide their incomes.
Although proposals for enterprise zones have been part of G.O.P. urban policy since the early 1980's, the House Democratic leadership -- and some Republicans -- showed little interest until this year. The Democrats cynically attached the enterprise zone proposal to a tax bill President Bush had pledged to veto. Now after the Los Angeles rioting, when it is evident that bipartisanship is necessary to save our cities, some Democratic leaders -- along with more Republicans -- are expressing genuine interest in these proposals.
So, if the marchers want more funds for housing, I agree. If they seek more for mass transit, I hope they succeed. But if they really want something new from Washington, they should urge the House Democratic leaders to approve an urban agenda that brings useful ideas to the table.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Now Give Stability a Chance in Lebanon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The resignation of the Syrian-imposed Lebanese prime minister, Omar Karami, and the massive popular demonstrations in Lebanon against the politics of the Taef regime (news article, May 7) raise the question: What comes next? 
 Regardless of who succeeds Mr. Karami, the economic and political situation in Lebanon will not improve because the new "cabinet" will be no different from the previous one. Syria will bring back people submissive to its will whose incompetence and corruption will not alleviate Lebanon's crisis. The members of any Syrian-appointed cabinet will include individuals who are figureheads and effectively controlled by Syria.
To gain from this crisis, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria will seek to control the Bank of Lebanon under a joint governorship between Lebanon and Syria and will force the Lebanese to surrender everything in exchange for bread and "peace."
According to Syrian officials, the Brotherhood treaty signed between Lebanon's Hrawi regime and Syria in May 1991 "supersedes the agreement at Taef and absolves the Syrian army from a required withdrawal [in September 1992] unless Syria and Lebanon deem it in their joint interests." Syria will not redeploy its troops and intelligence network from Beirut to the Bekaa Valley in September. The world community must not wait until then to search for an alternative to Syrian-imposed officials to challenge Syria's intransigence.
The vast majority of the Lebanese people support the legal and legitimate government of Gen. Michel Aoun in enforced exile in France. He is considered the only viable alternative to salvage the country from the continuing economic deterioration and creeping Syrian annexation. Hence, the United States must support a solution that coincides with the wishes of the Lebanese people by restoring the legal cabinet led by Prime Minister Aoun.
The opportunity for a real progress toward stability in Lebanon and the region should not be squandered again. The United States should be encouraged to take a decisive and courageous step toward freeing Lebanon from the Syrian Army and meeting the aspirations of the Lebanese people.
 
ELIE NAJM
Cary, N.C., May 10, 1992
 
The writer is chairman of the Council of Lebanese American Organizations.

BLACK WATER, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/ Dutton, $17.) A 26-year-old woman drowns when a senator's car goes off a bridge; but the point of view in this powerfully imagined novel belongs to the victim, whom we are made to know and whose tragedy we are made to comprehend.

DE GAULLE: The Ruler 1945-1970, by Jean Lacouture. (Norton, $29.95.) This final volume in Mr. Lacouture's monument to the colossus particularly features de Gaulle's foreign policy (alliance but independence) and his theatrical methods of getting his way.
A MAN'S PLACE, by Annie Ernaux. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $15.95.) An autobiographical novel that confronts the author's painful growth into incomprehension as she becomes a French intellectual while her father remains a hardworking shopkeeper.
THE BRIDE PRICE, by Grete Weil. (Godine, $20.95.) Mrs. Weil's beautiful novel, her first to be published in English, interleaves a narrative of King David and his infidelities with her own life as a German Jew who returned to Bavaria in 1947.
INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS: And Other Writings on Life and Death, by Anatole Broyard. (Clarkson N. Potter, $18.) Urbane, lyric, witty and gracious essays written mostly in his last 14 months by a former editor of The New York Times Book Review.
THE SHRINE AT ALTAMIRA, by John L'Heureux. (Viking, $19.) A stark, cleanly told novel of guilt and redemption following a hideous act of child abuse; the climax is unspeakably terrible.

HEADLINE: Everything Under the Sun

BYLINE: By Howard W. French; Howard W. French is the Caribbean bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:

A CONTINENT OF ISLANDS
Searching for the Caribbean Destiny.
By Mark Kurlansky.
Illustrated. 324 pp. Reading, Mass.:
Addison-Wesley Publishing Company.
$22.95. 
 ANYONE possessing more than a cursory familiarity with the disparate collection of nations that dot the Caribbean might sense that Mark Kurlansky had his work cut out for him with "A Continent of Islands: Searching for the Caribbean Destiny."
Mr. Kurlansky, who has reported on the Caribbean for The Chicago Tribune and other publications, seeks to create a coherent whole from a collection of colorful and far-flung geographic scraps, and he begins by introducing the unwieldy label "Caribbeans" to link peoples who almost unfailingly identify themselves by using their own countries' names.
Despite this and other unifying efforts, which are often built around fine descriptive passages and telling anecdotes, many readers and longtime visitors to the area may come away from this enterprising work as convinced as ever that the Caribbean is not a continent. For the book's vivid cataloguing of diversity in a region composed of sixteen independent countries, three French departments, five British colonies, two hard-to-define United States possessions and six semi-autonomous members of the Kingdom of the Netherlands suggests that the "Caribbeans" remain many peoples, their destinies perhaps as varied as their origins.
Decades of failed or still frustrated attempts at regional integration, some of which the author himself discusses, stand as testimony to this fact. So do cultural realities that, perhaps more than ever, make the Caribbean's inhabitants identify more often with people in Madrid, London, Paris, Amsterdam or New York than with one another.
The flaws of his organizational conceit aside, Mr. Kurlansky provides a highly readable introduction for anyone who cares to delve more deeply into the Caribbean and its cultures than any travel guidebook would permit. He brings an exuberance to his material and offers interesting discussions on topics ranging from the environment and AIDS to emigration, the condition of women and economic development.
To illustrate, for example, a timeless theme like the movement of people out of small nations that cannot support them to richer lands with greater opportunities, the author visits Santigron, a vanishing village in Suriname whose population has dwindled from 13,000 two decades ago to only about 300 now. "I don't want to go to Holland and have a car and a color television" as most of his neighbors have done, one of the remaining villagers touchingly explains. "I want to have those things here."
The book's greatest rewards come when Mr. Kurlansky moves beyond the merely topical to provide rich insights into the region's cultural makeup and historical legacy. He is particularly strong on matters of race and religion.
Illustrating the flip side of immigration, the expatriate life awaiting all those who leave behind their snug native surroundings, the author interviews the celebrated St. Lucian poet Derek Walcott about the uncomfortable discovery of another country's notions of race. "I live in America," says Mr. Walcott, a resident of Brookline, Mass. "In America I'm a black man, steadily from day to day. I don't think about it, but you encounter a glance."
DISCUSSING the struggle among religions, both more or less indigenous and imported, for which the area has been a battleground par excellence, Mr. Kurlansky describes a Roman Catholic priest in Haiti who condemns his voodoo counterparts, known as houngan, for delivering "a message of fear, never of liberation." But the next passage goes on to provide samples from a Catholic catechism, which hardly sound liberating: "Question: 'Who is the principal slave of Satan?' Answer: 'The principal slave of Satan is the houngan.' "
Then there is Knolly Clarke, an Anglican priest in Trinidad who speaks with frustration about the limits of his church's appeal to a people with still-strong African roots. "Our people believe in the reality of evil," he says. "People come here and ask me for a charm against evil." But the Anglicans do not dispense charms.
While Mr. Kurlansky's "Caribbeans" may have failed to forge anything resembling a cultural or political whole, he illustrates, in anecdotes like these, what is arguably an even more important point. In their various ways, all of these peoples have taken what they would from masters, colonizers and missionaries, and fashioned societies that are very much their own.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
In Boston, A Blend of Wit And Pathos

BYLINE: By Michael Kimmelman

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
THESE HAVE NOT BEEN FLUSH times in the art world, and they've been particularly rough on the Museum of Fine Arts here. Largely because of a costly expansion program in the 80's, combined with serious lack of foresight, the museum has incurred multimillion-dollar problems. It has laid off dozens of employees and entered into an agreement to rent parts of its collection to a new museum in the Japanese city of Nagoya. Less controversially, and like an increasing number of museums around the country, it has also begun to stress exhibitions based on its own collection instead of expensive loan shows.
Richard Artschwager's smart, and in places unexpectedly affecting, exhibition is an example. On view through July 26, it is the last installment in the museum's Connections series, overseen by the curator of contemporary art, Trevor Fairbrother. For the series, artists were invited to juxtapose their own works with works from the collection. 
 These in-house presentations have proved to be one of the few positive byproducts of the recession, but they are by no means foolproof. The Museum of Fine Arts also has on view an ill-conceived and crass exhibition called "Crosscurrents," which ends today. The gussied-up display, complete with faux columns and canopied benches, includes about 100 of the institution's European and American Impressionist paintings, insensitively and simplistically placed side by side to prove what most visitors already know: that Impressionism was an international movement. Post-Impressionist works are included, apparently to make the event bigger and more glamorous.
The real purpose of "Crosscurrents," of course, is to exploit the popularity of the Impressionist loan extravaganzas that museums like Boston came to rely on to help pay for their expansions, but which they now can hardly afford. During the 1970's and 80's, museums attracted visitors by stressing temporary spectacles at the expense of their own holdings. Now they are paying the consequences with desperate shows like this one, which masquerades as a blockbuster.
The aim of Connections is entirely different. Like similar series at the National Gallery in London, the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and elsewhere, it has been consistently stimulating because it promotes focused, fresh thinking about the permanent collection. (Where else would one see fifth-century Japanese bells fruitfully paired with a 14th-century Sienese panel painting?) And because the collection is linked with the work of the artist who puts the show together, it is presented not as something stodgy but as vital and alive.
Of course selecting the right artist is crucial. In the 69-year-old Mr. Artschwager, the museum chose someone who has spent three decades using unlovable industrial materials like Formica and Celotex to question the notion of the exquisite art object. His works are ironic and intentionally hard to place since they blur the boundaries between furniture and sculpture, painting and photograph, Pop and Minimalism, abstraction and representation. Not surprisingly, he has been an influence on many artists of the 70's and 80's.
Mr. Artschwager's choice of works for this exhibition is characteristically eccentric and obscure. The goal sometimes seems to be to point out the banality of museum installations in which objects are placed together merely because they are related in size or color. To this end, Mr. Artschwager has hung a minor French still life between the two parts of his own "Untitled (Diptych)" (1963), and put a brightly colored Monet landscape beside "Pig/Pig" (1984), with its streak of acid blue.
He has even suspended a 19th-century landscape directly in front of his "Garden II" (1974), a black-and-white painting that becomes like a shadow of the landscape, while the one work blocking the other also sends up the idea of compare and contrast.
The installation could hardly be more different in certain respects from the Connections show Brice Marden put together a year ago. Mr. Marden's presentation, like his work, was consistently elegant. There are works here that exult in their ugliness. Mr. Artschwager's gigantic chair of oak, Formica and steel, with its obscenely patterned cowhide upholstery, can bring to mind a trap about to snap shut. His "Contemplation" (1991) consists of a hulking table with bulbous chrome cutlery and Formica legs that seem to be melting into the base on which they rest. Between "Chair/Chair" and "Contemplation," he places a garish near-life-size Chinese earthenware figure from the 11th century.
Mr. Artschwager insists that a viewer consider a work not only for its content but also as an object on a wall or floor. The show, in two adjacent galleries, is arranged as if it were installation art, with idiosyncratic gaps between groups of works, the empty spaces sometimes punctuated by one of the artist's signature lozenge-shaped "blps." A lot of attention is paid to the sculptural implications of the rooms and in particular to corners. In one corner, a small hinged door hangs next to a big Ellsworth Kelly canvas whose curved outline echoes the shadow that the open door casts on the wall. On the other side of the painting is one of those tiny "blps," a comical David to Mr. Kelly's Goliath.
Despite its deadpan humor, the installation demands serious and careful observation. And with patient looking, works by Mr. Artschwager that seem at first glance simply chilling can reveal themselves to be tinged with a peculiar melancholy. His strange objects put into sharp relief the distance between mass production and individual craftsmanship. And just as he can revel in ugliness, Mr. Artschwager can also imply a respect for the mundane materials he favors, not as kitsch but as plain-speaking things that have voices of their own.
In one case, he places a painting of flowers by Courbet and his own monochrome "Sailors" (1972) on each side of a big Formica crucifix, as if to simulate a war memorial. In another part of the exhibition he creates a sequence of three works, the first a late-18th-century painting of two children, the next a severe image of his own called "Men's Dormitory" (1966), the last a Lamentation by the 16th-century German painter Lucas Cranach the Elder. The grouping describes a downward spiral from youth to death.
The last ensemble of works in the show sums up Mr. Artschwager's blend of wit and pathos. He hangs his own tear-shaped "Glass Drop" (1969) beside a beautiful fresco fragment of the head of a cherub, painted by a follower of the Italian Renaissance artist Correggio. This sentimental touch is undercut by Mr. Artschwager's wry sculpture in the shape of an exclamation point. He leaves a viewer off balance and looking at things anew -- which is precisely what one wants from a series like Connections.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An Artschwager connection: from left, Ellsworth Kelly's "Black Panel II"; an 11th-century Chinese figure; Mr. Artschwager's "Chair/Chair" and, in foreground, "Contemplation" -- Deadpan humor tinged with melancholy. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Brighton Beach;
Revising (Again) a Plan for the Baths Site

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN Florida it was easy. A decade ago, it took the developer Stephen Muss, president of Alexander Muss & Sons, based in Miami Beach, only six months to win approval for his 750-unit Towers of Quayside in North Miami.
Now the Brooklyn-born builder is in his sixth year of trying to win New York City's approval for a large-scale residential redevelopment called Brighton by the Sea on the 15-acre site of the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn. If built, it would give Brooklyn its first market-rate high-rise waterfront development in a generation. 
 His third plan for a residential rezoning is working its way through the city's public land-use review process. The two others were withdrawn, the second after an unfavorable vote by a City Planning Commission of diminished membership during the transition between mayoral regimes two years ago. A hearing before the City Planning Commission on the subsequently revised plan is scheduled for June 10.
On May 6, the revised plan had a public hearing before Borough President Howard Golden, a new step in the review process established by the City Charter revision of 1989. It brought out the nature of the latest revision. It also brought out supporters and opponents -- the latter unswayed by the reduction in the number of apartments and the elimination of a Florida-style health club -- and, for the first time at a public hearing on the plan, it brought out Mr. Muss himself.
"I just wanted to establish in your mind, Mr. President, that I am a 'Brooklyn boy,' " he said. He grew up on Ditmas Avenue and East 22d Street, went to public school on Glenwood Road and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School.
The third Brighton Beach plan, like the second, is the work of Costas Kondylis Architects of Manhattan. It provides 1.8 million square feet of residential space (down from two million in Plan 2). Instead of 1,730 apartments there are 1,600. The first plan had 2,096.
The number of buildings remains constant at five, forming a wide V oriented toward the beach as before. But the shapes have changed. Instead of straight towers they now dip down in steps toward the water. Two buildings drop from 28 floors at their peak to 22 floors; two others drop from 24 to 18. The effect is to provide more apartments with better views, plus more open space between buildings, the developer says.
The principal tower, closest to Brighton Beach Avenue, is 29 stories. It has been sited closer to the avenue, behind two new small parks rather than retail space as in the earlier plan. The sight lines have been straightened so passers-by on Brighton Beach Avenue will get unobstructed shorefront views. The developer would provide 1,700 spaces of covered on-site parking.
One major change is the dropping of an elaborate 44,600-square-foot public health club. Instead, there will be an "accessory" health club, for tenants only, of 34,200 square feet, built mainly below the level of the central court. From the boardwalk, therefore, no structure will obstruct views of the landscaped court and its walkways.
All the comparisons are between Plans 3 and 2. There was also a Plan 2A, submitted as an amendment to Plan 2 in a vain last-ditch effort to salvage success at the Planning Commission the last time around.
At the four-hour hearing in Borough Hall,36 individuals spoke in favor of Plan 3, saying it would help Brighton Beach and construction employment, and 21 spoke against it. Neighborhood opposition leaders objected to a "superblock without access to the waterfront" and "high-rises that would tower over the neighborhood." Fear was expressed that the Coney Island sewagetreatment plant would be overtaxed.
One opponent, Irwin Fruchtman, a former New York City Buildings Commissioner, predicted that the development would not be built even if approved. "The developer won't build at all," he said. "He'll only increase the value of his land six times."
Actually, the developer will only increase the land value if he is correct in assessing the market attraction of the site for residential development at the prices he will have to charge. That would trigger construction. A developer's belief in the future of the market is essential for continued residential renewal citywide.
MR. MUSS, for his part, says he will move ahead to develop plans and test the sales market expeditiously if the revised plan is approved. Final plans would be not be ready before the summer of next year if the plan wins final approval within four months. "There could be changes in the market by then," he said. "The New York market ebbs and flows like the rest of the world."
The market test would involve preconstruction sales for a single tower, the one at the waterfront end of the site of Coney Island Avenue. The strength of sales would determine how soon other buildings would follow. Mr. Muss also said he would hope to find an investment partner. That could be another New York builder.
He does not intend to sell the land without developing it, he said. If there is no market to build, he said, there is none for the land either. But construction could be done in five phases over time, rather than all at once.
Mr. Muss, who is 63 years old, is one of the 37 grandchildren of Isaac and Annie Muss. Isaac Muss was a carpenter who arrived in the United States in 1898 and built houses in Brooklyn in the 30's. All six of his sons went into the real estate business. One was Hyman Muss, whose son, Joshua, now runs the Muss Development Company in Forest Hills, Queens.
Another was the late Alexander Muss, Stephen's father, who built in New York and Florida. His final New York development was the 28-unit co-op at 733 Park Avenue, at 71st Street, probably the highest of high-end co-ops when it came on the market in 1969 as a housing recession was beginning.
Unable to find buyers at what were then imposing prices -- $250,000 for full-floor apartments of 3,000 square feet -- Mr. Muss rented the apartments with purchase options. Renters typically exercised the option in 1977, after the market had turned upward again, at prices by then pegged about 10 to 15 percent above the option prices, Stephen Muss said. In the late 70's outsider prices for these apartments were about $2 million, he said.
From 1952 through 1968 Alexander Muss & Sons built 20 subdivisions with about 20,000 houses under the name "Country Village" in Queens and New Jersey and on Long Island. The firm also built about 4,000 multifamily units. In 1962 operations shifted to Miami Beach. The five buildings of Seacoast Towers were built on Collins Avenue in Miami Beach, with 1,400 apartments.
Stephen Muss went on independently to build 1,200 apartments in partnership with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in Miami Beach, North Miami and Key Biscayne. And in 1978 he bought the 1,206-room Fontainbleau Hotel with financing from Equitable, and did a $100 million reconstruction. It is now the Fontainbleau Hilton, the "largest oceanfront convention meeting space in the world," Mr. Muss says. In Brooklyn he is acting as a principal in Alexander Muss & Sons, in which sisters who are also Alexander Muss's heirs have a stake.
The latest development plan is expected to win the support of Borough President Golden, who spoke in favor of promoting market-rate housing growth at the hearing, although there may be a request for adjustments.
The Brooklyn office of the Department of City Planning has been instrumental in the revisions of the current plan. Some planning commissioners may yet seek to leave their imprint on it as well. But the chairman of the Planning Commission, Richard L. Schaffer, endorsed the basic concept of utilizing the land for high-rise housing.
"It is a large site that has immediate access to mass transportation," he said. "It is a good site for major residential development."
