HEADLINE: Recession Is Ravaging Architectural Firms

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
EMPLOYMENT in the architectural industry in New York City has dropped 23 percent in the last two years, forcing firms to alter fundamentally -- and perhaps forever -- the way they do business.
"It will never be the same again," said Michael A. McCarthy, a partner in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, one of the largest firms in New York and the nation. "Beginning work in this city in 1964, I've had the chance to see a lot of ups and downs. This one, to me, is without a doubt the worst." 
 John Burgee and Philip Johnson ushered in the new era of commercial architecture in the 1980's with their A.T.&T. headquarters on Madison Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets.
"Our major practice, the one that we were known for, was high-rise buildings," Mr. Burgee said. "It seems that that building type has not only slowed down, it's vanished. It's not a matter that competition has gotten stiff. It has disappeared."
A. Eugene Kohn, a founding partner of Kohn Pedersen Fox in Manhattan, said he believed "this recession has been more extreme than most and did more damage to architectural firms."
Now, having shrunk, firms may decide to stay smaller. Rather than opening new offices in distant cities or hiring experts in special building types, they may rely increasingly on alliances with other firms. And rather than adding full-time staff when work comes in, they may continue to hire temporary employees.
For want of high-profile skyscrapers, more architects may try their hand at hospitals, jails, courthouses, schools, laboratories, public housing or mass-transit projects -- commissions that some might have spurned a few years ago as involving too much bureaucracy or specialization and too little creativity or money.
"Developers collected architects the way they collected art in the 80's," said Jerry A. Davis, managing principal in the New York office of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, which is based in St. Louis. "There's been a realization on a lot of firms' parts that they need to begin adjusting the focus of their practice."
They will also be competing for work farther and farther afield. "One of the best things about New York is that it has three airports," said John Belle, a partner in Beyer Blinder Belle.
Young architects will find that the traditional entry provided by drafting jobs has been foreclosed by computer-assisted design. Thwarted by the economy and technology, they may foresake traditional design work entirely for careers in real estate, government, teaching, construction, environmental preservation or nonprofit organizations.
Although some practitioners think they have detected the germ of recovery in recent months, the picture still looks bleak. The number of jobs in architectural services in New York City dropped to 6,482 last September from 8,424 in September 1989, according to the New York State Department of Labor.
The developer of 565 Fifth Avenue, at 46th Street, is promoting the 30-story structure as "the only Manhattan office building scheduled to be topped out this year." And unless the New York Exchanges Headquarters gets under way in TriBeCa, there may be no major commercial construction in the foreseeable future. Long-delayed developments include Times Square Center, by Mr. Burgee and Mr. Johnson, and Columbus Center, on Columbus Circle, by Skidmore.
New York City is not alone in its distress. As a rough gauge of the situation, the American Institute of Architects keeps track of classified newspaper advertisments for architectural positions. By this measure, employment demand has dropped in almost every major city. But it has plummeted in the Northeast. The number of positions advertised in Boston, for example, fell 89 percent from 1987 to 1991.
"There's a shaking out of offices," said Richard Brooker, a principal in the Architects Collaborative, of Cambridge, Mass., and San Francisco. "Some have gone right to the edge. Some have survived. The recession has caused people to re-look at how you practice architecture."
"WE are never going to reach the employment levels we demanded in the 80's," said Martin D. Raab, senior managing partner of Haines Lundberg Waehler in Manhattan. "We are never going to be fully employed at the level we've been turning out students. Last year, we lost 4,000 jobs and gained 4,000 students."
Or put another way: "About 80 percent of the class doesn't know what it's doing for the summer -- people are planning on flipping burgers or waiting tables." That was the assessment of Neil Platt, who has just finished his first year in Columbia University's graduate architecture program.
"I had a thesis class last year of six students," said Michele Bertomen, an assistant professor of architecture at the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip, L.I. "At least three of them still haven't found work in an architectural firm and they're extremely well qualified."
Even those with jobs are affected. It can devastate morale to watch coworkers depart.
"You get the sense that only in rare instances are they going to be able to find a new job," said Gerald B. Olanoff, who has worked in the Burgee firm and at Davis, Brody & Associates. "There's also the uncertainty about your own position. It gets everybody down and depressed. And it makes the office a tense place."
Mr. McCarthy said: "We've cut back by more than 50 percent. That has to have a tremendous impact on the creative talent of the city. It will be like 1973-74, when a large number of people left the profession or left New York entirely. There will be some degree of brain drain.
"We don't see a way out, a real turning point, until the end of the decade," Mr. McCarthy said. "If you're talking about no significant work until the latter half of the decade, you're talking about a situation that is somewhat similar to the 1930's."
In New York, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has shrunk to 200, from a peak of 425 at the end of 1988. Nationwide, the firm employs 700 people, down from 1,600 in 1988 and a high of 2,000 in 1981. Kohn Pedersen Fox is down to about 290 people, from a high of 350 in 1988 and 1989. Beyer Blinder Belle is down to 50 people, from 150 two years ago. Haines Lundberg Waehler has actually grown to 210 people, from 170 people two years ago, but is still 20 percent smaller than it was in the 80's.
Mr. Burgee's office has shrunk to 30 people, about half its former size. In a separate development, the firm has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code as a result of a $16 million judgment against it in favor of a former partner. A financial program is being prepared to allow the firm to continue operating.
Traumatic as it has been, the shake-up in the profession does not signify a complete collapse. "With all of the gloom and doom, I don't know any firms that were around five years ago that aren't here today," said Paul Segal, of Paul Segal Associates.
And there are even advantages to the wrenching process of streamlining -- at least from the principals' perspective.
"IT'S high time," said David M. Childs, the chairman of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. "We've cleaned house and it's been extremely healthy. We've been forced to make decisions we knew we had to make five or six years ago that we didn't want to make or didn't have time to make."
The recession, Mr. Kohn said, prompted Kohn Pedersen Fox to explore new kinds of buildings and technology, overseas ventures and smaller but architecturally challenging commissions. "The negative is obviously the sadness of letting go of very good people you care about," he said. "But the chance to rethink the structure and the philosophical approach of your firm is a good thing."
"We're in a new business," said Richard Roth Jr., chairman of Emery Roth & Sons, a 94-year-old firm. "We saw the handwriting on the wall that architecture is not going to be the bread and butter of the 1990's, so we formed an interiors company" -- Emery Roth & Sons Interior Design/Facilities Management. The new company will probably generate 35 to 40 percent of all income for Emery Roth this year.
Leon Moed and Raul de Armas, two longtime partners at Skidmore, left last year to form their own eight-person firm, Moed de Armas, with an office in downtown Manhattan. Mr. Moed believes that the small firm "is where the world is heading."
"From a client's point of view, first and foremost, he's confident that the principals are totally aware and in command of his project," Mr. Moed said. "Because of this intimacy, there's a certain efficiency. That isn't to say all of this doesn't rely on a network of professionals that you can involve on a selective basis."
The formation of strategic alliances is coming to play an ever more important role, in and out of New York City. "What we find ourselves doing a lot lately is teaming up," said Perry K. Neubauer, the president of the Architects Collaborative. Typically, his firm will do the design work and then a local architect will do construction documents.
Such alliances can be critical at a time when architects are stumbling over one another in a search for what little work there is. Much of it comes from government.
"Everybody is in everybody else's pea patch," Mr. Brooker said. As a result, local authorities are pressured by local architects not to do business with out-of-state firms. "There's a kind of Smoot-Hawley tariff act going on," he said.
Alliances are made to overcome not only geographic limitations but also shortfalls in expertise. "In order to win large government projects," Mr. Kohn said, "you almost have to associate with other firms. Rather than hiring expertise, you associate with firms that have it."
"A lot of commercially oriented firms are now trying to scramble around to develop an understanding and expertise in the institutional market -- health care and criminal justice buildings," Mr. Davis said.
And with good reason: "Those firms that have specialized in the health-care industry have tended to be healthiest," Mr. Raab said.
Institutions seem to offer another bright -- or brightening -- spot for architects.
"We do buildings for colleges and universities, and those seem to be happening," said Frances Halsband of the firm R. M. Kliment & Frances Halsband. "We're talking to a few people who are doing little projects in the arts and museum world. House clients have started to call us. That's a very good sign, that people are willing to look ahead and imagine themselves building houses."
Lenore M. Lucey, the executive director of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, said: "Within the last few months, things have started to move. It's moving like an iceberg, but it's moving. In general, there is a sense that while this year will not be a good year, it will begin to get better. A few firms have actually told me they're hiring."
There are, however, some permanent constraints on employment growth. One of these is computer-assisted design, known as CAD.
"Not only can we do more production work with CAD," Mr. Belle said, "but CAD will also make offices think much more carefully before they staff up -- if they have the opportunity to staff up."
Despite such obstacles, the profession still attracts newcomers. Ms. Halsband, who is dean of the school of architecture at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, said "more students than ever are applying."
"It's surprising, and I guess reassuring, that students don't seem to plot a whole career choice because of something going on this minute in the economy," she said. "Another piece is that many grown-up students are coming back to go to graduate school. The theory is that if things are slow, it's a good time to learn more."
One prospective graduate student, Stuart Magruder of Manhattan, majored in architecture as an undergraduate at Princeton University but decided not to continue his studies and took a job in advertisingToday he is thinking about a master's degree.
"It may be the best time to do it," he said, "going to school now and getting out in a couple of years, when the oversupply of office space will probably be leveling out a bit. I look at it as an opportunity."

HEADLINE: Groundwater

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stephen Hess, president of the developers' Association for a Better Long Island, is correct in saying in his letter on May 3 that groundwater can be protected by cluster development with covenants guaranteeing perpetual open space for the rest of the property. But location, type and overall development density are much more important. 
 For example, within the nine designated watersheds (Special Groundwater Protection Areas)that supply all of the Island's aquifers, the fast-disappearing open spaces are so vital to the quality of the groundwater that the Long Island Regional Planning Board has recommended five-acre residential zoning for the remaining large undeveloped tracts. These areas, about 25 percent of the Island, are the major precipitation recharge areas to the aquifers.
Five-acre zoning is already in place in several Nassau villages (Brookville, Matinicock, Mill Neck, Muttontown and Upper Brookville), and in four Suffolk towns (Brookhaven, Easthampton, Southampton and part of Southold). Five-acre zoning has also been upheld by the New York State Court of Appeals.
Open spaces in the Special Groundwater Protection Area watersheds are as important to the groundwater and ecnomy of Long Island as the Catskill and Croton watersheds are to New York City's reservoirs and economy. Clustering should be employed whenever a large tract is developed within a Special Groundwater Protection Area in order to preserve Long Island's water supply; with the number of units per cluster limited to the number based on five-acre zoning of the overall property. If developers and environmentalists can agree on this, cooperation can replace obstructionism, and the Island's economic recovery can begin.
 
JULIAN KANE
Hempstead, L.I.
 
The writer is a geology professor at Hofstra University

HEADLINE: Finding Those Who Owe Child Support

 BODY:
The article "State Hunts 300,000 Who Owe Child Support" (April 26) reports that there are in New Jersey alone "some 300,000 parents who owe an estimated $1.3 billion." Incredible!
Now that tests are capable of positively identifying a child's father, why don't we use them to do just that? With his Social Security number on nationwide computers, a percentage of his salary could be withdrawn and sent directly to his children -- no matter what state he is employed in. 
 Knowing that such action will be taken might motivate men to assume more responsibility for birth control -- something women have been demanding for years. It should also assure more children the birthright of being wanted and help achieve the touted goal of zero population growth.
The article indicates that the New Jersey Division of Economic Assistance plans to stop attempts at collection after three years of failing to locate the delinquent parents. Why? These deadbeats might one day win the lottery. Does the I.R.S. have such a moratorium?
 
ANITA MARTIN
Jersey City

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Cleaning Up on Pollution

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
After years of hypothesizing among economists and utility experts about the wonders of emissions trading, the Wisconsin Power and Light Company last week became the first utility to announce that it had actually sold pollution credits.
The company, which expects to build up the credits by exceeding Federal cleanup goals, sold the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Duquesne Light Company the right to emit an additional 25,000 to 35,000 tons of sulfur dioxide, the main ingredient of acid raid. In buying the credits, which can be used starting in 1995, the T.V.A. and Duquesne are in effect buying more time to install cleanup equipment or switch to cleaner fuels. 
 For Wisconsin Power, it was a case of doing well by doing good, but not for the first time, said Erroll B. Davis Jr., the president and chief executive of the utility's parent, WPL Holdings Inc. The company, based in Madison, is far cleaner than the average utility because of Wisconsin's strict environmental laws and its own determination to cut emissions.
For example, Wisconsin Power recently opened what it says is a first-of-a-kind plant to turn old tires into a fuel supplement for coal-burning electric plants. Six pounds of shredded tires are burned with each 94 pounds of coal. The rubber has about 25 percent more energy content per pound than coal and is a cheaper source of heat. Rubber also burns hotter than coal, and raising the boiler temperature helps cut some emissions, Mr. Davis said. "The only ones objecting are the mosquitoes, because we are eradicating part of their breeding grounds," he added, referring to abandoned tires.
Mr. Davis, 47, who has degrees in finance and engineering, came to Wisconsin Power in 1978, after stints at Xerox and Ford. He has been president since 1987.
The sale of the emissions allowances will have a modest effect on the company, adding between $10 million and $20 million to annual revenues of more than $1.3 billion. But Mr. Davis said the sale underscores Wisconsin Power's efficiency of operation.
"There is little we can do in the utility industry that represents sustainable, competitive advantage," he said. "We have to be as aggressive, creative and quick-moving as possible to sustain that advantage."
"I don't know what we will come up with next," he added, "but I'm not going to accept the responsibility of being the sole creative person here." Mr. Davis said his object was to "create an atmosphere that empowers people at lower levels to do things differently. That's very different from what you'll find in most of this industry."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Risky Business of Selling Short

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Do you believe that health-care stocks are still too pricey? That interest rates will spike, pushing down bond prices? Or that the stock market will stumble badly?
Mutual fund investors who saw trouble ahead in the financial markets once had no choice but to park their money in money-market funds. Now there is a way to stay invested and still profit from market declines: selling mutual funds short. 
 Short selling, an investment technique traditionally used by people who trade individual stocks, is available for fund investors from Jack White & Company, a discount brokerage based in San Diego, and Fidelity Investments in Boston. To sell short, you borrow shares from your broker and then instruct the broker to sell them. If the market drops, you buy shares on the open market at a cheaper price, replace the borrowed shares and pocket the difference as profit.
In selling funds short, the borrowed fund shares come from a pool held by the broker for other customers. Brokers reserve the right to require short sellers to cover their positions at any time. With actively traded stocks, that rarely happens. But because the supply of fund shares is limited to inventory held by the broker, this risk is higher with funds than with individual stocks.
Fund investors who want to sell short have to set up margin accounts, which lets them invest money borrowed from the broker. At both Fidelity and Jack White, investors need cash or securities equal to at least 50 percent of the value of the shares sold short. After that, collateral in the account must total at least 30 percent of the value of the shorted shares. If the value of the borrowed shares rises substantially, the broker may ask for additional collateral.
Investors who sell stocks short are wagering that a single company's fortunes will decline. A mutual-fund manager's goal is to avoid losing money, no matter what happens in the market. Thus, in selling funds short, you are betting not only that a market segment will decline but that a particular fund will not effectively counteract the decline.
That is a big bet, which Gerald W. Perritt, editor of the Mutual Fund Letter, calls "a dumb idea." He said, "Investors are better off picking a package of stocks and shorting them instead."
Both Jack White and Fidelity concede that short selling is risky. Today Mr. White says that half of his firm's short-sale business comes from professional investment advisers; the balance involves "particularly active investors." At Fidelity, short selling is confined to fewer than 200 active investors.
Fidelity was first on the market with a short sales program in late 1987; the program was closed in November 1989 because of a lack of interest, said Judith McMichael, a Fidelity marketing manager. Because of customer demand, Fidelity revived the program, which it began actively marketing at the end of March, she said.
With a total market value of all outstanding short positions equal to $10 million and 158 transactions in April, short selling constitutes a minute part of Fidelity's total $2.5 billion business in the 10 Select Portfolios for which short selling is available.
The Fidelity Select Portfolios that are available for short selling include American Gold, Biotechnology, Precious Metals and Minerals and Food and Agriculture. Fidelity Select funds focus on narrow market sectors. Investors pay the usual brokerage commission for their sales but are exempt from the 3 percent front-end charge. Funds are priced hourly from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
At Jack White, there are roughly 110 funds available for short selling, in more than 13 fund groups, all of which are no-load funds. Like regular fund investors, short sellers get the price at the close of the day.
Jack White has an inventory of $50 million worth of fund shares available for short sellers. While short sales account for less than 10 percent of the company's total no-load fund transactions, Mr. White says the program, set up about two years ago, is growing rapidly. As investors continue to move away from individual securities in favor of mutual funds, the "trend toward short selling will continue," he said.
Clearly, short selling is not for novices. At Jack White, typical short sales are $50,000 transactions. Fidelity cautions that the program is designed for aggressive investors.
What makes short selling so risky? While stock prices can fall only to zero, limiting your loss to the amount that you invest, there is no limit on how high share prices can rise. In fact, most mutual funds refuse to sell securities short because the technique is considered too speculative.
Which funds are good candidates for short selling? Obvious bets are sectors that have run up tremendously in value. The health-care sector was the big winner last year, rising 74.4 percent. While the stocks stumbled in January, some analysts say they have more room to fall. Another expensive sector is financial services, 1991's second biggest gainer, up 60.6 percent.
Investors who want to bet that interest rates will rise can short bond funds. In all cases, pick funds with volatile share prices because they will probably react most sharply to market declines.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1589 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 10-15

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

 
Running Out of Maneuvering Room 

With $18.5 billion in debt, a worldwide real estate slump and its $7 billion Canary Wharf project in London largely unrented, Olympia & York, North America's largest developer, did not have much room to maneuver. Still, under the guidance of Paul Reichmann, the family-owned enterprise held on for two months while it negotiated with creditors. Last week, it all caved in. Bondholders, tired of waiting to be paid, threatened to seize Olympia's First Canadian Place Tower in Toronto. To prevent that, Olympia and 29 of its companies filed for protection under Canada's bankruptcy laws. Its companies with American assets filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Having its properties protected"will permit more time to focus on the long-range issues" of debt renegotiation, said Robert S. Miller Jr., Olympia's financial adviser. That still leaves bondholders wondering when they will be paid.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Remaking T.W.A., in a Week
 
In between buying three paintings at Sotheby's last week for $1.5 million, Carl C. Icahn, chairman of the bankrupt Trans World Airlines, reorganized operations. Not only did he renegotiate an agreement to sell 40 landing slots and three gates at Chicago's O'Hare to American Airlines for $500 million in zero coupon bonds, but he also announced that T.W.A. would change its route structure. To keep ticket prices low, T.W.A. will send passengers through "mini-hubs," he said -- smaller airports like Minneapolis, Atlanta and Midway in Chicago -- instead of major hubs like O'Hare. And rather than buy new planes to replace its geriatric fleet, Mr. Icahn will lease planes for short periods of time. "You use the planes for the summer and then give them back," he said.
 
A Match Made in Hollywood
 
MGM Pathe Communications and the bankrupt Orion Pictures Corporation are both on Tinseltown's disabled list. MGM has a boffo distribution channel and lots of money (it is controlled by Credit Lyonnais, the big French bank) but no films to sell. Orion has 10 unreleased films but no money to distribute them. Though its film "Dances With Wolves" was a hit at the box office last year, Orion filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code two months ago; it owes creditors $500 million. Last week, MGM said it would bid for Orion. Though three other studios have made offers -- Savoy Pictures Entertainment, New Line Cinema and Republic Pictures -- analysts like an MGM-Orion combination best. "The financial capability of the backers is what makes the difference," said Jeff Logsdon, an analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities in Los Angeles.

Softer Suds -- in Name Only
 
People buy high-test brews, like malt liquor, to get more tipsy, anti-alcohol activists say. The Federal Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms Bureau doesn't mind the extra alcohol in these products, but it's not happy when brewers give them macho-sounding names, since it believes this encourages consumption. Two months ago the bureau stopped the G. Heilman Brewing Company from selling a potent malt liquor under the Power Master name. Last week Heilman said it would soon start marketing a new malt liquor called Colt 45 Premium in Philadelphia. Jack Killorin, a spokesman for the bureau, said the agency would not prohibit sales of the renamed suds. That was dismaying to the activists. "I'm outraged," said Alberta Tinsley Williams of the Coalition Against Billboard Advertising of Alcohol and Tobacco, in Detroit. "We will appeal to store owners not to carry the brand," she said.
 
If you think Power Master is too blatant, how about Black Death? That's a Belgian beet-based vodka whose ads feature the rock star Slash of the heavy-metal group Guns 'n' Roses. Its trademark is a coffin and a skull. Last week Black Death U.S.A., the Los Angeles based importer, said it would change its product's name to Black Hat. The trademark will remain.
 
Is Alexanders the First Domino?
 
Retail sales may be up slightly across the country, but that hasn't helped Alexanders, the department-store chain for budget-minded New Yorkers. After losing $40 million in the last 24 months, Alexanders filed last week for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. It will close its 11 stores in New York. "Alexander's retail business is not viable, and there is little prospect of turning it around," said Robin Farkas, the company's chairman. Reverberations may spread through New York's financial community. Donald J. Trump, the embattled real estate developer, owns 27.2 percent of Alexanders. Those shares were pledged to Citicorp as collateral for some of his loans.

A Run on Guns in L.A.
 
Even before the riots, Los Angeles was an armed camped. In the last five years, more than 500,000 handguns were sold legally there. But since the riots, weekly sales have increased by 50 percent, to their highest level in more than 20 years. More people are taking gun training courses too. "I always thought if there was a serial rapist or murderer loose my business would go up, but nothing beats a race riot," said Sean Collinsworth, the owner of Deadly Forces, a gun training service in Los Angeles. "People are really scared."

 
 
INTERNATIONAL


Japan's Corporate Paternalism
 
In Japan, companies are not just economic entities, they are social institutions. For that reason, though Japan's economy is in recession, its unemployment rate is not expected to creep up much past 2.1 percent this year. But if the recession persists, economists worry that even the most honor-bound employer may have to lay off workers. "If this does continue next year," said Sadahiko Hidaka, head of a Tokyo metal fabricating company, "we would have to start thinking about layoffs."
 
The Halfhearted Capitalist
Though he was one of the last people in the Soviet Union to turn in his Communist Party card (he didn't do it until after last summer's aborted coup) and though he never really came to believe in private property, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former President of the Soviet Union, was feted like a capitalist prince last week during his tour of the United States. Not only did he address the Economic Club of New York -- "The Government of Russia has carried its reforms to the edge," he warned -- but he also visited the New York Stock Exchange, squired around by former President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Gorbachev hobnobbed with business leaders to raise $3 million for the nonprofit Gorbachev Foundation in Moscow. And how did one of Moscow's diehard socialists travel? On a Forbes magazine jet named the Capitalist Tool.
 
Road Service for $143 Million
 
NASA's astronauts resorted to the old heave-ho when their high-tech capture bar failed to snag Intelsat's trailer-sized communications satellite. They managed to pull the satellite into the shuttle Endeavour's 60-foot cargo bay, where they attached a small rocket motor to send the satellite into the correct orbit. But the itemized bill for this space call was steep. NASA charged Intelsat $93 million for the launch plus $50 million for parts (labor was included). Intelsat was happy to pay.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Making Weak Banks Pay More
 
When the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted 3 to 2 to raise the premiums it charges banks to insure their accounts, it was a break with tradition. For the first time, weaker banks will be charged more than stronger ones. Healthy institutions will pay 28 cents for every $100 in deposits, instead of 23 cents. Weak banks will pay an additional 3 cents for each $100. The added cost may be enough to cause some banks to close, the industry argued. The regulators countered that the fund lost $11 billion last year and has a deficit of $7 billion. "We're trying to close a widening gap between revenues and expenses," said William Taylor, chairman of the F.D.I.C.

Why Inventories Are Up
 
"It's either very good news or very bad news," Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities in New York, said after the Commerce Department reported a gain of 0.4 percent in inventories last month. If the nation's companies restocked their shelves because of sales, it's good. But if they misgauged demand and ordered too much, it could lead back to recession, he said. So which is it? It's still too early to tell.
 
The Well-Mannered C.P.I.
 
With businesses still struggling to emerge from the recession, merchants are more concerned about moving the goods than raising prices. That's why the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was so well behaved last month. Prices at the consumer level moved up a slim 0.2 percent, the department said last week, the same as producer prices. With inflation practically nil, the Federal Reserve may be tempted to bring down interest rates in an effort to squeeze more growth out of a feeble recovery. "The Fed has to be worried that this recovery doesn't have enough steam to carry it through the second half of the year," said Lyle Gramley, of the Mortgage Bankers Association.

Let Them Buy
 
Under its chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, the Federal Communications Commission has rule relaxation on its mind. It has eased the rules governing radio station ownership, and last week it said it wanted to do the same for TV. The F.C.C.'s proposal would allow a company to own 24 TV stations, up from 12. It would also allow companies to own a VHF and UHF station in the same market.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Young, Black, Male -- and Elite

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
The voice of Imar Hutchins picks up speed when he begins to talk about FreeForm Academy, the educational venture he will immerse himself in full time after he graduates from Morehouse College in Atlanta this afternoon. "Privatization is coming in public education. We want to see a network of hundreds of FreeForms. A national system." The 21-year old senior laughs a little at his own sincerity but continues: "I wake up in the middle of the night and think, 'I have a vision. I have to go to work.' "
Mr. Hutchins and his classmates at the elite, predominantly black men's college are taking their fervor into the wider world during troubled times. The economy is bestirring itself but the job market for new graduates is the worst in decades, according to several surveys. And, two weeks ago, just as seniors were settling in for their last experience with the ritual torture known as final exams, the anomic images from Los Angeles exploded across their television screens. 
 A protest by Atlanta students, including several from Morehouse, against the Rodney King verdict evolved into a confrontation with the police. "In a way it was a good thing it was finals," said Marshall Norwood, 21, another graduating Morehouse senior, "because people had to calm down and study."
However it looks on television, a few students sharing a few moments of common cause in the streets does not an unruly mob of looters make. The young men of Morehouse, which numbers Martin Luther King Jr. and Spike Lee among its graduates, have little in common except some demography -- race and youth -- with many of the men who figured so prominently in film footage of L.A. and who populate white stereotypes of black behavior. But as they leave campus to start work, seniors say they know that race confuses some whites and that they face expectations their young white counterparts do not.
"We do get lumped together," Mr. Norwood said. Mr. Hutchins agreed: "The image that predominates is not a positive one." Similarly, the class valedictorian, Terrence Liddell, also 21: "It is always a factor, being a black male," he said. "We will always encounter people who see us as a threat."
Mr. Hutchins is realistic about the power of race as a leveler. He is a well-established member of the middle class whose great-grandfather was a college graduate. "If I walk into a department store, they don't know what school I go to," he said. "I face the same suspicion as any other black man."
If that realization is a sobering companion, the students view the imminent changes in their lives with the mix of dread and excitement of any frisky new graduates. "This will be a testing period," said Mr. Liddell. "I'm not afraid of change, just wary."

ONE thing the students seem unfazed by is the prospect of working in white-dominated environments. "I love to find out about different types of people," said Sean Allen, a 21-year-old economics major. Like other students, Mr. Allen, who in a few weeks will begin work at Cargill, the agricultural products company, credits Morehouse and his parents for providing the solid footing he needed to view achievement as a challenge not a burden. "Every day I see 3,000 young black men striving to make something of their lives," he said of his school. "Being a Morehouse student, I am constantly looked at and evaluated. It makes me do my best."
But even before Morehouse, his parents prodded him to focus on his goals: "My mother said, 'Life is short. You don't have time to procrastinate,' " he said. "Those who know what they want get what they want."
It is hardly surprising that these students are doing better than many in the class of 1992 nationally: they are at the top of their class. Mr. Liddell is moving to New York to begin Merrill Lynch's two-year training program for financial analysts. Mr. Norwood is returning after two internships to the Atlanta office of Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, to work full time. Mr. Allen will divide his time between Minneapolis and the cornfields of Iowa as he learns commodity trading at Cargill.
Mr. Hutchins expects to open the doors of the first FreeForm, his day-care center/ private school for children aged 3 to 9, in September. Like a true entrepreneur, he confidently predicts explosive growth of a chain of academies, along with software and publishing ventures, over the next five years.
All have been pursued by several prospective employers and when they talk of graduate and professional schools, they mention Harvard, Yale and Stanford. A sense of opportunities abounds, but so does a sense of caution: "I like to think I'm not the next Rodney King," Marshall Norwood said. "But I am at risk. All black men are."
 
 
 
WHY MOREHOUSE GETS THE BEST
 Sean Allen, Imar Hutchins, Terrence Liddell and Marshall Norwood could have gone virtually anywhere in the country -- they had acceptances from schools like Stanford, Cornell and Berkeley. But they chose Morehouse, a small college that has dedicated itself for 125 years to educating the best and brightest young black men. "I have no regrets about Stanford," said Mr. Liddell, the class valedictorian. "I would have performed just as well. But I would have been a number."
Both Mr. Norwood, who is from Atlanta and went to a predominantly white high school, and Mr. Allen, who is from racially and ethnically diverse Sacramento, Calif., wanted the experience of being at an all-black school. "I wanted to be in touch with myself in going out to the work force," Mr. Allen said. "If you know yourself, you can deal with a lot of the negatives out there."
The students seem to have the resources to ride out "negatives" like the Rodney King verdict. "You can't base any lasting effort on emotion," said Imar Hutchins. "I don't get caught on a roller coaster of highs and lows. If you allow yourself to be subjected to expectations, you will not be effective."

HEADLINE: All About/ECU's;
A European Currency Inches Toward Acceptance

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The ECU is a currency in waiting. Although it is slated to become the single currency of the 12-member European Community by 1999 at the latest, the European Currency Unit is still little known outside European financial circles. It is not a legal currency yet. In fact, there are no ECU bills, and the only coins are for collectors.
Yet since it was created in 1979 as a basket or weighted combination of the values of the 12 currencies of the European Community, it has slowly become a player in international financial markets. There is a growing ECU bond market that is used by Governments, international organizations and companies around the world. There are a commercial paper market, ECU bank loans, checks and credit cards. 
 Even though there are no ECU notes being printed, invoices, bills and other payments can be denominated in ECU's, which are currently worth about $1.25 each. The same is true for commercial paper or bonds.
The ECU is becoming an attractive way to reduce currency risk. Since the ECU is a basket of currencies, it is less likely to shift in value. For borrowers, the costs can be lower in ECU's than in their own currencies.
 
Selling the ECU
So Far, It's Hardly a Household Name
 The man out front on the ECU is Jean-Francois Pons, the Director of Monetary Affairs for the European Commission in Brussels. Mr. Pons, a French civil servant, must monitor the progress toward the introduction of the ECU as the single currency, seeing that the required hurdles are cleared along the way. And he must make a wary world comfortable with the currency. In short, he is the ECU's top salesman.
"For people in the street the ECU is something new," Mr. Pons said of Europeans. "And here," he added during a recent visit to the United States, "even in the financial circles, the ECU is not very well known."
Though the ECU was created more than a decade ago, the path for its transformation from currency crown prince to legal tender for Europe was not set out in a firm agreement until the meeting of European Community leaders at Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December. The road to a single currency will still be difficult. "It can always fall apart," said Mr. Pons. "But, really, I do not believe so."
The agreement calls for the establishment of the European Monetary Institute on Jan. 1, 1994. The institute will coordinate monetary policy among community members. Before the end of 1996, the European Monetary Institute and the European Commission will decide whether interest rates, inflation and budget deficits have converged enough in member countries to allow a move to the single currency.
If the convergence has taken place, the European Council -- the leaders of the Governments of the 12 community members -- can set a date for moving to the single currency. If no date is set by the end of 1997, the agreement states, the move will take place on Jan. 1, 1999. When the currency is in place, a new European Central Bank will take over in conducting monetary policy for all community members.
But there is a wrinkle in the Maastricht agreement. It does not say when existing currencies will be phased out. Its only word on the timetable is "rapidly." Mr. Pons said that the phase-out could take a year or two and that if it did, there could be a lot of confusion. For example, what do you use in a slot machine?
 
The Bond Connection
Helping to Lower Borrowing Costs
 The numbers show that the ECU is already taking on the character of a currency. It is now the second most widely used currency in the primary international bond market after the dollar. The total amount of ECU bonds outstanding rose 67 percent in the last two years. The total of ECU's kept for reserves by central banks jumped 76 percent in the same period. Bank lending was up 27 percent in the 12-month period that ended last September.
The most prominent use of the ECU is in the bond market. It is used by Governments, like Italy and France; by international institutions, like the World Bank and the European Investment Bank, and by companies.
American companies use the ECU because it can help them lower their costs of borrowing. Johnson & Johnson sold a 150 million ECU issue of five-year notes earlier this month. Two elements made the ECU bond market attractive, said Eugene D. Barron, assistant treasurer. One factor was that investors in Europe are willing to pay a little more for a prominent company's name and its high credit rating. The second was that at the time Johnson & Johnson was able to exchange its ECU notes for dollar-denominated obligations at favorable rates.
But while the market is attractive and much more liquid than in the past, it still experiences growing pains. With Johnson & Johnson's success, other companies and institutions have decided to go the ECU route. The result has been a flood of issues but not enough investor demand to absorb them easily. Mr. Barron said that if he had been raising money last week, he would not have gone to the ECU market.
In addition, the market is not for companies with lower credit ratings. For example, Citicorp also went to the European bond market two weeks ago but issued bonds in dollars, because borrowing in ECU's would have cost too much. The ECU market "is not a deep market, and it is volatile," said Steve Greene, who manages the funding desk for Citicorp. "It is not cost-effective for lower-rated issuers to issue in ECU right now."
 
Wary Americans
The Finex Exchange Finds Few Takers
 Will the ECU catch on in the United States any time soon? It does not seem so. The use of the ECU has not spread much beyond companies that are veterans in international markets, judging from the activity at the Finex, the Financial Instrument Exchange in New York. Finex, a division of the New York Cotton Exchange, has been offering a futures contract on the ECU versus the dollar since 1986, and it recently started offering an options contract. Both are used to hedge against currency fluctuations.
After a flurry of interest in 1986, with trading of about 100 million a day in ECU's, the interest in the Finex futures contract plummeted almost to zero after the October 1987 stock market crash and never recovered. About $125 million, at the current rate, is being hedged through the options.
Americans are not interested in the ECU, said Richard Jaycobs, the managing director of Finex, because "historically, American companies are woefully provincial about foreign exchange and foreign exchange risk."
Mr. Jaycobs used his father-in-law, Chris Nicholson, an importer of motorcycle parts, as an example. Mr. Nicholson told Mr. Jaycobs that "I let the person I am dealing with cover the risk." But Mr. Jaycobs said this means Mr. Nicholson is paying a premium he could avoid if he hedged the risk himself.
"What we are trying to do is to educate companies," he said. "If we do not do that, we cannot be competitive."
 
 
 
ECU CHECKS, BUT NO BILLS YET
 As it exists now, the ECU is voluntary. If you can get someone to accept a payment in ECU's, it is legal to do so. But you cannot force someone to accept the ECU as payment until it becomes legal tender.
The European Commission helps to support the currency's use by doing its budget in ECU's and paying 20 percent to 25 percent of its bills in ECU's. Those who are paid can convert the ECU's into a local currency.
Jean-Francois Pons, the Director of Monetary Affairs for the European Commission, carries ECU checks, and if he wanted to, he could get an ECU credit card. There are some hotels where he can pay his bill in ECU's. Firestone uses the ECU to do its internal pricing in Europe. European railways use the ECU to work out cross-border payments. Amadeus, a four-country European airline reservation system, denominates its commercial bills in ECU's.
But Mr. Pons has no ECU bills in his wallet. There are none yet. And he does not carry ECU coins, which are now made just for collectors. But two contests are being held to design the ECU currency, and one is being sponsored by the European Parliament.
Naturally, choosing the design will be tricky. As with most matters involved in melding the many sovereign egos of Europe, each country may want to retain some of its identity in the new currency. One solution that has been suggested, Mr. Pons said, is to have individualized ECU bills. One side would have the Europewide ECU design. The other side would have a different face for each member nation.

HEADLINE: Which Way Out?;
The Civil Rights Battle Was Easy Next to the Problems of the Ghetto

BYLINE: By JASON DEPARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots, many Americans feel some shame about the inner cities and most have at least some desire to see them improve.
But the country has watched passively for more than a generation as its urban cores have devoured the people who live there. And Washington politics last week offered little reason to think that things are about to change. 
 Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was racing about with plans for what he calls a conservative War on Poverty and a second civil rights revolution.
"This is my way of redeeming my existence on this earth," Mr. Kemp told a group of reporters at breakfast on Friday. "I wasn't there with Rosa Parks or Dr. King or John Lewis, but I am here now and I am going to yell from the rooftops about what we need to do."
But until recent days, Mr. Kemp's enthusiasms made him an outcast in his own Government. And for more than a decade, the more persuasive politicians have been telling themselves and the voters that the slums simply cannot be fixed. In Ronald Reagan's famous phrase: We fought a war on poverty "and poverty won."
Stasis, of course, is the norm in American social policy, and innovations -- a New Deal or a Great Society -- are the exceptions. The first was forced by catastrophe. The second was born during unparalleled prosperity. Neither fortune nor misfortune so abounds today.
Some Americans dream of seeing another Martin Luther King, Jr., step forward and offer deliverance. And yet the problem of ghetto poverty is, in some ways at least, a harder one to fix: the more Dr. King himself ventured into the slums, the more his movement faltered. Civil rights could be conferred by an act of Congress. What stroke of Presidential pen could abolish teenage pregnancy, patch the family, chase out drugs, or bring back good jobs?
Budgets are busted, movements are missing, and all the solutions seem open to question. If black leadership has fractured, so has white leadership. And reformers get little encouragement from the White House. President Bush speaks resoundingly about what is or is not a racial quota, but he has had little to say about the sorrows of the inner city. Hanging over the broken political edifice is a thick cloud of doubt about Government itself. It cannot even insure banks without losing hundreds of billions of dollars; how can it conquer poverty?
But to some it seems an odd moment for America to feel impotent. Communism falls. Apartheid follows. Why should the comparatively small problems of the American cities seem beyond solution? "If democracy can work in Eastern Europe," Mr. Kemp was insisting last week, "it can work in east L.A."
The riots were barely quelled when political gridlock seemed assured. Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, set off a Washington titter when he blamed the Great Society for the flames.
 
On Slippery Common Ground
 Fearful of adding to the public disgust with politicians, both parties gathered at an unusual White House meeting last week and pledged to work together. But it quickly became clear just how tenuous was the show of unity.
Even with White House backing, the emergency aid bill only squeaked through the House. Republicans opposed it by more than 2 to 1, attacking it as a reward to rioters; some Democrats denounced it as too mild a palliative. The more telling activity may have been in the nation's gun shops , where record numbers of people waited to arm themselves.
America has always stood out among industrial democracies for its aversion to social policy: Germany enacted widows' pensions and other forms of social insurance 50 years before America followed with the New Deal.
James Patterson, a historian of social policy at Brown University, cites several reasons. In part, he argues, it stems from the country's success ethic, the undergirding assumption that anyone can make it. In part it comes from long traditions of localism, which hold that the poor are their neighbors' problem.
Perhaps most of all, the aversion to Federal activity grows from the country's unique diversity -- racial, ethnic and regional. People support programs when they imagine the beneficiaries look a lot like themselves.
"To put it bluntly," Mr. Patterson said, "an awful lot of people oppose programs for the poor, in the past and now, because they think they benefit undeserving black people."
Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat among Mr. Kemp's heroes, was arrested 40 times in the 1960's and beaten without mercy. So it meant something last week when he said that desegregating the South was a modest goal compared to saving the underclass.
"It was easier to go and sit in at a lunch counter all day and let a lighted cigarette get put out in your hair," he said. "It was easier to march across the bridge in Selma and get tear-gassed."
The civil rights crusaders did in some ways face an environment more conducive to change. They had an expanding economy whirring beneath them, giving the whole society a confidence about the future it lacks today. They could coax support from Federal officials who were open to change. And since segregation affected all blacks, the movement could more easily harness the passion and talent of the middle class.
Segregation could be framed in pictures of school girls and police dogs; the images of today's underclass tilt toward gold chains and guns.
The awful 81-second bludgeoning of Rodney King seemed to have that old power of firehoses in Birmingham. Yet its moral force somehow blurred: he was a criminal suspect with a record, not a preacher. While it riveted the country, it failed to move a jury.
 
A Dream of a New Dr. King
 The last years of Dr. King's life were spent wrestling with these same questions: how to devise a solution to ghetto poverty and harness the political will to do so?
"He was baffled," said Senator Harris Wofford, then a King adviser and now a Pennsylvania Democrat. Senator Wofford said that during their last conversation, Dr. King even speculated about torching the worst slum in America, as a way of dramatizing its cruelty. "In the end, I don't think he would have done it," Senator Wofford said.
Those who dream of a new Dr. King often forget how reviled the old one was. And the lack of mythic successors is, at one level, a measure of his success. It is jail cells that produce Kings and Havels and Mandelas; enfranchisement produces congressmen and mayors, ordinary actors in the banal processes of politics. It is not just leadership that is lacking, but also and perhaps more importantly, the country's faith in Government itself. This has been eroded by its own failures in Vietnam and Watergate, by its mixed record in social policy, and by two decades of concerted efforts by conservatives to discredit it.
"To go from the Johnson landslide to the Reagan landslide in 16 years is a pretty fundamental shift in attitude about the role of Government," said Clayborne Carson, a historian at Stanford University.
The complaint that "there are no ideas," is deeply believed. But it is only partly true. Many social service models do seem tired. No one can claim to have the solution to teenage pregnancy and drug abuse. But the country basically knows how to shelter and provide health care to its citizens. Money is the stopper here.
Employment and welfare policies fall in between: no strategy promises to end dependency, but many have a chance at reducing it. Job-training efforts have broad support. So do calls for tax credits for the working poor and better child-support collection.
In Mr. Kemp's case, skepticism about Government bureaucracies and confidence about solutions both abound: In his plans for tenant management and ownership of public housing; for vouchers that let parents send their children to the public or private school of their choice; for tax breaks to lure businesses toward the slums.
Every idea has its weaknesses and enemies, but innovations always do. The New Deal and the civil rights movement -- each in its day was called the work of subversives. "What's missing is the coalition to put the ideas together," said Theda Skocpol, a Harvard sociologist.
If the history of American social policy offers any lessons, it is that breakthroughs will not come without strong Presidential effort.Here, argues Roger Wilkins, a historian at George Mason University, the charge that President Bush has neglected the poor gives him a unique opportunity.
Just as Richard Nixon had the anti-Communist credentials to go to China, he says, it is Mr. Bush who could lead the nation back to finish the work within its ghettos.
"There's one man in America who could make it happen," Mr. Wilkins said, "and his name is George Bush."

HEADLINE: Keeping the Seawolf Afloat;
In Battle of Budget, Democrats Defend Military Hardware

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BEFORE the Soviet Union imploded, the great divide between liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans was defined in large part by their clashes over guns vs. butter. Now,in an improbable role reversal, Congressional Democrats are challenging the Bush Administration to build more tanks and fighter jets.
This new stance has lent an ironic coloring to the battle over the construction of two Seawolf nuclear submarines, which each cost nearly $2 billion. The Pentagon says there is no need to build the ships, which were designed to track the Soviet submarine fleet, because a hostile Soviet Navy no longer exists. But Connecticut's Senator Christopher J. Dodd and Representative Sam Gejdenson, both passionate liberals who spent much of the 1980's opposing the Reagan defense buildup, have coalesced a bloc of Democrats and New England Republicans to guarantee the Seawolf program. 
 This week, a House-Senate appropriations conference committee is to decide on budget alterations that will preserve either one or both submarines. Mr. Bush lobbied personally to cut both, but by this point in the budget process he is all but powerless to stop the Seawolf.
Mr. Dodd and Mr. Gejdenson argue that both Seawolfs are needed to preserve the nation's security and technological edge -- and to save 10,000 jobs in Groton, Conn. New York Democrats made that pitch to salvage financing for the F-14 fighter plane built by Grumman Corp., Long Island's biggest employer.
Several California Democrats are partial to the B-2 bomber, the Stealth warplane designed to circumvent Soviet radar, built by Northrop in Los Angeles, while Midwestern Democrats struggle with the Pentagon to preserve funding for the KC-135 transport aircraft built by Boeing in Wichita, Kansas. Texas and Pennsylvania Democrats want more V-22 Ospreys in their states.
The wrangle over defense spending is a subtext to a larger philosophical question about the role of government in hard times. Democrats say they have no choice but to protect defense-related jobs because the Administration won't replace defense expenditures with social spending. They argue that the country needs a program that would pump tax dollars and incentives into converting defense-related production to high-tech industry.
Some Democratic lawmakers are warning their colleagues that their appearance of opportunism is bad for the party and the nation. "If the Democratic Party has any theme it ought to be bringing to this country," said Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, the Democratic chairman of the House Budget Committee, "it is the theme of reordering our priorities and that the time has come to invest in our society. I'm afraid we have failed to deliver on that theme."
 
Principal and Politics
 But because members of Congress are elected in part to guard the parochial interests of their constituents, there is no end to waste. In 1991, Mr. Panetta himself attempted but failed to save Fort Ord, a military base in his district that the Pentagon ordered closed.
Only a year ago, Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri, put principal above politics by supporting the Pentagon's decision to cut funding for the F-15 Eagle fighter by $627 million, even though that action would shut down McDonnell Douglas operations in his native St. Louis. He said that taking any other position would be "immoral." But after strong local protests, Mr. Clay has altered his position and become a booster of the aircraft. Along with other Missouri Democrats, he is lobbying lawmakers to support a proposal being considered by the Administration to build 72 more F-15's and sell them to Saudi Arabia.
Republicans typically join Democrats to save military projects in their respective regions, but the Democrats have opened themselves to the charge of hypocrisy because of their record on defense spending. Just a few months ago they heralded the peace dividend as the answer to the nation's fiscal and social woes.
Calling Senate Democrats "born-again submariners," Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who opposes the Seawolf, said on the Senate floor, "I can only hope that at some point they suddenly develop an equal passion for the overall defense of our nation and weapons systems that are not made in their state."
In what could have been a line stolen from a Democrat, Mr. McCain, who enthusiastically supported the Reagan buildup, added, "The cold war is over and so are the cold war defense budgets."
Representative Gejdenson, whose district includes the Groton shipyard, said he understands that the nation must cut defense spending. But he contends such a program would drive districts like his into a downturn unless the government creates an industrial policy to diversify local economies. He proposed that the government build a magnetic-levitation bullet train between Boston and Florida, and guarantee purchases of high-definition television and computer systems to encourage American companies to develop such technology.
"There are better things to choose to build," said Mr. Gejdenson, referring to the Seawolf. "But the worst thing to do is to choose not to build anything."

LENGTH: 300 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Surge of Incumbents Opts Out

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
With 55 voluntary departures and seven involuntary ousters in primary contests, the House of Representatives has already guaranteed itself more new members next January than at any time since 83 freshmen were elected during the 1982 recession. The postwar mark of 118 in 1949 is clearly within reach.
 Seven Senate retirements may matter less, but critics of Congress, within and without, are chortling over the impending House changes, hoping to see a new tone and purpose. And surely the freshmen will pronounce themselves perk-free. Some skeptics, like Thomas E. Mann of the Brookings Institution, foresee a freshman class that "perfectly represents the electorate, with lots of anger and self-pity and not a clue as to what to do." 
 But the hundreds of hopefuls might well consider the range of retirement reasons as a measure of the place they want to work. The House Bank is plainly an element in the turnover, but many departing members with lots of overdrafts had other reasons, too. For example, Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, had 515 overdrafts, but in this country most of his fellow 71-year-olds have already retired.
 Gus Yatron, a Pennsylvania Democrat with no overdrafts, had bypass surgery last year and a district that was being carved up in anticipation of his retirement.
 Perhaps the most instructive retirement of all is Vin Weber's. The Minnesota Republican, with 125 overdrafts, said he was not running because he didn't want to be part of a mean-spirited personal campaign devoid of national issues. But the reason such a battle was not worth it was his expectation that the House itself - hamstrung by the budget, divided government and general ill-temper - would continue to be like the campaign he spurned in its avoidance of the nation's real problems.

International 3-15

ABANDONED IN AFRICA
Once avidly wooed by Washington and Moscow with economic aid and modern weapons, the impoverished nations of Africa find themselves desperate for friends. Superpower rivalry has been replaced by international indifference. 1
 
Negotiations on South Africa's future remained at an impasse. 12
 
SUSPICIOUS LAB IN NORTH KOREA
The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said that a mysterious building in North Korea could function as the core of a nuclear weapons program if outfitted with additional equipment. 1
 
MISSION TO EXPOSE IRAQI ABUSES
The United States military is trying to spirit a huge cache of Government records and videotapes out of Iraq to document what Kurdish leaders call a campaign of torture and execution that has killed tens of thousands. 3
 
Turkey clashes with Kurds, and Iraqi Kurds postpone a vote. 3
 
Saudi Arabia is accused of deficiencies in basic civic rights. 13
 
DIETRICH BURIED IN BERLIN
Marlene Dietrich, the film star who embodied not only the fantasies of millions but also the complex German psyche, was buried in her native Berlin, where people are still not sure what to make of her. 8
 
U.N. CONVOY FLEES SARAJEVO
With fresh battles erupting around them, United Nations peacekeepers in effect dismantled their headquarters in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina. 10

LAOS MISSES SOVIET AID
When a Soviet Union existed, it was the main source of economic, technical and military sustenance for impoverished Laos. Relations have since hit bottom, and military and civilian aid has been canceled. 15
 
The Pentagon removes drug radar systems from Peru's jungle. 11

S.& L. BAILOUT ESTIMATE DIPS
After years of steadily higher forecasts of the cost of rescuing the savings and loan industry, a senior Federal regulator for the first time has issued a lower estimate. 1
 
BABY-BOOMERS AND MENOPAUSE
As the baby-boom generation approaches menopause, the once-unspoken topic is provoking frank talk among women accustomed to raising their voices and getting their way. And the sheer number of these women is creating huge new markets for menopause remedies and clinics and inspiring books and workshops about the change of life, 1990's style. 1

HEADLINE: Big Bankruptcy Dampens Hopes for Real Estate

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The decision by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the world's largest real estate company, to seek bankruptcy protection in Canada last week is unlikely to have an immediate effect on New York City's already distressed real estate market. But the long-term impact could be devastating.
The danger, developers and money managers say, would come if Olympia & York's New York portfolio is broken up by creditors and sold at fire sale prices, reducing the value of comparable properties. And if rents are slashed to attract tenants, other landlords would be forced to follow suit. 
 In any event, the bankruptcy filing certainly dampens any hopeful talk of a real estate recovery.
 
 
A 'Pall' Over Lending
 "It puts a pall nationally over any commercial real estate lending by banks or insurance companies," said Kenneth Lipper, chairman of Lipper & Company, an investment-banking and money-management concern in Manhattan. "The uncertainty and the notion that we haven't plumbed the bottom yet will discourage any budding aspiration or intention to re-explore or re-examine this market."
But others think the crisis at Olympia & York, which is owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto, may not make a palpable difference. That is because banks and other institutions are already unwilling to lend, property values are depressed and tenants are wary about taking space.
Some developers, owners and brokers believe the shock wave hit months ago, when the gravity of the Reichmanns' problems became apparent and banks began to set aside money to cover potential losses.
William Zeckendorf Jr., a New York developer whose father built and lost a real estate empire, said: "Whatever bad effects we were going to see have already been taken and discounted. In the long run, I think they're going to work the situation out."
Bruce Ratner, a developer who is active in downtown Brooklyn, sounded the same theme: "The banks have been accounting for it. The markets have been accounting for it.
"The banks were already skittish, so it won't have much of a real effect on lending. Those markets have been closed for better than a year. The banks weren't lending to any of us."
But Mr. Lipper, who was New York City's Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development in the 1980's, does not buy the worst-is-over theory.
"Obviously, it didn't come as a surprise," he said. "You could see the tidal wave coming. But still, when it hits, it breaks a lot of houses. Yes, it was discounted. But you never know the full impact until it hits the shore. And now it's hitting."
 
 
Biggest Effect in New York
 In the United States, New York is likely to bear the brunt of whatever happens to Olympia & York, the city's largest commercial landlord.
Nowhere else in America do the Reichmanns have the presence they have in Manhattan, where they control 14 buildings and more than 22 million square feet of office space. (To put the 22 million-square-foot portfolio in perspective, if it were packaged in structures the size of an Empire State Building, eight would be needed.) They also own one or two buildings in each of another 11 American cities.
"It's here and in Toronto where the issues are," Mr. Ratner said. "I don't think this will have any significant effect in areas where they have one or two buildings."
But David S. Solomon, a New York developer who has had financial troubles of his own, said Olympia & York's bankruptcy filing would have a "profound effect, because of their international reputation, because of their extraordinary success, because of their ability to think forward and not miss market opportunities."
He said it was "too early" to predict the consequences of Olympia & York's action, since it was not clear whether the New York properties would also be forced into bankruptcy.
 Protracted bankruptcy negotiations might actually soften the blow to the market by delaying the properties' ultimate disposition.
The developer Donald J. Trump noted: "Those buildings and structures may be tied up for years. And as much space as they have, New York is such a huge city that it's still a small fraction. It will not have any effect on New York or real estate in New York."
Steven A. Swerdlow, executive vice president and managing officer of the CB Commercial Real Estate Group, noted that many buildings were already in bankruptcy in New York.
As to the effects of the Reichmanns' troubles on the market, Mr. Swerdlow said: "Values are frankly so depressed already that I don't see this having that much of an impact. And the banks are out of the lending business for real estate, so you can't say they're going to pull out."
A similar sentiment was expressed by Donald Schnabel, vice chairman of Julien J. Studley, a real estate brokerage. "Somebody who had concerns two days ago will have concerns today," he said. "The concerns may be heightened, but I don't think it changes much."
Mr. Schnabel added: "The hidden issue that's difficult is what will happen to management. By that, I mean, who runs the buildings, who's keeping the buildings, who's minding the store?" Even a landlord who may stand to benefit from the confused picture at Olympia & York takes no comfort from the situation. "I'm sorry about it, and it's too bad," said Lewis Rudin, a leading builder and owner.
"It might help us in renting," he acknowledged. "People can come to us. We can make decisions. We have funds to fix up the space. We don't have to go to banks. That side could be a plus.
"But on the other side, it doesn't make our industry look good. I don't like to benefit from some other guy's problem."
It is possible that Mr. Rudin and other owners will not benefit at all.
"There are some major tenants who've been in the market and who were close to making decisions," said James A. Austrian of Austrian Roth & Partners, a real estate consulting concern in New York. "They just may go back to a higher altitude and start circling again, because there is a chance that there will be a fire sale."
Mr. Lipper discerned other potential problems. Mortgage holders desperate for cash might try to lure buyers with extremely low asking prices. Low sales prices, in turn, would force a reassessment of other comparable commercial properties.
