HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California;
Politicians Warily Gauge the Effects Of Los Angeles's Rioting at the Polls

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 15

 BODY:
For a week or 10 days after the riots that ravaged some parts of this city and terrified people in others, conventional electoral politics was swept from Californians' minds. The candidates fell silent, convinced that the voters would pay no attention whatever they said.
Now, with the state's June 2 primary election only a little more than two weeks away, the war of words is resuming among the contestants in the Republican and Democratic Presidential primaries and those seeking the nominations in not one but two Senatorial races here. Commercials are appearing on television, rallies are starting to attract lunchtime crowds, and a few bumper stickers and yard signs are evident, even in the fire-scarred neighborhoods of Los Angeles. 
 The political experts are still not sure exactly how California's political climate has been affected, and how long-lasting any changes might be. "We have to wait until the embers cool a bit more," said Joseph R. Cerrell, one of the most experienced strategists in this part of the country. Like many of his fellow Democrats, he recalled with trepidation that the Watts riots of 1965 helped to elect Ronald Reagan Governor the next year.
In particular, it is unclear what kind of political weather the state will be having this fall, when California's 54 electoral votes will constitute the biggest prize in the nation for President Bush and his rivals.
In addition, the political reaction of Los Angeles and California as a whole may say a good deal about that of the country. As David Reid writes in the introduction to his new anthology, "Sex, Death and God in L.A.," this "has become the American city the world watches for signs and portents."
 
Strong Conservative Words
 Conservative Republicans have spoken in the least guarded terms. Representative William E. Dannemeyer, who is running against John Seymour, the incumbent, in a Republican Senatorial primary, endorsed the verdict in the Los Angeles police brutality case while almost all other politicians were condemning it.
Bruce Herschensohn, who is seeking the Republican nomination to run for the other Senate seat, now held by Alan Cranston, a Democrat, said there was only one underlying cause for the riots: the looters and arsonists were "rotten."
And Patrick J. Buchanan, running hard in the Republican Presidential race here even though Mr. Bush has clinched renomination, has blamed much of the disorder on Mexicans' "coming into this country illegally and helping to burn down one of the greatest cities in America."
"If I got a third of the vote in the Republican primary in California," Mr. Buchanan said this week in advocating the construction of new ditches and fences along the border, "Mr. Bush would be building that fence in July and August."
More surprisingly, one of the leading Democratic Senate candidates has also decided to take a law-and-order approach in the aftermath of the riots.
 
A Liberal's New Approach
 Representative Mel Levine of Santa Monica, locked in a close race for the Democratic nomination to succeed Mr. Cranston, who is retiring, began broadcasting a 30-second commercial this week whose theme was spelled out in the words, "A democratic society can't tolerate mob rule." The advertisement says nothing about poverty or racism, as might be expected from a liberal like Mr. Levine, but instead blames the trouble on "a failure of political leadership."
"The leadership of the Democratic party," he told The Los Angeles Times in an interview on Wednesday in an obvious attempt to distance himself from the burdens of incumbency, "has spent more time explaining away the root causes of these problems than trying to provide public safety for the people who live in the inner city."
There is no question that the riots have cut deeply into the public consciousness, especially in Southern California, which casts 60 percent of the votes in the state. Not only was the loss of life great, but this time, the looting and burning were not confined to the inner city, spilling north of the Santa Monica Freeway into areas bordering some of the city's most affluent.
Along with economic stagnation, smog, traffic and other vexations, the riots also contributed to the erosion of the American dream that Los Angeles once represented: sunny, new, full of limitless opprotunity.
Only half of those questioned in a recent poll here said they would recommend to an out-of-town friend who was offered a job in California that he or she take it. And in the same survey, 4 of 10 Angelenos said that after the rioting they would never again feel as good as they once did about the city.
 
Strategy Could Backfire
 Shanto Iyengar, a professor of political science and communications at the University of California, Los Angeles, who studies the relationships between politics and the news media, sees "a cascading series of effects" of the riots on public thinking that will be hard for candidates to address in slogans and short sound bites for the television news.
"I believe that the coverage of the actual events stirred calls for law and order and sales of handguns," he said. "But look at local TV news now, and you'll see much more thematic material, much more searching for antecedent causes and solutions. That will push the public in the other direction, and that could mean that Levine's making a terrible mistake."
William A. Carrick, a leading Democratic consultant, also expressed doubt that 1992 would provide a rerun of the 1960's in politics here.
"People see this in the context of a decade of neglect of the domestic agenda," he said. "Of course they want safety, but they see real, festering problems, too, and nobody's going to score a lot of points with a simplistic approach."
A number of things may change the way these riots are viewed, as compared with those in Watts.
Watts blew up toward the end of three decades of almost unbroken Democratic control of the White House, marked by intense social activism. The disturbances that began in South-Central Los Angeles came after two decades of largely Republican control with much less Federal attention in social issues.
In addition, this region's longtime symbol of law and order, Chief of Police Daryl F. Gates, has been almost completely discredited, according to polls showing him with an 80 percent unfavorable rating among all voters. Mr. Bush campaigned with him in 1988, and Gov. Pete Wilson did so in 1990, when his magic was intact; both avoided him during Los Angeles visits this month.
 
Portents in a Poll
 One of Representative Levine's main Democratic rivals, Representative Barbara Boxer of Los Angeles, has described the riots as "the fires of neglect" by Republican administrations. But her television advertisements promote her as a woman fighting for abortion rights and as "a fighter for change," without any comment on the riots. The third Democrat, Lieut. Gov. Leo McCarthy, has broadcast no commercials so far. The contest is very close.
If Mr. Herschensohn, and his view of the looters as "rotten," are a fair test of the effectiveness of law-and-order appeals in the aftermath of the disorder, they appear to have had little impact. In a California Poll in March, he won the support of 28 percent of registered Republicans; in a new survey after the riots, between May 6 and 9, his support in a similar group was essentially unchanged at 29 percent.
Mervin Field, who heads the poll, says the riots' most important political meaning may be "as another sign of failure by the established political order." If so, that may have helped Ross Perot, the prospective independent candidate for President, who leads in Mr. Field's latest three-way survey with 37 percent to 31 percent for Mr. Bush and 25 percent for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee.
 
Gains for Challengers?
 The riots might also help Mr. Bush's and Mr. Clinton's challengers here, Mr. Buchanan and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., unless too many voters consider the nominating fights over.
Kurt Lohbeck, Mr. Buchanan's Southern California coordinator, said the riots "are a tangible demonstration of the breakdown Pat Buchanan has been talking about all year." Mr. Brown, speaking at City Hall on Thursday at almost the same time as Mr. Clinton was talking about education in East Los Angeles, tied his remarks squarely to what happened in the South-Central region.
"When our second-largest city explodes in riots and insurrection not seen since Civil War days, something is profoundly wrong," the former Governor said, criticizing Democratic leaders in Congress for appropriating money for the military and foreign aid but not for the cities. "The usual tepid response of photo opportunity and budget crumbs won't work any more."
Mr. Brown, whom polls show within hailing distance of Mr. Clinton here, has taken youths from the riot area on his campaign plane as a symbol of his commitment to the cities.

HEADLINE: Russians Not What They Used to Be in Laos, Too

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM

DATELINE: VIENTIANE, Laos

 BODY:
A senior Russian diplomat received a visitor at his modest embassy with a rueful smile. "You are probably the last to visit us here," he said. "We are moving to our big new embassy today."
The new chancellery was designed for a relationship that no longer exists. While there was a Soviet Union, it was this impoverished country's main source of economic, technical and military sustenance. "Now our relations are at bottom," the diplomat said. 
 When the new embassy was designed, Soviet diplomats, military advisers and technical specialists here, together with their families, numbered 5,000. Today, the diplomat said, 400 remain, and most will leave when work on the new building is completed.
Military and civilian aid has been canceled. Since Communist Laos came into being in 1975, Moscow provided Laos with hundreds of millions of rubles in grants and loans that it did not expect to be repaid. "Now we are looking for aid ourselves," said the diplomat, who insisted on anonymity.
In addition to providing development assistance, three hospitals, several schools and technical installations, the Soviet Union trained 7,000 young Laotians in its schools and technical institutes. Other Eastern European countries trained thousands more.
"We prepared a mass of specialists, but gave no thought to where they would work," the Russian said. "We trained railroad engineers for a country that has no railroads."
Products of Soviet or East German education can be found in many places in this somnolent capital, few practicing the art or science they studied. The waiter spent six years learning printing technology in Leipzig; an English-language interpreter at the Foreign Ministry studied East German law for six years; an automotive technician trained in Rostov-on-Don drives a taxi.
"Some of our aid was useless," the Russian said. The Soviet Union built a truck-rebuilding and repair garage at Savannakhet in the southern panhandle. It was capable of rebuilding 1,200 trucks a year, when there were fewer than 1,000 in the entire country.
The diplomat found the highest paradox in the Higher Party School, an institution of all Soviet-oriented countries, where party functionaries of leadership potential received their ideological backbone. "We gave them their party school last November, when it was finished, and we ourselves no longer even had a party," he said.
The Russian found some consolation in the fact that his American colleagues are also rattling about in an embassy that is far too big for present needs. It dates from the period when the United States was to Laos what the Soviet Union became in its succession -- the power behind the throne.
Today, the three countries that once formed French Indochina are for the first time since the last century free of the domination of countries far to the West. Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia are free from the decisive role that France, then the United States and finally the Soviet Union played in their destinies.
Laotian officials are still waiting for the United States to follow through on President Bush's announcement last November that he would raise relations to full ambassadorial status with the only Indochinese country that did not break with its former enemy. For now, Charles B. Salmon Jr., is heading the United States Embassy without the rank of ambassador.

HEADLINE: Raid on Indian Casino Inflames Issue of Self-Rule

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT McDOWELL, Ariz., May 16

 BODY:
Pounding drums and piercing chants echo a spirit of defiance that blazes in the desert night on the Yavapai-Apache reservation here. A sense of showdown looms as clear as the moon over Red Mountain.
This was the site of confrontation on Tuesday, when Federal agents seized gambling machines at the tribe's casino, only to be prevented from leaving the reservation by a blockade of vehicles driven by angry Indians. The standoff ended when Gov. Fife Symington negotiated a 10-day "cooling-off" period. 
 The deadline expires Friday, and the Governor says he doubts that any settlement on gambling can be reached so soon. The Indians say they will not permit the Federal authorities to remove the gambling machines, which have buoyed the tribal economy and sharply reduced unemployment.
"They will not do this to us," vowed Gilbert Jones, a tribal leader. "This time, they will not get away with it."
 
'These Are Sovereign Lands'
 The dispute, which has riveted the attention of tribes around the country, has raised an issue that goes far beyond gambling and cuts to the core of a centuries-old struggle: self-rule of Indian lands.
"There is a lot of anger in Indian country over this," said Tim Giago, the editor of The Lakota Times, an independent Indian newspaper in South Dakota. "The Indian nations are sick and tired of being treated like children. These are sovereign lands. Why in hell should these lands need the state's permission?"
For decades, Federal law barred tribes from running gambling machines on reservations. But under a Federal law that took effect last Monday, a reservation can offer gambling machines or any other form of gambling if it is legal elsewhere in the state, or if the reservation negotiates an exemption with state officials. Arizona has refused to sanction the video gambling machines here.
Although the Yavapai-Apache tribe has not filed suit, tribes in at least six states have sued over the new law, charging that officials have refused to negotiate in good faith, as the Federal law requires. At least eight states have also filed suit, challenging the authority of the law.
 
Gambling as Major Industry
 With few other economic opportunities, Indian reservations across the country have turned gambling into a major source of revenue for tribes.
More than 200 tribes have gambling operations that generate an estimated $2.5 billion a year, Charles Keechi, chairman of the National Indian Gaming Association, told The Associated Press this week.
In addition to providing jobs, the casinos have helped to pay for social programs, tuition and housing for tribal members. A Sioux tribe near Morton, Minn., for example, which draws 20,000 customers a week, has used the gambling profits to finance all college costs of tribal members. It also offers a $30,000 "loan" to each elderly member to use for a new house or for home improvements. The tribe asks recipients to repay 10 percent of the loan but does not enforce the request.
"We're finally getting the income that gives us financial independence," Mr. Giago said. "We are told, over and over: 'Get off welfare. Cut the umbilical cord to the Government.' But when we try to pull ourselves up by the bootstraps, we're slapped back down."
 
A Volatile Issue
 Mr. Giago said he feared violence if Federal agents returned to Fort McDowell to remove the poker machines forcibly.
Governor Symington agreed. "We could be headed for a real crisis and showdown," he said. "This is just the fuse that leads to a larger keg of dynamite. Let's face facts: What we're dealing with here is the terribly emotional issue of sovereignty on these lands."
Before the raid, the casino at Fort McDowell was bringing in about $2 million a month. The reservation is still legally running its bingo hall, but the video machines generated about 70 percent of the casino's profits. Since gambling was introduced on the reservation in 1984, unemployment has fallen to about 5 percent from 30 percent, said Clinton Pattea, the chairman of the tribe.
"This is our chance for economic development," Mr. Pattea said. "You know, we keep telling the Federal Government, 'We're not subordinate to the wishes of the state government. We are a sovereign land.' "
In the early 1800's, the Yavapai tribe had about 6,000 members and occupied 10 million acres in central Arizona. But in the 1870's, the Yavapai were rounded up under Federal relocation orders and forced to move to an Apache reservation in San Carlos, Ariz. Many Yavapai died during the trek.
About 800 Yavapai-Apache members live on the reservation here, which was created in 1903 on a former military installation. The 25,000 acres of desert land is dotted with cactus, mesquite and cottonwood.
 
'I'm With the Indians'
 In addition to its gambling business, the reservation owns a sand and gravel pit and raises hay and alfalfa. But gambling yields the overwhelming percentage of income. Almost all of the customers are white, many from nearby Phoenix.
"I'm with the Indians on this," said Bob Jones, a 70-year-old retired Army master sergeant, as he sat before eight bingo cards with his wife, Janette. "They're just trying to make a living. They're not harming anybody."
He added: "You know, first the white man came to take their land. And now he's after their money."
The seizure of the video gambling machines threw about 75 people out of work, about half of them Indian. One of them, Rose Thomas, had worked in the sandwich concession for $5 an hour.
Her husband, Delano, had gone to vocational school to learn the skills of operating heavy machinery. "My job was the family's only income," said Mrs. Thomas, who lives with her husband and two teen-age children in an old yellow trailer here. "Now what are we supposed to do?"
 
Nightly Powwows
 The video poker and pull-tab machines are locked inside moving vans on the casino parking lot, where a powwow has been held each night since the Federal raid to show strength and unity. Indians from around the country and a few whites have come to watch the chants, dances and speeches.
The seizure of the gambling devices here, along with raids on casinos at five other Indian reservations in Arizona, were ordered by Linda Akers, the United States Attorney. She said that the tribes had been notified more than once that the gambling machines were illegal. She also said she had no choice but to stop the gambling because the state and the Indians had not negotiated an agreement. "I try to enforce the laws across the board," she said. "And these casinos were operating outside the law."
Miss Akers, who was appointed by President Bush in 1990, said she had not decided whether to order another raid if the issue was not resolved by Friday's deadline.
Governor Symington, a Republican, has scheduled a meeting for Thursday with Indian leaders to discuss the issue. He has consistently opposed casino-type gambling in the state.
Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who was a sponsor of the law on reservation gambling, faulted both the tribe and the state for the failure to negotiate an agreement.
The Senator said he regretted that gambling seemed to offer the only hope of economic salvation for Indians.
"One of the tragedies," Mr. McCain said, "is that more acceptable businesses" refuse to locate on Indian land. He added: "So what do the reservations get? Gaming and waste sites."
 
A Roar of Defiance
 When the Federal agents arrived here soon after dawn last Tuesday, word spread fast, said Mr. Pattea, the tribal chairman. By the time the video poker machines were being loaded into the moving vans, a parade of cars and pick-ups had blocked the narrow entrance to the casino.
Moments later, a line of other vehicles, including a dump truck and front-end loader, surrounded the vans, with a dozen or more of the Federal agents trapped inside the circle.
As the blockade formed, a few Indians started to clap, then more joined in. As it became apparent that the agents were blocked, a roar went up.
Mr. Pattea went to the scene with a bullhorn and asked the people to disperse. A shout came back, "We're not moving."
Some Indians said they had finally outsmarted their foes, after generations of struggles.
"You could look around and see all these smiles," said Roddy Pilcher, the 36-year-old manager of cash and operations at the casino. "And people have been saying, 'We're going to win this one.' "

The Indians formed a blockade of vehicles preventing the agents from leaving the reservation. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Washington Marchers Demand Attention to the Cities

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Warning that the riots in Los Angeles were a symptom of widespread anger, tens of thousands of city dwellers marched through the capital today to demand that President Bush and Congress focus their attention -- and money -- on the cities.
As high school bands played marching tunes and buses arrived from cities along the East Coast, politicians, labor leaders and civil rights advocates criticized the Government. They said that while the Defense Department had received money for major weapons programs throughout the 1980's, Federal aid for urban programs was cut by almost two thirds to less than $15 billion. 
 "We don't want to have to burn our cities," said Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore. He said that he and several mayors were forced to go to Congress "tin cup in hand" this week as lawmakers were discussing building new B-2 Stealth bombers. "This is all about turning the national leaders around," he said.
Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said, "We have not had an urban policy in a number of years, and while we have squandered hundreds of billions of dollars on every conceivable kind of convoluted fashion, we have left our cities with their increasing burden of the homeless, jobless, hopeless and helpless."
 
Banners Call for Action
 Carrying banners that read, "Bail out neighborhoods, not banks," and "Health care for people, not profits," the marchers walked from Capitol Hill to the Washington Monument. Their messages reflected their frustration and their belief that while the Federal Government has money to prop up the wealthy, the foreign allies and the military, it cares little about the urban poor.
But the impact of the rally was diminished by the fact that it attracted far fewer people than its organizers had predicted. Only 35,000 people took part, according to the United States Park Police; the organizers had predicted more than 100,000.
Most of the people who attended the march were members of labor unions or were there as a result of the efforts of nonprofit organizations involved in social causes, from helping the homeless to the elderly. Many of the marchers were poor and unemployed. Typically, they woke up before dawn to travel to the rally.
There was little official Republican presence at the march. When asked to respond to the demands of the marchers, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, who was with the President in Texas, said: "I don't know anything about it. We have marches every weekend."
 
Rodney King's Words in Song
 In the shadow of the Washington Monument, the crowd grew more festive. Peter Yarrow, of the singing group Peter, Paul and Mary, played the guitar and sang a song he composed based on the words that Rodney G. King had used when he asked that the people of Los Angeles cool their anger at the acquittal of the police officers who had beaten him. "People, I just want to say: You know, can we all get along?" Mr. Yarrow sang, and the crowd joined along.
But even as some in the crowd threw Frisbees and baseballs on the sloping lawn, the words from the stage grew more impassioned.
"The flames that rose in Los Angeles have died, but dust from the city's ashes remains on each of us," said Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York. "We knew how close we were to the fire, and we must stop the anger and the pain before it is too late."
 
'Listen Up, America'
 Representative Maxine Waters, a Democrat who represents the Los Angeles district that suffered the most from the rioting, chanted: "Jobs, jobs, jobs, jobs. Listen up America." She added, "No justice, no peace. No justice, no peace. No justice, no peace. Listen up, America."
Plans for the march began months before the Los Angeles riots, but organizers and politicians say it has become enmeshed in the negotiations between President Bush and Congress over a response to the disturbances in Los Angeles. The Bush Administration appears ready to invigorate its efforts to promote an urban policy anchored by a plan for developing inner cities with tax breaks for businesses willing to invest there.
Congressional Democrats would like to push a much more ambitious program, emphasizing creation of jobs with public works programs.
Both Democratic leaders and Administration officials have publicly called for conciliation, but their ability to reach a consensus proved limited on Thursday, when the House could only narrowly pass a modest program of disaster relief grants and small business loans for Los Angeles and Chicago. Most House Republicans voted against the measure, with those from rural areas arguing that rioters would interpret new financing and programs as a reward for their violence.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who attended the rally, said the march would help urban legislators make their case, because "the squeaky wheel gets greased and cities haven't squeaked in a while."
He said the somewhat disappointing turnout was a symptom of the "anger and apathy in the cities," adding, "People in Brooklyn say, 'Nobody's going to listen to me.' "
Mr. Schumer also noted that urban people had less money and fewer ties to organizations than more privileged suburbanites, who are more likely to march on the capital to promote their interests.
 
Motivated in Manhattan

Those here were the highly motivated. Some said they had marched in the capital before for civil rights or against the Vietnam War.
"I wanted to make a statement, to change the priorities of the country," said Pat Caldwall, 60 years old, director of a private senior citizens center on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. She and three friends carried a long sheet painted with the words: "Cut the military budget. Save our cities. Save our kids."
Jay Weaver, 53, an elementary school teacher from Baltimore, said: "The Federal Government is supposed to protect the states. If the foreign countries want Federal aid from our Federal Government, then let them become the 51st state and pay taxes to our Federal Government the same as we do."
Speakers at the rally were long on oratory but short on specific proposals, while their allies in Congress in the crowd agreed that they need to come up with strategies that differ from those tried in the 1960's and 70's.
Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, tried to place the verdict in the King trial in the context of a broader moral crisis gripping the country.
"It's not just 12 jurors and a verdict, but 12 years of politics and exporting jobs overseas and losing jobs at home," he said. "What good does it do to protect oil in the Middle East and lose your soul in the Far West? If the Government can spend $8 million for Desert Storm, then it ought to spend eight times $8 million for the storm raging in the ghettoes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marleana White of Baltimore, right, surveying the crowd at the beginning of a march yesterday in Washington to demand that President Bush and Congress focus attention and money on the cities. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Briton Confident on Vote for European Union

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 16

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Major remains confident that the House of Commons will ratify a controversial treaty on European union despite the latest withering blast against the growing power of the European Community and Germany by his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, according to his aides.
With the debate set to begin on Wednesday, Mrs. Thatcher warned in a speech to business leaders and diplomats in The Hague on Friday that the more federal, centralized European Community envisioned by its executive commission in Brussels and by most Continental governments would bring "insecurity, unemployment, national resentment and ethnic conflict." 
 "Germany's preponderance within the community is such that no major decision can really be taken against German wishes," she said, so the best way for other countries to counterbalance it was as a loose confederation of sovereign states, not as a federal European union.
Mr. Major, who will begin a six-month term in the presidency of the 12-nation community in July, did not respond directly to Mrs. Thatcher's warnings. He has been steadily marking off a course on Europe that diverges from Mrs. Thatcher's almost as sharply as on domestic policy issues like her per-capita poll tax, which he scrapped soon after he succeeded her in November 1990.
Having won a new term in last month's general elections, Mr. Major thinks Mrs. Thatcher has had her say, according to his aides, and that it's time for Britain to move on from her by now well-known views.
"The Prime Minister wants us to be at the heart of Europe," one aide at 10 Downing Street said. The most powerful symbol of this was the Government's decision to allow Queen Elizabeth II to address the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, last Tuesday. Mrs. Thatcher, who said Friday that the European Parliament was often irrelevant, never allowed the monarch to address it during her more than 10 years as Prime Minister.
Mr. Major has been anxious to prove that he is his own man on Europe as well as in domestic policy. He, too, wants to see Europe evolve more as a confederation than as a federal union, but he seems to favor closer cooperation than Mrs. Thatcher does.
The Queen's speech, approved as a policy document by Mr. Major's Government, was far more conciliatory in tone than Mrs. Thatcher's remarks. "We are all trying to preserve the rich diversity of European countries because, if that diversity is suppressed, we shall weaken Europe, not strengthen it," the Queen said. "Differences of style and opinion are insignificant against the background of the proven commitment of Europeans today to reconciliation and democracy."
Mr. Major tried to assure the House of Commons on Tuesday that the sovereignty of Britain's Parliament was "not up for grabs" in Europe.
But, as The Economist magazine noted this week, Mr. Major has showed no sign of wanting to stop the process of making more and more British decisions in common with his neighbors; Mrs. Thatcher always did.
As one of Mr. Major's aides pointed out, the so-called "Euroskeptic" Conservative ranks in the House of Commons are thinner these days. Not only Mrs. Thatcher but some of the other staunch proponents of British independence are gone, including Mrs. Thatcher's close friend, Sir Norman Tebbit, who also did not run for re-election last month.
But the issue still arouses passion. Some of the remaining hard-line opponents of European union discussed strategy for next week's ratification debate over dinner at the Carlton Club, a Conservative stronghold, this week and said Mrs. Thatcher had expressed their views about the European union treaty negotiated at Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December.
Though the Government's majority in the House of Commons was reduced to 20 seats in the recent election, Mr. Major was not afraid that the ratification bill would fail, an aide said. The opposition Labor Party, divided by a leadership struggle after its defeat by the Tories, decided to ask its M.P.'s to abstain rather than vote against it.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Tells Graduates That Nation Must Face Problems

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 16

 BODY:
President Bush preached a doctrine of optimism and self-reliance at Southern Methodist University today, arguing that America is still a rising nation in global affairs and "is certain to remain so, if we refuse to settle for anything less."
But the President drew his strongest response from the 2,433 graduates and their relatives when he conceded the nation's shortcomings, not when he praised its strengths. 
 Mr. Bush was awarded the loudest applause for a stock line in hiscampaign speech, a call for Americans to care for each other more and sue each other less. And his remarks were interrupted by sustained applause when he allowed that "yes, for those of us in Washington, it is high time to get our own house in order."
 
Attack on Naysayers
 The President's speech, the first of three commencement addresses he plans this month, blended his standard campaign comments with an attack on "declinists," who he said were pessimistic about the nation's economic future.
The fashionable view, he said, is that this is "a country overrun by economic predators abroad and crippled by the insurmountable problems at home."
But, he said, "the fact is, America is more than the world's sole military superpower, though it is that. It is more than the world's political leader, though it is that, too. It is also the greatest economic power the world has ever seen, a country uniquely able to provide each of you unparalleled economic opportunity."
Mr. Bush said statistics showed that American workers were more skilled, more productive and better off than any of their foreign competitors, largely because the United States has given them more freedom to take risks and innovate.
But he conceded that "we must deal now with a few alarming trends that endanger our world leadership," including the need for improvement in education, health care, social programs, criminal justice and the labyrinths of the legal and governmental bureaucracies.
Not by coincidence, those issues are at the heart of the six-point legislative agenda that Mr. Bush has begun to push before Congress in the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots two weeks ago.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Short-Term Urban Policy

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Two weeks after the Los Angeles riots, the White House remains focused on the short-term goal of moving its existing urban policies through Congress and shows little sign of beginning work on a broader agenda of new programs to revive the nation's cities.
Although Administration officials acknowledge that President Bush's program is not a complete response either to the riots themselves or to more sweeping urban needs, none of Mr. Bush's advisers have been asked to draft major new long-range initiatives or significant new spending for cities, the officials said. 
 A working group led by Clayton K. Yeutter, the White House domestic policy chief, will review proposals for action that Mr. Bush might take later this year, the officials said. The group could become the vehicle for any major new initiative the President might make. But they said Mr. Bush was convinced by his visits to Los Angeles and other troubled cities in recent days that no fundamental change of direction was needed.
Instead, Mr. Bush plans to stick to the proposals he now has on Capitol Hill. He says they have been ignored by Congress and should be given a chance before new legislation is considered.
 
Landing in the Middle
 Thus an internal debate over the scale and content of Mr. Bush's public reaction to the rioting after the verdict in the Rodney G. King beating case has been resolved in favor of middle-of-the-road oratory, with a bent toward themes of law and order. It is this line that Mr. Bush has been delivering in his public appearances since the riots, and aides say there is no reason to expect the President to go further.
Despite continued protests by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, who has started to talk of a need to spend more money than the Administration has proposed, officials said, the White House debate was dominated by the budget director, Richard G. Darman, and by Mr. Bush's insistence on holding to the 1992 budget agreement, which permits no increase in the deficit.
"Everybody is together on the basic equation that we have the new programs and we just need to get implementation," said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. He was referring to Mr. Bush's proposals to create enterprise zones in urban areas, press for welfare and education change and use new spending to root out drug dealers and seed neighborhoods with social services.
"There's not a search on for some magic new formula, or a wand that can be waved to right these problems," Mr. Fitzwater said. "Two or three years of work went into the development of our programs the way they are, and our emphasis is on getting Congress to act on them. Our whole focus is on the legislative side."
 
No Single Voice
 The clarity Mr. Fitzwater described within the White House is blurred by the Administration's lingering difficulty in finding a single voice to speak to Congress and the public. Mr. Bush, Mr. Fitzwater and other officials have veered between conciliatory words toward Democrats and sharp accusations that the Democratic welfare programs of the 1960's led to the riots.
Moreover, Administration officials and outside advisers said there was no strong hand in the White House to mediate the views represented by Mr. Kemp and Mr. Darman, leaving the two officials clashing in private and increasingly in public as well.
At a breakfast meeting with reporters on Friday, Mr. Kemp took an undisguised swipe at Mr. Darman, saying that helping the cities would eventually cost billions more than the Administration now envisioned. "I'm not a bean counter; I'm not the director of O.M.B.," Mr. Kemp said. "I'm not going to engage in single-entry bookkeeping."
Behind the policy debate are complex political imperatives. For Mr. Bush, the violence in Los Angeles produced an unexpected and potentially damaging threat just when his campaign staff thought it was finally starting to reverse his political plunge.
 
Debate on Republican Policy
 While the Bush camp has tried to keep public attention on the shortcomings of Democratic-inspired welfare programs, the riots have also begun to produce a debate about 13 years of Republican supply-side economics, policies that Mr. Bush ridiculed in 1980 but on which he has long since staked his political fortunes.
"We left people behind," Mr. Kemp said Friday. "Any economy that moves forward has to go back and bring its weakest elements behind, or it loses its soul. It loses its moral example."
Campaign officials said their planning was focusing on how to meet the clear need to address urban issues without allowing that debate to drown out the President's message on other issues, including the law-and-order themes so important to conservative supporters and the foreign policy questions that Mr. Bush's advisers say they must exploit to defeat his challengers.
White House and campaign officials said that under these pressures Mr. Bush did not have time to craft a significantly new approach to urban affairs. So they seized on his existing proposals as a way of responding to the riots that was, they said, both politically responsive and responsible from a policy viewpoint.
"The bottom line is that you have to produce," one official said. "We put something on the table, and it's good momentum."
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Bush is genuinely committed to new approaches to urban problems, as the President and his advisers insist, or whether the White House is simply going through the motions, hoping that attention will soon shift to other issues.
Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies for the Heritage Foundation, said this would be tested in large measure by the amount of political capital Mr. Bush chose to expend on his legislative program.
"He doesn't suddenly have to become a born-again inner-city grassroots urban leader," Mr. Butler said. "Nobody would believe that. But he has to say, 'I'm behind this,' and he has to be there saying, 'I'm not going to pull the rug out from under Kemp at the last minute.' Every time Kemp has gone to push major proposals, in the past, the White House has been missing in action."

HEADLINE: Insurers and Lawyers Throw the Dirt Back at Polluters;
Shifting the Burden

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on May 3, Eugene R. Anderson and Robert M. Horkovich, partners in the New York law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, wrote about the high litigation costs associated with the cleanup of toxic waste.
The article, "Why Insurance Companies Say No," cited a recent study by the Rand Institute for Civil Justice, which "reported that nearly 90 percent of the money allocated by insurance companies in Superfund claims had gone toward legal and related 'transaction' costs, rather than for cleaning up pollution." 
 Moreover, the authors said, the study found that "42 percent of the outlays made by insurance companies went to fight policyholders' environmental claims."
The authors, whose firm often represents policyholders in disputes on insurance coverage, posed this question: "When faced with large claims for environmental liability, why do insurers run for cover, instead of providing coverage that was paid for by policyholders?"
The answer, they say, is that there are "gargantuan economic rewards for an insurance company that just says no."
The solution? Take the profit out of the pollution controversy, say Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich, by adopting a "pay now and fight later" rule. "Policyholders pay premiums up front," they say. "Insurance companies should not complain about paying claims up front."
The article generated a strong reaction from the insurance industry and from lawyers who represent insurers. Following are some of the letters that were critical of the authors' conclusions.
 
To the Editor:
Implicit in the article is the erroneous assumption that insurance policies issued to industrial policyholders provide coverage for the intentional and ongoing pollution of the land, water and air.
For decades, the oil, chemical and manufacturing industries have saved vast sums of money by not paying for waste treatment. They merely dumped the often hazardous substances they produced out the back door or they hauled them to the nearest landfill.
With the advent of public environmental awareness and the resulting legislation, like Superfund, these polluting companies fought the Government tooth and nail to avoid paying the enormous cleanup costs made necessary by their conduct.
When that approach proved unsuccessful, they desperately sought an alternate means of avoiding the economic consequences of their past practices.
The result has been an attempt to shift from their own shareholders to the insurance-buying public the economic burden of cleaning up the messes they had made.
As these companies know, however, the insurance industry has long held the position (and rightly asserted it in litigation) that the tortious (and often criminal) disregard of longstanding standards for waste treatment and disposal by policyholders relieves the insurers of the obligation to provide coverage for such polluting activities.
A fundamental principle of insurance is that any loss must be fortuitous -- that is, unexpected -- to be covered. In addition, policies issued in the past 25 years contain specific exclusions for pollution coverage.
It is a sad fact that civil litigation (not just environmental insurance coverage litigation) is consuming so many of our resources.
Nevertheless, the record is clear that in those environmental insurance coverage cases tried before juries, the insurance companies have won. Lay people seem to understand what Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich do not -- that a contract means what it says.
Insurance covers accidents, not intentional misconduct. Environmentalists have long been aware that American industry has used its backyard and ours as a national dumping ground. The slick attempt of the oil, chemical and manufacturing industries to shift the burden of cleaning up America to the rest of us should be seen for precisely what it is.
Let the buck stop where it should -- with those who created the present environmental disaster in the first place.
 
KIMBALL ANN LANE
MITCHELL L. LATHROP
New York, May 7
 
The writers, partners at the law firm of Adams, Duque & Hazeltine, represent insurance companies in disputes regarding coverage.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

INDUSTRY: NAICS541110 OFFICES OF LAWYERS (91%); SIC8111 LEGAL SERVICES (91%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (91%);

LENGTH: 657 words

HEADLINE: Insurers and Lawyers Throw the Dirt Back at Polluters;
Unfair and Unfeasible

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on May 3, Eugene R. Anderson and Robert M. Horkovich, partners in the New York law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, wrote about the high litigation costs associated with the cleanup of toxic waste.
The article, "Why Insurance Companies Say No," cited a recent study by the Rand Institute for Civil Justice, which "reported that nearly 90 percent of the money allocated by insurance companies in Superfund claims had gone toward legal and related 'transaction' costs, rather than for cleaning up pollution." 
 Moreover, the authors said, the study found that "42 percent of the outlays made by insurance companies went to fight policyholders' environmental claims."
The authors, whose firm often represents policyholders in disputes on insurance coverage, posed this question: "When faced with large claims for environmental liability, why do insurers run for cover, instead of providing coverage that was paid for by policyholders?"
The answer, they say, is that there are "gargantuan economic rewards for an insurance company that just says no."
The solution? Take the profit out of the pollution controversy, say Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich, by adopting a "pay now and fight later" rule. "Policyholders pay premiums up front," they say. "Insurance companies should not complain about paying claims up front."
The article generated a strong reaction from the insurance industry and from lawyers who represent insurers. Following are some of the letters that were critical of the authors' conclusions.
 
To the Editor:
The article levels a wholly unjustified attack on the insurance industry. However, it also highlights the wastefulness of Superfund's liability-based system, which is sending hundreds of millions of dollars a year to litigation rather than Superfund site cleanup.
Insurance policies never were intended to cover the cost of this cleanup. However, polluters, many of whom engaged in the long-term dumping of hazardous materials, have used the courts to press unjustified claims for coverage.
For example, when the E.P.A. recently caught a polluter who had deliberately discharged tons of hazardous waste directly into a New Jersey river for 18 years, the company made a claim against its insurer, arguing that the pollution was "accidental." The court decided the company did not have a leg to stand on.
Contrary to the article's assertion, it is neither fair nor feasible to expect insurers to "pay now and fight later." If insurers were to pay polluters' meritless claims, that could undermine their ability to fulfill promises to millions of policyholders expecting legitimate claims to be honored for workers' compensation, products liability, homeowners and auto insurance.
That is why the American Insurance Association, which represents more than 250 of the nation's property-casualty insurance companies, has made reform of Superfund one of its most critical public policy goals. In that effort, we are pursuing ways to rid the program of wasteful litigation expenditures. We support the creation of a no-fault, non-litigation system for activities that took place prior to the 1980 enactment of Superfund.
The association is also striving to work with those affected by and involved with hazardous-waste cleanup -- business, the environmental community, state and local governments, citizen groups, labor, the E.P.A. and Congress.
By working with all parties involved in the Superfund debate and cleansing the law of the components that foment unnecessary, unwarranted litigation, we believe that Superfund will be able to achieve what Congress intended: cleanup of the nation's hazardous wastes.
Insurance companies are saying "yes" to being part of the Superfund reform process, with a commitment to improve the current system.
 
ROBERT E. VAGLEY
Washington, May 6
 
The writer is president of the American Insurance Association.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: Insurers and Lawyers Throw the Dirt Back at Polluters;
An Absurd Conclusion

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on May 3, Eugene R. Anderson and Robert M. Horkovich, partners in the New York law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, wrote about the high litigation costs associated with the cleanup of toxic waste.
The article, "Why Insurance Companies Say No," cited a recent study by the Rand Institute for Civil Justice, which "reported that nearly 90 percent of the money allocated by insurance companies in Superfund claims had gone toward legal and related 'transaction' costs, rather than for cleaning up pollution." 
 Moreover, the authors said, the study found that "42 percent of the outlays made by insurance companies went to fight policyholders' environmental claims."
The authors, whose firm often represents policyholders in disputes on insurance coverage, posed this question: "When faced with large claims for environmental liability, why do insurers run for cover, instead of providing coverage that was paid for by policyholders?"
The answer, they say, is that there are "gargantuan economic rewards for an insurance company that just says no."
The solution? Take the profit out of the pollution controversy, say Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich, by adopting a "pay now and fight later" rule. "Policyholders pay premiums up front," they say. "Insurance companies should not complain about paying claims up front."
The article generated a strong reaction from the insurance industry and from lawyers who represent insurers. Following are some of the letters that were critical of the authors' conclusions.
 
To the Editor:
The article contains a number of gross distortions of the reality of the business of insurance and how responsible insurers handle claims.
Contrary to the authors' assertions, it would not be accurate to characterize the recent Rand study as establishing that it is more profitable for an insurer to litigate coverage than to pay a claim. While it might be true that 42 percent of insurers' expenditures in the context of so-called hazardous-waste claims were attributable to litigating coverage, consider the following:
* Not all coverage litigation is initiated by insurers. Often it is the insured or policyholder that commences litigation, even in the face of a valid denial of coverage by the insurer.
* A liability insurance policy is not a financial guarantee bond. The policies at issue in this type of litigation contain various exclusions and other restrictive provisions that exist to provide meaningful coverage at a reasonable premium.
If one examines the various judicial decisions in this area in the past 10 years, mixed results would be noted as to whether an insurer or insured was the prevailing party.
If nothing else, that should indicate that the issues relating to this coverage are complex, legitimate and effectively rebut the authors' absurd conclusion that "policy nullification by litigation is an easy way for insurance companies to make money."
* If any insurer would be so foolhardy as to operate under the premise that litigating coverage is the preferred way to handle claims, it need only look to a recent order in a Texas state court for an illustration of the dire consequence of such conduct.
In that case, in addition to finding the insurer liable for what it owed contractually under the policy, the court awarded the insured more than $75 million in punitive damages, more than $5 million in interest and $15.5 million in attorney fees.
Many states, in addition to Texas, have statutes that will allow effective sanction of insurers for any "bad faith" conduct.
In fact, the often overzealous application of these laws, coupled with judiciaries and jurors with a decidedly but misplaced anti-insurer bias, presents a practical deterrent to any unfounded denial of coverage by an insurer.
 
JOSEPH P. MONTELEONE
New York, May 8
 
The writer is vice president and claims counsel at Reliance National, a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., an insurance and real estate development company.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 790 words

HEADLINE: Insurers and Lawyers Throw the Dirt Back at Polluters;
Why They Don't Say 'Yes'

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on May 3, Eugene R. Anderson and Robert M. Horkovich, partners in the New York law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, wrote about the high litigation costs associated with the cleanup of toxic waste.
The article, "Why Insurance Companies Say No," cited a recent study by the Rand Institute for Civil Justice, which "reported that nearly 90 percent of the money allocated by insurance companies in Superfund claims had gone toward legal and related 'transaction' costs, rather than for cleaning up pollution." 
 Moreover, the authors said, the study found that "42 percent of the outlays made by insurance companies went to fight policyholders' environmental claims."
The authors, whose firm often represents policyholders in disputes on insurance coverage, posed this question: "When faced with large claims for environmental liability, why do insurers run for cover, instead of providing coverage that was paid for by policyholders?"
The answer, they say, is that there are "gargantuan economic rewards for an insurance company that just says no."
The solution? Take the profit out of the pollution controversy, say Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich, by adopting a "pay now and fight later" rule. "Policyholders pay premiums up front," they say. "Insurance companies should not complain about paying claims up front."
The article generated a strong reaction from the insurance industry and from lawyers who represent insurers. Following are some of the letters that were critical of the authors' conclusions.
 
To the Editor:
In 1980, the Superfund law imposed liability on polluters to clean up their hazardous wastes, whether they owned a polluted site or dumped their waste there or just hired someone else to do it.
The statute signaled a legislative judgment to impose the cost of cleanup on the parties that should have borne the expense of proper waste disposal in the first place.
Congress made a legislative judgment to accept no excuses: if you polluted, you paid to clean up the mess you made.
Nevertheless, instead of cleaning up dump sites, the typical corporate response to virtually all governmental enforcement actions has been protracted, unproductive and expensive litigation.
After Superfund was enacted, industrial polluters invariably attempted to transfer financial responsibility to others. They sued the waste haulers. They sued the municipalities that owned waste sites. They sued each other.
Most of all, however, polluters have sued their insurance companies. During the past decade, polluters have cast themselves in the role of "policyholders" and have initiated a torrent of environmental insurance coverage litigation.
The objective of this litigation is to get the insurance industry to foot the bill for the multibillion-dollar cleanup of the routine contamination that "policyholders" profitably carried out in the three decades before Superfund.
The most troubling aspect of the Forum article is its complete failure to explain why insurers should say "yes" to claims arising out of intentional pollution. Insurers, it seems, should just pay. Why? Apparently because they are insurance companies.
The sad truth is that because of the polluters' appetite for litigation, more than eight years pass on average between the time the Environmental Protection Agency first becomes aware of a hazardous waste site and the time cleanup actually starts. Indeed, the latest available statistics indicate that only 33 of the 1,175 toxic waste sites on the National Priorities List have been cleaned up.
Surely, insurance claims must be judged on the merits. In this connection, it is appropriate to observe that most of the environmental insurance coverage claims that have been litigated to judgment have resulted in a finding that there should be no insurance coverage for the pollution damage at issue.
Thus, for example, a California jury found after an 18-month trial that the Shell Oil Company was not entitled to any insurance for the $2.4 billion in pollution damage it caused by 30 years of intentional pollution at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Colorado. A verdict of no coverage was similarly rendered in a highly publicized insurance coverage trial in a case initiated by the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company.
The fact is that no liability insurance policy covers the cost of doing business. No insurance policy pays -- or should pay -- to clean up intentional pollution damage.
 
BARRY R. OSTRAGER
New York, May 6
 
The writer, a partner in the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, was lead counsel for the insurers in the Shell Oil insurance dispute. He is co-author of "The Handbook on Insurance Coverage Disputes."

HEADLINE: Insurers and Lawyers Throw the Dirt Back at Polluters;
A Hole in Their Argument

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on May 3, Eugene R. Anderson and Robert M. Horkovich, partners in the New York law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, wrote about the high litigation costs associated with the cleanup of toxic waste.
The article, "Why Insurance Companies Say No," cited a recent study by the Rand Institute for Civil Justice, which "reported that nearly 90 percent of the money allocated by insurance companies in Superfund claims had gone toward legal and related 'transaction' costs, rather than for cleaning up pollution." 
 Moreover, the authors said, the study found that "42 percent of the outlays made by insurance companies went to fight policyholders' environmental claims."
The authors, whose firm often represents policyholders in disputes on insurance coverage, posed this question: "When faced with large claims for environmental liability, why do insurers run for cover, instead of providing coverage that was paid for by policyholders?"
The answer, they say, is that there are "gargantuan economic rewards for an insurance company that just says no."
The solution? Take the profit out of the pollution controversy, say Mr. Anderson and Mr. Horkovich, by adopting a "pay now and fight later" rule. "Policyholders pay premiums up front," they say. "Insurance companies should not complain about paying claims up front."
The article generated a strong reaction from the insurance industry and from lawyers who represent insurers. Following are some of the letters that were critical of the authors' conclusions.
 
To the Editor:
The authors' explanation of why insurance companies are reluctant to pick up the enormous cleanup bill for policyholders' pollution never mentions the most compelling reason. It is simply that their liability policies do not provide coverage.
Generally these policies do not cover damages that are expected or intended from the standpoint of the insured. Property damage from pollution is often both. Additionally, most of these policies contain specific pollution exclusions.
 
RICHARD K. SCHOEPPERLE
Buffalo, May 4
 
The writer is a member of the law firm of Smith, Murphy & Schoepperle, which often represents insurance companies in coverage disputes.

HEADLINE: With Budgets Cut, Public Officials Seek Private Money

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Only a year after voters in this community near the Jersey Shore forced cuts in spending by voting against a school budget, education officials are planning to build an elaborate greenhouse for teaching plant biology. But instead of relying on taxpayers, the school board will use a private foundation backed by local businesses.
The greenhouse here is among dozens of programs blooming around the New York metropolitan area and the country as tight budgets force public institutions to seek private financing for activities once supported almost completely by tax dollars. 
 In Westfield, N.J., a private group is seeking to raise $250,000 to renovate a historic park near the center of town. In Connecticut, the United States Surgical Corporation, a medical equipment company in Norwalk, is paying about $190,000 to keep five state parks and forests staffed and supplied. And in Westchester County, the Charles Freihofer Baking Company is underwriting the cost of closing the Bronx River Parkway to cars and opening it to bicycles on certain Sundays in the summer.
Not all private support for local governments is monetary. Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical manufacturer based in Rahway, N.J., is giving management training to officials of Woodbridge Township.
 
Tiny but Important
 Such private aid, while still tiny compared with public spending, has sometimes been significant. Private funds, for instance, were largely responsible for the recent renovation of Bryant Park in midtown Manhattan. Private funds are also important because they are often used for innovative programs, said David Gallagher, executive director of Interface, a public policy research and advocacy group in New York City.
Still, questions are rising about the proper role of business in government and whether private financing favors wealthy areas over poor ones.
There have long been charitable donations to parks, schools and libraries. But public officials and business executives say that such activities are becoming more numerous and more organized as governments tighten their belts. Instead of organizing a bake sale, local school supporters like those here in Wall are beginning to adopt the sophisticated techniques employed by private universities to tap alumni and corporations for donations.
"All of the fiscal constraints that are closing in on everyone these days have caused us to be more innovative and to look for nonconventional sources of funding," said Dr. Francine Farber, supervisor of instruction at Bergen County Special Services, a regional school district in New Jersey that teaches handicapped children.
 
Businesses Tax Themselves
 The district is forming a private foundation to raise money to buy special computer and communications equipment for the children. On Long Island, foundations to support public schools have been formed in Manhasset and Rockville Center, and one is being considered in South Huntington.
Businesses are also levying special tax-like assessments on themselves to pay for sanitation, lighting and security in their neighborhoods.
There are 24 such private business improvement districts in New York City alone, in such neighborhoods as the Grand Central Station area, Times Square, Brighton Beach in Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens, according to the city's Department of Business Services. An additional 20 districts are in formation.
 
How the Privileged Give
 In New Jersey, there are 16 to 18 so-called special improvement districts, said a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. In Woodbridge, for instance, local merchants and the town government are sharing the $1.2 million cost of a program to improve downtown streets, parking and lighting. Such districts also exist in Philadelphia, Denver and other cities.
While nobody is against private support for school greenhouses, better street lighting and prettier parks, some officials and scholars say that the trend raises concerns.
In education, for instance, private money could widen the gaps between rich and poor districts. And business improvement districts could allow the wealthy to improve their neighborhoods without having to support poorer ones.
"It's another means by which the privileged are seceding from the rest," said Robert B. Reich, a Harvard University political economist.
There are also concerns that businesses are providing public services while avoiding normal politics, said Laurence Alexander, director of the Downtown Research and Development Center in Manhattan, which publishes newsletters on central city issues. "They represent some fragmentation of the ability to make decisions on the basis of what is best for the entire community," he said.
 
Supplementing, Not Replacing
 But defenders of the private efforts say they work closely with governments and school boards and are supplementing public services, not usurping them. The extra funds spent to improve a downtown shopping district, they say, could never be raised as part of a general tax increase.
In any case, the proponents of private financing say the amount of money involved is minuscule compared with tax revenues. The 24 business improvement districts in New York have a combined budget of $24 million, less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the city's $29 billion budget.
"There are things that are needed over and above what is in the budget that could really put the cream on your educational system," said John Weaver, the assistant superintendent of schools in Wall, a township of about 20,000 people.
 
Fund for a Greenhouse
 The Wall Foundation for Educational Excellence, which was started last year, hopes to raise at least $100,000 to supplement a school budget of about $25 million.
The school board and the foundation decided to spend as much as half the extra fund on a greenhouse for plant biology and special-education classes. Other money is going to teach parents how to help their children in school and to various smaller projects, including a sculpture being designed by fourth and fifth graders at the Old Mill School.
Last year Wall voters rejected the proposed school budget, forcing a cutback in spending of more than $1 million. That led to layoffs of some teachers and reductions in spending on textbooks, said Diane Noorigian, a member of the board of education.
But she and others said there was never any thought of using the foundation to pay for basic supplies or teachers' salaries, since the foundation could never make a significant difference in the basic budget. "We're not letting the taxpayers off the hook," said Robert Jenkins, a local businessman who is chairman of the foundation's trustees.
Mr. Weaver, the assistant superintendent, said a key to the success of the foundation was the active involvement of business people in the program, and not merely as donors. For example, Steve Barlow, the owner of Barlow Flower Farm here, helped design the greenhouse and will teach horticultural techniques.
Still, local officials and business leaders say private support for public activities is likely to become even more important in the future.
Margaret Sur, a councilwoman in Westfield, N.J., and president of Friends of Mindowaskin Park, which is trying to raise private money to renovate it, said: "It doesn't always have to be what the local government can do for me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Education officials in Wall Township, N.J., who are planning to build a greenhouse to help teach plant biology, are using money from a private foundation backed by local businesses. Steve Barlow, left, the owner of the Barlow Flower Farm, helped design the greenhouse and will teach horticultural techniques. With him was John Weaver, the assistant superintendent of schools in the township. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Police Intern Arrested for Stealing 10 Guns

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 16

 BODY:
A student intern for the Albany Police Department has been charged with stealing 10 guns from a police headquarters storage room and giving them to friends and relatives.
The intern, Alfredo M. Cano, 19 years old, of Albany, was arrested on Friday on grand larceny and weapons possession charges, said a police spokesman, Lieut. Robert Wolfgang. Mr. Cano was ordered held without bail in Albany County Jail. 
 The police said Mr. Cano stole nine handguns and one shotgun from a limited-access storage area on May 7. They were noticed missing on Thursday, and an investigation turned up Mr. Cano as a suspect, Lieutenant Wolfgang said.
Nine of the guns have been recovered and the police have leads on the whereabouts of the 10th, Lieutenant Wolfgang said. None were used to commit crimes, he said.
Mr. Cano was hired as part of the department's youth internship program aimed at giving economically disadvantaged students part-time jobs.

HEADLINE: Francis G. Fitzpatrick, 89, Mayor And Party Leader in New Jersey

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Francis G. Fitzpatrick, whose elections as the insurgent Mayor of Bayonne, N.J., and as Hudson County Democratic chairman signaled the demise of an old-line political machine 20 years ago, died on Friday at Bayonne Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Bayonne.
He died of cancer, a family spokesman said. 
 A longtime independent Democrat, Mr. Fitzpatrick was a leader in the move to oust the corruption-riddled party organization, overturning half a century of domination by two legendary political bosses, Frank Hague and John V. Kenny.
Mr. Fitzpatrick's election as the director of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders in 1951 was an early setback to the party regulars, but they regained control and ousted him.
Later he became the Commissioner of Bayonne, the city's top post, then led a campaign to change the city's form of government to a strong mayoralty. He won the first election for the new mayor's post and served from 1962 through 1974. During his terms, urban renewal projects and a new City Hall were built, and the city's finances were stabilized.
 
Appointed to State Post
 The final blow to the old regime came with Mayor Fitzpatrick's selection as chairman of the county party from 1972 through 1974. He won the job as an ally of Paul T. Jordan, the young Mayor of Jersey City, in a reform coalition.
But soon then two strong-minded mayors had a falling out. Their feud and power struggle was resolved only when Gov. Brendan T. Byrne appointed Mr. Fitzpatrick chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.
He served in the state post from 1975 to 1984, and during his tenure the turnpike agency reached record highs in use and record lows in traffic fatalities.
A tough advocate who relished the rough-and-tumble of politics, he called the state Democratic chairman a liar in 1972 and, citing losses in statewide contests, demanded his ouster. The chairman, Salvatore A. Bontempo, declined to comply. Even after Mr. Fitzpatrick assumed his state post, he kept his hand in local political disputes.
Born in Brooklyn, he moved to Bayonne as a youngster and never left. He worked days in oil refineries while studying at night. He graduated from John Marshall College in 1927 and earned his law degree there in 1930. He began working as an administrator in Bayonne government, then went into private law practice in the 1940's.
First elected a freeholder in 1945, he served on that board through 1951.
He was the Bayonne Commissioner from 1959 to 1962.
Surviving are his wife of 57 years, the former Marion Tierney; a son, F. Gerald, of Bayonne, and four grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Francis G. Fitzpatrick (Tom Christie, 1972)

HEADLINE: High-Riding Hamptons Settle Down, but How Far Down?

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
At the Sagaponack General Store, caterer to the rich and trendy, Mary Spellman is thinking about trying to bolster her business by offering express delivery service of her famous pot pies. Would people really pay $19 for 24-hour delivery of a pot pie -- even hers -- anywhere in the United States?
A few years ago, there would have been no doubt. One magazine described how a desperate yuppie could not persuade another customer to sell him the last chicken pot pie for $200. 
 Down the road, Ed Hollander, landscape architect, said the recession has so far spared his select clientele. "But wait," he piped up moments later. "I have noticed one difference: nobody's plunking down $50,000 to buy their wives weeping beech trees lately."
In ways gentle and savage, the recession has crept the length of Long Island's East End. The grand fortunes, the traditional backbone of the Hamptons, have felt hardly any tremors of the recession, though many felt the stock market crash of October 1987.
The blows rained harder on the people who flocked to the Hamptons in the 1980's to show they had made it. Their arrival fueled a building boom, sending housing prices skyward and creating the illusion of a wellspring of unbridled spending.
 
A Shuffled Social Order
 No one would go so far as to suggest that the economy's jolts have brought the Hamptons to heel. "That's a kind of abstract thought," mused Randy Schindler, publisher of Hamptons magazine.
But an economic Darwinism has shuffled the social order. The free-wheeling spending of years past, when the whiz kids of Wall Street would spring for houses before the walls went up, is over. Humbled M.B.A.s still make the ritual trek here, but they are more often taking time shares, bunking with friends and strangers.
Builders have gone out of business, at least the ones who flooded the market with houses on lots away from the ocean, north of Montauk Highway, counting on the moment's frenzied spending. Now, "For Sale" signs dot the roadside, and prices have plummeted 20, 30, sometimes even 50 percent. Banks have started listing foreclosed properties with real-estate agents, in the hope of getting more than distress prices for them.
A million dollars was once barely enough to buy a vacant oceanfront lot; now it can sometimes get a house on that property. These days, said Tara Newman of South Fork Realty in Sagaponack, $300,000 can buy: "Three bedrooms, two bathrooms, contemporary, north of highway with swimming pool."
A new species that Dan Rattiner, publisher of Dan's Papers in Bridgehampton, calls the "shabby yuppie," pads down Main Street, still wearing designer threads, but window-shopping and eating at home.
"They're still into conspicuous consumption, but they don't have the means to satisfy it," Mr. Rattiner said. "And the places that cater to them know that."
 
Smaller Parties Now
 Ask Mary Spellman, fed up with cooking for customers whose first words are often: "I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I'm throwing a party."
"You're so frustrated, because you want to do something special," she said, sitting in the bench seat at the General Store's window. "Your hands are tied before you even get to express yourself."
Still, the summer crowd has not given up on parties.
"Now, they'll invite 50 of their closest friends, rather than 50 of their closest friends plus 50 others just to show they could throw a party for a hundred people," Mrs. Spellman said.
If mad spending was the 80's badge of success, the 90's have given way to post-disaster survivalism. Call it scavenger chic. Or use the darkly delicious German word "Schadenfreude" for that deep sense of glee at another's misfortune.
 
Gleeful Distress Sales
 The new breed of house hunter squeezes impossible concessions out of desperate homeowners and builders, and often walks away from the deal. Buyers ask less about square feet and wiring, and more about the owner's distress.
"If they'd simply ask if we have any houses in foreclosure, I wouldn't mind," fumed Ms. Newman of South Fork Realty. "But you know they're just doing it so they can brag at some cocktail party about how the bank was banging down the door and they came in and swooped this house off the auction block and got an incredible deal."
Two walls of Ms. Newman's office are covered with snapshots of houses up for sale, their prices ranging upward of $300,000. In the last few years, prices on the glut of contemporary houses speculators built in the 1980's have dropped 20 to 30 percent. Traditional houses take longer to sell, but they have kept their value.
Along Job's Lane, chic shops remain empty. The French shoe designer Charles Jourdan is gone from its choice spot at the corner of Main Street. Elizabeth Arden did not open last year, though its windows remain decorated with closed white shutters and golden drapes. Some shopowners leave in the middle of the night, so residents awaken to the eerie discovery that another one has disappeared. "Thank God Ralph Lauren is still here," Ms. Newman said.
Those who cater to the wealthy shudder at each closing. "You lose the fashionable trade," worried Elaine Benson, owner of the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton. "Then you get the day trippers wearing black socks with white shoes."
 
Wait Until Next Season
 But the stores that leave are not being replaced with five and dimes. Instead, other upscale shops take their places, hoping to ride out one risky season before freer spending takes hold.
There are signs that this summer may pick up: post-office box rentals are running ahead of last year and Ms. Spellman reports early party orders. Then again, each spring for the last few dismal years has been heralded as the Season Things Will Turn Around.
For all the hard-edged indulgence those who serve the rich adopt when speaking of them, hope is measured in flutters of madness. "I did hear about one landscaper who's buying a $75,000 tree," Mr. Hollander, the landscape architect, confided. "He thinks it'll sell this year."
