HEADLINE: Confronting School Ills, Alabama Looks to Tax

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 16

 BODY:
About a year ago, a General Motors executive told state officials here just how close Alabama had come to landing the company's new Saturn plant, its thousands of jobs and millions of dollars in salaries and tax revenues.
The state's package of incentives had been among the best, the executive said, but company officials lacked confidence that Alabama was committed to a well financed education system that could supply the trained workers needed for the plant. Instead, the executive said, G.M. had chosen Tennessee because of that state's willingness to undertake education reforms and to commit itself to long-term financing to pay for improvements in its public schools. 
 The chancellor of the University of Alabama, Phillip Austin, said the decision confirmed what many in the state had known for years about the effects of low education budgets, racial turmoil in the schools and depending too heavily on low wages and low taxes to enticenew business.
 
$410 Million Tax Package
 With this and other setbacks in mind, the Alabama Legislature is about to vote on sending a $410 million package of state and local tax increases to the voters in the form of a referendum. Most significantly, it would require many of the state's 129 school districts to raise their local property taxes, and it would increase state taxes earmarked for education. Lawmakers will vote on the package on Monday, the last day of the session.
But because lawmakers gained support for the measure by trading benefits to powerful interests, including landlords, utilities and farmers, the package may win approval in the Legislature only to be defeated by voters in an Aug. 25 referendum.
 
Other States Reforming

The effort in Alabama comes as a number of other Southern states, including Mississippi, Tennessee and Florida, have shown a willingness to take the political risk of increasing taxes for education, said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based, not-for-profit policy research group.
"It is clearly a trend," Mr. Newman said, "with a lot of states trying to reform education and working hard at it and putting money into it."
Mark Musick, the director of the Southern Regional Education Board, said there were specific local conditions in each of the states fueling their unusual willingness to increase taxes.
"While it is not uniform across the country and the reasons are different, most Governors and legislators who are now more wary of tax increases believe that if they have to have an increase, the place where that is possible is for education," Mr. Musick said.
In Alabama, there is also a sense of playing catch-up. After long years of trading places with neighboring Deep South states at the bottom of the rankings for education spending and achievement, the state now seems more permanently anchored to the bottom, Chancellor Austin said.
Part of the problem, said Cathy Gassenheimer, director of the statewide education advocacy group A-Plus, was that unlike Mississippi, Tennessee and North Carolina, the state had never elected "a new south Governor" who had a vision that took the state beyond its old traditions and long-established power centers.
Others point to the defection of many white residents to private schools, an exodus that was prompted by integration pressures and has not diminished over time. There remain a large number of overwhelmingly black districts in which there is no broad interracial support for public schools.
 
Antiquated Tax Structure
 Another serious problem is the state's antiquated tax structure, which places an unusually large burden for education financing on the state.
According to James Williams, the director of the Public Affairs Research Council of Alabama, a private not-for-profit group based at Samford University in Birmingham, 20.2 percent of per-pupil spending is paid for with local property taxes, less than half the national average of 44.9 percent. Another 66 percent of per-pupil spending is paid for with state taxes; the national average is 48 percent. The remainder comes from Federal funds.
But Mr. Williams said that it was the minimal local tax effort that hurt the state most. Alabama ranked 49th out of 50 states last year in the level of spending per student, ahead of only Louisiana, and 48th in local education spending, just ahead of New Mexico and Hawaii.
The proposed tax package would have a strong impact on taxpayers here, raising the state portion of local property taxes as well as forcing school districts to raise their tax rates. Last fall in local votes on raising taxes for education, 10 of 12 districts defeated the increases -- a result that led state Representative Joseph Campbell, a supporter of the package, to lament that while many business leaders, the teachers' union and affluent voters were likely to approve the tax package, "Bubba isn't".
 
Property Tax Increases
 According to staff studies by Gov. Guy Hunt's study group on tax changes, the package would mean an increase of between 60 percent and 65 percent in the local property tax of most property owners.
As the plan made its way through the Legislature it attracted a lot of baggage from the wish lists of special interest groups. The Alabama Farmers Federation demanded a boll weevil eradication program that Natalie Davis, a Birmingham political scientist, angrily said would provide enough money to "send every boll weevil in the state to Disney World."
Other provisions ease some of the general tax burden on landlords and utilities in exchange for the support of those two powerful groups. And a number of measures that would limit tenure for principals, coordinate higher education planning and alter the way superintendents are picked were removed from the package to satisfy other groups.
 
Package Now Diluted
 "So the package is not really comprehensive reform anymore," said Ms. Gassenheimer, explaining why a month ago A-Plus threw up its hands and halted active lobbying for the package. With all the changes, she and others feared that much less than the $410 million generated by the plan would end up actually going to education. By some estimates, no more than $120 million would actually be spent to beef up education.
The person whom many credit with getting the package this far and making what some see as needed compromises is Speaker Jimmy Clark, a 70-year-old political veteran from Eufala who has threatened to tie up the entire state budget if the Legislature does not pass the education package and send it on to voters.
While Gov. Hunt appointed the study group that made the recommendations that led to the package, he has not taken a leading role, leaving that to Mr. Clark. The Speaker has played political hardball on the issue, noting that he was near retirement and had little to lose.
"Alabama may be the last state to come to grips with this issue because we have a lot of special interest groups in the state that just don't think education is important," said Mr. Clark. "Others just think that there is already enough money if it is just properly spent. But the fact is that there isn't enough money now, and we need better trained and educated people if we are going to grow. Right now many of our people are just unemployable."
Far away from the state Capitol, in places like Sylacauga, people like John Floyd, a former P.T.A. president and executive vice president of the local chamber of commerce, cheer Mr. Clark and other supporters of the package while remaining skeptical about what will happen to the measures when and if they get to the voters.
"If they rely on a vague reference to helping the children, the voters aren't going to buy it," he said. "It has just gotten to the point where people just don't trust government to do what's right."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 7, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 17 about a proposal in Alabama to increase spending on education misattributed a quotation. It was Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States (not Mark Musick of the Southern Regional Education Board), who said, "While it is not uniform across the country and the reasons are different, most governors and legislators who are now more wary of tax increases believe that if they have to have an increase, the place where that is possible is for education."

HEADLINE: CAMERA;
The Global Village Of Photography

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
AS the European Community ushers in a new era in politics by way of the Common Market, the international photographic community is also bracing for great technological changes. These two forces will be explored at the seventh annual Journees de l'Image Professionnelle, scheduled July 4-6 in Arles, France.
Vincent Bertomeu, the founder of the conference, known as JIP, said that this year's lectures and workshops will focus on electronic imaging, in which pictures are made without film and standard processing and instead are stored on electronic chips and disks. The conference is open to professional photographers and advanced amateurs alike. 
 "Changes in the European economy and photo invention will bring about growth in how we train people," Mr. Bertomeu said. "The revolution will change the direction of photography and those who work with pictures. They will have to produce an increasing number of new images."
Indeed, many photographers in the United States and Europe believe that electronic imaging will increase their ability to do business globally.
Vince Streano, the president of the American Society of Magazine Photographers, which represents some 5,000 professionals, met with Mr. Bertomeu recently to discuss photography's new role in the new Europe.
"We have to rethink our business in terms of Europe and on a global scale," Mr. Streano said. He added that computer graphics and the digital transmission of pictures have made photography more than ever an international business.
There will be 17 workshops and lectures in the conference, including these:
*"The New Digital Generation," a lecture by Mr. Streano and Dick Weisgrau, the director of magazine photographers' group, will offer information from an survey by the group on the present and future of professional photography. The speakers will also discuss, among other subjects, how electronic imaging affects a publication's design; computerized picture data banks; changes in business methods, and copyright protection.
*"Between Classical and Digital," a lecture by the European fashion photographer Frank Horvat, will introduce the use of digital images on a computer.
*Jeff Dunas, a photographer, will demonstrate how Sony's electronic technology can be used.
*The digital still-life workshop will include a discussion on how to shoot for catalogues using new technology.
*A press workshop, sponsored by Kodak, will introduce photojournalists to the new electronic-imaging cameras.
*Another workshop will tell participants how to convert silver pictures, negatives and transparencies into digital images and vice versa.
"When I went to Europe last year, I saw the possibilities of the Common Market as a vehicle for us to reach Europe with our pictures and the new technology," Mr. Streano said. "There are opportunities, and there are dangers."
One of the dangers is a possible disregard of copyright law. "When pictures are transmitted and sold globally," Mr. Streano said, "it is important that users in foreign countries are aware of copyright laws and obey them."
More information about the conference and a registration form are available from JIP, 1 Rue Nicolas Copernic, 13200 Arles, France; telephone: (33) 90.96.44.44; fax: (33) 90.96.47.77. No entry fee is required, but registration forms, along with a passport-type ID photo, are due by June 25. Accommodations can be booked through the Tourist Office, 35 Place de la Republique, 13200 Arles, France.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOODS;
Straight Out of Brooklyn

 BODY:
WHEN Matty Rich, the director of "Straight Out of Brooklyn," closed his clothing store, Matty Rich's Red Hook, in Park Slope last month, it was a chilling reminder that the recession has felled even the most altruistic of ventures.
For Mr. Rich's store was one of several owned by such notable black directors and actors as Spike Lee and Christopher Martin, stores that were created to infuse some life, and cash, back into the neighborhoods that have inspired their film careers, the neighborhoods they grew up in. 
 "Matty wanted to show the black community that it is possible to open your own business," said Susan Nowak, a spokesman for Mr. Rich. "He wanted people to know that you can be young, black and an entrepreneur. But in these economic times, people just couldn't afford to buy as many clothes. And Matty just couldn't help the store grow because of all the projects that he's working on."
Still, Mr. Rich is marketing a line of trendy sports clothing that he once sold at his store. One shop that is considering his line, called Matty Rich Wear, is IV Plai. That store, in East Elmhurst, Queens, is owned by Mr. Martin (a k a Play of the rap-and-film duo Kid 'n Play). IV Plai is not as high-profile as Spike's Joint, Mr. Lee's store in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, but it is not doing badly. Mr. Martin hopes to sell his line, the Select Group, to major retail stores and plans to open shops in other cities.
IV Plai carries custom-made leather and denim items that are designed by Mr. Martin.
"I love fashion," he said. "And I knew I would give back to the neighborhood when I could."
In fact, the store sits in the old game room where Mr. Martin and his friends used to hide out. "It was a select group of us that we allowed to hang here," he said.
"There is this fear in the entertainment business that you'll end up going back to your old job at Burger King," Mr. Martin said. "I'm going to make sure that never happens."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Martin's store, IV Plai, is run by his sister, Teri Martin. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Thrifty Traveler in 10 World Cities;
Rio de Janeiro

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

 BODY:
Finding a place to stay is only one of many choices facing the traveler on a tight budget. Here are suggestions on where to eat, what to do and what not to do from 10 New York Times correspondents in cities around the world.
 Since meals can be had in most of Rio's restaurants for under $50 a couple, why not try the rare restaurant that specializes in Brazil's distinctive regional cuisine? Opened last Nov. 15, on Brazil's Independence Day, Cafe Brasil offers spicy fish soups from the northeast ($10) and black bean and sun-dried beef stew ($7) from Minas Gerais, the native state of Leonardo Braga, the English-speaking owner. To accompany, try a lime juice and rum caipirinha ($1.40) or a passion fruit mousse ($1.25). Far off the tourist track on a quiet side street in Rio's Botafogo neighborhood, Cafe Brasil has a lightly bohemian ambiance of bossa nova music on the stereo and tropical plants hanging from the Mediterranean-tile roof. Cafe Brasil is at 25 Rua Capitao Salomao, Botafogo; telephone 266-6483.Reservations help, but are not a must. For plenty of diversion with no admission fee, head for Rio's Sunday Hippie Fair, where piranha paperweights, Amazon hammocks, fanciful kites and T-shirts depicting voluptuous women in string bikinis are among the wares. Sprawling over Ipanema's General Osorio Square, the daylong fair makes souvenir hunting one stop. A few tips for haggling in the warren of booths selling paintings, belts and bags: cut the asking price by 40 percent, don't flash money and wield a pocket calculator. With Brazil's inflation, $50 should pass through the 150,000 cruzeiro mark any day now. 
Foreign tourists can explore this continent-sized nation with a Brazil Air Pass. Purchased for $440 outside Brazil, this 21-day pass allows nonresident foreigners to fly to five domestic cities beyond their port of entry. For example, after arriving in Rio, a visitor could fly to Manaus, the capital of Amazon tourism, then down to Bahia, the center of African-Brazilian culture, then to Brasilia, the modern capital on the high plains, then to Iguassu Falls , Latin America's largest waterfalls, and finally back to Rio. All this costs less than a $700 Rio-Manaus-Rio ticket, bought in Rio.
 Arriving in a Rio hotel, you will be tempted to follow instructions by the bedside and call home. Be aware that hotel surcharges and Brazilian telephone rates add up to $3 a minute charges for international calls. You can cut the cost to almost $1 a minute by using an American operator to call collect or to place the call on an A.T.&T. or M.C.I. credit card. From just about anywhere in Brazil, an A.T.&T. operator is reachable by dialing 000-8010; an M.C.I. operator is reachable by dialing 000-8012, and Sprint at 000-8016.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 14, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 17 about Rio de Janeiro misstated the date of Brazil's Independence Day. A reader's letter, dated May 26, points out that it is Sept. 7; Republic Day is Nov. 15.

HEADLINE: California With a New York Edge

BYLINE: By Hendrik Hertzberg; Hendrik Hertzberg is a senior editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

AFTER HENRY
By Joan Didion.
319 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22. 
 JOAN DIDION writes well. More often than not, she writes beautifully. That is the main attraction of her work, and the main reason why her reportorial pieces, whatever their other merits and demerits, afford the pleasures of literature. "After Henry" shows that the author of 1968's "Slouching Towards Bethlehem" and 1979's "White Album" has not lost her touch.
In the three main sections of "After Henry," mostly consisting of material that first appeared in either The New York Review of Books or The New Yorker, Ms. Didion moves easily from coast to coast and back again. Under the heading "Washington," she offers a long, shrewd meditation on the Reagan Presidency, a sharply drawn report on the 1988 Presidential campaign, and a prescient snapshot of the incoming Bush Administration, which she correctly predicts will be shaped by a self-created "situation in which the space available for domestic maneuvering had been reduced to zero." The seven pieces in the "California" section, the book's longest, surest and most varied, explore the psycho-political connotations of elements of Western civilization ranging from Patricia Hearst to brush fires to The Los Angeles Times. "New York" consists of a single essay on what she takes to be the meaning of a famous crime, the case of the 29-year-old investment banker raped and beaten nearly to death as she jogged in Central Park in 1989.
Ms. Didion's strength is her sensibility, which is perfectly expressed by, and in some ways identical with, her style. Cool, precise and ironic, she is a master of the pointed use of quotation marks, deploying them like a pair of surgical tweezers. She is an expert geographer of the landscape of American public culture, and she knows that the lines on the maps most of us use seldom correspond to the real boundaries. She is sensitive not only to the uses and misuses of language (her own words are chosen with great care) but also to the patterns formed by the eddying interplay of politics, celebrity, status anxiety and the media. Above all, she is good at noticing and analyzing what she calls "narratives" -- the stories people unconsciously or half-consciously construct in order to make sense of the public events in which they are caught up, whether as participants or as observers. Some of her best essays are narratives about "narratives": when she covers a story, in other words, the story she writes is the story of the stories about the story.
The Didion sensibility, at once languid and Olympian, falters when its subject is itself. An instance is the title piece, which introduces this collection, a seven-page tribute to Ms. Didion's editor Henry Robbins, who died in 1979 at the age of 51. The piece is much more about Ms. Didion's formerly uncertain sense of self, her unfamiliarity with death and her early insecurities as a writer than it is about Robbins, who is pictured as having reassured her about these frailties but remains otherwise frustratingly indistinct. However genuine her love for her friend, she does not restore him to life on the page.
But her cool eye sees sharply when it surveys the rich texture of American public folly. Her article on the 1988 campaign shows her method at its best. What she has to say about the manipulation of images and the creation of pseudo-events makes familiar territory new again. She fashions an illuminating case study out of an incident in which Michael Dukakis played catch with an aide at planeside. The incident -- "what was referred to among the television crews as a 'tarmac arrival with ball tossing' " -- was designed to be a metaphor for the candidate's regular-guy toughness. Ms. Didion traces its progress through articles by Joe Klein, Michael Kramer and David Broder, until it becomes, "at least provisionally, history" -- and takes its place in the bogus "narrative" of the 1988 campaign.
"It is understood that this invented narrative will turn on certain familiar elements," she writes. "There is the continuing story line of the 'horse race,' the reliable daily drama of one candidate falling behind as another pulls ahead. There is the surprise of the new poll, the glamour of the one-on-one colloquy on the midnight plane, a plot point (the nation sleeps while the candidate and his confidant hammer out its fate) pioneered by Theodore H. White. There is the abiding if unexamined faith in the campaign as personal odyssey, and in the spiritual benefits accruing to those who undertake it. There is, in the presented history of the candidate, the crucible event, the day that 'changed the life.' "
Four years later the names and plot points have changed, but the "narrative" threatens to remain the same if the election again turns on "character." Still, Ms. Didion errs, I think, when she rather airily endorses the hoary radical shibboleth that the "choice among determinedly centrist candidates" that American politics normally offers is "fictive." The new makeup of the Supreme Court, to take one example, is very nonfictive indeed.
This points up a weakness of her national political coverage, which is also a weakness of her sensibility. The story of the stories is indeed a story -- but so is the story itself. Her focus on the swirl of "narratives" is useful as a way of exploring political image-mongering, but surprisingly limited as a way of describing the brute political and social realities against which candidates and ideas must in the end be measured.
Ms. Didion's reporting on California, however, is more firmly rooted in such realities. And she has always been at her most original when she writes about the state she knows best. "The extent to which certain places dominate the California imagination is apprehended, even by Californians, only dimly," she writes in her essay on the Hearst case. "Deriving not only from the landscape but from the claiming of it, from the romance of emigration, the radical abandonment of established attachments, this imagination remains obdurately symbolic, tending to locate lessons in what the rest of the country perceives only as scenery."
Ms. Didion locates many such lessons. Much of the Berkeley campus of the University of California was built by Patricia Hearst's great-grandmother Phoebe; so "for a Hearst to be kidnapped from Berkeley, the very citadel of Phoebe Hearst's aspiration, was California as opera." Wyntoon, Phoebe Hearst's misty, Gothic country estate, embodies northern California and "wilderness sanctified," just as San Simeon embodies southern California and "wilderness banished." Ms. Didion finds an ingenious parallel between Ms. Hearst's "abrupt sloughing of the past" when she became the gun-toting Tania of the Symbionese Liberation Army to the don't-look-back spirit of the emigrants of the Donner party, who forsook all attachments when they headed west in 1846. In a report on the psychology of earthquakes, a minor shock "lent a certain moral gravity to the way [Los Angeles] happened to look that weekend, a temporal dimension to the hard white edges and empty golden light." In Ms. Didion's hands, even a report on real estate prices can acquire the ominous quality of film noir.
Elsewhere in the "California" section, she evokes the now perhaps too-familiar seductive anomie of which she has long been the foremost chronicler. "A good part of any day in Los Angeles is spent driving, alone, through streets devoid of meaning to the driver, which is one reason the place exhilarates some people, and floods others with an amorphous unease," she writes -- elegantly, but with her word processor on cruise control. Fortunately, she sometimes parks the car to write knowledgeably and piercingly about the politics of L.A. zoning, Hollywood screenwriting and more.
In her long concluding essay, Ms. Didion casts the Central Park jogger case as a clash between "one vision, shared by those who had seized upon the attack on the jogger as an exact representation of what was wrong with the city," of "a city systematically ruined, violated, raped by its underclass," and an "opposing vision, shared by those who had seized upon the arrest of the defendants as an exact representation of their own victimization," of "a city in which the powerless had been systematically ruined, violated, raped by the powerful." These two "narratives" were subsumed in a third, "the transforming narrative of 'contrasts,' " in which even the "criminality of the city and its related absence of civility could become points of pride, evidence of 'energy': if you could make it here you could make it anywhere, hello sucker, get smart."
Within this framework Ms. Didion offers some brilliant observations about undercurrents of the case. She explores the double-edged symbolism of interracial rape. She reviews, with economy and appositeness, the "entire complex of loaded references," for American blacks, "around the question of 'naming': slave names, masters' names, African names, call me by my rightful name, nobody knows my name." (The jogger remains anonymous to this day in the New York dailies, while the black press repeatedly printed her name. Ms. Didion connects this to the legacy "in which the specific gravity of naming locked directly into that of rape, of black men whipped for addressing white women by their given names.") And she debunks the "sedative" notion that "if the city's problems could be seen as deliberate disruptions of a naturally cohesive and harmonious community, a community in which, undisrupted, 'contrasts' generated a perhaps dangerous but vital 'energy,' then those problems were tractable."
Ms. Didion plainly finds the "black" vision of systematic oppression morally superior to the "white" vision of systematic mayhem. But both visions are contemptible exaggerations, and it is far from clear which, in today's New York, is the more damaging. Moreover, both are rejected by millions of New Yorkers, black and white. These New Yorkers are absent from her schema.
In her discussion of the Rev. Al Sharpton, Ms. Didion seems to admit of no role for black political leaders other than the media-driven polarities she terms "the Good Negro" and "the Outrageous Nigger." Disqualified for the first role by a lack of "refined manners and good grammar," she suggests, Mr. Sharpton has been obliged to cast himself in the second. With this argument, and because the rage Mr. Sharpton expresses (and exploits) is shared by many blacks, she essentially absolves him of responsibility for his destructive demagogy. Surely this is as patronizing as the stereotypes she otherwise deplores.
MS. DIDION is right to connect the growing disharmony of New York life to economic hardship and injustice. But her specific accusation of an "unindict able conspiracy of criminal and semicriminal civic and commercial arrangements, deals, negotiations, gimmes and getmes" is an unexpected echo of naive goo-gooism at best, Dan Quayle-style scapegoating at worst. It's puzzling to find Joan Didion attributing New York's woes to high taxes, too much regulation and too many unions. In any case, gimmes and getmes have been the city's modus operandi for more than a century. So it's hard to see how they can be responsible for its current travails.
Perhaps Ms. Didion brings too much California comfort to her observations of New York. The flip side is that her observations of California have a nice New York edge. In one of the best anecdotes in this book, she recalls that while covering the 1988 Democratic National Convention she had to wait in line for a rotating press pass that would give her access to the convention floor for 20 minutes. Spotting an acquaintance from her screenwriting days, the film director Paul Mazursky, she noticed that Mr. Mazursky had a V.I.P. floor pass -- "and, since I was working and he seemed not about to go on the floor, I asked if I might borrow it for half an hour.
"He considered this.
"He would, he said, 'really like' to do this for me, but thought not."
The story beautifully clinches her point, which is that the Hollywood screenwriters' strike was more about status and hurt feelings than about money. And by telling it, Ms. Didion gets deliciously even with Mr. Mazursky. Really, though, writing well is her best revenge.

HEADLINE: Limousine Operators Fighting City Licensing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
LIMOUSINE operators in Westchester are up in arms over an attempt by the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission to levy a series of fees on suburban-based taxis that pick up passengers in the city.
"If they get away with it, I can say goodbye to a business that took me 15 years to build," said Walter Bell, owners of Walter's Personal Car Service in White Plains. "It makes me very angry, especially because there's no real reason behind it. It's only a scheme to raise money for New York City." 
 Richard J. Guberti, president of the 187-member Limousine Industry Council of Westchester, said that if new fees went into effect his group's members would be forced to raise their prices by more than 40 percent and that at least half of the smaller companies would be forced out of business.
"The exorbitant amount the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is proposing to license all suburban and taxi limousines is not justified," said Mr. Guberti, who owns Excell Limousine Service in Mount Vernon. "It's only another attempt to raise money for the city."
 
'We Don't Cruise for Business'
 "None of us do business in New York City," he said. "We don't have 212 telephone numbers. We don't advertise for business there. We don't do 'point-to-point' business there. We don't cruise for business like their gypsy cabs do. All we do is pick up customers in Westchester and drive them to and from airports, theaters, proms and restaurants in the city."
Under the commission's most recent proposal, out-of-town taxis that pick up passengers in the city would be charged the same $250 licensing fees as city-based cabs. In addition, the proposal calls for a $50 fee for a license for each driver and a $100 fee for the radio-dispatch base of each out-of-town company.
Originally, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission had announced that on March 2, 1992, any suburban limousine not in compliance found in New York City would be seized and towed. The deadline has been extended to June 1.
Mr. Guberti said that if Westchester operators were forced to raise their rates by 40 percent to cover higher operating costs resulting from New York City licensing requirements, the average charge for a sedan holding up to three passengers going from White Plains to La Guardia Airport would rise to $91 from $65, not including tolls, parking fees or tip. The average charge for a stretch limousine carrying up to six passengers from White Plains to the Manhattan Theater District would rise from to $151 from $108.
Mr. Guberti also said that Westchester operators were concerned that if they are licensed by the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission their insurance rates could be raised.
"We'll probably be treated by the insurance companies as vehicles operating within New York City and be charged much higher premiums," he said.
He estimated that insurance would likely increase by $1,500 a vehicle, and by imposing its requirements on suburban operators the city would open the operators to further business taxes.
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke is working with Westchester's state legislative delegation to bar the city commission's attempt to impose fees on suburban limousine operators.
"I've already written to the county executives of Nassau, Putnam, Rockland and Suffolk Counties, who are behind our efforts to bar the New York Taxi and Limousine Commission from levying licensing fees on suburban operators," Mr. O'Rourke said. "At the same time, our county attorney is researching the law to determine what retaliatory measures we can take, such as establishing our own taxi and limousine commission, the power to levy similar fees on taxis and limousines that do business in Westchester."
"But frankly," Mr. O'Rourke added, "I feel that's a tactic of last resort. We don't want to engage in a border war in which everyone loses."
 
A Second Try in Albany
 A bill proposed by State Senator Norman Levy to regulate fees equitably for all limousine companies, which was passed by the Senate but defeated in the Assembly, has been reintroduced.
To give the State Legislature time to work on a solution, Mr. O'Rourke has tried to get the Taxi and Limousine Commission deadline extended to the end of the year.
"Although we weren't able to get the City of New York to agree to declare a six-month moratorium on the enforcement of the licensing provision on suburban taxis and limousines, I have been in constant contact with Mayor Dinkins, whom I have always found to be reasonable and fair," Mr. O'Rourke said. "The Mayor has agreed to continue our negotiations on a day-to-day basis in hopes of resolving the matter amicably."
The County Executive said that any additional fees "would be disastrous for all the entrepreneurs who through hard work and on their own have established businesses."
 
Livelihood in Jeopardy
 Mr. Bell is one of those entrepreneurs. He capitalized his fleet of five late-model Lincoln Town Cars and one stretch limousine himself.
"I've put a lot of money into my business," Mr. Bell said. "The Town Cars cost me about $20,000 apiece; the limo about $40,000, and that does not include the insurance. Now the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission wants me to give them what amounts to over $15,000 out of pocket. That's if I want to be able to pick up my passengers in the city or at area airports.
"What's strange about the whole thing is they say it's O.K. for me to pick up passengers in Westchester, but I can't pick up the same passengers in New York City for a return trip without being licensed by them."
Since 90 percent of his business is generated by Westchester corporations, much of it in airport trips, Mr. Bell said, his livelihood would be in jeopardy should the New York City licensing provisions go into effect.
"In this business, you are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week," he said, "and the competition is fiercer than ever because a lot of corporations are downsizing and cutting back on all services. It took me more than 10 years to establish good personal relationships with corporate accounts. And I know I'd surely lose most of that business if I couldn't provide them with airport pickups.
"People say, 'Well, you can always raise your rates,' but if you do that in today's world, you price yourself right out of the market," Mr. Bell added. "Corporations will simply turn around and rent cars for their executives and have them drive themselves instead."
 
A Threat to Hotels
 Richard Eisley, president of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the fee proposal would deal a blow to the county's convention and tourist industry. "Our hotels, conference hotels and historic attractions would all suffer along with the limousine industry," Mr. Eisley said. "We're backing their battle to the hilt."
James Moricone, owner of James Limousine Service in White Plains, has a fleet of 17 vehicles. Most of his business is with corporations in the area, like Pepsico and its affiliates, with which he has contracts to supply car and limousine service on demand.
"If the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission has their way, my fleet would be reduced to five vehicles," said Mr. Moricone, who is an executive director of the Limousine Industry Council. "That's all I could afford."
The one- and two-car fleets would be forced out of business, Mr. Moricone said, "or else they would join the thousands of illegal drivers who are already competing with us."
"I'd say that our industry -- already hard hit by the recession -- would lose 50 percent of its present members," Mr. Moricone estimated.
Noting that there are plenty of New York City taxis coming into Westchester every day, Mr. Moricone said: "Are we going to shut them out to get even? Are we going to guard the borders of the county? It would be better for all of us in the industry, in Westchester and New York City, if we solved the problem by issuing state permits to operators or through establishing reciprocal agreements between counties."

HEADLINE: Scofflaws Give Communities A New Line Item

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
LAST fall New Britain paid $1,875 for five Denver boots, devices that immobilize illegally parked cars until their owners pay outstanding parking tickets. "We had more than $60,000 in unpaid tickets, and we had to do something," said the supervisor of the New Britain Police Department's traffic division, Sgt. Joseph S. Rizzo.
It proved to be a good investment: New Britain got back more than half the cost of the boots the first day, snaring two of the city's worst scofflaws, who owed $1,000 between them. Since then, the boots have brought in more than $15,000, Sgt. Rizzo said. As tax collections fall and municipal expenses rise, towns are looking at all sources of revenues, and parking ticket receipts are getting increasing attention. Across the state, officials are using a variety of methods to collect unpaid parking tickets, which can amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars. 
 Besides the boot, which is used in at least a dozen cities and towns, municipalities are employing collection agencies, installing computer systems to more readily identify scofflaws, or impounding the vehicles of those with unpaid fines.
Some towns are starting to use a law to block parking-ticket scofflaws from registering their cars, and adopting ordinances to double or triple the fines after a certain number of days.
Towns are also going after more parking-ticket revenue by raising the fines so it is no longer practical to park in a no-parking zone. Bridgeport, a financially beleaguered city, hired six meter attendants this year to patrol the downtown district; they were looking for drivers parking 20 minutes in a 15-minute zone, parking too far from the curb or parking in a loading zone.
Police say that even in these times, people are willing to risk a ticket if it means saving a few steps. Some tickets are put on vehicles parked just a few feet from garages, where people could have parked legally and a lot less expensively. The Collector of Revenues in Mansfield, Pamela V. Wells, said that the number of tickets issued in that town, primarily on the University of Connecticut campus, had been climbing sharply, from 30,000 in 1990 to 35,000 last year. The Town Council decided it was due in part to an old fine schedule -- tickets were all $10, with no late penalties. So they raised the levies, depending on the offense, to as much as $25, and instituted a $5 charge if the tickets were not paid in 21 days. Still, the town expects to issue about 30,000 tickets this year, based on the trend so far, Ms. Wells said.
The boot, which has been around for the last 10 years, is becoming one of the most popular methods of cracking down on scofflaws.
In Greenwich, one of the first towns to employ the device, a traffic technician, Scott T. McConnell, said that a list of scofflaws was updated every two weeks and given to police officers. "Most of the tickets are given out in the central business district, to people who are there on a regular basis," Mr. McConnell said. "They have to come to work, and if they're on that list they're going to be spotted sooner or later."
Mr. McConnell said it was not unusual to snare people with $500 or $600 worth of parking tickets. "We have five boots, and they're used pretty steadily," he said.
In New Britain the new boots are being deployed with a more sophisticated method of tracking scofflaws: hand-held computers that get updated daily. "We catch up with people a lot quicker," Sergeant Rizzo said. "If someone makes the scofflaw list on a Wednesday night patrol, we know about it by Thursday morning, and the next ticket he gets, he gets the boot."
The computers also print out tickets, Sergeant Rizzo said, which speeds up the process considerably. "We can tag a whole line of cars in 40 seconds -- zip, zip, zip," he said. "We're getting real high-tech."
Sergeant Rizzo said that the police were also concerned about a $5 ticket for overtime parking in a one-hour zone being cheaper than paying $8 for a parking garage for the day. As a result the police asked for, and got, a city ordinance that allows for multiple ticketing: after one hour the car gets its first ticket, after two hours it gets its second, and so on. "If you get five tickets in a restricted area, that's $50, but after 10 days it's $150," Sergeant Rizzo said. "It can add up to some real money pretty quickly."
 
'Question of Image'
 Parking violators aside, not everyone likes the boot. The parking enforcement administrator for the City of New Haven, Charles A. Wailonis, said that he has some boots but does not use them. "It's a question of image," he said. "Driving down the street and seeing a car with a boot on it doesn't translate into, 'Welcome to New Haven.' "
Even in New Haven, which has $506,000 of unpaid tickets from people who owe at least $150 each in fines, scofflaws do not get off any easier. When their cars are spotted they are towed to an impoundment area where they are held until the owner pays the fines as well as towing and storage charges. Mr. Wailonis said New Haven was impounding 40 to 60 cars a week. "A year ago we were probably impounding about 30 percent fewer cars than we are right now," Mr. Wailonis said. "Some of it is the fact that more people are not paying their parking tickets, probably because of the economy," he said.
But it is also because those who hand out the tickets have been given radios that allow them to call for a tow truck.
Last month the city also began using a different towing company each day rather than a different one for each call. "That allows them to beef up their staff on their day, and keep a couple of trucks right in the downtown, ready to go," Mr. Wailonis said. "That's cut way down on our response time."
Mr. Wailonis also said that New Haven has started to take advantage of a law that allows the state's five largest cities to block scofflaws from registering their cars. In January it sent a list of 300 scofflaws to the State Department of Motor Vehicles. On April 28 it sent 375 more names. The registrations on those cars, including vehicles owned by people from out of town, cannot be renewed until the parking fines are paid.
Ms. Wells said Mansfield and other smaller towns were lobbying for the same power. She said it could have a particular effect in a college town like Mansfield. "A lot of these cars are driven to campus by the student but registered to the mom or dad, and when the notice of the tickets comes home the student is told to take care of it," Ms. Wells said. "If all of a sudden they can't renew their registration, that will certainly get some action."
 
$20,000 a Year in Fines
 The Tax Collector for Bristol, Esmonde J. Phelan, said that that city collects about $20,000 a year in parking fines, but he is not sure how many scofflaws there are because the records have never been computerized. "I'd like to say we're collecting two out of every three tickets that we're giving out, but I'm not sure the collection rate is that good," Mr. Phelan said.
A project to computerize those records by June has been delayed because of personnel cuts, Mr. Phelan said, "but there's no question we have to computerize that list if we want to maximize our collections.
"There's no question the process of computerizing the records would pay for itself in short order," he said. "And, as long as there's a need to give a parking ticket, we should have a vehicle to collect it. Otherwise, it's not fair to the people who pay their fines on time."
In Waterbury, the Deputy Police Superintendent, Richard J. White, said the city recently doubled the price of a parking ticket, and imposed late fees for the first time -- though they offered scofflaws amnesty for a month. The program was so successful that one scofflaw called from his new home in the Middle West to settle a bill of several hundred dollars, Mr. White said.
"There was a little criticism that we shouldn't give them the chance to pay at the old rate," Mr. White said. "But the fact is, 100 percent of nothing is still nothing."
Mr. White said Waterbury has also started to take advantage of the law that allows it to block scofflaws from registering their car. "We'd like to get some boots, but with times the way they are we can't afford the investment," he said. "I think we'll accomplish just as much as we did if we impounded the car this way but it's a longer process. The registration period in Connecticut is two years, so if you've just registered your car you're in the clear for two years, but we're going to get you eventually."

HEADLINE: A Daunting Challenge for Graduates

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
STARTING out or starting over -- either way, finding a job these days can be difficult. For many recent college graduates and for experienced workers, obtaining employment in a changing marketplace is becoming daunting.
Although most job seekers do not need an expert to confirm what they already know from personal experience, economists and labor-market analysts -- while not describing a hopeless situation -- report that not only are the jobs few and the competition keen but also that this situation is not likely to change dramatically in the near future. 
 What recent graduates are discovering as they look for jobs is that their stiffest competition is coming not from their peers but from the ranks of displaced older professionals, many of whom have a proven track record to offer a new employer.
"College grads today are interviewing against some very experienced and highly skilled workers," said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Department of Labor. "For new graduates, with diplomas in hand, not even that piece of paper automatically opens doors anymore."
Although there are fewer graduates entering the job market, primarily because of the baby bust of the 1960's and 1970's, they are looking for work at a time when unemployment in the county has hit historically high levels. Westchester's jobless rate in March was 6.2 percent, the highest figure for that month since 1977.
And although census figures show that in 1990 there were only 11,940 21-year-olds in the county -- 10 percent fewer than in 1980 -- young adults are trying to enter the work force at a time when, in addition to high unemployment, the number of jobs has declined. Westchester lost 10,800 jobs between March 1991 and last March; at last count, there were only 372,600 jobs, the county's lowest March job count since 1984.
All that adds up to the fact that it has become a buyer's market for recession-weary employers, who can demand highly developed job skills, sometimes in exchange for only a part-time position that offers few or no benefits and no long-term commitment.
"It's an extremely difficult time," reported Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Office of Commerce and Economic Development. "The competition keeps jobs at a premium and holds wages down."
 
Some Industries Still Flourish
 Nevertheless, even at a time when many corporations are cutting back their operations and there is only a glimmer of hope that a recovery is in sight, there are pockets of jobs and some industries are forging ahead, the State Labor Department reports.
"Without a doubt, it is a difficult job market," Mr. Surdey said. "But it's not an impossible one."
Topping the list of growth industries is the health-services field, which includes nursing, respiratory therapy, radiological technology and home health care. The aging of the population -- with about one-third, the Baby Boomers, now in middle age -- is resulting in a greater demand for health professionals.
"And prior to the Great Depression, there was another baby boom," Mr. Surdey said. "That group is in their 60's and 70's now and demanding even more health services."
The jobs for health-care professionals can be found in nursing homes, hospitals and doctors' groups, some of which are self-contained medical centers that often have on-site pharmacies and testing laboratories.
 
500 Students on a Waiting List
 "If we look into the future," Mr. Surdey said, "one out of every six jobs generated will be in the allied health fields."
At the Job and Career Center of Westchester Community College in Valhalla, Richard Putnam, the center's director, reported that student requests for courses in health fields were soaring, with 500 students on a waiting list to enter programs related to the field.
In 1989, the last year for which the college had data, respiratory therapists earned an average starting salary of $32,000, radiological technologists started at about $38,182 and registered nurses at $32,662, Mr. Putnam said.
"Relative to other fields of employment, health care is faring better," the director said. "But that's only relatively speaking. Because health-care workers are holding on to their jobs, new hiring has slowed down and "employment isn't what is was a year or two ago," Mr. Putnam said.
In addition to the health services, the job outlook is somewhat better than average for social-services providers, insurance carriers and business services.
Specifically, as many firms reduce their size and contract for services that were previously provided in-house, Mr. Surdey said that companies performing those functions could benefit.
"Most of the job growth will be in small and medium companies because of all the restructuring," Mr. Surdey said.
Some of the services now in demand are advertising and marketing, personnel and human resources, computer and data, legal and paralegal, auditing and accounting, management and public relations, engineering and architecture, research and testing for the environment and products, decorating and maintenance of building interiors and security.
 
Computer Skills in Demand
 Also, professionals with advanced computer skills are in demand. At the Westchester Private Industry Council, the director, Renee Guy, reported that the county-administered organization has set up a retraining program with Mercy College for displaced Nynex workers who can learn such computer programming languages as Pascal and Unix and re-enter the job market at salaries that often start around $60,000.
"The whole world of the dislocated worker is new," Ms. Guy said. "And colleges are recognizing that as the traditional student population dwindles, schools need to go after a new adult market. The time is right for adult education and retraining."
Retraining is also often the main factor for blue-collar workers facing unemployment. "There is no market any more for assembly-line workers," Ms. Guy said. "We are losing all our factory jobs in Westchester."
At the Board of Cooperative Educational Services for Southern Westchester, the director of the occupational education division, Joseph Schwartzberg, called the proposed closing of the General Motors assembly plant in North Tarrytown "the classic example" of the changing marketplace for factory workers.
 
Enrollment Up at Center in Valhalla
 "A narrow focus for an employee is all well and good if business conditions stay the same," Dr. Schwartzberg said. "But as companies change and work gets exported to other parts of the world, workers here have to have broader-based skills to survive."
Adult enrollment this year at the Southern Westchester Center for Technical and Occupational Education, run by Boces in Valhalla, was 300, compared with 60 adult students six years ago, said Dr. Schwartzberg, the director of the center. He called the increase "clearly a function of economics and the changing workplace."
There is a demand for blue-collar workers in such fields as computer repair, building maintenance, office machine repair, trucking and the hotel and hospitality industry.
Many of those jobs, however, pay less than assembly-line workers are used to earning. "The difficulty G.M. workers will have is that they are not going to make the same kind of money," Ms. Guy said.
"But that problem," she said, "is rampant among all dislocated workers. It is something most white-collar workers as well are going to encounter."
 
Starting One's Own Business
 As all segments of the working population face layoffs and a shrinking job market, many blue-collar and white-collar workers are considering entrepreneurship. Robert Bierman, supervising coordinator for the Hudson Valley Region of the State Labor Department, called it "a growing trend of 'I've always wanted to start my own business.' "
At Mercy College, the president, Dr. Jay Sexter, said the school was seeking grants to set up a program to help people start new businesses and obtain bank loans in a tight economy.
Mr. Surdey said, "If you can get the capital, it is definitely a good time for this. And with modems and databases, more businesses can be operated from a home office."
About 9 percent of the county's work force is self-employed, he said.
For those preferring to work for others, Mr. Surdey recommended applying at small and medium-size companies rather than at larger businesses that may still be cutting back.
"Keep your goals high," he said. "Keep your eyes on the Fortune 500 companies. But, if you want a job, you many have to be willing to start lower than you had wanted to."

LENGTH: 933 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Human Whirlwind In South-Central L.A.

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Marva Smith Battle-Bey delayed her long-planned trip to Chicago and Detroit by two days in the wake of the Los Angeles riots, but when she returned last Tuesday she hit the ground running. Phone calls have been flooding the 13-year-old private nonprofit Vermont Slauson Economic Development Corporation, deep in the heart of riot-ravaged South-Central Los Angeles, which Mrs. Battle-Bey, the president, has run since 1981.
She and her staff are on the front lines of the "Rebuild L.A." movement because they already know how to do it. With money scraped together from the City of Los Angeles, foundations and banks, they have built a neighborhood shopping center, an affordable apartment building and a low-rent "incubator" to house five fledgling businesses; they rehabilitate 75 to 100 housing units a year. The black-owned McDonald's at their Vermont Slauson shopping center has so little competition right now that on Monday it ran out of french fries. 
 Today, Vermont Slauson is struggling to keep up with the sudden onslaught of meetings and requests. "I'm trying to catch up," Mrs. Battle-Bey tells her husband on the phone. "I can't; it's a whirlwind." At her narrow storefront at Vermont and Slauson, which was miraculously spared in twin conflagrations that engulfed the stores on either side, Mrs. Battle-Bey, an imposing woman in her late 30's, wearing a flowing lavender pantsuit, starts her 8:30 A.M. staff meeting. As she sorts through mail, her staff fills her in on various meetings she couldn't attend.
Opportunities await. Mrs. Battle-Bey is already dusting off old projects because they now have a better chance of getting funding. There's now plenty of real estate to be developed, she reminds grimly: at the intersection of Vernon and Central, four corners of prime space, leveled in the riot, are available.
And there's more money chasing these projects. "It takes a crisis and newsworthy attention," Mrs. Battle-Bey said. "Now, we can put all the things together that we couldn't get done in the last 10 years, when there was no money. Everybody wants to be involved in this crisis intervention and resolution. We'll try to be as selective as possible, do our own stuff, let the dust settle."
Like many nonprofit workers, Mrs. Battle-Bey and her staff are accustomed to throwing around acronyms and abbreviations: today's agenda includes mentions of S.B.A. (Small Business Administration), FEMA (Federal Emergency Management Agency) and C.C.E.D.A. (California Community Economic Development Association). So far, they aren't encouraged by the data on loans and disaster assistance. "Sounds like folks have a couple of things to jump through to get money," Mrs. Battle-Bey said. "We'll get more information tomorrow at the Mayor's Office, and I'll report back on what's happening at Rebuild L.A.," a project headed by Peter Ueberroth that will parcel out private contributions, mainly from corporations.
Richard McNish of the Community Redevelopment Agency drops in unannounced, eager to report that Vermont Slauson is apparently on a list of five agencies that Washington will endow with a portion of some $12 million in direct equity financing. "This is the best money in the United States," he says. "It's liquid money in the bank. It doesn't go through the city."
After Mr. McNish leaves, the group discusses setting up open-air farmers' markets for street vendors and conducting small focus groups. But Mrs. Battle-Bey exhorts her employees: "I don't want you to think about what our response should be. I want you to think about what the need is and how we can address that need. We can fund much of this ourselves. We're not going to sit around and wait for little pots of money. If they come, great. We'll do our programs regardless. We still have proposals on the table for funding -- like our $2.5 million entrepreneurial plastics manufacturing company that actually produces products and provides long-term jobs."
Mrs. Battle-Bey still has to conduct continuing business, including her weekly confab at the construction site at Central Avenue and 40th Place, 20 almost-finished units of affordable housing. En route, Mrs. Battle-Bey surveys the scarred landscape and complains, "I can't find doughnuts anywhere."
Vermont Slauson owns this building, so she's responsible for riding herd on construction quality and costs. In a trailer cramped with five construction supervisors and an architect, she selects the colors for the oak doors, the table in the laundry room and the child-safe height of the roof railing. One supervisor reports that as soon as they finished painting the outside walls, graffiti vandals sprayed them right through the fence. Mrs. Battle-Bey instructs him to clean it up right away or more will follow and happily pockets two sugary crullers as she leaves.
After picking up a bean-cheese-avocado burrito and a large lemonade at a Mexican food stand across the street, Mrs. Battle-Bey takes a damage tour along Vernon and Broadway. Flea markets, or "swap meets," were targeted not only because looters wanted goods, especially clothing. They might also have been targeted, she says, because of anger at Koreans who ran the markets but would not let other vendors participate. Many gas-station markets were hit. And one burned-out bank was community owned.
The problems in Los Angeles "have been building for the last 10, 15 years," she says. "It's a whole different kind of inner city than it was after the Watts riots, with more ethnic diversity, and some communities in transition. The trouble isn't over yet."

HEADLINE: History Has Questions for Gorbachev;
What Does He Know and When Will We Know It?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN SESTANOVICH; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Russian and Eurasian studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV, it used to be said, plays a weak hand brilliantly, and this talent was never more in evidence than during his just concluded two-week tour of the United States. Mr. Gorbachev is out of office, on a meager pension, and is hounded back home by charges about his role in this or that abuse of power. Yet he got Americans to treat him like a head of state, promise him millions, and confine the conversation to such tame questions as who started the cold war (no one was going to blame him, after all), how to reorganize the United Nations, and how to deal with global environmental pollution. The man at the center of the most important political revolution of our time came and went without providing a single new revelation, not one sharp insight or telling detail, about what happened.
For Russians, this result will come as no surprise. Radio Moscow recently expressed doubt that Mr. Gorbachev had anything "new, practical, interesting or unexpected" to say to foreign listeners. His ability to grow rich while saying nothing will be especially galling to those former Soviet officials, high and low, who -- whether as consultants to Western corporations or as participants in oral history projects -- are trying to sell what little they know about the system for a few measly dollars. Even Pravda, now the voice of reaction, grumbled that when he gets home Mr. Gorbachev ought to tell his own people the truth about such episodes as the crackdown in the Baltic states in January 1991.
 
A Thin Account
 Mr. Gorbachev sometimes avoids pointed questions by saying that he has to save his best material for his memoirs, now nearly finished. He said the same thing last fall while preparing his book, "The August Coup," and it is worth remembering how thin and insubstantial a recounting that turned out to be. American publishers seem to remember; they have reportedly balked at the sums Mr. Gorbachev is asking, realizing that for all that he has said and written in the past ("master of the 40-minute sound bite," someone once said), he has left us with a long list of questions about perestroika and only the most fragmentary answers. 
 A publisher who wants the real story of how reform became a revolution probably needs to begin with just such a list of questions, pressing the last leader of Soviet Communism to do what he has never done: detail his relationship with party conservatives, how he maneuvered around them when he could, mollified them when he had to and joined them when it served his interest.
The question that led Pravda's list would be as good a place as any to start. How did last year's crackdown in the Baltic states come about? It is possible that Mr. Gorbachev simply wanted to restrain the Lithuanian and Latvian separatist movements a little, had no idea that local commanders would conduct the operation in such a brutal manner and pulled back when he saw bloodshed. Possible. Yet some hard-line supporters of the crackdown subsequently asserted that Mr. Gorbachev had actually promised them he would suspend the Baltic parliaments and impose "presidential rule."
What did he tell them -- and what did he plan to do next? Russian democrats insist that the crackdown was meant to be the first step toward closing down their own newly elected government as well. This is hardly wild speculation; once the Baltic offensive failed, Mr. Gorbachev started up a campaign to impeach Boris N. Yeltsin as chairman of the Russian parliament.
Here again, it is conceivable that the drive against Mr. Yeltsin was authored by hard-liners in the Russian Communist Party. Yet one former member of the party's Politburo recently denied this, saying Mr. Gorbachev himself kept badgering them to seek Mr. Yeltsin's impeachment. Had this effort succeeded, the effect on future events would have been incalculable. The conservative old guard might not have had to launch a coup against Mr. Gorbachev in August. He would already have become their prisoner.
To push Mr. Gorbachev to be candid is not, of course, to focus exclusively on the shameful episodes of perestroika. We also know too little about his finer moments, like the East European revolutions of late 1989, which earlier Soviet leaders would obviously have tried to crush. Was there a debate within the leadership about how to deal with the sudden collapse of their "fraternal" allies, or not? The usual Kremlinological tea-leaf reading suggests that there wasn't, and Yegor K. Ligachev, at the time the leading conservative critic of perestroika, has said there was no interventionist faction pushing Mr. Gorbachev to do the wrong thing.
Is Mr. Ligachev telling the truth? And, if he is, what explains the hard-liners' moderation? Were they restrained because they could not stomach a blood bath, or because Mr. Gorbachev, who had by 1989 abolished regular Politburo meetings, managed to keep the issue from being discussed? Or was it that he managed to reassure those who were unhappy with where things were heading -- perhaps promising the military that he would never pull Soviet forces out of Germany? Answers to these questions can help us understand what we now only guess at: the finality with which the Soviet establishment accepted the loss of empire.
The collapse of Soviet control in Eastern Europe was followed almost immediately by a collapse on the home front. In February 1990 the leadership of the Communist Party agreed, at Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion, to surrender its constitutional guarantee of a monopoly on political power. Conservatives first made a furious show of opposing this idea at a special Central Committee meeting. Then, with only a handful of "no's" and abstentions, they meekly voted to accept a multi-party system.
How did Mr. Gorbachev pull this off? Can such an astounding result really be explained by the party tradition of deferring to the leader -- that is, by Stalinist means in the service of anti-Stalinist ends? Or did Mr. Gorbachev persuade conservatives to go along with his plan by promising them that he would not implement the new law? (And in fact, he did not.)
Neutralizing potential opposition from the military was as important as any other part of Mr. Gorbachev's effort to move conservatives to accept reform. His "new thinking" was an attempt to demilitarize Soviet foreign policy, and both the political and economic reforms he embraced were clearly intended to undermine the power of the entire military-industrial complex. But results were another matter. In the late summer of 1990, when he seemed on the verge of accepting the controversial "500 days" economic reform plan, the loudest objections were from the defense industry. When he left office at the end of 1991 the debilitating drain of resources into military spending had barely been slowed.
The failure to make a sustained and effective attack on military spending is especially puzzling, because few things that Mr. Gorbachev could have done would have so greatly improved his chances of success. What happened? Did he fail to understand how important the problem was, understand but not know what to do, fight but fail to get his way, or choose not to fight at all, because the generals -- and the "generals" of industry -- were just too powerful to take on? An honest account of this matter would not only explain the balance of political power in the system over which Mr. Gorbachev presided. It would tell us much about institutions that are still part of the system over which Mr. Yeltsin presides.
What would move Mr. Gorbachev to tell the story of perestroika as only he knows it? For the kind of book described here, publishers would surely be willing to pay far more than they would for bombast and evasions, which they may expect of him. Yet in the end, money may not be enough of a lever. (His recent fund-raising success has seen to that.) Before he writes memoirs worthy of his amazing career, Mr. Gorbachev will have to make a larger choice: He has to abandon hope of a political comeback and rest his claim to greatness on what he has already accomplished. The final chapter of the book he is writing suggests that he has chosen differently. Its title (which he divulges with a grin): "Everything Is Still Ahead."
