HEADLINE: Cuban Journal: Havana and Beyond

BYLINE: By MARY MORRIS; Mary Morris is the author of "Wall to Wall: From Beijing to Berlin by Rail," forthcoming in paperback from Penquin.

 BODY:
As the taxi speeds, we pass the crumbling arches of the colonial houses that line the Malecon. Rubble lies in front of some. Others with no roofs or upper floors are held up by makeshift scaffolding. The frames of windows stand empty, open to the sky. On the lower floors, beneath the collapsed roofs, laundry hangs drying. A rooster struts on a Baroque balcony. Designed in 1857 by the Cuban engineer Gen. Franciso de Albear, the Malecon was at one time prime real estate - the seafront drive of Havanna. These formerly glorious houses were the dwellings of the privileged. Now as many as 10 families live in a single building among the ruins.
 The fading crimson, sun-drenched yellow and cobalt blue facades provide the hint of a playful past, but now they look as if they haven't been painted since the dictator Fulgencio Batista fled in 1959. Later we learn that they are painted, but Cuba can't get seaworthy paint to protect the Malecon from ocean sprays. This doesn't explain the rubble, the ancient scaffolding. It's not clear whether things are being restored or just propped up.
 Our car stops for a light (all the cars that don't carry tourists go through the light), and I gasp as a boy dives off the sea wall for his afternoon swim. Young men stroll, clasping the hands of their girlfriends who walk above them, along the sea wall, in what seems to be a courtship ritual, Havanna-style. Other people - almost exclusively young men - sit alone, facing the sea, looking north toward Florida. They appear as if they have nothing to do.
 As we begin to drive again, the last light of day catches the Malecon. For an instant the facades become a burst of color and you can see a splendor that was.
 IN 1962, I CLUTCHED A FRIEND'S HAND AS WE listened to John F. Kennedy call Castro's "bluff". Uncomprehending, we stared at my father who sat shaking his head. "What is it?" we asked. "Are we going to war?" "I'm not sure," he muttered. "I just don't know." Thus a curtain fell on an island to which one's parents sneaked away for a long weekend of gambling and frolic. America's playground, Cuba was called, a mere 90 miles from Key West, Fla. Now, flying down from Canada for a week's visit, it was to me a land cloaked in mystery, tinged with romance and rage.
At the bar of Havana's Hotel Inglaterra, where we are staying, black men in white linen suits with red ties, probably Jamaicans, are hunched over, doing business. My journalist husband and I have left our somewhat Spartan room, with its small balcony overlooking the Parque Central, to sip our first smooth rum drinks. A lone singer plays the maracas. Two little girls in yellow crinoline, hair braided, race to the adjoining dining room, recently refurbished to its former elegance of wrought iron and tile. Silverware clinks as waiters, who all seem to be named Ernesto or Fidel, serve grilled shrimp and sliced mangoes to German, French and Hispanic tourists, the majority of whom have that listless look that comes with the packaged tour. Cubans themselves almost never eat shellfish or swordfish, though their seas are rich in them. Highly valuable seafood is exported and the money goes to buy baby formula, among other things.
We pay for our drinks in dollars, just as we paid for our taxi ride. One can actually travel throughout Cuba and never need to change money, except perhaps to buy a newspaper or ride a bus. Faced with the loss of Soviet aid and the dire need for hard currency, Cuba has turned to tourism. And everything in the tourist economy is done in hard currency. Meanwhile, we are told over and over again, it is forbidden for Cubans to own dollars or even to enter the stores that carry the items that dollars will buy.

AS WE VENTURE OUT, IT IS dark and a different reality greets us. Boys beg for Chiclets and pens, "Please for school; we have nothing to write with." When I part with my lone Bic, the boy races off without a word. At a counter to the left of the hotel where tourists dine, a long line forms. People lean against a wall, arms folded, resignation in their eyes. They are waiting for "pizza," thick dough with a glop of cheese and some sauce on it, which is what their pesos will buy. Grease oozes through the paper wrappers; no one seems eager to eat.
Crossing the Prado, we head through the Parque Central and up Empedrado Street. A stray dog wanders into the road, without peril. Even on this main drag there are virtually no cars because gasoline is very scarce.
We enter the maze of streets of Old Havana, lighted by occasional street lights, but guards -- either regular police or the local Committee of the Defense of the Revolution -- are everywhere. We feel safe, but also ill at ease. We gaze into rooms where men stare at bargain-basement television sets that offer generic soap operas or predigested news.
The streets themselves are oddly devoid of life. There are no shops, no grocery stores. No restaurants or places to eat. Nowhere to go except where we are going, the Bodeguita del Medio (literally little grocery store in the middle). Hemingway had a phrase about this restaurant that has been immortalized on a plaque in the bar, "My daiquiri in the Floridita, my mojito in the Bodeguita." Here we dine on rice and beans (the best I've ever had), excellent roast chicken, fried plantains and, of course, those rum mint juleps known as mojitos. We are serenaded by state-paid troubadours who sing Latin love songs. During our trip all we will hear are love songs.

CALLE OBISPO RUNS from the Plaza de Armas to the Floridita bar. In the morning, the darkness and mystery of Old Havana lift, and the ubiquitous lines form. Cubans, ration books in hand, stand in line for about 5 eggs a week, a chicken every 10 days, a liter of milk a day if they have small children. The lines seem to move faster than they do in Russia, and the Cubans are jovial. They talk as they wait, often of the shortages. One toothless old woman walks away, shaking her head. No potatoes that day, but her shopping bag is full of oranges and bananas.
We stop at a cigar factory to buy some cigars, and learn that we can take a tour of the state-of-the-art facility. The workers, we are told, work eight hours a day, get six months paid maternity leave, lifetime guaranteed employment and a full pension after the age of 55, if they so choose. I ask a woman who must be close to 60 how long she has worked (23 years in the factory) and how long she plans to continue. She dances a rumba for me in her seat, "As long as I'm moving," she says. Her job is to put the little bands around the cigars.
After a visit to the Museum of the Revolution, which occupies the former Presidential Palace -- the exhibition begins, without irony, with Columbus -- we head to the coffee shop of the Riviera Hotel.
If I were to make a movie about Las Vegas in the 1950's, I'd film it in Havana -- at the Floridita or at the Riviera, Meyer Lansky's old casino. Havana itself is a kind of period piece, a kind of living museum. What few individually owned cars are on the streets are all preblockade -- De Sotos, Hudsons, Edsels, Chevrolets, painted iridescent gold and black or red and white, puttering along on what should be their last legs. The Riviera, too, is vintage 50's, the real thing. Now a hotel, its casinos have been turned into cabarets and a spacious lobby with starry light fixtures and a silver bank of elevators.
We order sandwiches and malteds, which are thick and smooth. Our waiter, who sees me scribbling, asks what I am doing. I tell him, which I do not tell everyone, that I am an American journalist. He then launches into a brief history of Cuban socialism and his theory of the current economic crisis. He explains that the Cubans have food, but it is bad food. Fastidious people that they are, they have no soap.
He leans over my arm. "You want to write something about Cuba, just go into a hospital," he says, "See what kind of care we really get. I don't mean the tourists who come for marrow transplants or heart surgery, but the Cubans. But don't tell anyone I told you. They'll put me in jail." We give him four bars of the Ivory soap that we were told to carry with us and he thanks us profusely.

HAT EVENING "SUENO Tropical" ("Tropical Dream") is playing near our hotel and we decide to go see it. But just as we are about to change money (the only time we try to do so), a tour arrives and we cannot get near the Inglaterra's front desk. We ask the bartender if she will give us some change in pesos, because we want to go to the movie. She has seen it, and says it is very funny, but she cannot give us change in pesos. Instead, she hands us a napkin enclosing a three-peso note (worth about $3.75). "I am not changing the money," she tells us emphatically. "This is a gift from me." We leave her a $5 tip.
The movie, made in Cuba, is, to our surprise, a spoof on gender relations -- an abusive husband dreams his wife goes off to work every day while he stays home with the baby. The film opens with a pregnant woman giving a man her seat on a bus. The theater is packed, and the Cubans never stop laughing.
After much difficulty and expense (Cuba does not provide incentives for the individual tourist), we rent a car and head east toward Trinidad, the old colonial city of smugglers and pirates. Along the way we pause for a visit to the Hemingway House in San Francisco de Paula. Hemingway bequeathed this house to Cuba, and it is much as he left it. Set in a grove of bamboo and palm trees, draped in bougainvillea, it feels as if Hemingway has just gone out fishing and will be back in time for his mojitos.
One of the woman guards and I strike up a conversation. She was a young girl and a neighbor when Hemingway lived there. "The last time I saw him was in the summer of 1960. He was walking through town and he was quite mad." She pauses, blushing slightly, "But he was a man, let me tell you that. He was really a man."
We head south. Bougainvillea lines the median strip. Sweet-smelling fields thick with sugar cane and plantains extend on either side. Oxen plow the fields, though this is to save gasoline. Indeed, we have the highway almost to ourselves. A few guaguas (public buses) pass. One is broken down by the side of the road. The right lane of traffic on the main freeway out of Havana is being used by bicycles (Cuba recently imported 500,000 of them from China) and hitchhikers. Pickup trucks carry workers from place to place and whenever one pulls up dozens pile on.
In the distance the cane fields are being burned. Dark smoke fills the sky. More smoke comes from the cane factories. We leave the main road and journey into the countryside, but the map grows vague. Roads are paved, but have no names. They are dotted with piglets and schoolchildren in their red-and-white uniforms (literacy of those under 30 is said to be almost 100 percent). We are lost, so we pick up our first hitchhikers -- a young couple with a baby, heading in the direction of Cruces. He speaks a Spanish I can barely comprehend, but I learn that he works in the cane factories and owns his own house. We leave them at Cruces and make our way to Cumanayagua, where the road divides. We've been driving for almost six hours when I stop an old woman for directions. She speaks for a long time, and I nod, but then I sink into the car. My husband says, "Well, which way?"
"I didn't understand a word she said." It is the low moment of the trip.
"Try again," he says.
I get out and several men come up. They gesticulate wildly, measuring turns, dips in the road. I follow their hands along imaginary roads. We drive on by the seat of our pants, past an alpine lake in a valley among mountains. There are no road signs and a mountain range is ahead of us. We are low on gas. Buzzards eating road kills take flight as we drive past. Boys gallop by on horseback, ignoring a cow that stands in the middle of the road. We pick up an old man who is going to Trinidad. He has spent the day cleaning fish, and the stench is nearly unbearable.
We deposit him in downtown Trinidad where we're told there is a hotel, but we find nothing. We head for the Ancon, the large tourist hotel on the beach, where the food is self-service and the furniture glorified Best Western. It is packed with English-speaking tourists from Montreal. The sand seems to be imported from elsewhere. We are there 10 minutes when the lights go out for the evening.
In the morning we visit old Trinidad and its magnificently refurbished Spanish colonial houses, complete with 19th-century plumbing. Then we head back across the country, toward Cuba's northern beaches. We are not far out of Trinidad when we pick up a grandmother carrying milk from her cow to her new grandson in Cienfuegos. At the crossroads to Cienfuegos she gets out. "Can somebody help these people get to Abreus?" she shouts. Three people who don't know one another, two men and a woman, all jump in. Only the woman, a nurse, is going as far as Abreus, where she tells us there is a fiesta going on.
At Abreus, we park near the main plaza, which is decorated with palm fronds; the usual music blares. Cubans slurp ice slush and sway to the music, a kind of salsa rap. In an alleyway is a broken-down carousel, its wooden horses like a child's drawing, hand-carved. We stroll down a dirt road where the houses are all primitive, in some cases with thatched roofs, but very clean and well kept. A sign in front of one reads, "Don't tie your horses here." In each home, as a kind of centerpiece, a television set, compliments of the revolution, stands.

IN THE MIDST OF MILES and miles of orange groves on the road north, we pick up a young woman with pink shoes, giant earrings and blonde hair with dark roots. She is going to Cardenas and will send us on to Varadero.
Our rider is chatty and good spirited and we begin to talk. I ask her where she lives and where she works. "I live in Cardenas, but I work where you picked me up."
"It's a long commute," I say.
"Yes, it takes two hours, each way, but there is no work in Cardenas."
"What do you do?"
"I'm a dentist. Actually I'm a cranial surgeon, but I do dentistry."
I look at this young woman in pink shoes. "You're a surgeon?" She nods. "Isn't there some easier way for you to get to work?"
She shrugs. "Oh, people know me, they pick me up. It's not so bad."
"You don't feel . . . inconvenienced?" I ask hesitantly.
"Oh, it is temporary," she says. "We have to work hard to overcome this period in our history."
"Well what do you think is going to happen here -- with Fidel."
"Oh, I hope nothing. I love Fidel," she says as if she is referring to her boyfriend. (We know, however, that one can go to jail for a long time for "insulting" Fidel and the jails, we have heard, are full.) "My country has given me my education, my work, my house. All the patients I treat are treated for free. I hope he lives 20 more years."

VARADERO IS ON A LONG narrow peninsula on Cuba's northern coast, with the sea on one side and a bay on the other, somewhat like Palm Beach, Fla., geographically speaking. But the comparison stops there. While it is a strip of fairly fancy hotels with elaborate facilities -- hotels that serve the Canadian and European tourists who come for their winter holidays, most of whom fly into Varadero and stay put -- it is peculiarly devoid of commercialism. There are the generic Intur tiendas, which sell the same rum and cigars and chocolates and shoes throughout Cuba. There are a few beach barbecues, but basically what you have in Varadero, besides a kind of funky Cuban version of Club Med, is a pristine turquoise sea and a white beach, the real thing.
I ask for a room with a view of the sea at the Punta Blanca, an older hotel, and we are given a stuffy room with no balcony, over a noisy discotheque. Knowing the language is helpful here. I return to the desk clerk, an unenthusiastic worker, and say, "We have come a long way and we are very tired, and we'd like something a little more comfortable."
So she hands me a key that opens a small house with a wraparound porch that sits at the edge of the sea. Next door is Al Capone's old guesthouse, a magnificent stone structure with French windows and wide stone arches that face the sea. It has been turned into an around-the-clock bar, and we beat a path between our house and Al Capone's.
We dine at a Creole restaurant where we see the one phrase of public social protest we will see on our entire trip. Graffitied across a poster is Fidel's revolutionary motto, "Socialismo o Muerte," revised to read "Fettucini o Muerte." We eat swordfish while the pre-paid musicians play love songs. A handsome young Cuban joins in with bongos and his lover, a European tourist with a cowbell, tries to keep up her end of the percussion. But then a drunk old man with a Hatuey beer in each fist sings some prerevolutionary decadent lyrics and the restaurant claps along.

HAT NIGHT EL NORTE blows in; the seas rise. In the morning it is cold and jellyfish line the beach. We walk, bundled up, while undaunted French tourists, bodies greased, sunbathe bare-breasted along the shore. When we return to our room, the maid has folded our towels into swans and my husband refuses to disturb them.
The next afternoon, a man who works at the hotel approaches us. "Please, I want to ask you a favor," he says. "Could you go into the tienda for me; I want to buy a pair of red shoes for my little girl." He displays dollars in his hands. Then he shows us a slip of paper, about four inches long. "That is the size of her foot," he says. "And I have another little girl." He adds two fingers to the piece of paper. "This size."
"You can't go buy them yourself? With dollars?"
He puts his fingers to his lips. "I can't even have dollars, but we all keep some of our tips, everyone does it. Can you do this? As a favor?"
It is this slip of paper cut to the size of his child's foot that wins me over. The woman who works in the tienda knows just what shoes, what size. She gives us a knowing nod as we leave.

UR LAST NIGHT IN Havana we join a group of German tourists, who keep tapping their watches, unaccustomed to Latin time, as we await the bus to take us to a cabaret. At last it pulls up. The automatic doors fling open and there, sprawled across the paunch of our aging driver are a pair of long black legs, a white skirt hiked up high to the thighs. The woman pulls down her skirt and rises with stunning indifference. "Tropicana," she says, shuffling into her tour director's seat.
The Tropicana has been in continuous operation since 1939. Neither war nor revolution has changed it or stopped it. Arriving, we file past a fountain with statues of nude nymphets dangling bunches of grapes. Mirrors are everywhere. For several hours the rum flows at $5 a shot and the girls, dressed in G-strings and spangles, kick and writhe and gyrate. The audience of former Eastern bloc and future European community members offers perfunctory applause and after the 25-minute finale files out despondently.
We return to the bus where our tour director in her white skirt sits smoking a cigarette. The driver drives so slowly that the Afro-Cuban dolls on his dash barely budge.
We cruise the Malecon at a snail's pace. The sea calm, the moon full, it is cast in blue like an opera set. Inside the dark stairwells of what appear to be abandoned buildings lights flicker. Two people embrace. I peer up toward the collapsed roofs and missing top floors and there, through the empty window frames, I see the stars.
 
SOME WORDS OF CAUTION

The Cuban tourist industry is designed to keep you on the tourist trail. If you follow it, Cuba will appear more or less like any other place. But if you deviate or scratch the surface, you may see that all is not as it might appear.
One morning before breakfast I placed two phone calls -- one to our daughter in Florida, the other to a former close associate of Fidel Castro's, in Havana, whose number had been given to me. The calls were put through without any difficulty, though the operator made an audible gulp when I said "Florida." Afterward, my husband and I went for a morning stroll along the Prado, stopping for a cup of coffee. Then we returned to our room to leave our sweaters.
We came upon the maid in the vestibule in front of our room. She stared at us, wide-eyed. The door was open, and another maid stood in the doorway. "Good morning," we said. They didn't say anything, which is unusual in Cuba. We walked in to find a man with a razor blade in one hand and a pencil in the other. With the pencil, he was literally tapping the phone.
"Is something the matter?" I asked.
The man looked up, startled but smiling. "Inventory," he said. He had a computer printout with him, and some small silver tags.
"Oh," I smiled. My husband stared at me, lips pursed. The man and the two maids quickly left the room.
Later, over lunch, when we mentioned to the former Castro associate that we suspected that our phone might be tapped, she just nodded. "Probably," she said. Never discuss money on the phone, she told us. Or anything of substance. Certainly not politics or whom we might be seeing.
On another occasion we met an Ethiopian man with a Canadian passport who was traveling with two white Canadian friends. He told us, "Everywhere I go I am stopped; they pull me over and say, 'What are you doing with tourists?' I tell them that I am a tourist. When they see my passport, they let me go." MARY MORRIS
 
RULES AND REGULATIONS

Although Cuba is constructing new hotels, often as joint ventures with European hotel companies, few Americans are signing the guest registers. Under sanctions imposed by the United States Government, American citizens, while technically free to travel to Cuba, are prohibited from spending any money there unless they are journalists, scholars or Cuban-Americans visiting family members who live on the island. These regulations are backed up by penalties of up to 12 years in prison and $250,000 in fines, although to date no individual traveler has been penalized.
Some back doors are open, however. SUN HOLIDAY TOURS, Post Office Box 531, Montego Bay, St. James, Jamaica (telephone: 809-952-5629), offers day trips from Montego Bay for $177 a person. The excursions depart every Wednesday, and the price includes round-trip air fare, in-flight snacks, an airport reception and transportation to, and a city tour of, Santiago de Cuba. And, for those who wish to bend the rules, package trips to Cuba can be booked through Canadian travel agencies. Some typical prices for seven-night packages offered by AIR CANADA VACATIONS, the major purveyor of such trips, range from about $350 a person, including air fare between Montreal and Varadero Beach and accommodations in a standard beachfront hotel, such as the Punta Blanca, to about $590 a person for air fare and a suite in the new Melia Varadero Hotel. Meal packages (breakfast and dinner daily) are an additional $119 a person, and service charges add another $109 each. Day trips to Havana can be arranged.
A recorded advisory concerning travel to Cuba (and many other countries) is available from the State Department: 202-647-5225.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 692 words

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Toward an Even Playing Field for All

BYLINE: By FAY VINCENT; Fay Vincent is the commissioner of Major League Baseball.

 BODY:
On Saturday, May 2, at Comiskey Park in Chicago, the White Sox honored some 25 former Negro League baseball players who, because of the accident of birth, were never able to play in the major leagues. The irony, of course, is that while these aged but quietly dignified men were standing on the field to receive long overdue recognition, the rest of the country was wondering whether the rioting in Los Angeles would spread to other cities. The tribute in Chicago had been planned months in advance, and therefore there was a poignancy, in some sense awful, to what was taking place at the ball park. 
 Before the ball game, the old-time ballplayers came out on the field and mingled with the rest of us around the batting cage as the White Sox players and the Texas Rangers went through the customary pregame drills. I sat in a golf cart, and soon Jimmy Crutchfield came over and sat with me. Crutchfield, 82 years old, is widely considered to have been one of the finest outfielders ever to play in the Negro Leagues. One of the reporters asked him what this day meant to him, and the old gentleman was so moved by the effort to express his feelings that tears came to his eyes and he was briefly speechless.
 
The Proudest Achievement
 We chatted about his career and some of his great moments in baseball. At one point he reached for his wallet and took out a faded clipping. The article from a 1930 Chicago newspaper described the East-West All-Star Game. Proudly he pointed me to a paragraph that described a catch he had made as "one of the greatest catches in baseball history." And then came a moment I will never forget.
"Jimmy," I asked, "what are you proudest of?"
"Commissioner, the thing I'm proudest of and what I tell my wife all the time is that I never hated anyone," he said.
The statement was so simple, so stark, I had to pursue it.
"Look, Commissioner," he said, "we never talked about the system. We grew up in it. We never knew anything different. We knew we couldn't change it and we never thought it would change. In the fall we would play the white guys and they couldn't change the system either. It wasn't our fault and it wasn't their fault. The fact is we just never talked about it."
And so the ceremony went on. Crutchfield and the others took their bows and I was left to think about what Jimmy had said.
While other cities were on alert and Los Angeles was burning, Jimmy Crutchfield was proud to tell me, "I never hated anyone."
 
Contributions Overlooked
 In fact, the Negro League players I have come to know have expressed little bitterness at their treatment by Major League Baseball. Still, their contribution to baseball and to our society has been largely ignored. For decades, they kept baseball alive in the black community, and they have every reason to be thanked by all of us, and especially by current black players. Major League Baseball honored 75 alumni from the Negro Leagues at Cooperstown last summer, and I took that opportunity to apologize to those wonderful gentlemen for all the indignities to which they had been subjected. Somehow my apology seemed like pretty thin soup.
But perhaps Jimmy Crutchfield's memorable statement can be our theme as baseball tries to play a tiny role in helping our country address the consequences of decades of racism. The ghetto, the parlous level of minority unemployment and the lack of opportunity for young black Americans all bear some resemblance to the problems these Negro League players faced before 1947 when Jackie Robinson was finally able to play for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Jimmy Crutchfield knew then and still knows that hatred is not a solution. Instinctively he knew, as did his fellow players, that hating could produce no useful result.
Major League Baseball, of course, has a long way to go to redeem itself by affording minorities better opportunities both on and off the field. And while baseball has a full set of its own problems, Jimmy Crutchfield might have given all of us a beginning point as we try to come together to build a more decent nation. I think Jimmy can be proud of much more than he admitted.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Commissioner Fay Vincent with Jimmy Crutchfield, right, at a recent tribute to Negro League players in Chicago. (Debra Meeks)

PUB-DATE: May 17, 1992,

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Cold Spring Harbor

BYLINE: By BRET SENFT

 BODY:
THE first inhabitants of Cold Spring Harbor were Matinecock Indians, who discovered fresh-water springs under a salt waterharbor. They called it Wawapex, "at the good little water place."
"You can actually dip your bucket in and pull up fresh water if you know the right spot," says Rufus Langhans, the Huntington Town historian. 
 The Matinecock name still holds for this small, low-key community where wealth is enjoyed but not put on display.
Laura Gutkowski, a 10-year-resident, finds such attitudes refreshing. She declines to discuss her husband, Robert, president of Madison Square Garden, or the size of her house, saying: "No, you see, that's a very un-Cold Spring Harbor thing to do."
Such aversion to pretension may be a holdover from the hard-scrabble ways of early settlers: among them, the Titus, Sammis, Roger, Jones and Hewlett families, who established farms and water-powered grist and woolen mills around the harbor in the mid to late 1700's.
In 1836, John H. and Walter R. Jones (descendants of Maj. Thomas Jones, owner of vast property from Cold Spring Harbor to Jones Beach) founded a whaling business. Their ships traveled the world until oil was discovered in Pennsylvania in the 1860's.
"Someone made kerosene in Pittsburgh, and that did us in," said Rufus Langhans, the township historian.
St. John's Episcopal Church, founded by the Jones family in 1835, still stands southwest of the hamlet in Laurel Hollow, serving 600 families. Three of its stained-glass windows were donated at the turn of the century by Louis Comfort Tiffany, a parishioner whose Laurelton Hall was on the harbor's west shore.
Through the early years of the 20th century, locally produced lumber and bricks were shipped by coastal vessels to New York City and several resort hotels flourished from 1880 until World War I. But hilly terrain and the estates of older families prevented large-scale development, and when the local industries flagged, the population shrank. With fewer people to serve, there was no need for commercial strips.
"And that was really the salvation of Cold Spring Harbor," said Ina Katz, curator of the Whaling Museum on Main Street. "I often say that it went from the 19th to the 21st century, and missed the 20th century altogether."
Stores and malls are abundant in Huntington, less than three miles away, and there has been no lack of culture. The Whaling Museum has an original whaleboat and gear, an extensive collection of scrimshaw -- tools and artwork carved from whalebone -- and a recently installed education center. In the summer, it conducts walking tours. The Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities has rotating exhibitions in its gallery.
The renowned Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, which has a hamlet mailing address but is actually just across the border in Nassau County, has 40 buildings on 95 acres on the harbor's west shore; its DNA Learning Center (on Main Street east of the village) provides a hands-on laboratory for schoolchildren, an exhibit on DNA, and genetics education programs used in the school.
ACROSS North Hempstead Turnpike from the laboratory is the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery and Aquarium, with its hatch house, trout and turtle ponds and two aquarium buildings with the state's largest collection of native freshwater fish, reptiles and amphibians. The Nature Conservancy, a conservation group, has its Long Island chapter at the 93-acre Uplands Farm Sanctuary on Lawrence Hill Road; nearby is its 14-acre St. John's Pond preserve, open to hikers and birders.
The housing stock is diverse, with smaller lots close to downtown and larger Cape Cods, colonials and ranches on two-acre lots north of Main Street.
"But you really can't define the area in one way," said Pat Fratto of Sammis Real Estate. Houses on Titus Lane to the north, she said, may include "a mint colonial on two-acres ($600,000-$700,000), next to a two-bedroom cottage on three acres ($330,000), next to a five-bedroom Victorian new construction (sold four years ago for $1.1 million)."
A four-bedroom colonial on two acres is generally $500,000 to $700,000, "but it varies with this economy," said Susan Ferris of the Daniel Gale Agency. "I'd say prices have come down 20 to 30 percent. But they're on the rise."
Of the three restaurants, Wyland's Country Kitchen and the Cold Spring Harbor Inn, both on Main Street, are open only for breakfast and lunch. The Inn on the Harbor, on Harbor Road, is open until 11:30 P.M. and serves northern Italian fare and seafood.
Richard and Sandra Brehl, 20-year residents, raised six children in a six-bedroom ranch house overlooking Main Street, whose 50 shops sell mostly gifts, crafts, artwork, quilts and bedding.
"I do miss the pharmacy, the bank, the bookstore," said Mrs. Brehl, "but we came here for the school district. All the kids got an excellent education."
The school district includes Lloyd Harbor to the north and Laurel Hollow to the west (into Nassau County) and a northern section of Huntington. There are 1,400 students in two elementary schools (in Lloyd Harbor and Laurel Hollow) and the Cold Spring Harbor High School, which is in the hamlet and houses the junior high school as well.
At the elementary level, whole learning programs emphasize language arts, writing and literature. Science classes enjoy collaborative programs with the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.
The high school has advanced-placement programs, a speech/debate team, a strong foreign language and student exchange program with Russia, Spain, France and Japan, a newspaper and a publication drawn from electronic mail linked to high schools around the world.
SEVENTY percent of the students take part in the sports program, which is "always strong" in soccer and lacrosse, said District Superintendent Francis Roberts.
The district's tax rate, he noted, is the third lowest in western Suffolk and eighth lowest in Nassau. To keep it low, parents raise funds when necessary -- for a computer writing lab, a new boat for the crew team, an art gallery in the high school.
Judi Porpora, president of the Central Parent Council, her husband, Steven, and their two children live in a five-bedroom colonial on Shore Road overlooking the harbor. Mr. Porpora, a stockbroker, is president of the Eagle Dock Beach Foundation, which owns and maintains the nearby beach for resident use. Membership and mooring rights are $125 a season.
Besides 50 slips at the private Whaler's Cove Marina, there are perhaps 200 moorings in the harbor. "We don't have a lot of water here," said Aaron Westergaard of H & M Powles Marine Agency, a fishing station at the head of the harbor.
The fishing station's main building, including a clam bar, burned in 1988 and was scheduled to be demolished last Friday. Residents and town officials disagree on its future. A new structure is to go up next spring "as a concession and not as a longterm lease," said Pat Reiss, a town spokesperson. Local residents sugggest a contextural building leased to Mr. Westergard, a close relative of the late Powles brothers.
"It's common sense to stay with a known entity," said Thorndike Williams, a local architect fighting to save Powles.
Farther north on Shore Road is the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, founded in 1921 by old-money families, including Walter Jennings, co-founder of the company that became Mobil Oil.
"I applaud the club's efforts to keep it spartan and understated," said Mr. Porpora, himself a member with his family.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Main Street in Cold Spring Harbor, with its aura of the past. (Eddie Hausner for The New York Times)

Distance from midtown Manhattan: 34 miles.
 
Rush-hour commutation to midtown: 54 minutes by Long Island Rail Road; $7.75 one-way, $163 monthly.
 
Codes: Zip, 11724; area 516.
 
Government: Huntington Town Supervisor (Stephen C. Ferraro, Democrat) and four council members, all elected to four-year terms.
 
Where's the Sign?: Billy Joel did an album called "Cold Spring Harbor" but never lived in the community. Yet last July a patch of green overlooking the harbor on Main Street was dedicated and named Billy Joel Park. Within hours, its handmade sign was gone. An overzealous fan? Maybe. But naming the park fell to the town, which owns the land -- a sore point with residents who wanted a say in the matter. "The park could have been named after a lot of other things -- for ships, or people who really helped the community," said Lee DeMartino, a lifelong resident. "Believe me, that sign is probably hidden somewhere right here in Cold Spring Harbor."

HEADLINE: Americas Approve Forceful Steps To Restore Ousted Haitian Leader

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 17

 BODY:
Foreign ministers of the Organization of American States met here today and approved strong new measures aimed at restoring Haiti's elected President, including a denial of port rights to any ship that delivers goods to Haiti.
The renewed effort to isolate Haiti's military-backed Government and reinstate the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was ousted in an army coup last September, is built around a trade embargo adopted in October by the organization's 37 members. All the nations in the Western Hemisphere except Cuba are represented. 
 The sanctions have crippled Haiti's economy, but the coup leaders have resisted any compromise that would restore Father Aristide to power. Haiti has survived largely on fuel and other goods from Western Europe and European-controlled Caribbean islands.
Under the new measures, ships that do business with Haiti will be banned from all member nations, and visas will be denied to supporters of the coup. The foreign ministers will also ask the European Community to refrain from trading with Haiti.
Even as they approved measures that could completely shut down Haiti's economy, diplomats acknowledged the risk of accelerating the desperate exodus of Haitian refugees aboard rickety boats. To alleviate the misery, the foreign ministers also called for more humanitarian assistance to Haiti.
"This is a constant concern," said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who is leading the United States delegation here. "We are on the horns of a dilemma. Once you tighten the embargo, it begins to hurt and you increase the refugees."
While the ministers considered tough new measures on Haiti, a last-minute appeal by Peru prompted them to delay discussion of retaliation against that country for the suspension of the Constitution by President Alberto K. Fujimori. His seizure of dictatorial powers on April 5 has led to a cutoff of nearly all international aid, thwarting his stated goal of reviving the economy. [Page A8.]
Mr. Fujimori flew here tonight, and diplomats said he would appear before the foreign ministers on Monday to outline new steps his Government was planning to meet international demands for a return to democratic rule.
Diplomats described the organization's pressure on Haiti and Peru as a vigorous affirmation of the organization's post-cold-war commitment to democracy. Before the coup in Haiti and Mr. Fujimori's seizure of dictatorial powers, many of the envoys contend, all of the hemisphere's countries except Cuba had democratically elected governments.
In summarizing the tighter sanctions against Haiti, a senior United States diplomat said, "Now the people who sell goods to Haiti will have to decide whether it is worth it or not." But he acknowledged that the embargo had done little so far to restore democracy in Haiti.
Rep. Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who has been a strong critic of United States policy toward Haiti and who attended the meeting as an observer, said of the resolutions: "It is the first time I can actually be proud of the leadership of the State Department on this issue."
But European diplomats said they saw little chance that the European Community would impose a matching trade embargo against Haiti. The envoys, attending as observers, cited their trade accords with many third-world nations.
"We have already suspended our aid and technical cooperation with Haiti since Oct. 3, and that is a lot" said Antonio Menduina, a counselor for political affairs at the community's mission to the O.A.S. in Washington. "To do more would be to denounce the Lome Treaty. We don't have the legal ability to tell our companies that they cannot trade with Haiti."
 
Possible Appeal by U.S.
 United States officials said that Canada and the United States were considering approaching the 12 members of the community, rather than the community as a whole, to ask them to tighten sanctions against Haiti.
In addition to the suspension of port privileges, the foreign ministers agreed to tighten controls on civilian air traffic with Haiti to insure that people traveling there do not engage in commerce.
United States diplomats said the Treasury Department would offer to help member countries improve their monitoring of commercial exchanges with Haiti. To satisfy several Caribbean nations whose diplomats have complained of a lax enforcement of the embargo, the resolution included a provision for regular publication of violations.
Canada, which said it would provide $5 million in urgent humanitarian aid to Haiti, proposed a strong condemnation of human rights violations in that country. It was quickly accepted by the United States and other members.
The resolution also implicitly rejected any efforts by Haiti's current leaders to try to end the political crisis without acknowledging Father Aristide's presidency and allowing him to choose a new prime minister.
"This resolution shows an effort to raise the pressure significantly and close the loopholes," said Luigi R. Einaudi, the United States Ambassador to the O.A.S. "It is saying very clearly that we are not going to simply forgive and forget."
Father Aristide's representative expressed pleasure with the resolution but emphasized that its provisions must be strictly enforced.
"The resolution is a beautiful one, as everyone can see," said Juan-Robert Sabbalat, Haiti's foreign minister in exile. "But all the other resolutions have been beautiful, too. The Haitian people have been suffering for eight months now. Pretty words are nice, but we must await their application."
The exodus from Haiti has swelled in recent weeks, with the United States Coast Guard intercepting an average of 250 refugees a day at sea. At least 29,000 Haitians have tried to reach the United States by boat since Father Aristide was overthrown.
 
Haiti as Example to Peru
 As the ministers awaited President Fujimori, several diplomats expressed some optimism that he and other Peruvian leaders were seeking to avoid the isolation that has befallen Haiti by moving quickly toward a restoration of democratic government.
Mr. Eagleburger, the United States delegate, said the Peruvian President was expected to make "proposals with regard to a constituent congress and referendum" that might satisfy the organization's demands for the return of democracy.
"It suggests he takes this all seriously enough that he is coming to explain where he is going and where he wants to go," Mr. Eagleburger said.
One senior United States official commented, "If they are moving away from a rigid position toward something that seems to be moving toward democracy, we would see that as positive. But we still must wait and see."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS
A Dream Undone -- A special report.;
Riots Ruin a Business, and a Neighborhood Suffers

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS with MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 17

 BODY:
It took Wenefrette Conner a week to gather the courage to visit her burned-out businesses, and even then, gripping the hands of her daughter and business partner, she said, "I didn't know it was going to hurt so much."
Collapsed now into their own ashes, her chiropractic and skin-care clinics represented more than a decade of personal struggle and a climb into what Mrs. Conner thought was economic security. And, along with scores of other small black-owned businesses destroyed in the recent riots, the clinics symbolized the efforts of black residents to build an economic base in an area filled with poverty. 
 About 1,600 businesses were severely damaged in the rioting, most of them here in South-Central Los Angeles. City officials have estimated the losses at nearly $800 million. A large proportion were Korean-owned, as rioters vented years of frustration and anger against a group that many blacks said was exploiting their poverty. But many were small black-owned businesses, consumed, like Mrs. Conner's clinics, by flames that spread from their Korean-owned neighbors, or made targets precisely because they signaled success in a community of have-nots.
In the days after the fires, a succession of mourners crept under the yellow police tape to take a final look at Mrs. Conner's clinics and their blackened neighbors on Crenshaw Boulevard near Leimert Park: the bookkeeper from the chiropractic clinic, the manager of the skin-care shop, the proprietors of surviving businesses from around the corner, an old customer hoping in vain to find and comfort an owner.
Fifteen of Mrs. Conner's employees are out of jobs today, and, for the most part, on the unemployment rolls. A network of suppliers that furnished everything from stationery to herbal drinks has lost a steady income. A corner of the city has lost the daily trade of Mrs. Conner's workers. The ripples go on and on.
"Everything is like a jigsaw puzzle: you get one missing part and it's not complete," said Richard Fulton, the owner of Fifth Street Dick's, a tiny coffee shop around the corner. "You're all tied together anyway. You hurt no matter if you never knew them. You hurt just because they disappear."
Here is the story of one of those missing parts:
 
The Owners
2 Novices Became Models of Success
 Sixteen years ago, two single working mothers -- Mrs. Conner and her daughter -- determined to make something of themselves and enrolled in a course to become chiropractors. In 1980 they gathered about $5,000 from friends and opened Family Chiropractic Services, painting its walls pink and furnishing it with a small jungle of plants and a quiet background of jazz.
"It took a lot of guts, a lot of guts," said Mrs. Conner's daughter, Priscilla Feldsher, who is now 35 years old. "Not being businesswomen at the time, we learned by trial and error. We were taken advantage of, and we made mistakes, but we were determined to make it."
Working without bank financing, she said, they plowed their profits back into their business, buying more equipment, hiring more employees and expanding in 1984 to open M.F.I. Skin Care Clinic next door.
Only weeks before the riot, Mrs. Feldsher said, they paid nearly $2,000 to a designer to prepare a floor plan that would have combined the two clinics and expanded the treatment rooms. They had installed new lighting and were making other renovations.
And the two clinics had grown into a considerable economic enterprise. The monthly payroll was approaching $20,000, on top of a combined rent of more than $4,000, Mrs. Feldsher said. Some $500 to $800 a month went to cover utility and telephone bills, an alarm system and petty cash payments.
The two women had developed a steady clientele in addition to their walk-in trade. For competitive reasons, Mrs. Feldsher said, she did not want to disclose her clinics' earnings. But she said she was turning a modest profit based on a standard rate of $55 for a top-of-the-line treatment session in either outlet.
 
Praise for Koreans
 As working women, she said, she and her mother, now 57 years old, can serve as models of determination and success. But with black businesses attempting to rebuild in South-Central Los Angeles, she said, the best models are the local Korean enterprises.
"The Koreans have a different type of community," she said. "They help each other. They lend to each other. We aren't a good example because we had to do everything ourselves. No banks financed us. No relatives financed us."
Surveying the cinders of her businesses, she noted another aspect in which she offered a poor role model: like many other black-owned shops in the area, she had no insurance. "That was something that we just never thought of," she said. "When we started, we had nothing to insure. So here we are, left with what we started with."
Starting over again, she and her mother stood in line for three hours last Friday to apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration. Most of their financial records were destroyed in the fire, and they are not sure how much help they will get.
"My mother has grandchildren she is raising, and I've got my children, so it's going to be a tough battle," Mrs. Feldsher said. "But we're determined to make it."
 
The Employees
Bereft of Paycheck And Second Home
 Nellie Torrecillas, 42, had been the office administrator of the chiropractic clinic almost since it opened, and as with so many employees in so many businesses, it had become much more than a workplace for her.
"It was like a home for me," she said as she picked her way through the ashes and charred beams of the clinic. "Sometimes I was sick and people would say to stay home, and I would come to work because this was my home."
On a salary that rose to almost $400 a week after taxes, she said, she had been supporting four relatives in her homeland of Mexico while sharing an apartment here with the clinic's secretary, Maria Perez, 26, and Ms. Perez's 2-year-old son, Steven.
This week, the two women were working on the basis of loyalty alone, digging through charred and sodden files without pay in an attempt to make an accounting.
Soon, Miss Torrecillas said, they would no longer be able to pay their rent. "I'm not going to be homeless, I hope, because my sister always says I can come and live with her," she said.
Like other employees bereft of their workplace here, she said she had little hope of finding another job. "There's nothing to go look for," she said. "Am I supposed to go to Beverly Hills to look for a job?"
 
Happy Memories
 Exploring the remains of the clinic, Miss Torrecillas crouched to look under what seemed to be a melted metal desk in the vain hope that a set of cassettes with a course in mechanics had survived the flames. "They cost me $500, and I've still got to pay for them," she said. "I have to keep on paying $59 a month, and I have no paycheck now."
At this moment, though, amid the shambles of her life, the future seemed to have less impact on her than the past.
"I remember the first day I came over here and I was so happy that they hired me," she said. "I thought, 'Somebody is giving me a big chance. I come from the ghetto and somebody thinks I am good for something.'
"We used to have pictures on the wall here with the way we used to look, skinny," she said. "Now we look fat. We used to have pictures here of boxers, famous boxers, that came to our office to be treated, and where are they? Not even the wall is here any more."
 
Pitiful Artifacts
 Ms. Perez, the secretary, had considered herself a happy person, supporting herself and her son on take-home pay of $511 every two weeks in a job she loved.
"They destroyed a lot of people's lives, like myself," she said of the rioters. "They destroyed my career. I don't have a job. I've got to give my son an education and at the same time I've got to start all over again myself."
Without prospects for a paycheck, she has already had to take her son out of the Crenshaw Academy preschool nearby.
Next door at the skin-care shop, the manager, Darryl Conner, 32, who is also Mrs. Conner's son, attempted to salvage something from the ashes. He recovered one or two bottles of face cleanser, some plastic caps used during facial treatments and a quarter of a bottle of alcohol.
"That's it," he said, holding up his trophies in a single paper bag. "Everything else is gone: steam machines, hair-removal machines, high-frequency machines, ultraviolet machines, skin-care products, not to mention furniture."
As for himself, he said, he had lost a salary of about $500 a week, in exchange for an empty future. "I'm laying low. I have to just wait for the next day to come, because all I know how to do is skin care."
 
The Suppliers
Big Network Feels Damage to Clinics
 No one on the staff knew his full name, but the delivery man for United Parcel Service was almost a member of the family, visiting nearly every day with supplies for the two businesses.
"He told me this was his area, Crenshaw, and now just about everything is burned down," said Miss Torrecillas. "I bet you he doesn't have any job now, because what is he going to deliver?"
Before the riots, he would bring more than $200 worth of materials each week from West Surgical Medical Supplies in downtown Los Angeles, including gloves and $40 rolls of paper bedding.
More than $100 of ointments, elixirs and mineral ice would come each week from a Burbank company called Professional Medical Inc. A Costa Mesa company, Dartel Laboratories, supplied vitamin supplements as well as medicine for arthritis and high blood pressure.
Arthur L. Raines, a 63-year-old black entrepreneur, was preparing to expand his business with Mrs. Conner, selling cases of a dark liquid health supplement that he imported from Canada. The concoction, containing 14 herbs, retails for $39 a bottle, and he sold it wholesale for $362.25 a case.
"We were just getting ready to do something big," he said of his deal with Mrs. Conner. "This is very painful."
 
The Winners: Builders
 On the other side of the South-Central area, on a street of burned-out buildings and angry graffiti, Inez Garrett, who had sold as much as $2,000 a month worth of supplies to Mrs. Conner, sat behind barred doors in her organic-products outlet and waited to feel the impact of the riots.
"I can't tell yet," said the 84-year-old Mrs. Garrett, surrounded by dusty flacons of herbs and potions. "I'm still sitting here with my products. I'm waiting to see which customers come in and which don't come in."
As with any small business, Mrs. Conner's shops developed a support system of workers, all of whom will now be struggling with the loss -- a janitor, a cleaning woman, a plumber, an air conditioning mechanic and the painter who periodically refurbished the front windows with their proud announcements: "Problem skin . . . treatments that work. Acne . . . look better, not different."
Rising from the ashes of the rioting, however, some black contractors were planning for a busy future as they cruised slowly by, writing shop names and telephone numbers on clipboards and on the backs of envelopes.
"Where there is destruction, there is also opportunity," said Voyer Penn, the owner of V. P. Plumbing, impressive in a tailored suit and gold chains. "I don't really want to go on people's disaster, but I might as well get a piece of it myself. I'm basically here to do the job. That's the top and bottom line."
 
The Community
Client and Friend Face an Emptiness
 At Radiant and Raw, a small black-owned barber shop just down the block that is still in business, Charles Moses, a co-owner, was already feeling the loss of his neighbors.
"On this block, all the businesses got along pretty well," he said. "We did business with each other. Now there is no place to go get snacks. We lost the skin-care center. We lost the fish market. We lost the manicurist down there. We lost our copy center. We lost the chiropractor."
He said he had often referred customers to the two enterprises owned by Mrs. Conner and Mrs. Feldsher. "It's affecting us quite a bit, them being gone," he said. "They sent people down. We sent people to them."
Mrs. Feldsher said she and her mother and their employees had themselves provided considerable trade for surrounding businesses, including a Mexican restaurant, a pizza parlor, a grocery store, clothing and shoe stores and a beauty supply shop.
Some employees, like Ms. Perez, had enrolled their children in nearby day care centers. In addition, Mrs. Feldsher said, she had been active in the local merchants' association and chamber of commerce, in local politics and in providing free screenings for the poor and the elderly at health fairs.
In a small but regular way, she had advertised in the local black newspapers and on a black-run radio station.
Most of all, she said, she was distressed at the sudden rupturing of long-established relationships with the customers and patients who had come to depend on her businesses.
One of these was Juan Richardson, who stood staring for a long time the other day at the remains of the skin-care shop. "Man, that was a good place," he said. "I'd come about once a week and sit in a chair and get some steam and a facial mask."
As with many small black-owned businesses, the transaction had been as much personal as professional. While clearing up a problem with his complexion, he said, the people who worked here had also helped him to confront his life as a drug dealer.
With Mrs. Conner's guidance, he said, he had given up a $500-a-day drug business in exchange for a $5-an-hour job as an office temporary worker. "It wasn't easy, but she showed a better way," he said. "She treated me like a son."
 
The Landlord
Voice of Investor Is Voice of Doubt

In Beverly Hills, the landlord, Hoyt Leisure of Leisure and Carpenter management company, said he would probably have to rebuild his property under the terms of his insurance policy, but he was not enthusiastic about it.
The reconstruction would involve the entire burned-out, block-long building that includes Mrs. Conner's clinics as well as a black-owned print shop, copy center and beauty supply store, a Korean-owned liquor store and fish shop and a Vietnamese-owned nail parlor.
"It's been a reasonable investment," Mr. Leisure said of the 63-year-old building where the rents for the 12,000 square feet of space range from 60 to 70 cents a square foot, as compared to about $2.50 a square foot in Beverly Hills.
"But if I were starting off fresh that's probably not where we would put our money, because of the character of the neighborhood," he said. He spoke of struggling businesses, vacant or run-down stores, a closed theater and fears of a return of violence.
Given the multitude of uncertainties, Mr. Leisure said, investors would be unlikely to move in quickly to South-Central Los Angeles. "I think a prudent person would want to stand back and evaluate the situation fairly carefully," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Helping Top Schools Correct Some Bad Fractions

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"IF I were going to public school," said Sheldon Gilbert, a 16-year-old from Jamaica, Queens, "I wouldn't be thinking of Yale or Harvard."
He is thinking of applying to Yale or Harvard next year, though. And the reason he is going to Horace Mann instead of a public high school is that when he was in the fourth grade, his mother heard about Prep for Prep. 
 The program is in its second decade of identifying bright, highly motivated New York City students, most of them black or Hispanic, and helping to place them in independent schools, including Brearley, Collegiate, Dalton, Fieldston, Horace Mann, Poly Prep, Riverdale Country, Spence and Trinity, where the program is based. Promising smaller classes and individual attention, the nonprofit Prep for Prep depends almost entirely on philanthropy, not on the government.
Placement is just the beginning. Intense preparation, continued counseling, Saturday and after-school classes, summer institutes and a new alumni group that harnesses the experience of 300 Prep for Prep students who are enrolled in college or have already graduated also distinguish the program as an effective tool to save some of the city's children.
Saturday's "Save Our Cities-Save Our Children" march in Washington was a noble effort to prick the nation's conscience. This year alone, New York received $860 million less for its expense budget and $3 billion less for construction than it would have if Federal funds were flowing into the city at the same rate, adjusted for inflation, as they were a decade ago, before its burden was worsened by homelessness, AIDS and crack.
But the march's impact will depend less on how many people took part than on how many of those who didn't are persuaded that saving the cities is in their interest, too. That includes Congress and the President, whose "weed and seed" prescription for urban revival evokes Chauncey Gardiner's vacuous metaphors in Peter Sellers's film "Being There."
So far, last month's Los Angeles riots have generated more outrage over the failings of criminal justice agencies than over the failures they inherited from the social welfare and education systems. It is easier to take symbolic steps against discrimination in South Africa than to take substantive ones to repair the impact of poverty and racism at home.
Last year, only 4 in 10 black high school students passed their final examinations in South Africa, and only 1 in 10 black seniors scored well enough to qualify for university admission. The results were attributed to disparities in spending between white and black school systems, poorly trained teachers, truancy and violence.
In New York City last year, only 3 in 10 blacks completed public high school on schedule. Among black high school seniors, about 1 in 10 qualified for the more rigorous Regents-endorsed diplomas.
Prep for Prep is making a dent in those dismal numbers. The program is being replicated in Buffalo, Massachusetts and New Jersey -- its potential for expansion limited mostly by the availability of scholarships from independent schools and by contributions to cover administrative costs.
"All we can do is structure an opportunity," says Gary Simons, the program's founder and executive director. "We have managed to create an ethos that the young people don't feel something was given to them on a silver platter or that they were demeaned by the process."
"Would most succeed anyway?" Mr. Simons asked. "I guess it depends on what one's definition of success is. A portion would end up going to college, though I think the percentage going to the most rigorous institutions would be a pittance. And some would just drop out. Some of the brightest are already turned off. But we see a lot of parents raising children in difficult situations who have not lost faith."
Later this month, Prep for Prep will send acceptances to about 150 fifth graders and 60 seventh graders among more than 2,000 who were nominated by the city's public schools, with whose enlightened indulgence the program has flourished.
"We have, I believe, two choices," Mr. Simons said two years ago. "Either we allow Howard Beach and Bensonhurst and the Rev. Al Sharpton to write the epitaph for our generation, or we invest in the education of young people who have the potential and -- let us hope and pray -- the vision and determination to lead people into the system, to develop our capacity to be one people, to teach us that people of diverse backgrounds can and do have fundamental hopes and aspirations in common."
"We really don't have a third choice," Mr Simons said.

LENGTH: 1356 words

HEADLINE: Riverside's Pastor at Center of Turmoil

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Black and white they come to Riverside Church, more than a thousand strong each Sunday. It is a church sizzling with life and remarkably integrated at a time when blacks and whites tend to go separate ways for worship.
But tensions are running high these days at Riverside in a dispute that threatens to disrupt the delicate racial balance that the interdenominational church has tried hard to achieve. The congregation is deeply divided over the actions, leadership and style of its pastor, the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr., who is the first black to head the church. His appointment three years ago was seen as a mighty witness to Riverside's long-standing liberalism. 
 His critics accuse Dr. Forbes, 56 years old, of being authoritarian, aloof, too spontaneous in worship and too much of a fundamentalist, especially in his sermons. They say that under his leadership, more blacks have joined, whites have left and collections have declined. His detractors are both black and white, and they insist that their criticism is not racially motivated. Most are not calling on him to resign, just to be more responsive to complaints.
Average Sunday attendance at the imposing stone church in Morningside Heights is 1,404, down 10 percent from five years ago. Gifts and donations for the seven-month period ending Jan. 1 were $1.7 million, a 3 percent decline from the same period the previous year.
"We have to ask, why is membership down? Why is giving down?" said Howard Geiger, the treasurer of the church's religious corporation, and one of Dr. Forbes's more vocal critics. "I believe it is a protest against the senior minister's leadership."
But a spokeswoman for the church, Joan Bacchus, said membership had remained steady, at about 2,200.
The dispute over Dr. Forbes has involved open letters and petitions that complain about everything from the length of his sermons to his choice of liturgical music.
The divisions at Riverside have grown so deep that a professional mediator was called in to resolve a dispute that began when Dr. Forbes tried to dismiss his second-in-command, the Rev. David Dyson, who is white. But Dr. Forbes's attempt has been rebuffed by the church council, a 26-member board that hired both men.
Yesterday, after services at the church, the president of the church council, Geoffrey Martin, told church members, "The mediation process has not produced a reconciliation." Then the council issued a statement affirming Dr. Forbes as senior minister but saying he would have to find a way to work with the man he had tried to fire. Mr. Dyson is a former labor organizer who was brought in a year after Dr. Forbes arrived to help him translate the church's inspirational message into social action. The council appointed a committee to develop "meaningful work" for Mr. Dyson.
Mr. Dyson said he did not know what the statement meant for the future and declined to comment.
Dr. Forbes may have been alluding to the dispute in his sermon, which focused on using "vision to transcend division."
Neither man would discuss the details of their dispute.
Dr. Forbes's supporters acknowledge that his leadership differs from his predecessors' and that he has altered the length and style of the the worship service. Some parishioners have complained about "interjections" during the service -- like shouts of "Amen" and hands lifted skyward -- and applause afterward. An unsigned memo distributed during a service said such displays "produce dramatic and esthetic disjuncture."
Some longtime worshipers were shocked recently when Dr. Forbes ended a sermon with an "altar call," an invitation to anyone to so inspired to "come forward and accept Jesus in your life," which had never been done before at Riverside.
But Dr. Forbes's supporters say the congregation hired a black minister with a Pentecostal, Bible-based background and now should adjust to a leader who naturally attracts minority worshipers and who is not perturbed when a service runs longer and is louder than usual.
In a recent interview in his office in the church, Dr. Forbes said many critics based their views on stereotypes of black preachers. He said he remained committed to Riverside's historical tradition even as he tried to foster traditions that reflected its newer members, many of whom are black, Hispanic and Asian.
While Telemann and Bach are still heard within Riverside's limestone walls, so are spirituals and hand-clapping gospel music, as well as newer forms like sacred jazz and liturgical salsa.
The changes raise the ire of Betty Sheets, a former chairwoman of Riverside's board.
"To me the preaching is fundamental, thin fare indeed for someone seeking understanding and enlightenment," she wrote in an open letter to the congregation. "I do not need to return to the Sunday School of my youth; I need a thoughtful adult perspective."
It was a surprising indictment, given Dr. Forbes's reputation as one of the best preachers in the nation. For more than a dozen years before coming to Riverside, he was a professor of preaching at Union Theological Seminary. And he has been pastor at several black churches in the South, including St. John's United Holy Church of America, in Richmond.
A colleague at the seminary, the Rev. William Kennedy, who is also a member of Riverside's council, defended Dr. Forbes. "I think Jim has an amazing intuitive sensibility to know just where the congregation is," he said. "And the way he brings the congregation in and taps our spiritual needs is really remarkable."
Dr. Forbes makes no apology for his fondness for Bible stories. "I do not begin a sermon from the headlines of The New York Times," he said. "My emphasis is on Biblical preaching that has social relevance."
That is a departure from his immediate predecessor, the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, who left to head a nuclear disarmament organization in Washington. Dr. Coffin was also besieged by complaints, but by critics who founds his sermons too topical and not Biblical enough.
Riverside is affiliated with the American Baptist Churches and the United Church of Christ, both of which give member churches a great deal of autonomy. Dr. Forbes was ordained in the American Baptist Churches and the Original United Holy Church, International, a Pentecostal church of which his father is a bishop.
Riverside's troubles, said the Rev. Carl Flemister, the regional executive minister of the American Baptist Churches of Metropolitan New York, are "a test of its liberalism."
"We're going places we've never been before," he said, noting that Riverside's racial makeup -- now estimated at 50 percent white and 50 percent minority -- is highly unusual.
Dr. Forbes insists that he is struggling to keep Riverside integrated.
He attributed both the decline in church contributions and the anxiety over the congregation's growing racial diversity to the poor state of the economy. "Now more than ever," he said, "people are looking for stability, especially in their church."
An unsigned memo, which purported to represent the views of "many staff members," accused Dr. Forbes of ruling with an iron hand and demanding the loyalty of his subordinates. The memo also said the pastor called anyone who challenged his authority "racist."
A longtime church member, Elaine Olaoye, a psychologist, said she hoped Dr. Forbes would not frame the attacks on him in racial terms. "Riverside has made a concerted effort to make Jim comfortable," she said. "And it's a two-way street. To assume that Riverside must accommodate him and that he must not accommodate it, that's racism."
But Dr. Olaoye is confident that Dr. Forbes can succeed at Riverside. She sees his problems there as part of his transition from a seminary teacher to a pastor who must administer a church with an annual budget of $4 million and a staff of more than 100, from clerical to clergy.
"I'm a professor of psychology," Dr. Olaoye said. "If I were put in charge of a major clinic in New York, I would go crazy. That is what Jim is going through. It is a very different kind of experience than being in the classroom."

HEADLINE: Crackdown by Peruvian Leader Brings No Peace

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 17

 BODY:
When President Alberto K. Fujimori seized near-dictatorial powers on April 5, the pillars of his rationale were to fight terrorism and drug trafficking and revive the economy.
Six weeks later, he is facing growing pressure on all three fronts, a sign that his newly assumed powers have not yet worked in the public's favor. 
 Peru's tenacious Maoist guerrilla group, the Shining Path, has shifted to a strategy that the Government seems virtually incapable of confronting, setting off huge car and bus bombs around the capital. A 600-pound truck bomb exploded on Thursday within blocks of the Presidential Palace, shattering a number of windows.
While many Peruvian business executives were heartened by Mr. Fujimori's emergency decree, their euphoria gave way to sober reflection after nearly all international aid was cut off. A previously booming stock market has stalled. Hundreds of millions of dollars deposited in banks have been withdrawn from the country out of fear of instability. The banking system is in crisis, and foreign investment is at a standstill.
 
Meeting in Bahamas
 That grim economic picture is what prompted Mr. Fujimori to fly to the Bahamas today to speak directly to foreign ministers of the Organization of American States.
The political and economic isolation threatening Peru is even reminiscent of the days when Mr. Fujimori's political nemesis and predecessor, Alan Garcia, was refusing to make payments on foreign debt and trying to nationalize the country's banks.
"Peru is not totally isolated yet, but it is getting there," said a senior Western official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "But this is the history of Peru. It has shown a willingness again and again to withstand international pressure almost always to its detriment."
In its battle with the Shining Path, the most violent guerrilla organization in Latin America, the Fujimori Government has made some short-term gains, experts say. Last week, Mr. Fujimori paraded triumphantly around the grounds of the Miguel Castro prison as more than 300 Shining Path inmates who had lost a four-day battle with the police lay face down on the dusty ground.
Two police officers were killed, but the Shining Path, known as the Sendero Luminoso, lost at least 36, including five high-ranking members.
 
'A Loss for Sendero'
 "You cannot deny that in terms of a military battle, this was a loss for Sendero," said a sympathizer with the movement who insisted on anonymity our of fear of police retribution. "They fought against impossible odds and in the end surrendered."
Though the Shining Path may have to retrench and shift its strategy, it has shown remarkable resiliency in replacing fallen members. The movement's political control over shantytowns in and around Lima has grown considerably in recent months, and the forcible prison takeover may even help it recruit a new phalanx of dedicated members from among the families of the slain rebels.
"The fact is that Fujimori won and Abimael Guzman won," said Carlos Tapia, an expert on the Shining Path, in a reference to the leader of the guerrilla organization. By responding to the Government crackdown with huge car bombs, the guerrillas have intensified a climate of fear and tension in Lima, giving an impression that the Government has actually lost some control.
Mr. Fujimori will come under even heavier pressure to show progress against the guerrillas as a July 5 plebiscite approaches in which the people will vote on whether to support his seizure of power.
He will be able to show little progress in fighting drug trafficking or reviving the economy.
The Peruvian Government announced in April that the air force would take control of municipal airports in the Upper Huallaga Valley, the source of 60 percent of the world's coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. But seizures of drug shipments have continued to decline and the production of coca leaf has increased.
After a Peruvian aircraft opened fire last month on a United States transport plane, the Pentagon removed two radar systems that had been used to help track drug planes in the northern jungle. Washington has also halted Green Beret training for Peru's antidrug agents.
But the biggest setback may be the loss of international aid. Before Mr. Fujimori dissolved Congress and suspended the Constitution, Peru was close to receiving a $1.1 billion aid package from 11 industrialized countries, led by the United States, Japan and Germany. A $220 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank and other credits from the World Bank were in the pipeline.
After the United States announced it was withholding all but humanitarian aid, one country after another announced that they too would halt aid until democracy returned to Peru.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

lTHE DEBATE OVER PRIVACY AND ABUSE
After 16-year-old Tawana Scott was charged with murder last May for abandoning her baby to die next to the swirling waters of the Harlem River, her relatives were left with many questions -- among them, why had New York City's child-welfare authorities returned the baby to Tawana when she had abandoned the child once before? In this case, as in any case in which a child under its supervision dies, the city's Human Resources Administration had the same reply: no comment. The response springs from laws intended to protect the privacy of families, but increasingly these laws are being questioned as some advocates for children charge that the laws too often shield bureaucracies that function poorly and make dreadful mistakes. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY 

ADDICTION CENTER TO OPEN IN MANHATTAN
Three leading authorities on substance abuse are starting a national center in Manhattan to examine and work against all aspects of addiction, from chain-smoking and alcoholism to cocaine and heroin abuse. The Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, which opens today, is intended to bring under one roof professionals from a variety of fields. The center will be financed by philanthropies and corporations -- it has a five-year, $8 million commitment from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J., and at least $2 million from a number of the country's major banks and corporations. B3.
 
OFFERING A PATH TO SUCCESS
Prep for Prep is in its second decade of identifying bright, highly motivated New York City students, most of them black or Hispanic, and helping to place them in independent schools, including Brearley, Collegiate, Dalton, Fieldston, Horace Mann, Poly Prep, Riverdale Country, Spence and Trinity, where the program is based. Promising smaller classes and individual attention, the nonprofit Prep for Prep depends almost entirely on philanthropy, not on the government. At a time when the numbers of black and Hispanic students who graduate from high school in the city are dismal, Prep for Prep is making a dent. Metro Matters, B3.
 
WOMAN STABS SON TO DEATH, POLICE SAY
A woman described as struggling with depression killed her 2-year-old son with a kitchen knife and slashed the throats of her mother, grandmother and 8-year old daughter as they lay sleeping in a Bronx apartment, the police said. She then tried to kill herself. B3.
 
CITY TO SELL $1 BILLION IN SECURITIES
New York City is scheduled to sell more than $1 billion in new tax-exempt securities this week, when conditions in the credit markets for the city appear better than at any time since the late 1980's. The ripple effect of Olympia & York Ltd.'s bankruptcy filing in Canada is the only potential problem for the city's offering, but it is not expected to be a serious one. D7.
 
REGION
 
PORT AUTHORITY FACES REVIEW
