HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls for Review Of Port Authority Plans

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, citing a "tunnel to nowhere" at Kennedy International Airport and other projects gone awry, called yesterday for a sweeping review of construction programs of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to cut waste and to safeguard against "ill-conceived capital investments" during hard economic times.
In a separate interview, the Governor proposed that New York and New Jersey set up a new and independent oversight panel that would monitor the authority's management and productivity and create greater accountability in an agency that he said had become "a kind of government all its own." 
 Expressing "grave concern" over "huge Port Authority investments in projects that have never been built or have been canceled after brief tests," Mr. Cuomo asked the agency's top officials to survey capital programs of the 1980's and 1990's and to report to him and to Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey in a month.
 
'Past Mistakes'
 "In the wake of recent press reports on tunnels, computers and similar ill-fated investments, it is clearly time to review thoroughly and systematically the recent capital project history -- and even more important, the future capital project plans -- of the Port Authority," the Governor said.
The Port Authority's chairman, Richard C. Leone, said Mr. Cuomo's request for a review and his suggested oversight panel were "appropriate and timely," and added: "Even the best intentions need to be tempered by discipline and accountability. The current leadership of the Port Authority wants to insure that we learn from past mistakes and are more prudent in the future. The governors, who appoint us, have a right to expect no less."
Mark Marchese, a spokesman for the Port Authority, which has just begun a $5 billion, five-year plan of improvements for its airports, bridges, tunnels, bus terminals and other transportation operations, said the agency "will be happy to provide the governors with a prudent plan that will effectively minimize the risk associated with carrying out a capital plan of this magnitude."
 
Projects Postponed
 Governor Cuomo's request comes at a time of mounting criticism of the Port Authority, particularly over a $3.2 billion airport expansion program, begun with fanfare in 1985 as "J.F.K. 2000," that included a $21 million baggage tunnel that has never been used; a $22 million computerized freight mover that was halted after six weeks, and a largely unused $56 million parking garage.
Many of the Kennedy Airport projects were drawn up in the booming 1980's, when a central terminal complex flanked by hotels, automated people movers and an elaborate baggage-handling system was envisioned. But as the recession and hard economic times set in, some big airlines went bankrupt and many of the projects were postponed indefinitely.
After a series of Newsday articles criticized some of these projects, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat from Queens, accused the authority last month of "shooting craps" with scarce resources and suggested Congressional hearings. Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat, proposed legislative hearings and tighter controls on agency spending.
On May 1, Mr. Cuomo asked the authority's executive director, Stanley Brezenoff, for a "thorough accounting of what went wrong" with the 1980's projects, which, the Governor noted pointedly, had been launched prior to the appointment of the agency's current leadership. That review is expected to be completed later this week.
Yesterday, however, Mr. Cuomo said it was "becoming increasingly apparent" that "a broader review is required to make recommendations on how we can prevent this from happening again." He said he had asked Mr. Leone, Mr. Brezenoff, and the agency's vice chairman, Vincent Tese, to conduct the review and report back to him and Governor Florio by June 15.
Mr. Cuomo said the agency had an "incomparable" record for expanding and improving the transportation infrastructure of New York and New Jersey and he said the review would assure that its "history of progress continues."
In a later interview, Mr. Cuomo said that "all bureaucracies have to be weeded and watched," and he said he would ask his aides to meet with aides to Governor Florio to discuss the establishment of a panel to oversee the agency's management and productivity.

HEADLINE: Inquiry Into U.S. Aid to Iraq Urged

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

 BODY:
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, said yesterday that he would seek the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the secret American buildup of Iraq before the Persian Gulf war and the Bush Administration's "obstruction of justice."
In what was apparently the last straw for Mr. Gonzalez,Attorney General William P. Barr said on Friday that he would no longer provide Mr. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, with classified documents unless he was assured that the Congressman would not disclose the information. 
 Mr. Gonzalez replied that his speeches did not jeopardize national security because he disclosed classified information dealing with past policies, not continuing or future plans.
 
Seeking an Independent Counsel
 "He can't point to any national security conflict -- there is none," Mr. Gonzalez said in an interview yesterday. He said he would ask the House Judiciary Committee to recommend the appointment of a counsel to pursue the investigation and he expected the panel to do so. The chairman of that committee is Jack Brooks, also a Texas Democrat.
"The chairman has indicated to me that he is of like mind that we should proceed on this," Mr. Gonzalez said. "Our staffs have already started preparing the paperwork."
He added: "I think Mr. Barr is very confused. He thinks that we in the Congress, and I in particular, are in the position of some lowly state prosecutors."
The Ethics in Government Act specifies that a majority of the Judiciary Committee in the House or Senate can require the Attorney General to investigate whether sufficient evidence of wrongdoing exists to warrant appointment of an independent counsel.
 
Attorney General's Response
 Since Mr. Barr is one subject of Mr. Gonzalez's investigation, it is not clear how he will respond to such a vote by the Judiciary Committee. In the past the Attorney General has regarded such votes as binding.
Currently, two independent counsels are conducting inquiries. Lawrence E. Walsh is investigating the Reagan Administration's sale of arms to Iran and clandestine aid to Nicaraguan rebels, and Arlin M. Adams is investigating accusations of corruption against the Department of Housing and Urban Development and its former Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr.
Mr. Gonzalez's approach to the Judiciary Committee is very much in character. A loner whom some colleagues in Congress view as an eccentrice, for most of the last two years he waged a campaign to unravel the Bush Administration's economic ties to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. For the most part, nobody listened until recently.
Mr. Gonzalez, who is 76 years old, began his hunt after he stumbled onto a major banking scandal involving the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro in 1989 after reading a brief newspaper article about an obscure Atlanta bank that had issued a $2 billion line of credit to Iraq.
"I wondered, what kind of a bank is this?" Mr. Gonzalez recalled recently. "Ordinarily, a transaction of this kind would be initiated out of New York by a big, old bank, an international bank."
"When I learned that the Atlanta bank was a branch of B.N.L., an Italian bank, I said, 'How in the world could it issue that vast sum of money?' " Mr. Gonzalez said.
 
Steady Stream of Disclosures
 He has been providing the answers in a series of lengthy speeches on the House floor that began on Feb. 4, 1991, three weeks before the cease-fire in the United States-led war against Iraq.
His steady stream of disclosures, largely ignored by colleagues and only recently pursued by news organizations, portrayed a secret network of international transactions that enabled Iraq to expand its military power in the year before its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
In the process Mr. Gonzalez discovered that the assistance had been made possible by a policy initiated at the highest levels of the Bush Administration, which has been less than eager to help him get to the bottom of the embarrassing affair.
The Congressman's speeches are peppered with references to secret documents, including a National Security Directive signed by President Bush in October 1989 that directed Government agencies to expand economic aid to Baghdad on the ground that such action would help moderate Iraq's belligerent behavior.
The financial aid to Iraq was primarily indirect, in the form of commercial loans backed by United States guarantees mandated by top officials of the Reagan and Bush Administrations. The primary source of the loans was the Atlanta bank.
In the late 1980's, the bank lent Iraq a total of $4 billion, much of it mired in fraud. Mr. Gonzalez says he believes that much of $1.9 billion in loans from the bank that were backed by guarantees from the Commodity Credit Corporation went to buy arms, while another $2.1 billion enabled Iraq to buy related military equipment like telecommunications technology, electronic components, heavy engineering equipment and semiconductor devices.
Reagan and Bush Administration officials also persuaded the Export-Import Bank, a Government agency, to provide loan guarantees including $484 million for an Iraqi oil pipeline.
In his speeches about the United States policy, which also included relaxed controls on technology exports and the sharing of intelligence with Iraq, Mr. Gonzales says the key players included President Bush; his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger.
"This issue shows all of Henry's strengths," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat and member of the Banking and Judiciary Committees. "He can see down the road ahead of others, and once he fixes onto something, he pursues it and won't let go. He's willing to use unconventional methods."
But critics say Mr. Gonzalez's unyielding persistence and penchant for acting alone also reflect a legislative weakness that has prevented him from forging coalitions in Congress.
A 30-year veteran of the House, where he represents part of San Antonio and its suburbs, Mr. Gonzalez is a passionate advocate known for his fiery temper. Six years ago at the age of 70, in a San Antonio restaurant, he punched a 40-year-old patron in the head after the man called him a Communist. The district attorney dropped charges in return for a public apology from the Congressman.
Mr. Gonzalez says his initial efforts to unravel the Lavoro scandal were stonewalled by the Justice and Treasury Departments, the Federal Reserve Board and some state regulators. Each had its own reasons for trying to quash the Gonzalez investigation.
The Justice Department contended that Mr. Gonzalez's inquiry could jeopardize its own investigation, and Dick Thornburgh, the Attorney General at the time, expressed his "profound disappointment" when Mr. Gonzalez convened his first hearing on the Lavoro bank in October 1990, just as the Administration was assembling the international coalition that was to go to war against Iraq three months later.
 
Loss to U.S. Taxpayers
 "I felt that that couldn't have been the reason," Mr. Gonzalez said. "I felt that it was embarrassing to explain why the taxpayers had to foot the bill for $2 billion." He estimates that $800 million is still owed the Federal Government because of the loan guarantees.
The Treasury said it feared that the House investigation could cause the loss of foreign bank funds in the United States. That was echoed by the Federal Reserve and some state regulators, who also said they had no authority to collect data about foreign bank transactions in the United States.
The White House saw the investigation as a Democratic effort to embarrass President Bush. "They were sensitive because of the then unknown role of the policy makers with respect to Iraq," Mr. Gonzalez said. "In retrospect, I can see why that would be embarrassing."
Unable to obtain data from his own Government, Mr. Gonzalez turned to the Italian Government, which provided leads that the Congressman's chief investigator, Dennis Kane, followed in the United States. The Federal Reserve, the Export-Import Bank and the State and Agriculture Departments eventually cooperated with his investigation, but the Justice Department and Customs Service never complied with subpoenas for documents.
On Feb. 28, 1991, the day after President Bush ordered the cease-fire in the war, the Justice Department investigation bore fruit. Mr. Thornburgh announced a 347-count indictment against four Iraqi officials and three former executives of the Atlanta bank, charging fraud involving more than $4 billion in loans and a secret set of "gray books" not reported in the Italian bank's official records. Two of the former executives pleaded guilty to charges that they had helped funnel illegal loans and credits to Iraq. The other defendants have not yet stood trial.
 
Provision Added to Crime Bill
 Mr. Gonzalez had already succeeded in inserting a provision into the 1990 Crime Bill that made foreign banks subject to American criminal statutes. He also was instrumental in legislation approved last year that made the Federal Reserve the prime regulator of foreign banks, pre-empting the role of state regulators.
In his initial speech on the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Mr. Gonzalez advised the House, "I have developed evidence clearly linking B.N.L. loans to a network of companies that helped to build the Iraqi war machine."
Two months later, Mr. Gonzalez disclosed that a Federal Reserve work paper stated that Secretary of State Baker had talked to President Hussein in September or October of 1989 about the Lavoro scandal, and that officials of Treasury, State, Defense, the Office of Management and Budget, Commerce, Agriculture and the Office of the United States Trade Representative were among those who had held a meeting in late 1989 to discuss its implications. Mr. Gonzalez said he did not know the substance of the discussions.
In March he obtained a memo that he said disclosed that the National Security Council "is providing coordination for the Administration's response to Congressional document requests for Iraq-related materials."
Mr. Gonzalez said he was distressed that the memo "gave the White House a direct hand in regulating the flow of information to the Congress, thus limiting oversight of Iraq policy." The memo will be the subject of a Banking Committee hearing on May 29.

HEADLINE: BEACH HAVEN JOURNAL;
Shore's Shops Face the Annual Scramble

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

DATELINE: BEACH HAVEN, N.J.

 BODY:
LIKE a farmer scanning her seeded fields for the first signs of green, Barbara Buchan took a long look up Bay Avenue before returning to her store to set out the novelties she hoped would attract the waves of vacationing impulse shoppers who will soon crowd the Jersey Shore.
But the chilly spring weather has kept the main street of Long Beach Island as empty as a beach house in February. Under the severe economic rules of the summer tourist trade, every slow week before the season begins will have to be made up during the 10 crucial weeks leading up to Labor Day. 
 In that span of days, shore business people like Mrs. Buchan in her Dollar Parlor, Bill Dowd in the pizzeria around the corner, Lew and Anna Richards at the Crust 'n Crumb bakery and hundreds of others up and down the Jersey Shore will trade 9 or 10 months of idleness and odd jobs for a delirium of 12-hour workdays and 7-day weeks. They will try to feed, dress, amuse and entice the migrant crowds of happy, sunburned and free-spending tourists while removing as much of their money as possible.
For most summer business people, those two and a half months, with spikes of extra activity at Memorial Day, the Fourth of July and Labor Day, will bring in three-quarters of the year's income.
For Mrs. Buchan, a good summer means an easy winter, maybe in Florida or "doing antique shows." A bad summer means having to get a winter job.
Like farmers depending on a one-crop harvest, the summer business owners are understandably worried about weather.
"That's what we're like, a bunch of farmers out here, looking at the sky," said Mr. Richards, who with his wife took the down payment they had saved for a move to Florida and put it into the Crust 'n Crumb. Its previous owner gave up and moved on after last Halloween's floods left the bakery awash in a tide of moldering doughnuts.
Spring is one of the "shoulders" of the season, in the local commercial language, and the chilly weather so far has made Jeanne DiPaola, head of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce, cautious about predicting a big payoff this season.
"I would say that this cool weather has given us a shaky start," she said.
But last year was a good year and the popular wisdom around here is that the lingering recession will keep families closer to home and at the shore instead of sending them overseas or to more distant parts of the country.
And summer rentals are running ahead of last year's rate, despite the colorful 'For sale' and 'For rent' signs that bloom on many streets.
Above all, the start of every season is also a season of optimism, and the shopkeepers at Bay Village know what kind of weather they want.
"Sun," said Mr. Dowd, the 27-year-old proprietor of Bay Village Pizza. "If we can't have sun all the time, sun on weekends to bring the weekenders, and the clouds on weekdays, so the people who are spending the week will go shopping instead of sitting on the beach."
Mrs. Buchan says her best year was in 1985, when, recently divorced and with children to raise, she bought the Dollar Parlor from its previous owner. But last year was good, too, she said, and with the Chamber of Commerce organizing new and better fall attractions -- the Chowder Cook-Off around Halloween, the visit from Mr. and Mrs. Santa Claus on Thanksgiving -- her business can take in more dollars by staying open on weekends in the fall.
Mrs. Buchan's shop is banked floor to ceiling with every imaginable gewgaw selling for under $3, which is her limit. Squirt guns, playing cards, whoopie cushions and personalized toothbrushes are crowded next to plastic trolls, American flags and ingenious little boxes for spreading butter on corn. It is a cheerful business for a cheerful woman.
"I have certainly come to love it," she said. "My daughter married into the family here," she said, meaning one of the landlord's sons, "and my son and his wife have Sur La Plage -- they sell beach wear -- two blocks down."
While they hope and plan for the start of the summer rush, the business people at Bay Village are also counting out the last dollars carefully budgeted from last summer's sales. This is the time of year when that budget is tightest.
"We're all really scraping by right now," said Melissa Maschal, who is married to John Maschal Jr., whose father owns the complex of stores.
"The tenants' first rent payment isn't due until May 31, so it isn't just the tenants who are having to get by. By the beginning of May around here, we're all hitting the banks for loans."

HEADLINE: Coming in Hope, Staying to Struggle, Leaving to Die;
Gambling on Better Care, H.I.V.-Infected Puerto Ricans Seek Help in New York City

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Luis Alberto Lopez settled down in New York City two and a half years ago hoping, not for the American dream, but for a longer life.
He finds less stress in his native Puerto Rico, he says, and he misses his family, the sun and the beach. But Mr. Lopez is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and he says his access to medicines, specialists and experimental treatments is better in the states than on the island.
"My mother said, 'Why don't you stay? I'll take care of you,' " said Mr. Lopez, 26 years old, who tested positive for H.I.V. in late 1989. "I told her, 'If I stay here, I think I'll die much faster.' "
 
In Hopes of Health Care
 While Puerto Ricans have traveled to New York for economic reasons for decades, those who are H.I.V.-positive have been coming more recently to fight a killer disease and, when faced with defeat, return home to die.
Now, responding to the strains such flow has created for AIDS services and families, officials in New York and Puerto Rico will for the first time try to measure the size of this migrant group and its needs.
In one collaborative effort spearheaded by the New York State Department of Health's AIDS Institute, two offices planned for New York City and the island this fall will document the travel patterns of H.I.V.-infected Puerto Ricans and assist them in transferring medical records, continuing medical treatment and finding clinical and social services as they arrive. The offices are expected to serve up to 200 clients apiece annually, with financing from United States Public Health Service.
And Mayor David N. Dinkins, who is in the Caribbean this week, is expected to announce an agreement on Wednesday between San Juan and New York City, home to nearly a million Puerto Ricans, to identify and coordinate AIDS services available in each city for the H.I.V.-infected population that travels between them. The officials also plan to seek financial support from both Washington and private foundations to improve services.
 
An Unknown Number
 It is not known how many Puerto Ricans travel because of AIDS, but health officials in New York and Puerto Rico say that anecdotal evidence indicate that the number is significant. Health officials say that H.I.V. itself has been exchanged back and forth across the air bridge linking New York City and San Juan.
Both New York and Puerto Rico have suffered a heavy toll. New York State has the nation's second highest per capita rate of new cases reported to the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Puerto Rico, a commonwealth of the United States, has the fourth highest. As of last March, Puerto Rico had reported 6,849 AIDS cases since the beginning of the epidemic and New York State 44,176, more than 38,000 of them in New York City.
And on the mainland, AIDS is striking Puerto Ricans proportionately more than any other Hispanic group, with most cases stemming from intravenous drug use, according to studies by the Centers for Disease Control.
Many H.I.V.-positive Puerto Ricans come to the mainland in response to disparities in Medicaid coverage and Federal disability benefits. The Social Security Administration, for instance, does not pay Supplemental Security Income benefits on the island, but Puerto Ricans are eligible for the program on the mainland.
Medicaid has a dollar cap for Puerto Rico and does not pay for treatments and services there that it covers on the mainland, such as private nursing care. In 1990, the cap was $79 million, while the commonwealth spent $519 million on medical care for the indigent, officials in Puerto Rico said.
Dr. Gabriel Torres, medical director of the AIDS center at St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, treats about 30 visiting Puerto Ricans at any given time. He said that some of his patients had discontinued certain treatments when they returned to Puerto Rico because the treatments were not covered by Medicaid there.
"Finally, you'll get all the tender loving care and chicken soup your mother will provide," Dr. Torres said, "but you won't get the medical treatment you need."
Dr. John V. Rullan, director of Puerto Rico's Office of AIDS Affairs and Communicable Diseases, said that a network of seven AIDS clinics that opened in late 1990 adequately serves the island's H.I.V.-infected population, which is estimated at 40,000. The clinics provide, free of charge, uniform medical care and psychosocial services throughout Puerto Rico and currently see 5,000 men, women and children, he said.
"If they gave me more money I'd do more," Dr. Rullan said, "but let nobody be mistaken that we can't take care of our people and have to send them to New York."
 
Model for Other Cities
 In New York City, the pilot program prepared by the New York State AIDS Institute and commonwealth officials will involve agencies that already work with visiting, H.I.V.-infected Puerto Ricans, like the Hispanic AIDS Forum and St. Vincent's and Bronx-Lebanon hospitals. Barry Gordon, regional AIDS coordinator for the U.S. Public Health Service in New York City, said that, if successful, the new offices could be replicated in other cities with large Puerto Rican communities, like Hartford and Philadelphia.
Health officials and advocates for people with AIDS in both Puerto Rico and New York say that, although services have improved tremendously in the last year, the demand still overwhelms the island's resources. Jorge Irizarry, a member of Act Up, an advocacy group for people with AIDS, in Puerto Rico, talked about the short supply of medicines for certain conditions. "Some people give false addresses to register in different clinics," he said, "so that they can get all the medicines they need."
Those who have the money to pay for medication and private doctors themselves or through insurance still find on the mainland preventive treatments and experimental drugsnot found on the island, advocates for people with AIDS say. Many patients who leave Puerto Rico wait until the final stages of the disease to return.
Dr. Jaime Rivera Dueno, executive director of the San Juan AIDS Institute, a nonprofit organization that treats AIDS patients, says that the number of H.I.V.-infected Puerto Ricans coming back now seems greater than the number who leave. Between 1989 and last year, the institute alone counted 64 patients from New York and New Jersey, which also has a large Puerto Rican population.
 
Back Again
 "Unfortunately, we are seeing more and more patients in such a poor state that the families are not prepared to deal with them," he said.
Luis C., 36, says he has gone back to Puerto Rico at least 15 times since he moved to Newark in 1988, drawn by a 12-year-old daughter and a supportive family. The last time, he gave away his furniture and said goodbye to friends in New Jersey, planning to stay in Puerto Rico for good. But a month later, a painful bout with herpes zoster, or shingles, a viral infection common among people infected with H.I.V., drove him back to Newark. He spoke on condition that his full name not be used.
"In Puerto Rico they treated it like an allergy," he said, noting he went to a municipal hospital in a small town of the island. "Here, the doctor needs only to look at my face to say, 'You're staying in the hospital today.' "
But Puerto Ricans with H.I.V. have to overcome a number of hurdles once they arrive on the mainland. Medicaid is not available until they have established residency for at least 30 days, New York State health officials say. Often, they must negotiate the maze of AIDS services by themselves because there are very few AIDS community organizations specifically serving Hispanic people.
But on the mainland, Puerto Ricans with H.I.V. say, along with better treatment, they find less stigma and a more organized advocacy community. Luis Alberto Lopez, who said he also felt more acceptance as a gay man, said he was inevitably drawn to AIDS work.
 
A Longing for Home
 A computer data operator, Mr. Lopez is participating in a trial of a drug intended to bolster his immune system. He is preparing himself for the upcoming international AIDS conference in Amsterdam.
"It helps a lot to be active," Mr. Lopez, who has become a member of Act Up, said. "It keeps you alive and it keeps you informed."
But even now, after nearly three years, he remains homesick.
"As soon as the AIDS cure comes, I'd move down there," he said. "I always hope to return."

HEADLINE: Francis Fitzpatrick, 89, Mayor And Party Leader in New Jersey

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Francis G. Fitzpatrick, whose elections as the insurgent Mayor of Bayonne, N.J., and as Hudson County Democratic chairman signaled the demise of an old-line political machine 20 years ago, died on Friday at Bayonne Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Bayonne.
He died of cancer, a family spokesman said. 
 A longtime independent Democrat, Mr. Fitzpatrick was a leader in the move to oust the corruption-riddled party organization, overturning half a century of domination by two legendary political bosses, Frank Hague and John V. Kenny.
Mr. Fitzpatrick's election as the director of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders in 1951 was an early setback to the party regulars, but they regained control and ousted him.
Later he became the Commissioner of Bayonne, the city's top post, then led a campaign to change the city's form of government to a strong mayoralty. He won the first election for the new mayor's post and served from 1962 through 1974. During his terms, urban renewal projects and a new City Hall were built, and the city's finances were stabilized.
 
Appointed to State Post
 The final blow to the old regime came with Mayor Fitzpatrick's selection as chairman of the county party from 1972 through 1974. He won the job as an ally of Paul T. Jordan, the young Mayor of Jersey City, in a reform coalition.
But soon then two strong-minded mayors had a falling out. Their feud and power struggle was resolved only when Gov. Brendan T. Byrne appointed Mr. Fitzpatrick chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.
He served in the state post from 1975 to 1984, and during his tenure the turnpike agency reached record highs in use and record lows in traffic fatalities.
A tough advocate who relished the rough-and-tumble of politics, he called the state Democratic chairman a liar in 1972 and, citing losses in statewide contests, demanded his ouster. The chairman, Salvatore A. Bontempo, declined to comply. Even after Mr. Fitzpatrick assumed his state post, he kept his hand in local political disputes.
Born in Brooklyn, he moved to Bayonne as a youngster and never left. He worked days in oil refineries while studying at night. He graduated from John Marshall College in 1927 and earned his law degree there in 1930. He began working as an administrator in Bayonne government, then went into private law practice in the 1940's.
First elected a freeholder in 1945, he served on that board through 1951.
He was the Bayonne Commissioner from 1959 to 1962.
Surviving are his wife of 57 years, the former Marion Tierney; a son, F. Gerald, of Bayonne, and four grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Francis G. Fitzpatrick. (Tom Christie, 1972)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Timing Is Good for a Big New York City Offering

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
New York City is scheduled to sell more than $1 billion in new tax-exempt securities this week, when conditions in the credit markets for the city appear better than at any time since the late 1980's.
The ripple effect of Olympia & York Ltd.'s bankruptcy filing in Canada is the only potential problem for the city's offering, but it is not expected to be a serious one. 
 As the city's biggest commercial landlord and one of its largest taxpayers, the company owes more than $140 million in property tax payments.
 
Confident About Payment
 With a tax payment of about $75 million due on July 1, city and company officials said last week that options had been explored about whether some or all of that payment might be delayed.
But city officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, expressed confidence late last week that payments would continue to be made and pointed out that relative to the $7 billion to $8 billion in property taxes the city collects each year, Olympia & York's contribution is fairly small.
Analysts tended to agree. And the real estate giant's problems had no effect on prices being quoted on the new bonds late last week.
"When people file for bankruptcy their property taxes continue to be paid," said Colleen Woodell, a senior vice president at Fitch Investors Service.
Nevertheless, city officials conceded that the issue had been raised at meetings with investors late last week.
"Questions came up relative to this," one city official said. "But we don't anticipate this as being a major problem. Their properties are fully leased, and their property tax payments are current."
On Friday, participants in the municipal bond market said the new bonds were quoted at yields ranging up to a maximum of 7.35 percent on securities maturing from 2013 to 2022.
However minimal the impact of Olympia & York's problems on the city's finances may prove to be, the company's bankruptcy filing nonetheless is a complication that City Hall apparently did not contemplate when it announced last week that it was moving up the bond sale to late May from July, as originally scheduled.
 
Period of Low Supply
 After being in a free fall for the better part of three years, the economy seems to be bottoming out. Interest rates on outstanding New York City securities are at their lowest levels in more than two years. And New York State, an important competitor for tax-exempt investment funds, has not been to market with a new issue in some time.
"There has been a dearth of issues," the city official said. "That is a reason why we are coming to market at this time. We also think we are managing well in a difficult time."
Although New York's financial condition appears to have stabilized, municipal bond market participants said the decline in yields on the city's bonds had more to do with underlying market trends than with greater comfort among investors about the city's prospects.
For two years, "there has been a compaction in rates," the head of one municipal bond desk at a New York investment bank said. "And anytime yields come down, people start reaching for paper that has lower ratings."
Currently, yield differentials between A- and AAA-rated municipal bonds are as narrow as 15 basis points to 20 basis points, the investment banker said.
For New York City, whose bonds are rated A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., the difference in yield over AAA-rated bonds is about 85 basis points.
Still, that is markedly better than the yield spread of 1.80 percentage points the market demanded on city bonds over AAA-rated securities at the depth of New York's current financial crisis.
 
Fed Panel to Meet
 While Olympia & York's woes have the potential to cause unease among some buyers of New York City debt securities, analysts said its problems are not likely to influence decisions or debate at the Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday, when members of the central bank's Open Market Committee are scheduled to meet.
Rather, policy makers will probably be more concerned with the overall health of the economy.
Some recent indicators suggest that the momentum established in the first two months of the year is waning.
Based on recent data, "the pattern suggests that the debate is about to shift from how rapid an acceleration is under way to whether growth is matching the relatively good first-quarter performance," James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, wrote in Data Watch, a weekly publication for clients.
Many analysts expect coming data, including a report expected on Tuesday on how the home-building industry fared last month, to reinforce the notion that the economy is losing steam.
But there are not yet enough signs to warrant a move by the Fed to cut interest rates, these analysts said. Rather, at the meeting a move to ease credit conditions will probably be approved, but not put into place for a few weeks.

HEADLINE: A Shot in the Arm for Health

 BODY:
Only 30 years ago, getting over measles, rubella or mumps was a rite of passage for American children. By 1983, however, vaccines had made these maladies rare. President Carter started a huge immunization initiative. Now President Bush has proposed another, to make up for callous economizing by the intervening Reagan Administration. In its eagerness to cut money from social services, it revived these highly contagious diseases.
During the Reagan years, the price of vaccine went up and Federal funding for childhood immunization went down. In 1987 Congress insisted on spending more, but that was too little and too late. By 1990, there were 26,520 cases of measles compared with 1,497 in 1983, and cases of mumps had nearly doubled. Rubella, too, was up, though not as much. 
 President Bush's current response is also too little. He initially asked for $259 million, which Congress wisely upped to $298 million. And the President said last June that he'd send a team of officials to six cities "to learn why kids aren't getting immunized." Health professionals already knew perfectly well why: too much red tape, and too little money. Now he is asking for $359 million and proposing ways to loosen the red tape. Even so, the American Academy of Pediatrics says that amount is $140 million short of adequate.
One dollar spent on immunization saves at least $20 in future medical costs -- and that doesn't include wages lost to the working parent who stays home with a sick child. Vaccinating the victims of Dallas's measles epidemic last spring, for instance, would have taken $45,000 in public funds. The costs of their illnesses are calculated at $1 million or more.
The Reagan Administration's cheese-paring on child health cost a lot of money and more than a few young lives. Mr. Bush's initiative is a step in the right direction, but not yet big enough.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
'We Are Innocent'

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
If the Persian Gulf war promised a new era of collective responsibility, Yugoslavia heralds its early demise.
A television film clip from the Balkan war zone catches the future. Cradling her murdered child, a mother cries: "They are killing us, but we are innocent." 
There should be no mistaking the consequences of would-be peacemakers failing to stop this slaughter: The new world order will be like the old one. The most ruthless will feel free and be free to kill as they wish within their own borders -- in Cambodia, Afghanistan, Angola, Russia, China, name it.
 If Westerners wanted to be coldly realistic about the matter, they could adopt an attitude of limited tears. That is, there is simply too much misery everywhere for even the wealthy and courageous to combat. Western countries have their own problems and cannot cry for everyone.
That probably is the underlying feeling among most Americans, Europeans and Japanese. But conscience forbids such selfish realism. So Western governments are compelled to "do something" -- without spending much money or risking any lives. Thus the present approach of trying to pressure and isolate President Milosevic of Serbia and other Balkan killers. But these bad guys simply do not take outside peacemakers seriously. The United Nations, the European Community and the United States keep on threatening the killers with ever greater diplomatic and economic sanctions. And the killers just go on about their deadly business.
American and European diplomats have no illusions about this. They are trying to put up as good a front against the killers as they think their domestic politics will bear. And the diplomats want to do everything they can within those limits to bring Balkan leaders to their senses about the long-term consequences of murder and civil war.
That is why U.S. and European officials were dismayed last week when Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali ordered U.N. peacekeepers out of Bosnia and talked of withdrawing all U.N. forces from the region. It was a weak-kneed green light to the killers. And the Security Council voted quickly on Friday to correct this impression and reaffirm its peacekeeping mission. Yet the atmosphere at the U.N. is one of deep pessimism and resignation.
Everyone concerned with the Yugoslav problem knows there is only one decent chance to stop this horror: Peacemakers have to establish the only kind of credibility killers understand. They have to convince themselves, and then convince the Milosevics, that they are ready and able to use force.
European and American leaders have gone much too far in slamming the door shut on even the possibility of using force. It seemed gratuitous, for example, for the State Department to reiterate last week that the Administration was giving "no consideration" to armed intervention.
Public opinion in the West would not be happy about intervention, but would probably give leaders some leeway. The trick is for the leaders to find a military course of action that would not worry Westerners about an opened-ended ground war, yet still jar Balkan leaders.
It would be best if such military planning were authorized by the U.N. or the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. But given the urgency of the situation, European nations and the U.S. have to be prepared to accept direct responsibility.
Above all Western leaders need to show resolution -- even if only to announce planning to keep the Serbian air force grounded or to bomb military airfields and bases.
The U.S. and the Europeans have to show at least this minimum level of seriousness. Anything less would be a moral and practical self-delusion.
However messy this situation, it is too easy to say nothing can be done to cool historical Balkan hatreds. Perhaps the West would not be so cool-headed if Christian Croats were being killed instead of Bosnian Muslims. Hand-wringing realism and resignation will not answer the cries of the innocent.
Post-cold-war ground rules for decency and humanity are being set in the Balkans today. The issue is whether they will be written by George Bush, Francois Mitterrand, John Major and Boris Yeltsin -- or by killers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: SIDELINES: OBSTRUCTED VIEWS;
Buy Me Some Peanuts . . . and That's It

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

 BODY:
Team executives have been blaming the cold spring weather across most of the country for major league baseball's drop in attendance so far this season, a dip of about 3 percent.
Another reason, however, could be the ever-rising cost forof a family of four to attend a game, now averaging $85.85. That figure comes from a survey by Team Marketing Report, a Chicago-based sports business publication, and it is 10 percent higher than last year. Why? A 12.3 percent rise in food and souvenirs, a 7.7 percent hike in ticket prices, all while the recession continues. 
 The cheapest one-day, four-person outing, $72.28, is inat Cincinnati; the most expensive is in Toronto, $112.83 (in United States dollarsmoney). Those figures include the prices of four seats, two beers, four hot dogs, four soft drinks, two souvenir caps, two programs and parking.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 21, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Sidelines column in SportsMonday this week misstated a comparison of attendance figures for major league baseball. Total attendance through last Sunday's games was 2.1 percent higher than the corresponding total for 1991.

HEADLINE: $3 Billion Pledged For Business Loans By Bank of Boston

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 18

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston pledged today to make $3 billion available for new loans to businesses in New England. It was a sign of renewed confidence in the region's battered economy and an effort to increase the bank's own business.
With aggressive marketing, the bank plans to find new borrowers, especially among small and medium-size businesses that have been hit hard by the recession and companies in inner-city areas. 
 Ira Stepanian, the Bank of Boston's chairman and chief executive, said he hoped the availability of new loans would overcome widespread concern about a shortage of credit that has hampered the New England economy for three years. He estimated that the money would create 30,000 to 50,000 jobs. New business development, as well as a stronger economy would, in turn, help create more business for the bank.
To generate maximum publicity for the bank's policy and raise public confidence that banking in the six-state region is returning to normal, Mr. Stepanian and other bank officials, joined by area politicians, repeated the announcement in ceremonies today in three state capitals, Boston, Hartford and Providence, R.I.
In Boston, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d and Gov. William F. Weld took part in the announcement, with Mr. Weld saying, "This is a real mood-changer. I've been waiting for a long time for a day like this one."
In Hartford Gov. Lowell P. Weicker and Senator Christopher J. Dodd attended a ceremony, while in Providence, Gov. Bruce Sundlun and Senator John H. Chafee took part.
The $3 billion would represent a significant expansion in lending for the Bank of Boston, which made $800 million in new loans to businesses in New England last year, according to Ira Jackson, a senior vice president of the bank. The bank, the 21st-largest bank holding company in the United States and second-largest in New England, has $13 billion in total loans outstanding in New England, down more than 20 percent since the recession began here in 1989, Mr. Jackson said.
Under the bank's new initiative, bank officers will call on 25,000 businesses over seven months and visit 2,500 inner-city businesses. The number of loan officers will also be increased.
The latter move was not prompted by the riot in Los Angeles three weeks ago, Mr. Stepanian said, but was instead linked to the Bank of Boston's program to expand bank branches in minority areas of Boston, Hartford and Providence.
 
Collapse of 90 Banks
 Some economists were skeptical about how successful the Bank of Boston would be in attracting borrowers from small and medium-sized businesses, since much of its work in the past had been with larger companies. But Mr. Jackson said the market was there, adding that one branch in Waltham, Mass., received more than 100 phone calls this morning since the announcement.
Rates and terms for the loans under the new program will vary according to the size and type of loan, said Constance Hubbell, a spokeswoman for the Bank of Boston, and will not be specially reduced to attract customers.
In the last three years, New England has been hit by the worst economic slump since the Depression in the 1930's, losing 10 perecent of its jobs, said Andrew Sum, the director of the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University here. Regionwide, employment fell to 5,334,000 in March from a peak of 5,966,000 in February 1989, Mr. Sum said, using figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
During that time, 90 banks failed in New England, not counting savings and loans, many saddled with bad real estate loans made during the boom years of the mid-1980's, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. As bad loans multiplied throughout the banking system, even healthy banks had large losses and became much more cautious in lending, even to customers with excellent records, prompting outcries from many businesses that no credit was available.
Mr. Sum, like other economists here, believes that the New England economy has stopped losing jobs and that there are some modest encouraging signs, like a small rise in homes sales, automobile sales and help wanted ads, along with an improvement in consumer confidence. But New England has not yet started recovering, he said.
 
'All the Help We Can Get'
 "So we can use all the help we can get," Mr. Sum said, referring to today's announcement by the Bank of Boston.
Economists say a number of other banks in New England have also started loaning money again as they returned to profitability in late 1991, though with less fanfare than the Bank of Boston's action today. A key turning point, several said, was an agreement between the region's three largest banks earlier this month to jointly loan $120 million for the construction of a new arena to replace the old Boston Garden, the home of the Boston Celtics basketball team and the Boston Bruins hockey team.
One factor behind the Bank of Boston's announcement today, several of the economists said, may simply have been concern that as the region's banks returned to profitability and have money to loan again, many businesses have grown cautious and are financing themselves out of cash flow, not taking out new loans.
Frederick Breimyer, the president of the New England Economic Project, a group of regional economists, said the Bank of Boston's action today was unusual in its scale and the publicity it generated. "Its symbolic value is very encouraging," he said.
But Mr. Breimyer warned that "turning the economy around is a longer-term proposition, with a lot more work to be done," than just making some loans, however extensive.
In making the announcement, Mr. Stepanian said: "We wanted to send a message that we are out there and we want to make loans. We felt we just haven't been getting the message across with all the talk of a credit crunch."
Mr. Stepanian acknowledged that the recession had caused the Bank of Boston to reduce its lending. "For a while, this caused us and others in the industry to focus inward and solve our own problems, making us less responsive to the needs of businesses," he said.
The bank experienced large losses in 1990 and 1991, but it has now enjoyed three successive quarters of profitability, putting it in position to resume its regular lending, said Mr. Jackson, the bank vice president.
The Bank of Boston is a superregional bank holding company, whose subsidiaries include The First National Bank of Boston, Casco Northern Bank in Maine, Bank of Boston Connecticut, Rhode Island Hospital Trust National Bank and Bank of Vermont.

HEADLINE: Thailand's Military Is Seen As Grasping Spoils of Power

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Throughout the 1980's, as Thailand's economy boomed, an exhilarating sense of change began to infuse the new middle class that was quickly putting its civilian stamp on the social and political life of the country. At every intellectual gathering where tomorrow's Thailand was discussed, one theme was heard: The days of coups and dictatorships are over; the army will have to play by political rules.
Today, many young, middle-class Thais were on the streets of Bangkok facing an army willing to destroy a dream so as to maintain its hold not only on political power but also on the economic spoils of near-absolute authority. 
 To the army, civilian rule in Thailand is a threat to the privileges that have made generations of colonels and generals rich. It would jeopardize their immunity from prosecution in corrupt and sometimes criminal acts, Thai political scientists say. It would sooner or later remove them from the boards and directors' chairs of major industries.
 
Civilian Corruption Cited
 It could end their involvement in a host of nefarious trades, including narcotics. A former high official of a nearby Asian country once recounted how he sat at regional conferences on heroin trafficking with Thai offciers he knew were involved in transporting drugs from the Golden Triangle area, the world's largest center of opium production.
"They were very, very greedy," said Sulak Sivaraksa, a leading Thai Buddhist intellectual, who was forced into exile in the West this year after he accused Thai military leaders of playing a major role in stripping the tropical hardwood forests of Thailand, Burma and, most recently, Cambodia, for personal gain.
Thai military leaders counter such charges by saying civilian politicans have often been very corrupt. They used that argument when they overthrew Prime Minister Chatchai Choonavan in Feburary 1991.
Diplomats in the region say the Thai military is the channel through which the Khmer Rouge raise money by selling Cambodian natural resources, gemstones as well as timber.
Mr. Sulak said today that the tragedy was that it did not have to come to this. "They could have made enough money without a coup," he said, referring to the 1991 army takeover.
Since taking charge of the country in the 1930's under the guise of a constitutional monarchy, the Thai military, always friendly to the United States and largely successful in promoting an image of respectability to the outside world, has escaped the international opprobrium heaped on military rulers in Pakistan, Indonesia or Bangladesh.
But behind the civilian veneer of Thai life, the country has long history of violence and warlordism.
Thailand was never colonized because successive Siamese dynasties were able to keep neighboring armies and distant colonial powers at bay through a combination of military strength and diplomatic dexterity.
By the 19th century, the center of institutional life had coalesced around a strong royal family, the Chakri dynasty, which began to modernize the country.
After the monarchy's powers were curtailed by the military in the 1930's -- at the same time that Thailand replaced Siam as the country's official name and the nation began to flirt with European fascism -- the army devised a strategy of using the immense moral power of the King as a cloak for its own authority. Crimes against the honor of the King -- lese-majeste -- became the most henious of offenses, punishable by long imprisonment or death.
But such charges were often lodged, as they have now been against Mr. Sulak, to curb dissent.

HEADLINE: Haiti Dispute: Limits on U.S.;
Other Concerns Appear To Block Strong Action

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Although the Bush Administration continues to insist that it seeks a speedy restoration of democracy in Haiti, the policy appears to be hobbled by domestic political concerns and a reluctance to risk confrontation with Latin America and Europe over a naval blockade or other direct intervention.
President Bush's unwillingness to raise the stakes in dealing with the Haitian military leadership that overthrew the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30 is puzzling to some members of Congress and area experts. They say that by breaking the political impasse and ending a regional embargo the Administration would also serve its goal of stanching the flow of refugees once again heading in large numbers toward American shores. 
 "We are rapidly reaching the point where the hardest question will need to be posed," said Robert Pastor, a Latin America specialist who served on the National Security Council under President Carter. "Is it humane to starve this country indefinitely with no realistic strategy for restoring a constitutional system?
"It would be criminal for the inter-American community to walk away from Haiti, but unless it does more soon, it may be compelled to do less," Mr. Pastor, now a professor at Emory University, said in an interview today.
In dealing with the crisis in Haiti, as with Peru, Administration officials say they prefer to give the lead role to the Organization of American States, an international body with no enforcement arm and a long record of avoiding direct confrontation.
 
Ships Arrive Regularly
 Steps taken by a special O.A.S. ministerial meeting this weekend in the Bahamas, including the withholding of visas for coup supporters and the barring from hemispheric ports of ships trading with Haiti, do not go far beyond policies already adopted unilaterally by the United States.
Requests to European nations to stop doing business with Haiti fall short of formal demands for adherence to a regional embargo, although crucial supplies are reaching Haiti regularly on European vessels. The Europeans say that economic sanctions against Haiti would violate the Lome Convention governing their aid to the world's poorest nations.
A blockade of Haiti is considered unworkable and unwise, Administration officials say, because the ships that would be stopped first would almost inevitably be European. The Administration is now trying to work with European leaders on tackling problems in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and a confrontation over Haiti would introduce strains.
The O.A.S. called for an economic embargo within hours of the Sept. 30 coup. But when the military leadership in Haiti demonstrated that it would not buckle under economic pressure or abide by a political compromise worked out by Father Aristide and the O.A.S. in February, the 37-member hemispheric organization ducked consideration of a regional peacekeeping force as well a blockade.
Creation of an international force to intervene in the Haitian standoff is not advocated by Father Aristide, who says that he does not want to be restored to power on the shoulders of foreign troops.
In interviews, the exiled President has said that the United States has enough political muscle to intimidate the usurpers of his office without the use of force. He recalls how American intervention forced Jean-Claude Duvalier into exile in 1986 and Gen. Prosper Avril a few years later.
 
'Pro Forma Statements'
 But on visits to Washington, Father Aristide is never given the public attention by the White House or State Department that would send a strong message to the Haitian military. In mid-March, he spent nearly a week in Washington without meeting with a high Adminstration official.
"What we get here are almost daily pro forma statements from both the State Department and White House that we are for the restoration of Aristide," said Larry Birns of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a private policy group. "But these are almost bloodless, mechanical statements not reflected in political initiatives."
In Congress, there has been a widespread belief that President Bush has been told by political advisers that any controversial action on Haiti could have a negative effect on business leaders who have invested in Haiti at the urging of Republican Administrations eager to make the Caribbean a showcase for private enterprise. Existing embargo rules already have been bent to allow American-owned industries to continue functioning in Haiti.
The second group of influential voters who have been judged to be opposed to both Haitian immigration and deeper involvement in Haiti's political crisis are the Cuban-Americans of southern Florida. Throughout Latin America, diplomats say, the Haitians are regarded as people with a language and culture that are closer to Africa than to most people in the Americas.
Black Congressional leaders say that the Bush Administration is equally indifferent to Haitians' suffering in their homeland and the refugees risking their lives to leave it.
"Bush's silence on Haiti is deafening," Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said in a recent interview. Mr. Conyers has been a strong supporter of Father Aristide and an advocate of granting "safe haven" to Haitian exiles.
He added, "I am outraged at the policy, which has become as bankrupt as Reagan's 'constructive engagement' was in South Africa."

HEADLINE: Trial Testimony Is Begun In Killing of Yale Student

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 18

 BODY:
 Testimony began today in the murder trial of a New Haven youth accused of shooting a Yale student during a robbery last year and leaving him to die outside a church. It was the first slaying of a Yale student in New Haven since 1974.
The police say that the accused youth, James Fleming Jr., 17 years old, was driving around the city with friends looking for someone to rob when he set upon Christian Prince, 19, a Yale sophomore from Chevy Chase, Md., on Feb. 17, 1991. 
 The killing led to stringent new campus security measures. It also highlighted racial tensions and town-gown problems facing Yale and other schools with inner-city campuses.
Yale is situated on the fringe of tough, impoverished New Haven neighborhoods, and economic contrasts between those neighborhoods and the university can seem stark. The city's per-capita income in 1987, the most recent year for which statistics are available, was $10,702, less than half what a Yale undergraduate pays in tuition for one year.
Yale students are aware of these contrasts and of the anger of some inner-city residents; even before Mr. Prince was killed, they were often reluctant to walk alone on city streets.
 
Statement Is Retracted
 The New Haven police say that Mr. Fleming and some of his companions set out to rob "a cracker" -- a derogatory term for a white person -- on the night Mr. Prince was slain. A police report said Mr. Fleming told an accomplice, "I ought to shoot the cracker" before firing at Mr. Prince.
The prosecution's case centers on a 31-page statement from Randy Fleming, who is not related to James Fleming.
According to the police, Randy Fleming said that he, James Fleming and two other youths saw Mr. Prince walking down the street as they were riding in a car, looking for someone to rob. He said he watched as James Fleming put a gun to Mr. Prince's head, took his wallet, then taunted him and hit him in the face with the weapon. Mr. Fleming then took a step back, according to the account, and shot Mr. Prince in the chest.
But six weeks after he gave the police this statement, Randy Fleming said in court that he made up this account because the police had threatened to charge him, as well, with murder if he did not cooperate.
During jury selection, James Fleming's lawyer, Frank Iannotti, a special public defender, asked a potential juror about his reaction to the verdict in the Rodney King case in California. He asked several other potential jurors about their feelings toward blacks. The jury that was selected has one black person among its 12 members.
 
Body Is Discovered
 During testimony today in New Haven Superior Court, James Van Bergen, who was a Yale drama school student in 1991, recounted driving down Hillhouse Avenue shortly after 1 A.M. and discovering Mr. Prince "lying spread-eagled on his back" at the base of the steps of St. Mary's Church.
Josh McHugh, a friend of Mr. Prince's, testified that he was with him at a campus party that night, which they left about 1 A.M. Mr. McHugh testified that Mr. Prince, a member of the lacrosse team, said he had to go home because he wanted to be rested for practice the next morning.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Jackson Asks His Party to Pay Attention to the Poor and the Cities

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, May 18

 BODY:
Accusing both political parties of being unresponsive to the crisis in the cities and the pain of the poor, the Rev. Jesse Jackson challenged the Democratic Party today to "renew its commitment to people in need."
If Mr. Jackson is able to energize the Democrats' most liberal wing, it could complicate the effort of Gov. Bill Clinton, the party's likely Presidential nominee, to unify the party behind a set of moderate positions and to run a nominating convention in July without a division over policy. Throughout the campaign this year, the Arkansas Governor and his supporters have tried to appeal to the middle class and have paid less attention to the needs of the poor than Democrats have in the past. 
 In testimony before the party's platform committee, which held a daylong hearing here today, and at a news conference afterward, Mr. Jackson refused to criticize Mr. Clinton directly and promised to endorse his party's candidate in the general election.
But Mr. Jackson's target was unmistakable. He urged those preparing the party's platform not to "go with the flow on capital punishment" or "walk soft on right-to-work laws," and he complained that the party's "most visible leadership did not answer the call" and show up for the march in Washington on Saturday in support of more Federal aid for cities.
Mr. Clinton supports capital punishment, a position Mr. Jackson called immoral. The Arkansas Governor has never seriously tried to overturn his state's law outlawing closed-shop union contracts, and he did not march on Saturday.
Mr. Clinton's supporters who testified today, including Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Robert Shapiro, one of Mr. Clinton's chief economic advisers, urged the platform committee to adopt a set of moderate stands, including a tax cut of about $300 a person for the middle class and a variety of tax breaks to stimulate business investment. They said little about the poor and the cities.
 
Concern for the Middle Class
 In the party's rush to soak the rich, Senator Breaux cautioned, Democrats should "make sure we don't drown the middle class."
Mr. Jackson, by contrast, said the country's problems would not be solved "by tax gimmicks or $300 gift certificates."
Many politicians are contemptuous of party platforms, noting that Presidents rarely feel bound by them once elected.
Still, even if platforms in America do not carry the weight they do in some parliamentary democracies, they serve to distinguish the guiding principles of the parties.
The Democratic platform this year, for example, is sure to support legalized abortion, guaranteed medical insurance for all Americans, new Federal spending for education and public works and a commitment to end homelessness. None of those planks are likely to appear in the Republican platform.
Over the years, Democratic platform fights have led to walkouts, even riots, but Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, said he thought this year would be different: "We're free of the kind of ideological splits that have plagued us in previous cycles."
Mr. Brown and other Democrats are hoping that it will be the Republican Party, sharply divided over abortion, where an ideological rift will be most apparent this year. The Republican platform committee will have a hearing on the issue in Salt Lake City next week.
But the abortion question arose here today when Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania urged Democrats to modify their usual plank supporting abortions without restrictions. Governor Casey argued that the position had hurt the party's Presidential candidates in the past.
Mr. Casey seemed to have relatively little support among party leaders. Mr. Brown said after the Governor's testimony, "I thought his view was not in concert with a majority of Democrats or a majority of the American people."
Mr. Brown, who was Mr. Jackson's convention manager four years ago, brushed off Mr. Jackson's challenge today as immaterial to party unity. Others said they could not tell yet whether Mr. Jackson intended to roil the waters.
The platform will be drafted at sessions in Washington and Santa Fe, N.M., next month and then will be submitted for a vote to the Democratic National Convention in New York in July.
In 1984 and 1988, when Mr. Jackson won large blocks of delegates in the primaries, he had significant influence on the platform. Four years ago, for instance, planks on South Africa, drug policy and voter registration, among others, were written at his insistence, and he caused debates on the convention floor on such touchy issues as tax policy and self-determination for Palestinians.
This year, of course, he did not run in the primaries and has no delegates, although he maintains a good deal of support among Democratic voters, particularly blacks.

Jesse Jackson being interrupted by Benjamin Kendall, a student at Oberlin College and an AIDS activist, as he testified before the Democratic Party's platform committee in Cleveland. Mr. Kendall left after he was told that he would have a chance to speak later. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: An Empire Run Amid Rice Paddies

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YUJIANG, China

 BODY:
Retailers in bankruptcy? A crumbling real estate market? A global recession? The problems might as well be happening on Mars, as far as Zhang Guoxi is concerned.
While gnarled old peasants slog barefoot behind water buffaloes in the rice paddies here, Mr. Zhang, apparently China's richest private businessman, has found a better way to make a living. 
 A balding 39-year-old who dropped out of school after the sixth grade, Mr. Zhang runs an international business empire based on furniture exports, property development and stock trading from his 10-story corporate headquarters, which juts above the paddies. From this remote country town he has emerged as an entrepreneur with assets worth tens of millions of dollars.
 
Defining the Limits
 Mr. Zhang (whose full name is pronounced JAHNG gwaw-shee) is one of the best measures of how much capitalism the Communist authorities are prepared to tolerate in their drive for national prosperity. For 15 years, he has more or less defined the frontier of what can be tolerated, and despite the hardline oratory from Beijing in the last few years, he continues to thrive.
"Sure, I live very well," he said, grinning, when he was asked how many homes he owns. "Very well!"
After a pause, he added with a mischievous gleam in his eye: "So I should say, 'Long live Comrade Xiaoping!' " The reference was to Deng Xiaoping, the 87-year-old paramount Chinese leader, who since January has led a new drive to carry out further capitalist-style changes in the economy.
In a society where peasants earn cash incomes of about $150 a year, Mr. Zhang is rich in a way that can scarcely be fathomed, rich in a way that the Rockefellers are rich. He sips Remy Martin cognac, and he has a chauffeur-driven car waiting for him in each city where he has an office. The state even provides him with his own police station of a dozen officers solely to protect his company and serve as his bodyguards.
Mr. Zhang may be leading the pack, but there are many other business tycoons emerging across China, capturing the spirit of the times. In the 1970's, many Chinese wanted to be revolutionary; today, they want to be rich. Most private businesses are only about a dozen years old, but they are expanding rapidly and branching across the nation and even the world. By the end of the century, China's private industrialists may be far more numerous and powerful than they are today.
"Deng Xiaoping has always said that China should let some people get rich first and let these people pull the economy along," said Christine Wong, an associate professor of economics at the University of California at Santa Cruz. "Now that Deng Xiaoping has reasserted his dominance in trying to formulate economic policy, I expect that things will look up for people like that."
Already the wealth and power that Mr. Zhang has gathered are jarring, partly because his base is not Beijing or Shanghai, but this small county seat of Yujiang in Jiangxi Province. Jiangxi is a poor, landlocked area that early in the century was a Communist guerrilla base. Most of the buildings around Yujiang are dilapidated brick homes with propaganda slogans proclaiming "Socialism is Good!" or calling on people to have just one child.
 
Touches of Modernity
 Mr. Zhang's corporate headquarters rises abruptly from these surroundings, 10 stories of gleaming modernity with international direct dialing and fax service, in a sprawling compound that also includes a goldfish pond and two marble arches -- "I'm an artist, after all," he explained. His buildings have their own slogans, but they are not political: "Guard against fires!" the banners warn.
Financial success carries political risks in China, and for that reason Mr. Zhang prefers to refer to his enterprise not as "privately run" but as "people run." But he does not dispute that his company is privately owned -- after all it is called the Guoxi Group, named after him -- and Government ministries have publicly referred to it as a private company.
Mr. Zhang is also discreet enough to dodge questions about his personal spending habits and about his net worth, but he finally acknowledges that $30 million or more might be a good estimate.
"More or less, more or less," he repeats, each time accenting the word "more."
 
Some Special Skills
 Entrepreneurs in China often run into trouble with grasping officials, who arbitrarily impose huge taxes or who force the owner to sell to the Government. Mr. Zhang has had few such problems, and his methods offer a window into the skills that business tycoons need to succeed in China.
One of the most crucial skills is cultivation of Government and Communist Party officials, a task that the gregarious Mr. Zhang assumes with ease. He is a good friend of the provincial governor and of county officials, and he has contributed more than $1.5 million in recent years to local charities and public causes.
"He is a good party member and an excellent businessman," Gov. Wu Guanzheng said of Mr. Zhang at a recent public meeting. "For many years he has loved the party and the people, and done many good deeds."
The latest good deed -- and the purpose of the meeting -- was Mr. Zhang's contribution of $200,000 to endow a new Zhang Guoxi Education Foundation. Everything he contributes to seems to bear his name: the Zhang Guoxi Big Bridge is being completed to link Yujiang with the other side of a broad river.
"Boss, three cars can pass at a time on the bridge, no problem!" Luo Genshen, the head of the construction team, says obsequiously as Mr. Zhang stands in the middle of the bridge and inspects the work. After asking a few questions, Mr. Zhang returns to his Nissan Cedrick to be chauffeured to his next spot on a round of inspections.
 
Providing Services
 Mr. Zhang also helped pay to bring running water and international telephone service to Yujiang. In addition, he contributed the only other structures in Yujiang that rival his headquarters in height: a television relay tower to improve local reception and a seven-story science tower at the local school.
Perhaps because of the philanthropy, local officials regard Mr. Zhang as a great hero rather than an evil capitalist. "We hope that more Zhang Guoxis will emerge!" The Jiangxi Daily News declared in a front-page headline. And local Communist Party officials have formally called on the entire community to "learn from Comrade Zhang Guoxi."
In some parts of China, including Beijing, Communist Party organizations have officially banned wealthy entrepreneurs from joining the party. But Mr. Zhang joined the party in 1972, long before he struck it rich, and he not only remains in the party but serves as party boss of his enterprise group, while also holding down the posts of chairman and general manager.
Zhang Guoxi's name means fruit of happiness, because at birth he was only a bit more than four pounds, the size of a small fruit. His mother died when he was 2, and after finishing elementary school he dropped out and began work as a carpenter. A few years later, in 1973, he sold his family home for $250 and used the money to start his company.
Initially, the company made carved wooden chests, when it was not fighting off criticisms and investigations by Communist Party ideologues who denounced it as the "tail of capitalism."
 
Recalling Rough Times
 "I'm fine now, and people see me going abroad and praised in the papers, and so on," Mr. Zhang said soberly. "But back in 1973 to 1977, it was really rough and I was often hungry. If I told you about those years, you'd be in tears."
After Mr. Deng came to power in 1978, the company prospered and began to export the wooden chests and other carved furniture to Japan. Then it branched into the manufacture of gold-plated Buddhist altars, which in Japan sell for about $10,000 each.
As business grew, Mr. Zhang opened offices in three Chinese cities, as well as Japan, Hong Kong, Canada and Germany. The Guoxi Group became a general international trading company, with interests ranging from stock trading in Hong Kong to Chinese restaurants in Germany. The company is about to open a new trading office in Thailand and is building a nine-story hotel in the southern Chinese resort of Sanya.
