HEADLINE: PERUVIAN PLEDGES DEMOCRATIC RULE

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 18

 BODY:
President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru told foreign ministers of the Organization of Amerian States today that he would restore democratic rule in his country within five months by holding elections for a constituent assembly to replace the Congress he dissolved on April 5.
Mr. Fujimori, whose appearance at the O.A.S. general assembly here was arranged only Sunday on the meeting's eve, urged the hemispheric organization not to isolate his country for its breach of constitutional rule, but instead to support the sweeping changes he has proposed for Peru's crisis-ridden political system. 
 In a 25-minute speech peppered with harsh attacks on the country's traditional political parties, Mr. Fujimori called for a sort of direct democracy that he said would include a new constitution, broad publication of Government initiatives, public referendums and direct popular election to political office, instead of closed party-controlled slates.
"In no more than five months we will see the establishment of a democratic constitutional congress, including the direct representatives of the people," Mr. Fujimori said. "With this, Peru will have achieved full constitutional legitimacy."
 
'Hidden Dictatorships'
 Mr. Fujimori described Peru's political parties, which he campaigned against as a maverick candidate for President in 1991, as "hidden dictatorships." He vowed not to prohibit the parties, but said his proposals called for "direct participation of the citizenry instead of the traditional elitist dialogue of party chieftains and union bosses."
In a seeming retreat from more defiant positions taken in previous discussions with foreign diplomats since he seized extraordinary powers, Mr. Fujimori coupled his call for new elections with an invitation to the O.A.S. "to participate with us in this process" by advising on electoral procedures and furnishing official observers.
In an initial indication of the reception of his proposals, the foreign ministers and other O.A.S. delegates gave Mr. Fujimori's speech only the politest of applause. Several diplomats said that while they were encouraged by several of the promised measures, especially the vote for a new constituent assembly, they remained troubled by the vigor with which he attacked traditional political parties.
"It was a shocker, but we are going to have to swallow it," a United States official said, adding that details of Mr. Fujimori's proposals, once available, would have to be carefully examined. "He moved a fair bit, but he can't admit that he has moved a fair bit. That's where the tension is."
Before Mr. Fujimori's address, another senior United States official said that "if the Peruvians want U.S. assistance, it's going to take a lot of movement on their part." After hearing the speech, the same official expressed uncertainty over whether Mr. Fujimori's presentation would prove sufficient to help restore normal relations.
 
'Some Rigidity' Remains
 Barbara J. McDougall, the Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, expressed similar ambivalence. After noting that the Peruvian leader had come closer to fulfilling demands for a restoration of democratic rule, Ms. McDougall said, "There is still some rigidity in his approach."
The United States canceled $167 million in aid to Peru after Mr. Fujimori's suspension of the Constitution and closure of Parliament. Although he made no direct reference to that aid, Mr. Fujimori repeatedly suggested that his country required international financial help to fight a leftist insurgency and the illicit traffic in coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine. Peru is the world's largest producer of coca.
Mr. Fujimori's decision to make an extraordinary address to the O.A.S. followed strong measures taken by the organization, including a hemisphere-wide ban on trade, in an effort to reverse the coup last September that ousted the elected President of Haiti.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Gets That G.M. Feeling

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
For General Motors, yesterday wound up the sales pitch of a lifetime. Its short video presentation, which it displayed around the country, was a smooth one. Fresh-faced adolescents and bare-bottomed babies grinned from the seats of G.M. cars. Happy customers breezed by in their Cadillacs and Chevrolets.
But this time the world's largest auto maker was not selling cars and trucks, it was selling itself, in the form of the largest stock offering by an American company. Later this week, G.M. plans to sell up to 57.5 million new shares of its common stock to raise $2.29 billion. The money will dress up G.M.'s battered balance sheet and pay for everything from new-car development to new tools and equipment. 
 In terms of size, the next-ranked such deal by an American institution was done by Conrail, the freight railroad, which raised $1.46 billion by selling stock in 1987.
"There hasn't been anything this important in a long time," said Robert H. Stovall, chairman of Stovall/ Twenty-First Advisers, a money management firm, and a longtime G.M. watcher. "This could set all kinds of records in terms of numbers of individual investors buying. It's a major event in the distribution of stock."
It is also the monster that dominates Wall Street. Almost every brokerage house in the country is trying to sell part of the offering, partly because the market is ripe for a stock sale of an icon of corporate America. But more significant is the fees.
Compared with the mega-fees booked from mergers in the 1980's, the G.M. underwriting fees may look modest. But if the sale is a complete success -- nearly everyone predicts it will be -- Wall Street's estimated cut will be anywhere from $69 million to $115 million. Offerings like this have fatter profit margins for brokers, providing a big incentive to sell the new shares. And best of all for investors, G.M. effectively pays the sales commission -- not the customer.
Since it announced its stock offering late last month, three teams of executives have hopscotched around the world to 17 cities, meeting with investment managers to pitch the stock and G.M.'s plan to nurse itself back to health after a record $4.5 billion loss last year.
In fact, two of G.M.'s private airplanes have been in constant use to help transport the well-rehearsed management team of 10, and their Morgan Stanley & Company investment bankers, from London to Hong Kong to Minneapolis to New York. Translators have rattled off the minutiae of earnings per share and car-platform renovations in English, Japanese and French.
More than 500 institutional salespeople at Morgan Stanley, which is leading the stock-sale effort, have called up investors around the world to pull A crowd to the road-show sessions, which ended yesterday with stops in Baltimore and Philadelphia.
In the end, though, the well-laid plans could be undone by the market's unpredictable cruelty. "It would screw them up if the market tanked from here," said Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service, an investment newsletter. "They could still get the deal done, but odds are they wouldn't want to."
So far, the stock market has been awaiting G.M. with open arms. The more cynical of analysts say they wish the auto maker could run its businesses as brilliantly as it has timed its stock offering, which stands to capitalize on the current market euphoria.
Indeed, the Dow Jones industrial average, of which G.M. is a component, has set a string of records in 1992. G.M. shares, which closed yesterday at $39.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, up 12.5 cents each, have risen 36 percent this year. The rising market gave G.M. a comparatively less expensive means of raising money, rather than borrowing it from banks or selling bonds.
G.M. may be savvy to exploit a market of willing investors, but it did not expect them to clamor for its shares without instituting radical changes. Analysts have little doubt that much of the corporate dressing-up of recent months -- plans to eliminate 74,000 jobs, close a score of plants and realign top management -- was in preparation for the offering. "The status quo was just not enough," said Tom Galvin, an auto analyst at C. J. Lawrence.
The preparations actually began three months ago when a team of G.M. and Morgan Stanley executives visited analysts at the powerful agencies that rate corporate debt. The ratings agencies' displeasure with G.M. has been no secret: only a month before the stock offering was announced, the Standard & Poor's Corporation downgraded G.M.'s senior debt to A-, from A. Companies perceived as high risks by ratings agenies pay higher interest rates for short-term borrowings.
A number of securities analysts believe the ratings agencies played the largest role of all in determining just how much stock G.M. needed to sell to bolster its capital base and its spnding plans. Neither the analysts, G.M. nor Morgan Stanley would publicly discuss that or other matters surrounding the offering because Securities and Exchange Commission rules restrict companies from promoting their stock before the price of the shares is set, which could happen as early as tonight.
Although G.M. has recently come to symbolize much that is amiss in Corporate America, analysts say it has displayed clear evidence that it is finally willing to make painful changes. Thus, investors might be willing to buy the shares on the hopes and dreams that a once-great American institution -- the nation's largest industrial corporation -- could turn around and become regularly profitable. G.M. is also buoyed by the fact that investors are eagerly buying shares of "cyclical" industrial companies whose fortunes improve as a recession ends.
As a household name, G.M. can also peddle its stock with relative ease to individual investors, who may feel quite comfortable buying shares of a company in a business they can understand. Further assisting the brokers is the simplicity of the deal itself. In contrast to the complicated financial science of the 80's, the G.M. offering is as basic as it gets: common stock. Said one analyst whose firm is selling G.M. shares, "The G.M. deal is a return to the way business used to be done -- conservatively."
But many an expert on the company makes a persuasive case that G.M. has been a loser that can stumble again. It is a troubled company, they say, and it has not delivered on past promises to improve. Analysts say the stock has been a huge disappointment, never climbing above its record price of $56.875 a share, set in 1965.
 
Individuals Seem Interested
 Several of the deal's eight underwriters are already seeing unexpectedly strong interest in the stock from individual investors, as opposed to large institutional buyers like pension funds and mutual funds. "This is the kind of stock you can beat the tom-tom on and sell in retail houses," said Mr. Stovall, the money manager. "They will pitch it as the American Dream -- the great turnaround and all that."
For individuals who already hold G.M. shares, though, the new stock is being issued at a high cost; the price of the existing shares dropped $2.75 each when the company announced on April 24 that it would offer the new stock.
For the deal to succeed, institutions will have to absorb more than half of the offering, experts say. And institutions have good reason to buy. G.M. shares are so widely held and so actively traded that they offer big investors the attraction of "liquidity" -- meaning they can easily and quickly sell their large holdings.
A second factor helping sell the deal to institutions has to do with the the way Wall Street pays favors. Institutional investors like to buy shares of large, liquid companies like G.M. in a stock offering, because they get to choose which brokerage firms will be assigned the commissions. Big institutions use those "selling concessions" as a way to pay brokerages back for things like research reports. "You can pay a lot of people in an offering like this," said one institutional buyer. "The G.M. deal is a political deal where you can take care of favors owed."
 
No Time Behind the Wheel
 As a longtime adviser to G.M., Morgan Stanley was a shoo-in for the business. Keeping to its conservative, white-shoe image, it advised the company to hold down the road show's razzle-dazzle. The meetings with money managers and analysts included none of the test-driving around race tracks that has accompanied other Detroit pitches to investors. At the New York presentation at the Helmsley Palace last week, for instance, G.M. management gave a largely subdued, businesslike presentation, with the exception of the polished video presentation.
G.M. executives tried their best, of course, to put the company's best face forward. They reiterated that G.M. expects its work force to be 20 percent smaller by 1995. Also, the G.M. board "recognized the importance of future dividend stability," said the chief financial officer, William E. Hoglund, hinting that the dividend, which was reduced last year to $1.60 a year, from $3, would not be eliminated.
Mr. Hoglund even suggested that cost savings would be an impressive $1 billion more than that outlined in the stock sale's prospectus. G.M. expects to cut $2 billion in material costs and $4 billion in labor expenses by 1995, he said. "Four plus two equals the $5 billion in the prospectus, which is how I got to be C.F.O.," he joked.
 
The Japanese Question
 Though the tone of the New York meeting was cordial, it hit a few predictable bumps. One money manager noted that several people in the room owned Japanese cars, and asked Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, how he hoped to compete with Japanese products for the loyalty of the group. ("I suppose they will shop and compare," Mr. Stempel said, and come to like G.M. cars.)
Another questioner took the issue further, asking, "Why should a customer go from a superior product to a slightly inferior product?" Mr. Stempel replied that the auto maker would not be satisfied "until we are the quality leader."
Whether that happens quickly enough to satisfy investors is yet to be seen. But under the glittering lights of two great crystal chandeliers at the Helmsley last week, it was difficult for some to forget that G.M. has a long way to go before it presents its new corporate model to the world.

HEADLINE: West Haven Reels From Layoffs

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HAVEN, Conn., May 14

 BODY:
With sunbathers already lolling on the beach here and rollerbladers racing along the three-and-a-half-mile Boardwalk, this waterfront town hardly projects an image of financial distress.
But a mile away at Town Hall, employees are reeling from the dismissal of one-fourth of the city's 300 workers two weeks ago. And officials are furiously trying to balance the budget of a town whose economic woes recently forced it to submit to state control. 
 "We got hit pretty substantially," Public Works Commissioner Arthur C. Ferris said of the layoffs. Calling it "the toughest day" in his 31-year career with the city, he said he had dismissed four mechanics, three tree-trimmers and a secretary. But even the layoffs, which will cut one-third of the projected $10 million deficit this year, have done little to placate constituents whose property taxes are going up 20 to 40 percent. Taxes for an average house are expected to rise to $3,400, from $2,700.
"They're spending way too much money that we don't have," said Michael Matera, an unemployed truck driver walking along Savin Rock Beach. "There are city jobs paying $70,000, while they're cutting people way down below. We have three fire districts we don't need. And everywhere you go, taxes are going up."
Donna Muzyka, another longtime resident, said she expected her landlord to raise her rent because of higher taxes. But her biggest concern was for her daughter Christa, whose "kindergarten teacher is upset they didn't get raises."
"I worry about the schools," her friend Donna Stackpole added. "If they don't have money to pay teachers, they'll make the classes too big, and children won't learn."
 
Tax Cut in '91
 The troubles are hardly singular at a time when many cities have slashed services and payrolls because of cuts in Federal and state aid, as well as reductions in tax revenues. The particular problems, however, might have been foreseen last year, when West Haven was the only one of the 169 towns in Connecticut to cut taxes. The recent history is a cautionary tale of how a proud working-class community of 55,000 people can abruptly slide from apparent economic well-being to the brink of insolvency.
Unlike Bridgeport, a poverty- and crime-plagued city whose budget is also subject to a state review board, West Haven is a town of well-maintained wood houses, stable businesses like Miles Pharmaceuticals and the peaceful ambience of a small New England town, complete with a town green, where the quiet is broken only by the sound of church bells.
Mayor H. Richard Borer Jr. insisted that "being financially distressed gives us the opportunity to scale down government without significantly reducing services." But even the minor cuts are symbolic.
Trash collections will be reduced to once a week, from twice a week. Nonprofit groups may be unable to use school buildings for evening meetings, and the number of free summer concerts will be reduced, to 12 from 30.
 
$700,000 or $7 Million Deficit?
 The troubles surfaced three months ago, shortly after Mr. Borer had taken office. Although the previous mayor, Clemente F. Evangeliste, had forecast a $700,000 deficit for the 1991 fiscal year, a long-delayed audit released in February showed that the deficit was actually $7 million, and the audit projected a $10 million shortfall for the current fiscal year.
"It was a monster of a deficit that certainly took us by surprise," said Mr. Borer, a former real-estate appraiser. "What we found was poor budgeting and complete incompetence" by the past administration.
He faulted Mr. Evangeliste for increasing spending while cutting taxes and significantly overestimating revenues from the state.
Mr. Evangeliste denied that he left the city's finances in shambles, saying: "We were West Haven's first professional management team. When we left, we were about $500,000 in the red. Businessmen like us are used to facing cash-flow problems, and Borer is a young guy who probably got all panicky."
Six weeks ago, with the city unable to pay its employees' health-insurance premiums, bond-rating agencies like Moody's and Standard & Poor's downgrading West Haven bonds to junk-bond status. Standard & Poor's lowered its rating, from BBB+ to BB, and Moody's changed, from Baa1 to Ba.
Mr. Borer turned to the state for emergency aid.
"In early March, we paid a visit to the Mayor, advising him we were very concerned about the city's financial condition," said Linda R. Savitsky, director of municipal finance services for the State Office of Policy and Management, which oversees the review boards for Bridgeport and West Haven. "Then, with Moody's getting nervous, he came to us on March 30, saying they needed help."
Four days later, legislation was passed and signed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. creating a state board to control West Haven's finances in exchange for up to $35 million in loan guarantees for bonds enabling the town to pay its bills. The board has sweeping powers to set the tax rate, negotiate labor contracts and approve borrowing and line-item transfers in the Board of Education budget.
The seven-member panel, which will pass judgment on Tuesday on the proposed $90.5 million budget, will function for as long as a decade, until all of the city's new bonds come due.
The city's finance director, Francis J. Kelly, acknowledged that the board "has substantial authority" to veto the town's budget and impose spending cuts, additional layoffs and higher taxes. But, he insisted: "We're not really giving up our financial independence to the state. The only thing different is that we'll hand over our finances for them to review."
But, Ms. Savitsky said: "The message to West Haven and other towns is that if they come to the state for help, the state's role won't be strictly advisory. We mean business. If this happens in other towns, the state will come in quickly and take control of their finances."

HEADLINE: A Ferryboat Again Plies Mid-Hudson

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y., May 14

 BODY:
After a lapse of 35 years, ferry service resumed this month across the Hudson River between Kingston and Rhinecliff.
The service consists of one ferryboat, a converted small Navy launch that can carry 40 passengers; for now it operates only on weekends. 
 "I see it as a chance for people without a boat to get out and enjoy the river," said Paul Ruge, Supervisor of the Town of Rhinebeck, which includes Rhinecliff.
Four times on Saturday and Sunday, the 40-foot-long ferryboat, named the Indy 7, makes the trip between the bustling Rondout Landing here and an unfinished dock alongside the Amtrak rail station in Rhinecliff. In July and August, the trips will be run daily.
The new ferry service leaves Kingston every hour from 12:30 P.M. through 3:30 P.M, and Rhinecliff 10 minutes after the hour from 1:10 P.M. through 4:10 P.M. The round-trip fare is $3 and $5 if a stop at the lighthouse is included, said Girard G. Henne, the captain of the Indy 7.
 
Stops at Lighthouse
 The boat stops at the Rondout Lighthouse, where the Rondout Creek meets the Hudson. The three-story yellow brick lighthouse, still an active Coast Guard beacon, is part of the Hudson River Maritime Museum on the Kingston waterfront.
Mr. Henne, a former Navy man, grew up around water. He bought the Indy 7 at a Navy surplus sale last year and converted it to civilian use.
"In the Navy it was called a 'liberty' boat," he explained, "because it was used to ferry sailors to shore" from the carrier Independence. "I tried to keep it Navy, painting it the Navy gray again."
The Indy 7 is the first ferryboat running across this area of the Hudson since the Kingston-Rhinecliff Bridge, four miles to the north, opened to traffic in 1957. For years before that, a much larger vessel carrying both vehicles and passengers operated ferry service as often as 15 times a day.
In addition to the new ferry service, Mr. Henne uses the Indy 7 to bring school groups to the lighthouse on weekday field trips. Today, for example, 47 fourth-grade students from the Brinckerhoff Elementary School in Fishkill, in Dutchess County, made the trip.
He also operates a much larger boat, the 300-passenger Rip Van Winkle, which runs Hudson sightseeing cruises out of Kingston.
Officials on both sides of the river see the small ferry service as a way to increase tourism, a major industry in the mid-Hudson Valley.
"It means that we can get museum visitors to the lighthouse on a safe vessel at a reasonable cost," said Lynn Beman, director of the Maritime Museum.
Mr. Henne expressed optimism about the future of ferry and cruise business on the Hudson. "Despite the recession, the passenger count is going up," he said. "Perhaps people are not going in for big-ticket vacations, but staying nearer to home on short vacations."
